NBA 2K20 builds upon the franchiseâ€™s well-established foundation with a deep, polished basketball simulation that strives to balance realism, accessibility, and a wealth of content. Developed by Visual Concepts and published by 2K Sports, this installment refines core gameplay mechanics, introduces meaningful changes to player control and presentation, and offers an expanded career mode that showcases the seriesâ€™ continued commitment to storytelling. While the game delivers an incredibly immersive on-court experience and a variety of game modes to satisfy different playstyles, it is also weighed down by persistent issues with microtransactions and monetization that affect the overall experience.

On the court, NBA 2K20 offers some of the most fluid and lifelike basketball mechanics to date. The player movement system feels more grounded, with better weight and momentum physics that make actions like driving to the hoop, defending, and transitioning between plays more realistic. Shot timing, dribbling, and passing have all received subtle but noticeable improvements, making skillful play more rewarding. The AI also feels more competent, with smarter defensive rotations and more natural off-ball movement from teammates. These refinements contribute to a satisfying gameplay loop that captures the nuances of real basketball.

The MyCareer mode is once again a major highlight, delivering an engaging story that blends Hollywood-level production with player customization and development. In NBA 2K20, players create their own characterâ€”nicknamed â€œCheâ€â€”and guide him through a dramatic journey from college basketball to the NBA. With a cast that includes Idris Elba and Rosario Dawson, the narrative touches on themes of loyalty, sacrifice, and personal growth, offering a surprisingly emotional arc that grounds the usual athletic rise-to-glory in a human story. Off the court, players can train, sign endorsements, and interact in the Neighborhood, a shared online social space that functions as a hub for various activities and modes.

MyTeam, the seriesâ€™ fantasy team-building mode, returns with new challenges and card collections, but it remains one of the most contentious aspects of the game due to its heavy reliance on virtual currency. While the mode itself offers deep strategic gameplay and competitive appeal, the progression system can feel grind-heavy without spending real money. This creates a noticeable imbalance between players who invest time and those who spend cash, particularly when it comes to acquiring top-tier cards or competing online. The presence of microtransactions throughout various modes, including cosmetic upgrades in MyCareer, undermines the gameâ€™s otherwise strong design and alienates some players.

Presentation-wise, NBA 2K20 sets a high bar with authentic broadcast-style visuals, lifelike player models, and impressive arena atmospheres. The attention to detail is strikingâ€”everything from jersey movement and facial animations to crowd reactions and commentary is meticulously rendered. Commentary teams are dynamic and vary depending on the game, offering new insights and dialogue that keep games feeling fresh. The soundtrack, curated with a mix of hip-hop and mainstream hits, adds energy and modern flair, complementing the on-court action well. Audio design, from the bounce of the ball to the roar of the crowd, further enhances immersion.

Franchise mode, or MyLeague/MyGM, continues to offer one of the most comprehensive management simulations in sports gaming. With tools to control every aspect of a teamâ€”from roster decisions and finances to drafting and player moraleâ€”this mode remains a haven for strategic thinkers and NBA purists. The inclusion of detailed stats, historical data, and adjustable settings means players can craft the league of their dreams or recreate historical seasons. However, some fans may find that innovation in this area has slowed compared to other parts of the game.

In summary, NBA 2K20 excels in delivering a compelling and authentic basketball experience, thanks to its refined gameplay, deep modes, and immersive presentation. Its commitment to storytelling and realism is evident in every dribble, pass, and cutscene. Yet, the pervasive presence of microtransactions and the grindy nature of some modes hold it back from achieving its full potential. For fans of the sport, itâ€™s still one of the best virtual representations of basketball available, but it also serves as a reminder of the growing tension between game design and monetization in modern sports titles.

Coloring Book: Professions is a simple colouring book (online) for children.

Some of the colours are quite similar to each other, so it might be best used for older children, rather than younger ones (that obviously depends on the developmental level of the child).

Sometimes the achievements don't seem to register when the colouring of a page has been correctly completed; however, when that happens, just hold down the W key and click your brush onto the picture, which should trigger the relevant achievement.

One negative was that you cannot turn off the background music - so, if you want to play your own background music whilst colouring, you're plumb out of luck.

On the basis of it being for children, it seems to be worthwhile, as it should keep kids amused for a while.

Dead Cells â€” Fast-Paced Roguelike Action at Its Finest

Dead Cells is a masterclass in tight, fluid combat and procedural design. From the very first run, the game hooks you with its fast-paced movement, responsive controls, and endless surprises around every corner. Every level feels alive, challenging, and meticulously crafted, keeping you on your toes while rewarding skill and experimentation.

Combat is both satisfying and strategic. Whether youâ€™re slashing with swords, raining arrows from a distance, or experimenting with magical abilities, every encounter demands quick thinking and adaptability. The variety of weapons, abilities, and power-ups ensures no two runs feel the same, making every death feel like a learning experience rather than a setback.

The procedural levels are beautifully designed, blending consistency with unpredictability. Youâ€™ll explore sprawling castles, perilous biomes, and hidden areas, all teeming with enemies, secrets, and loot. Each run is a fresh challenge, keeping the game endlessly replayable.

Progression is rewarding and fair. Unlocking new weapons, mutations, and abilities encourages experimentation and creates a sense of growth across multiple runs. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenge and satisfaction, making every victory feel earned.

Visually, Dead Cells is stunning. Pixel art meets fluid animation in a style thatâ€™s both retro and modern. Coupled with an energetic soundtrack, the gameâ€™s atmosphere feels tense, vibrant, and utterly alive.

Final Verdict:
Dead Cells is a thrilling roguelike that combines fluid combat, clever design, and endless replayability. Challenging, rewarding, and endlessly fun, itâ€™s a must-play for anyone who loves action-packed platformers and roguelikes.

â€œFast, fluid, and endlessly rewarding â€” Dead Cells proves that roguelikes can be both challenging and exhilarating.â€

Continue?9876543210 is less a video game and more a strange meditation on mortality and meaning, wrapped in pixel art surrealism. You play as a recently â€œdeletedâ€ videogame character, wandering through liminal dreamscapes while trying to find purpose in the fleeting seconds before oblivion. Itâ€™s a premise that sounds bizarre on paper, but in practice itâ€™s oddly affecting.

The experience is deliberately disorienting. Environments shift from neon-tinged ruins to unsettling voids, populated by fragmented NPCs who speak in riddles and philosophy. Sometimes youâ€™re given small tasks or light combat, but the real draw is the mood: itâ€™s melancholic, existential and often quietly beautiful.

Technically, the game is modest. The retro visuals are raw but evocative, the soundtrack experimental yet fitting and performance is smooth on just about any PC. That said, the mechanics can feel inconsistent and players looking for tight controls or conventional progression may find themselves frustrated. This isnâ€™t about mastery, itâ€™s about reflection.

What makes Continue?9876543210 stand out is how personal it feels. Itâ€™s one of those rare indie projects that dares to ask questions most games avoid: What does it mean to end? To fade? To accept? It wonâ€™t resonate with everyone - in fact, many will likely bounce off its strangeness - but those who connect with its wavelength may find it lingers long after the credits.

So, it's strange, uneven and sometimes frustrating, but also hauntingly original. If you value experimental art pieces as much as games, Continue?9876543210 is worth the plunge.

This game is the most mixed-up 'mixed bag' i've ever played.

The good stuff- the idea is amazing, and the game captures the sense of hopelessness that wandering lost around the recesses of RAM might entail. I really like the dialogue too, which has a kind of meaningful meaningless quality, like haikus written by a gifted chimp. The music is quite good, and the basic organisation of the game (wandering around talking to people, finding clues, collecting game resources and then battling to save yourself) is well organised and a good idea for how to conduct this kind of game. So based on originality and thoughtfulness, it would be a 10/10.

However, the execution of the above gameplay is a solid 0/10, and since the gameplay is most of the game, it hurts the overall experience really badly. Generally, the game well captures the futility of trying to escape deletion because it is nigh impossible not to fail over and over and over again, based on flaws in the game mechanics rather than your skill. The combat is incredibly bad, making safe zones suddenly kill you, murdered enemies spring back to instantly and unavoidably shave off half your health (every enemy can do this), and enemies spawn teleported right on top of you to instantly initiate punishing combat with no chance to evade.

The punishment for failure also increase geometrically- every time you make a mistake, the punishment gets worse by 1. For reference, you need to build shelters towards surviving a storm every few levels, and each shelter takes a couple of conversations or minigames to build, with bigger (more effective) shelters taking more. Then when you fail, you lose a shelter. Fail twice, lose 2. Fail 5 times (throughout the whole playthrough), and you lose 5, then 6, then 7 shelters each time. Given how arbitrarily you fail, and that the game actively selects your biggest and most valuable shelters for deletion (i've played it enough to be sure this isn't random chance), the possiblity of getting past level 3 or 4 is extremely low for any given playthrough. Add in poor collision detection with environments (falling off parts of maps to your death), continue screens which also delete between 1 and 7 shelters every time, and randomised puzzles and level order, and you have a recipe for extremly consistent frustration. So I give the gameplay 0/10, with the developer either being really lazy on this element (doing no playtesting to realise what a piece of junk his game is to actually 'play') or really hostile to people who pay for his work (taking the 'avoiding deletion is really hard' story element as an excuse to ruin the gameplay element of the game).

I still really enjoyed Continue?, finding it artsy and thoughtful without being too pretentious. But being almost impossible to finish due to game design unfortunately takes it down quite a few notches.

In reality, I have played this game for a hell of a lot longer than 42 hours. Nuclear Throne is a brilliantly designed game made on a barely functional engine. It has procedural generation, snappy shooting, a lot of content, and various other nice but not very remarkable qualities. What truly transforms the game is Jukio Kallio's masterpiece of a soundtrack. Suddenly, with that occasionally badass and often somber score, everything is re-contextualized. The procedural generation is the unshakable will of a creature that should have died long ago, the shooting is a fight for a message bigger than oneself, the oppressive difficulty suddenly feels obvious. Inevitable. Why would this be easy? Why would there be an end in sight? It's just a job, after all. Just our daily lives. No other roguelike manages this quality. This feeling.

I might have ruined this game a bit for myself by playing it too much in early access. I don't know what I wanted really but I don't think it's meaningfully different enough from the first game. It's more of the same with some new bells and whistles. If that's what you're looking for in a sequel I can't say I blame you. Playing it on full release with a fresh save file has just exacerbated some problems I have likely had since the original Hades. It's really an issue with roguelites in general. It's that I don't know how much better I'm actually getting at the game as opposed to me just hitting the arbitrary stat point that makes it just easy enough for me to succeed. I'm sure I am getting better at it, but I'm just bound to be successful eventually regardless of if I am or not really.

This is terrific for accessibility and likely why the genre as a whole has taken off like it has. I just don't think I'm into these kind of games as much anymore (rogueLITE specifically). The whole slow incremental statistical progress just leaves me thinking everything is just a matter of time. I don't know if I'll ever beat Slay the Spire on Ascension 20, but if I ever do I think I will feel like I earned it. There are of course difficulty modifiers in this game too and I think they help if you're looking to challenge yourself. I just might have a fundamental problem with the meta-progression aspect.

As before the character artwork is great. There is a ton of great voicework and music. This isn't a bad game by any means just one that I think I personally won't be finishing.

tl;dr: active development is constantly improving the game in significant ways, and the game holds a lot of promise. 

[h1][/h1]

While I haven't played the game *too* much (I bought it primarily to help support its development and out of interest for the setting), what I have seen is enjoyable and interesting and if you can find several people to play with, it should be a great great time. 

The main reason I am writing this review though is to say this: development might be a tad slow, but the devs are constantly dropping devblogs explaining *what* they're working on and *why* they're working on it - the most recent update showed off the complete removal of Unreal Engine's pathfinding system for a custom system which would allow the AI to better navigate the dirty, war torn environments of the game instead of getting stuck (as you may see complaints about). To me this means they're actively seeking out of the box ways to solve player complaints and make the best game they can. They're not compromising by cleaning and sterilizing the environment like so many modern shooters, they took the time to find a system that'll actually work well to facilitate future development while retaining their vision. 

Because of that, I give it a positive recommendation. If you're short on cash, wishlist it, but if you and a friend are interested then the game is definitely worth trying. It holds a lot of promise and it's constantly moving in the right direction. 

(Also, the emphasis on historical accuracy and respect for the setting really shows and is worth mentioning).

[h3] Good but not great [/h3]
I did all achievements, it took like 60h (while I spent some hours just being afk doing other things) and I think this game is pretty nice but not great. 

[b] Pros [/b]
- No bugs, works fluently 
- Cute characters
- Clear distinction between builds
- Progression system offers some creativity
- Each darkness level adds to the difficulty in a different way
- Weapons and character abilities are unique
- Upgrades are meaningful although a bit RNG-heavy but its normal in Roguelikes.

[b] Cons [/b]
- No magnetism to temporarily attract XP from all over the map which makes collecting XP tedious
- Builds are distinctive but there arent many
- Character abilities are unique in themselves but some are too similar to others or just useless (like Hastur)
- Bosses are always the same and it gets boring quick
- Barely any achievements motivating creative gameplay 
- Only 3 maps
- Not enough enemy variety
- Colour palette is always the same
- Progression system offers some creativity but is way too underwhelming and too simple

All in all its a nice game but far from being actually great but for anyone interested the price can be worth it. I had some fun but I recommend to only play it when you really feel like it to have fun. After a while I just started rushing the achievements to get it over with lol

Is Halo Infinite the return of a legend or an attempt to revive the franchise?  
An overview of an ordinary player who grew up on Halo, but is not afraid to tell the truth.

---

When Microsoft announced Halo Infinite in 2020, fans around the world held their breath. After all, it wasn't just a new game â€” it was a promise to bring back the "Golden Age" of first-person shooters, an era when Halo 2 and Halo 3 forced schoolchildren to hide their Xbox under their desks in order to have time to play before the bell rang. However, what we got in the end is not just a game. This is a story about high ambitions, technical failures and an unexpected rescue.

---

ğŸŒŒ Plot and atmosphere: "The Master Chief is against everything"

Halo Infinite unfolds events immediately after the events of *Halo 5: Guardians*. Master Chief, one of the most iconic characters in the history of video games, finds himself alone on the destroyed Zeta Halo ring structure, with almost no memory and a broken suit. His ally is AI **The Weapon**, a conscious copy of Cortana, who is trying to figure out why she exists.

The plot doesn't break your brain, but it's atmospheric, emotional, and sometimes even philosophical. Especially if you've been following the saga from the beginning. There is no overload of dialogues or characters here â€” everything is focused on the Chief, his inner struggle and reconnecting with humanity. And yes, the finale leaves a light aftertaste... and a burning desire to see the sequel.

---

Gameplay: freedom, but with caveats

The company is, perhaps, the main trump card of Halo Infinite. Unlike its linear predecessors, here you will find an open world on a huge ring structure. You can explore locations, clear out the bases of banshee bandits, find secrets, upgrade the Chief's abilities - all this in a free manner.

The gameplay is back to basics: ** No exoskeletons**, **No teleporters** â€” just stormtroopers, shields, grenades and your mind. The Return of the Grappling Hook (Grappleshot)** it has become a game changer: with its help, you can both accelerate in battle and perform spectacular jumping tricks. You can feel the weight of the Chief's body â€” he's not a superhero, he's a soldier, and this has its own aesthetic.

However, **artificial intelligence** is a sore spot. Enemies often behave strangely, especially in difficult levels. It happens that the elites just stand and wait for their death, instead of attacking. It spoils the impression, especially when you want to feel challenged.

---

, Graphics and technical side

At the time of release (December 2021), Halo Infinite looked like... ** modestly **. Many fans criticized her for her "plastic" graphics and empty landscapes. But Microsoft and studio 343 Industries** did something that developers rarely do â€” they  listened to the community.

Over the past two years, the game has received ** many updates**: improved terrain texture, added dynamic lighting and weather, redesigned animations. Today, Halo Infinite looks the way it should have looked when it was released â€” beautiful, large-scale, epic.

---

ğŸ•¹ï¸ Multiplayer: Chaos, but fun

Multiplayer in Halo Infinite is free â€” and this is a bold step. It brings back the classic gameplay: Slayer, Capture the Flag, Big Team Battle** on huge maps with tanks and helicopters. All this works on an updated version of the Slipspace Engine, created specifically for this game.

Problems? Yes, they were. At the start â€” inconvenient menu,  lack of rating modes,  problems with weapon balance. But gradually 343 Industries fixed everything. Today, multiplayer is a **live community** where beginners can practice and veterans can hone their skills.

---

Historical context: from Bungie to 343 Industries

Halo was born within the walls of Bungie, a studio that gave us not only a cult shooter, but also a cultural phenomenon. The first game was released in 2001 exclusively on Xbox and became a "system game" â€” without it, the console simply did not make sense.

But in 2007, Bungie left Microsoft, leaving the franchise in the hands of an internal studio, 343 Industries, named after one of the AI characters in the Halo universe. At first, fans were skeptical about the change of creators, but Halo 4 (2012) and Halo 5 (2015) Proved that the spirit of the series is alive.

Halo Infinite was conceived as a **relaunch**, but with respect for the legacy. And although its development was accompanied by layoffs, leaks and internal conflicts, the game eventually became what many were waiting for: ** a love letter to fans from themselves**.

---

Conclusion: is it worth playing?

yes. Necessarily.  
Halo Infinite is not perfect, but it is ** honest**. It shows that even in the era of battle royales and loot boxes, it is possible to make a shooter in which the main values are freedom, tactics and a sense of adventure.

If you:
- we grew up on Halo 2 over a LAN network,
- Do you want to experience nostalgia with a modern look,
- just looking for a high-quality shooter with a soul,

â€” then **Halo Infinite** is your choice.

And if you don't believe me, just download the multiplayer for free and see for yourself: The chief is still in business**.
I don't care what anyone says about this game - it's a true Halo entry and an awesome one.

After a rough start, this game clawed its way out of the woodworks to be in some way, complete. It is now at the very least a game I can revisit for years to come. Multiplayer is and has been an amazing experience.

Halo Infinite has the best multiplayer gameplay in the series! Its a ton of fun, the weapons are great and the state that the game finished in is really good. Yes there are a ton of paid cosmetics and yes the prices are way too high but overall the game is great.  Dont believe the hate. This Halo game was 343s swan song and while there were issues it was definitely the best multiplayer and campaign of any of their games.

Having played this after Hades it feels very cozy, with the type of endearing characters and fantastic soundtrack that later games would make me expect. I love how Darren Korb's urge to play duets with Ashley Barret and then intertwine them in videogame narratives is a constant through the years. Voice acting is phenomenal, and I loved some of the ideas for making the world of The Downside stand out more.

Most of the time I didn't have issues with the sports game they introduce (in fact game feel is excellent) but, for a gameplay device that, as I understand, is meant to add spice to what is otherwise a visual novel, it feels very strange to have to deal with the typical "+5% jump distance" elements, which I often frown upon in other games. Just like in those, eventually they add very little to the mix. Did Pyre really need merchants, gathering plants, etc.?

In the end what I enjoyed the most was the story, the unusual way to deal with consequences and the perhaps almost tragic nature of what you are led to decide for the characters that you grow to love.

If you're a fan of Final Fantasy V and/or Bravely saga, this is a must.
Even if you aren't a fan of precision platformers (like me), this game makes you forgive that because it massively adds to it's core point: exploration and adventure. And you'll feel that from the first minute.
Also, the workshop is full of awesome content. Some of the mods even turn the game upside down to offer a fresh experience. The game is updated frequently to mantain the modding scene (and the main game if needed) working and out of bugs.
And, well, there is a demo, so if you have any doubt, just try it.
10/10, I'll ride a salmon through the depths of the sea again.

Absolutely phenomenal JRPG in the style of Final Fantasy V or Bravely Default.

Heavy emphasis on exploration, with some (forgiving) platforming. Minimal guiderails through most of the game. The game gives you a lot of rope and it's up to you what to do with it.

It's also got a fairly solid modding scene on an already replayable game.
I have game ADHD so I will likely not play more than a few hours; destined to never finish. But I can tell this game SLAPS and deserves a positive rating.
A love letter to JRPGs and the first six final fantasy

This game is the epitome of a labour of love. 

There are so many details to keep an eye out for while exploring that you will continue to discover hidden loot, bosses, and shortcuts well into your 3rd playthrough. The replayability, difficulty assist options, and freedom to build your party up as you want it...

One of few games that I believe are an absolute 10/10.

Dark Souls III is the best Dark Souls game.

The extreme difficulty remains balanced throughout whilst punishing mistakes and greediness. The boss fights are excellent with a few exceptions. The hardest bosses are in the two DLCs with some having up to three phases! These bosses are accompanied by an impeccable soundtrack.

The game in general feels a lot smoother and faster paced compared to Dark Souls II with the level design being less confusing. Boss runbacks have been reduced with heavy emphasis on shortcuts, with the longest being Oceiros, the Consumed King at one minute fifteen seconds and the shortest being Slave Knight Gael at four seconds! There is Dark Souls 1 nostalgia included here, such as the return of Blacksmith Andre, Anor Londo, Asylum Demon and Capra Demon corpses scattered throughout Smouldering Lake, as well as the Stone Demon enemy from Lost Izalith. 

The "Focus Points" (FP) system returns from Demon's Souls to perform miracles, sorceries, pyromancies and weapon/shield "Skills" which allow for special attacks and abilities. Performing these actions drain your FP bar, which is the blue line underneath the red HP bar. FP doesn't regenerate, so you have to consume an Ashen Estus Flask. You can choose whether you would rather have more Estus Flasks (for healing) or Ashen Estus Flasks by talking to Blacksmith Andre.

The poetic storytelling makes a return with a very worthy final boss of the base game and both DLCs. NPC side quests make a return, with most worth pursuing to acquire certain items, such as a Titanite Slab, Silvercat Ring and the Pyromancy Flame being the most useful.

Dark Souls III contains new additions such as a red cross next to weapons that you don't have the correct stats for. The Homeward Bone can take you to Firelink Shrine or the last Bonfire rested at, unlike previous Dark Souls games. Upgrading armour sets have been removed. A new stat called "Luck" has been added which is useful for farming rare Covenant items and upgrade materials. Estus soup is a new healing station that refills your HP, but there are only three of them in Lothric.

Alas, covenants in this game don't benefit PvE as they're more suited to PvP, unlike previous Dark Souls games.

Easily the best Dark Souls game and a fantastic way to conclude the series.

Sekiro is honestly one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had. Itâ€™s a true â€œget goodâ€ kind of game but in the best possible way. Nothing is handed to you, nothing is easy, and thatâ€™s exactly why itâ€™s so incredible.
Every boss made me rage, every mini-boss humbled me, and every new area felt like some fresh form of punishment designed personally for me. But the moment you finally learn the patterns, tighten your parries, and land that finishing blow? Pure dopamine!!!

The combat is sharp, fast, and brutally honest. If you mess up, it's on you. If you succeed, itâ€™s because you earned it. Thatâ€™s the magic of this game, it makes you better not just in skill but in patience and mindset. 

The world is stunning, the soundtrack is perfect, and every encounter feels handcrafted to push you just past your limit. Itâ€™s challenging, itâ€™s unforgiving, but itâ€™s also insanely rewarding. Once you get that â€œI understand it nowâ€ moment you will feel unstoppable.

I actually loved this game. It's not as Dark Soul's like as I initial had thought, but that's not a bad thing in this case. Any Elden Ring/Dark Souls players will have an easy time with this game. I beat the last 4 bosses without a single death and that made me feel just as powerful as you should in a game where you're essentially the perfect automaton fighting a mass produced army.

Also I'd like to say that the story is A-Tier for me, the world is unique being in France during the reign of King Louie XVI and Marie Antoinette, and the addition clock work robots as the main character and enemies made this a unique experience. But as I said the story was pretty fun, no crazy plot twists or crazy revelations but just straightforward plot development which is not always in action heavy games.

This game is tagged as souls-like, but if it is, then it' a very generous souls-like. Can you imagine souls-like with infinite stamina (if built right) and infinite usages per item(as many as you can buy/collect))?
Overall, recommended if in discount, since it was released a while ago, no point of buying it full-price unless it's masterpiece, which this one is not.

Pretty good game overall, I'd recommend if you are looking for a soulslike that is short, has a fun story, and decent combat. 
I will say, the story is by far the strongest part of this game. I also really like that the devs tried a new spin on the genre, by adding interesting movement abilities. However, the levels were a bit too simple to really let these shine (even when backtracking, these abilities were used in pretty simplistic ways). 
The combat was okay, there were only a couple of weapon types (though they came with different special attacks, they were largely the same). The enemy variety was good considering the short runtime. 
The combat overall was really easy even w/o the assist mode. The bosses were a letdown - they were incredibly easy, and didn't really have any moves or combos to worry about. Also, their attack hitboxes were *really* bad - a lot of them you could just hug and they'd not be able to hit you with most of their attacks.
As a complete package, this is a fun game for the ~15hr runtime (not incl DLC). However, get it on sale, it is far too expensive at full price for what you get. But at ~$10, this game is a pretty fun time.
good game. 7/10, french revoltion but with soul eating robots.

Very interesting story, beautiful graphics and generally good gameplay and battles. This idea of automatons being the real enemies in the french revolution is an interesting view.

It is typical of a dark souls type of game with steep learning curve and monsters that respawn after each death or interaction with saving point.

In other games, where monsters do not respawn after each death and saving point, I usually play on adventure mode, like the step above story mode, but never hard core mode. I get tired of the unending grinding of games like this, where your progress don't mean shit if you havent reached a saving point. Killing 50 monsters just to die to the boss, and then having to kill them all again, is not my idea of fun.

Big plus that they have added "assist" mode so you can play more as in a story mode or similar to enjoy the game more, avoiding the unending grinding and actually be able to finish the game, even as an average player.

This would make for a great intro to Soulslikes for anyone hesitant or afraid of them.  This  has a great mode where you can essentially play it as easy as you want (take zero damage, even!) And while that is tempting, I'd encourage newbies to maybe just play the tutorial that way to get the hang of the mechanics and then go back and start a new game on the default difficulty. The tutorial/first level of this is by far the most difficult part and if you can get by that on default difficulty, then you can beat the game easily.  (even on default difficulty, there are items that can just trivialize bosses.) 

In addition, this game has a pause button so it is better than all the FromSoft games combined.

Played the game for almost 25 hours (Steam time) at time of writing the review, I have completed a NG run and done all side quests playing an engineering/ alchemy build, I plan on doing NG+ runs and getting the DLC.

I paid Â£1.69 for this game and my review would be exactly the same had I paid the full Steam price. I knew almost nothing about the game before going in apart from it was a 'soulslike' with average reviews, being able to get the game so cheap is why I bought it.

I really enjoyed this game, there's lots to really like and it does a lot of things better than other 'soulslikes', looking at you LIes of P.

First thing I will say is when you make your character pick a realistic skin tone/face, one the black ones is actually beautiful. A geisha robot may look cool at first but the cut scenes look ridiculous and the more realistic face does play into the story.

It seems to be commonly known the game has issues, I'm usually able to run game on high overall graphics setting  at 80-100fps or ultra at 50-60fps. On this I had to play the game on medium overall settings capped at 59fps. The game does have, for a lack of a better term, a 'janky' feel to it but without playing it on a very high end PC I don't know whether that is caused by performance or just that's how the game is, part of me thinks it's both as you do play as a robot and all the enemies are robots so some the movement design may be contributing to that janky feel. However none of this affected my enjoyment of the game.

The game does a lot of really good things. Combat, build variety and level design are ones that I'll touch on. 

The game has the typical 'soulslike' stat equivalents of ST, DX, health, stamina but the two interesting ones are it's version of magic is elemental alchemy and the stat called engineering. Alchemy dictates how strong attacks using weapons that have one of the games three elemental types (frost, fire, electric) are and engineering increases your armour stat, increases the damage multiplier for status effect and increases loot drop. 

These two stats really synergies well together because instead of having a magic meter for using weapons elemental attacks that you recharge at rest points or replenish with items (which you can do) you have a set number of uses of these alchemy attacks and the main way you recharge the alchemy uses is from loot drops from enemies, 90% of enemies drop either health or alchemy charges or grenades but increasing the loot drop stat increases the number of items dropped. It's a really interesting synergy and I appreciate the thought that has gone into it.

My play-through was using this alchemy/engineering synergy but I would like to experiment with other builds as the weapons in the game encourage different play-styles. There's no block or parry abilities as default but some weapon types do have them as abilities. I played as fast attacking elemental build using elemental damage from my weapons to quickly build up status whilst dodging enemy attacks, you could play a counter attacking style using your weapons counter attacks to do big damage and knock enemies back and use grenades to inflict status. Stamina management is very important as you become immobile if you fully drain the bar so a stamina build for constant movement and attack could be an option.

Level design is somewhere I think the game really shines. At first the game feels relatively linear with the usual go forward, find a shortcut back to the rest point etc. But as you progress through the game you'll start to notice doors with certain locks or high ledges with items on that you can't access as well as the areas starting to opening up. This is because the areas aren't linear they are actually quite large and open with multiple routes and lots to explore, as you go through the game you unlock traversal abilities that allow you to access these areas. The side quests in the game do a really good job of encouraging you to go back to the these areas and access new sections using the traversal abilities.

I really have to commend the devs on the areas they've designed, it would have been so easy to just make a game like Lies of P, whose areas look like long corridors in comparison.

Another thing the devs need a commending on is the story and lore, mixing in real world historical events with a sci-fi story is difficult and then basing a game around it is difficult and I respect what they've attempted.

As this is 'soulsike' difficulty needs to be mentioned. First thing I need to mention and another shout out to the devs heres is that the game has almost no cheesey enemies or BS. This game falls in line with almost every other game of the genre in that the standard enemies are not too difficult and you may die occasionally as you learn enemy attacks, develop strategies on how to deal with encounters and such. 

But where this game really differs is in terms of difficulty is the bosses. I died about 5 times on the first boss then almost every other boss afterwards I beat on 1st or 2nd attempt. I've really been off put by games where it takes me hours to beat a boss and you essentially have to be able to beat them perfectly to beat them at all, so on one hand it's refreshing to not have to deal with that but I would like to have seen them a little tougher. 
The main source of the games difficulty comes from having to deal with groups of enemies. Enemies do hit hard and they can hit very quick. In the final section of the game there were a few sections where I had to deal with groups of strong enemies that just felt impossible but these were in large areas where I could just run past to nearby rest place, which does make me think these may have been implemented as intentional resource farming spots.

Apart from the performance issues I don't have any major criticisms but I do have some minor ones. The character really needs a lantern or light device, this is common in 'soulslikes', to light up areas, Some of the very dark areas one does appear but there are a lot of other areas where this would have been really beneficial as your character can almost blend in to the environments and if there's not other light sources the game can look dull. The game is also quite buggy, I had plenty of occasions where I would be taken to the desktop, game still running on pause and I had about 4 occasions where the game just full on stopped. I'm not sure if it's a bug but there were a few occasions where I would use a rest place, quit the game then when I come back my character would be nowhere near the rest place I was at when I last played.

Overall I've really enjoyed my time with Steelrising so far, exploring the games world, combat and building my character have been really enjoying. I have to give a lot of respect to what the devs have tried to do here because there is so much of it that's well done, it's  just a shame about the performance issues. I don't know much about them but I'm hoping they get to keep on making games and improving on what they've done.

The story is cool, with interesting sidequests (story-wise). And the combat feels nice (when you get the basic perks, until then it is very lacking). My problem with this game is all the "go to point A, meet guy, go to point B, do X, go back and forth a couple more times". So basically, you walk a lot, just for something that could've been a letter.
But if you don't mind that or you are going just for the main quest, the combat makes up for it.

Among Us, where do I even begin? It's 2020, during the lockdown. My son, being extremely bored, asked me to buy him this game as it was quite popular during that time. Fortunately, I agreed and got him the game. I barely got to see him because he was just too busy playing this silly little game, I would only see him during dinner, but I wanted to spend more time with him. So, I started watching him play, letting him teach me how the game works, and eventually, he let me play it myself. I was bad at first, but with his help, I actually started winning. Then, I bought the game on my own computer, and we started playing together. We would stay up late, my wife yelling at the both of us to go to bed. We were having the time of our life, but eventually, the game started dying out, and so did our relationship with the game. I was browsing my steam library when I found this, and decided to share my story with everyone here to reminiscence my favorite times with my son.

Anyway, have fun; not much else to say.

I have played Overwatch 1 and 2 for over 3,000 hours since the first anniversary in 2017.

At launch and within the first seasons of Overwatch 2, Overwatch was possibly at its worst in terms of player trust and enjoyment factor. Outside of the political and company drama and allegations, it did not launch with the originally promised PvE, which the community was told not long before launch, as well as the sudden fundamental shift from 6v6 to 5v5 and being unable to return to Overwatch 1.

Now that we are in Season 19 and dramatic changes have occurred such as Microsoft's acquisition, the shift from Overwatch League to Overwatch Champions Series for esports, the frequent changes and updates with new content, game modes, and characters, Overwatch 2 IS NOT Overwatch 1, though I believe it has settled into a comfortable rhythm as a live service game. It has been well-optimized and gone through the growing pains of development. It still has bugs and many things that can be improved, but this is a game that you can easily pick up and play in any way you  are wanting to.

Pros:
- Multiple ways to play: Quick Play Role Queue or 6v6 Open Queue, Mystery Heroes, Competitive 5v5 & 6v6, rotating Arcade game modes, Stadium Quick Play or Competitive, and a fairly robust Custom Games browser WITH a workshop.
- Many heroes to play or try in each role, with one new hero every 2 seasons. There HAS to be at least one hero you will like to play.
- Largely dynamic cosmetics (lootboxes were brought back) and no pay-to-win, Mythic skins OVER TIME aren't locked to the Battle Pass anymore (a currency now but still has to be purchased and rewarded from playing)
- Regular updates
- Accessibility features and highly customizable options & settings
- Map voting (still needs some work)
- Hero bans in Competitive (also still needs work)
- Ping system
- Toxicity, slurs, and other social discourtesies are not endorsed by the developers and are often cracked down on.
- Very visible Competitive SR system (dramatic shift since OW2 launch). Finally added Leaver Compensation in Competitive.
- Matchmaking is actually really good, especially in Competitive. Of course there will ALWAYS be human factors. Unpopular opinion, I know.
- Cares for its streamers

Neutral:
- Not as much artistic expression as before but can still dish out interesting cosmetics
- Hit-or-miss collaborations and Battle Passes
- Practice Range
- Perks add more info bloat to the already visually-cluttered gameplay experience but can also make it more interesting
- Balancing is a menace
- Meta is not as strict as before

Cons:
- Bloated with features, information, and visual effects that can be overwhelming
- Menus can be confusing to navigate and some stats are missing
- Console is the younger sibling that gets all the hand-me-downs and late updates
- Frustrating gameplay (as is typical in pvp), particularly in its identity when it comes to balance changes (one-shots or not? CC or not? Counterswapping or not?)
- Certain heroes get more cosmetics love than others... I'm looking at you, Kiriko, Juno, etc.
- Certain pre-existing game modes like Archives and Competitive Mystery Heroes are non-existent
- Tutorial and how-to-play experience is still lacking
- Looking-for-Group is not in OW2
- Disciplinary action appeals are not fleshed out enough yet. My advice is to practice self-control so you don't have to grapple with this.

Just be warned that it is continually building upon its disciplinary action features. Toxicity is frowned upon by the devs, which, in my opinion, should be normalized. I don't care if it's "normal in other PvP games" to be toxic or display poor sportsmanship. This is a video game with other people, so be courteous and be the better person.

Overwatch has had its major ups and downs, times that it was a good game and times that it was a bad game. Play it if you want to, don't play it if you don't want to. But to me, Overwatch will always be an easy comfort-pick in terms of gameplay loop, personal expression, socializing with friends, and competitive integrity. It's so much more fleshed out than many other hero shooters because of its long runtime and passionate development, even through Blizzard's long and controversial history.

Don't take it too seriously. Unless it's your job to play professionally. YES, you can have fun. Don't follow the crowd, okay? You can actually learn a lot of great lessons just from experiencing all that the game and community has to offer... or frustrate you with.

Destiny 2 is like that Ex you keep going back to because the sex is good, but once the serotonin crash hits, you realize it wasnâ€™t worth getting the clap and a sore ass from being pegged in the middle of the night. Then the cycle repeats when she shows off her flashy new $100 dress every year.

However, this is still THE BEST GAME EVER!!! I even lost my house and job playing this game, because to me itâ€™s worth more than my college education. I used to grind for hours on end with nothing but an extension cord and my modded Chromebook. Right now, Iâ€™m even considering renewing my DLC subscription (3,642 hrs on Xbox) & (10,000 hrs on PC).

This game has ruined my life, and I couldnâ€™t be happier about it.

Despite what people say, this game is amazing. I would say that this game is a shining example of what a next generation game should be, even if it is now... years old. This game has set a standard for gaming that not very many can come close to competing with. Anyway if you like sci-fi and first person, and don't mind paying for expensive add-ons, you will be addicted.

Destiny 2 has a variety of issues with its monetization, new player experience, and (as of this review) a bit of an identity crisis having to do with how it wants to present its new seasonal content. But the gunplay, abilities, and general world of Destiny is unmatched. As someone with thousands of hours on this game prior to playing it on PC, this game is incredible, but the developers have a habit of dropping the bag. If you can bear with the rough patches, you'll be rewarded with such a unique gameplay experience in an incredible world. If you've got the time, give it a whirl! But no one could fault you for passing on the experience, given its past issues.

I dont remember this game sucking that bad at launch and didnt review it but holy crap i cant recommend this game at all. just read the books, its sad that all of the metro games suck but they changes this to play more like stalker. like i seriously just want to wander in the wastes and collect trinkets and shoot the occasional skag/hostile scavenger, this is all just artificially difficult to pad out playtime. i remember how short this crap is and on my current playthrough i havent even stolen the strain yet and ive died 30+ times. 

Do not buy this game and if you do play it on normal bc its just trying to pass the 2 hour refund deadline; NOTHING you do in the rest of the game minus that stupid gas filled tunnel on the third map are as hard as this horrible intro. like they have seriously made the intro as bad as atomic hearts for some reason.

I loved the previous Metro games and played both almost endlessly, but I don't think I can recommend this game for the people that really enjoyed the other games. I LOVE the story and atmosphere of this game, and the visuals and crafting mechanics are a good addition but holy crap can this be a slog when it comes to getting all the moral points if you want to be a "good" person at the end of each level, or if you like exploring everything in general. Don't get me wrong I enjoy exploring and the combat is also very fun, but running around a map maybe TEN TIMES the size of the biggest level in Last Light while having the stamina of a newborn baby gets very annoying very quickly. Sure you get a car sometimes but having to get in and out of the car after the 50th time when scavenging or exploring gets super annoying, even though its only a few seconds of an animation. If I was able to run for way longer without running out of stamina every 10 seconds or if I overall moved a bit faster I feel like it would fix this issue, but as of now I'm really not enjoying the exploration like I did in the previous titles.

As a massive fan of the original game, I do not like the sequel. It feels like less of a co-op game and more of a "everyone split up and do their own thing" kind of game because the game is designed in ways that punish you for wanting to stay together with your teammates so it just feels heavily discouraged. Enemy spawns struggle to split between 4 players in different parts of the map so it results in the hardest difficulty feeling hilariously easy at times when one or more people barely get any spawns and just freely do objectives, but if you stay together you all get all the enemies spawns pretty much all the time which just ends up wasting so much time.

Helldivers 1 was built, designed, and balanced a lot around co-op centric things, your team had far more reason to have different roles and loadouts instead of making a strong versatile build that can do everything independently, team reload mechanic was a much stronger and encouraged mechanic, and the team was not allowed to be separated.

A lot of strategems and weapons also just feel worse than the HD1 counterparts in terms of damage, ammo economy, and general effectiveness. The standard Breaker shotgun and the Kinetic Shield are some of the worst offenders to me.

HD2 also lacks some crucial teamwork focused strategems that people like me desperately want back, such as the Rep-80 heal beam gun, or the Angel Guard dog medical backpack. The stim pistol was not a fun addition to the game as trying to hit people with that is insufferable, I don't care if people say it's skill issue, it is not fun, and not like it's very effective anyway cause players tend to die faster than it can heal anyway.

Player survivability in HD2 also just does not feel as fair or as fun as HD1 too. The incap system was completely removed so you just outright die (Gives another less incentive to use SMG's compared to HD1, hell you can't even carry artillery shells with one hand and shoot a one handed weapon at the same time anymore either), and weak enemies can even kill you in just a mere few hits sometimes. The games survivability relying so much on stims is not particularly a design choice I like either. I wish they kept the incap system and players being a bit tankier, and you had very very slow health regen instead if you arn't taking damage. (Stims should of been something in the grenade slot instead to replace grenades in my opinion.)

I don't like how armor went from a cosmetic only thing in HD1 so you could wear what you want and select the perk you wanted separately, to now armor passives have to be handcuffed to armors that I don't want to wear while the ones I want to wear have awful passives or ones I really don't want to use cause it won't complement my build. Which is rather annoying.

Performance and game stability is also not particularly great either. This game used to run well on my system early on but after a bunch of updates it feels like it really struggles to be stable, I know they started trying to address this though it's still not anywhere near how well the game used to run yet. (I acknowledge more major engine tech stuff may take time, but felt I'd mention this.)

I donno, maybe it's a hot take, but I do not like this game because it took away the biggest thing I praised the original for and that's feeling like a true co-op designed experience first and foremost, where lone wolf gameplay was actively discouraged. I don't like some of the other design decisions/changes too. I'd only recommend this game if you are okay with it being nothing like the original game, the game itself isn't terrible, but as an original fan it feels too alienating for me, like it was catoring to a completely different audience for the sake of being mainstream. 

There's a lot more I'm probably forgetting off the top of my head right now, so I'll end it with this. TLDR: I wish this game just tried to be more like HD1 in almost all aspects but with the third person perspective change and with more content/features, not drastically change or redesign things that worked just fine before.

I enjoyed the idea of a game where all players are working together instead of against one another, where all efforts are for the whole team rather than yourself. Playing with my friends was a blast as we tried many different combinations and weapons to tackle bugs, bots, and otherwise. While the game was fun in the beginning, the game now feels like a slog or chore. The personal secondary objectives to get medals used to be "Use X gun for Y kills" or "Use an airstrike or sentry gun for Y kills." Now it's always "Collect samples" or "Evac 3 times from a faction-specific map." The major orders follow suit with them just being "Hold planet Z because why not?"

The samples I've collected have been in my inventory for over a year now; having upgraded my personal ship to the maximum, I don't think there will be any personal ship upgrades in the future or at all. 

The enemies are slanted towards the bugs last time I played, with them having numerous updates/upgrades from invisibility to flying acid dragons and fog-spewing chargers, while the bots do have different types of the flamethrower variety. It would be pretty cool if they had ships dispersing fog or invisible patrols or had fighting styles like the Illuminate.

The game is fun if you have a dedicated group of friends, but the way it is now, I don't see the point in playing it if every update is just a new coat of paint on the same thing.

As someone who adored this game and played the shit out of it on both console and PC from pre launch to survivors of the void, I cannot in any ways recommend you purchase it as the IP itself now belongs to some of the most scummy corporations in gaming, and that was clearly illustrated in how they destroyed the far more stable PC version of the game, and superimposed their buggy, FPS locked console port retroactively onto it.

But! you may be thinking, didn't they patch it? Surely it's all fixed now right, why the hate?

To which I direct you to take-two's EULA for not just this game, but everything they have a hand in. Even in absentia of the horrific anti-consumer practices that gearbox themselves are guilty of going back as far as them embezzling funding from SEGA to use on their own projects, if you look at the EULA that Take-Two is now making mandatory on virtually all of their games you will find that they have declared for themselves the rights to access and collect the following information:

-Your name
-Your Email
-Your phone number
-Your photo
-Your mailing address/zip code
-payment or purchase info
-age
-gender
-password
-platform ID
-Software products played
-Survey data
-geolocation
-and the systems or platforms you play their product on/through.

Furthermore, they also "share" (read:sell), your information with the following:

-Vendors that perform services and support for them
-Take-Two group members
-Advertisers and third party advertising partners
-Other third parties

I realize that I'm going to most assuredly get flamed for daring to mention these things, likely by a bunch of addict lobotomites who are perfectly willing to sell their privacy, and any dignity or self-respect under the auspices that no one will actually come to collect on them personally, but as someone who purchased this game and played it for ages long before the IP was unceremoniously sold off and gutted by a company I despise due to their long history of abusing their customers, I cannot overstate how much I despise this entire series of events.

And yes, the truth is we're all trapped in this awful market environment, run roughshod over by corporate interests and information brokering thieves, but to have it so blatantly done to a game I loved, and considered one of the best in the genre? To see it literally become unplayable in a proper state for a year before they actually fixed things, and have everything unique and fun about it be dragged out and abused for all it's worth by unscrupulous corporate asshairs who couldn't give a shit less about something that was until that point, crowd funded and beloved by its community? It's like purchasing a car and then a decade later the company changes hands and they break into your house and reengineer every part of your vehicle to function worse so they can sell you back the parts they just stole from you. We aren't renters, we are owners of these things, at least we damn well should be for the amount of money we pay for these products. Enough is enough.

I cannot, and will not support this, and I say if you have any respect for yourself or what this game was before they infested it, cut them off. Let something new take its place someday, and God willing let that indie dev not decide to sell out their baby to the devil.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
After a decade, this game still fails to really be the social game hub that it promises.
The scope of the game has stretched it so thin, and despite some amazing work from the art team, including the sweet OST by Donglekumquat, it wastes so much of its effort on creating games that are destined to go unplayed, or forever be half-baked.

For a social game, Tower Unite is really bad at incentivising being social, and that is no more apparent than in the highly popular casino, where about half the lobby will be pressing their space bar for hours on end at the slots, while the adjacent poker hall, a game perfect for social interactions with strangers, sits empty. The Arcade is full of minigames, yet only a handful of the 20+ are even multiplayer, and the ones that really payout are once again just mindnumbingly pressing the space bar for hours on end. 
The game's poor balancing of rewards can encourage players to be antisocial.

Tower Unite is capable of putting out genuinely great games, I would still hold its Minigolf as one of the best out there, and you can easily lose yourself in its condo system for hours with how much possibility it has, but so much of its development has gone towards things that are pointless, games that are buggy, unbalanced, or simply lack the demand. 

A social game doesn't demand a weak quake imitator requiring years of development when most of its other features are still incomplete. 
Something as simple as checkers can bring strangers to socialise, and Tower Unite really needed more things like that, simple ways for strangers to be brought together, and I think in its tunnel vision to check off Kickstarter promises they forgot that that was the most important part of the game's concept.

review_text:
TLDR: The moderation is HORRIBLE and enough of the condos are riddled with sexual content (even depicting minors...) for it to be an ongoing problem. Don't support this game's echo chamber and hive mind/mob mentality. 
Initially starting out on this game I was impressed by the creative capabilities with condos and the amount of activities you could do with friends, so much so that I purchased one of the supporter packs. I'm a pretty reserved person so I don't speak up too often but after playing for a while in the plaza with my friends I began to notice the same kinds of people coming on making inflammatory statements, sexual comments, and just downright degeneracy. Then you look at their Steam profiles and see that many of those who frequent this game are SEVERELY detached from society, mentally unwell, and/or promote unhealthy things (like "consensual" sexual content with those who are underage). They seem to go by a "we don't take care of things unless they're reported" mentality unless you're speaking out against their hypocrisy, THAT is when you get some kind of ban as I have seen and heard of from many players, friend and not. They claim to defend against things like bigotry and certain figures so they can use those things as a blanket statement to silence what they don't agree with. I had a friend having a proper cordial discussion with a trans individual about how we should help take care of the trans community's mental health when they're young instead of just thrusting them onto HRT when someone came up and started harassing my friend, yelling over them, making load noises with items, and acting like my friend was being transphobic (they certainly are not and stated such several times). Evidently, after those 2 individuals went off to "chat" my friend was banned the very next day for HARASSING after never receiving so much as a warning prior to this. I can go into even more detail on other instances of inappropriate moderation but this review is already long enough and I'm honestly done with this game.

Now that the dust settled on RE2, and more than half a decade passed since i last played RE7, i REALLY notice how all the fun moments of this game take place on a tightly scripted roller coaster. 7 years ago i was terrified and didn't notice at all, but now standing in the one spot that the game allows me to not be seen by "daddy" feels very boring and over-designed. Since RE7 came out about 3 years after Alien Isolation, i really expected there to be a much more open map, or options to fight back against anyone else than the molded. After all, the invincible family promote exactly the same gameplay as the Alien: stalk and hide. 
Amnesia: The Bunker clearly had the same aspirations, and took a tighter designed approach to its core loop with an algorithmically randomized bunker that prompts the player to figure it out on their own, instead of bombarding them with duller and duller chase sequences.

But everytime you are allowed roam around an area at your own pace you are either set up for the next jumpscare (eta <2 minutes), or you just fight molded. Large goo guys. They have big heads that burst open on headshots. They walk as if they have a stick up their ass. And they are veeeery boring, i even remember how dull i found them when i first played it. And unlike the first RE games, there is no real way to walk by them without wasting large amounts of ammo. sad.

I never made it to the ending since i heard that was where the molded stuff peaks, and i feel i've REALLY seen enough of it by now. All the best parts of this game are a tasteless and gory slasher film. Exactly what RE needed at the time, but not what i cherish about the series at all. 2/5

It is far too much a simulation. If you want to find out what it feels like to manage a mid table team-then this is the game for you. Teams will finish roughly where the stats say they will, your input is minimal. The computer will 'level' you to your average position no matter what-I lost all 3 left backs in a day (two in a match and one in training) so that my team settled back to where the stats engine said it usually would. Don't believe me-then save a match and play it 8 or 9 times with the same team and instructions. If you had any influence the results all would be the same. But you get a whole string of results-in one run I had everything for 0-0 to winning 3-1 and losing 5-2.  It just gives you the quale of choice, when none really exists,

The game is really good if your goal in life is to be a football manager. The only thing I hate about this game is that they included apartheid Israel in it. If the occupation Zionist fascist racist country was not there, I would definitely purchase the game every year and recommend it to everyone I know.

I wish I could give this a good review.
Its a great concept but far too much going on to make it playable. Its almost like you are racing against yourself, clicking around trying to keep up to attacks, unhappy people, research, building, resources, planting. You reach a point where you have too much to tend to your people become useless and die.  
It becomes a frantic click this click that, this person is smashing his own stuff, out of wood, no food, attack, click on each person individually put them in defend mode then place them where they need to be. Why they don't just attack when invaded I do not know, instead they will stand there with an AK-47 and die. 

You find yourself pausing the game constantly making adjustments then high speed then pause. Otherwise, your stuff gets destroyed and you don't even realise. Playing on regular speed is far too slow and high is far too fast. So its fast to pause, pause to fast, fast to pause. Its incredibly frustrating. 
There is just too much going on to be clicking around and reviewing every single tiny detail. Pause, Play,Pause,Play,Pause,play, I've never played a game where I spend more time on pause than Playing.

If I make someones job a wood cutter. I don't want to have to tell them constantly where to cut and how much.(maybe make it so they cut AND replant the area)?
Being able to set mining depth would be nice, instead of locked in 3 blocks.
Pick and plant farms would be nice also. Instead of picking randomly and planting later. 
The structures are too week. I don't even bother making steel walls or fences now because you use up valuable resources repairing them. They are just destroyed too easily.
Having your armed people fight when threatened would be good. I thought there was a way to set that without constantly pausing and manually doing it but maybe i'm thinking of something else.

A really cool concept that falls flat on its face due to not delivering on its core premise that time only moves when you do. While the minute movement doesn't seem significant, the window for action shrinks as the set pieces become more daring and difficult, amplifying the issues of having time moving at all when you aren't. There is also an imprecision and inconsistency to the collision detection that plagues the game. Finally, while the method of story presentation was intriguing, I found the overall experience grating. A disappointing game that seemed really good from the outset and the initial levels.

The VR Version is so cool because you have both of your hands position, rotation and yaw, plus your HMDs position with position rotation and yaw that manipulate time, here you just have aim and movement, the gameplay feel 2 dimensional compared to the vr version. Yes, here there's an acutal story, but honestly, I don't really bother about that because the gameplay just feel so much flatter now

I really enjoyed Gwent when it was part of Witcher 3 and was happy to be a part of the beta for the game when it first came out. I then forgot about the game and didnt play it for quite sometime, I played again around the Ciri Journey right before the Witchers set. My favorite decks were Devo Symbiosis, Thrive Monsters, Point Slam Monsters, Firesworn Swarm, and Northern Realm Siege Engines and sometimes Reavers. I had a great time with the game back then and got to Rank 2 on the ladder, I never hit Pro Ladder because at the time it felt like Nilfgard was incredibly oppresive to me. I stopped playing again for quite some time.

Recently I tried playing again and after giving the game some time to relearn the cards and the meta, I can tell you the game fucking SUUUCKS now. It feels terrible. The player councils have nerfed anything that remotely feels fun. The game feels VERY reactive now, and decks with high complexity are pushed way further than simple fun decks. The game feels oppresive to new players and is VERY unforgiving and overall just not worth playing. 

The player council balance factions are adverserial against each other and will frequnetly just tit for tat nerf/buff decks that they prefer. It feels awful. If you are a new player stay away, while the game is built to be rewarding, it is also very punishing and unfriendly in the sense that you will be made to feel like a loser for not having any powerful decks, you will repeatedly be farmed by better players for A LOOOOONG time before you get anywhere.  

If you are a returning player, you should stay away, long gone are the days of playing big splashy cards that feel fun to put on the board, and instead the game has been replaced with what essentially feels like two blue players in MTG playing counterspells against each other for 3 rounds. Instead of trying to buff all the bad cards to be more powerful and fun, the game has pretty much nerfed all of what used to be good impactful cards, and buffed meaningless reactionary cards so that the game tilts way into rewarding reactive players just for being reactive and punishing proactive for daring to do anything. 

Stay away and dont waste your money and time. The game feels awful now, its frustrating that I cant ever go home again to when I was playing the game, but it is what it is. DO NOT RECOMMEND AT ALL.

Additionally the game interface has several display bugs now that used to not be present, and will not update even after you complete quests, which can feel infuriating. The quests for the seasons feel unfairly difficult to complete for the amount of rewards you get.  

The community on reddit is borderline toxic, with a lot of player refusing to see the other side of the argument and are just paritsan and unhelpful. They want to turn Gwent from something which was fun for a majority of players to a game that is focused on just appealing to the top 10% of ladder and players and thats it. They could care less about anyone else, to them that's balance and fun. If you dare to complain they just say you can't understand their grand vision.

Don't expect any meaningful changes or updates to the meta, it will continue to degrade until its just the most boring/meaningless cards in the world being buffed while anything that could even remotely fun or powerful continues to get nerfed.

Gwent? More like player councils Gwent and ruined the game.

Having gamed on a PC for most of my life, I find this game a bit bland for my taste. I can see how people that used to play FFX etc on PS2 see it as a polished version of what they used to play as kids, but I just can't seem to get immersed in it.

I've tried so much to like it, but I get bored and cannot come to terms with the limited gameplay, even though there's so much customization with different weapons, skills and attribute combinations.

The game world lacks soul, even though everybody says that there's a very engaging main story with plot twists, which I cannot find the courage to follow because of the boring gameplay.

I used to love old JRPGS on SNES and PSX, but there was the perceived freedom that you were in an open world. This game just throws you in a PS2-like linear minimap that you have to navigate and inevitably come across a minimap boss that looks like it's come from the Dark Souls series.

Anyway, I get the nostalgia some people may feel playing this game, but I just can't recommend it to anyone remotely interested in a game world that actually feels alive and your meaningful interaction with it.

I don't know where these positive reviews are coming from, must be people that completely ignore the games performance and are only factoring gameplay mechanics, lore, and world-building.. all of which are incredible. This WOULD be the greatest turn-based rpg I have EVER played.

WOULD. The truth though, is that this game stutters so badly and so frequently it is practically unplayable in Acts 2 and 3. Your game is going to be a little bit choppy in Act 1, worse in populated areas; you'll forgive it, because you're enjoying the story and game so much. Then Act 2 will come, and it will get worse. Cutscenes are now a choppy mess, character dialogue is constantly glitching out, so you're constantly pulled out of immersion. But you're invested at this point, so you sludge through the glitchiness to Act 3.

Then when your refund-window is LONG expired, and you're coming out of Act 2 finally on your way to Baldurs gate, and the truly performance-intensive areas are finally here... oh boy, it is bad. Non-stop stuttering, there is not one spoken word that isn't choppy, and the game truly becomes unplayable. I cannot believe a GOTY game performs like this. 

I WANT to finish it, I WANT to recommend it- but I can't. It's straight up broken, and the devs aren't doing anything.

[b]I wish this wasn't  a roguelite.[/b]

If this game stopped being a roguelite, this would be so much better game. If either:
1) It added a checkpoint system every few levels so you don't have to start from the beginning again.
or, 2) It got rid of all upgrades and unlocked all abilites and weapons from the very start and ending this game was purely based on skill.

Either one of those and I would be actually playing the game to the end because it's such a cool game to play with especially on a handheld. In the current state I can only recommend it if you get someone's save file or a mod that does either of the above two things, otherwise I don't recommend any roguelite and that includes this game.

Roguelites have blown up in popularity but people have forgot how little dopamine hits every now and then can be really addicting and can really suck you in and just feels like you're progressing or having fun while inside your head, you're just agitated, nervous and fucking terrifed of dying in a video game.

Let's preface this simply by saying, I enjoyed my first 50 hours with this game. Interesting character dynamics, fun varied combat, challenging but satisfying combat, all around I enjoyed nearly all of that 50 hours; But you wanna know why I have an extra 30 hours? 

Achievement hunting, specifically ONE Achievement. Now, I'll be the bigger man and won't spoil what it was, but I'll explain a bit about this game's rouge-like element. Each of the games zones are made out of rooms. Combat, challenges, survive etc. There's a particular type of room called Encounter Rooms. They often give great benefits. Issue is, they're also bloody rare. You can go 10-20 runs without seeing one. To get 3 achievements, you need to find each of the 3 zones encounter rooms and that's not all. Some of these achievements can only be done AFTER finishing the prior one so if you low-ball cant get a certain encounter in a previous zone, you're SOOL for a while. 

Worse part is, you can customize the difficulty of your runs, you can make Zagreus stronger or weaker as you see fit, but all that pales to the sheer fact you cant control Encounter Rooms. It's literal RNG baked into the game. So you really can't cheese this outside letting the mobs kill you after wasting 15 minutes into a run.

Overall, Great game but the encounter rooms made it overstay its welcome. Won't immediately try out Hades 2 now its fully released But I hope they did fix this of all things.

review_text:
Oddly super clunky combat despite it being the entire point. Zombies'll sometimes attack random bits of buildings while having clear paths to you. Hitboxes are jank as hell and you'll be hit from much further than you'd think of a melee range. 

Menus are designed weirdly, making them difficult to navigate. Descriptions of various things don't match the logic of the game, including controls explained in the tutorial. Stat numbers and denotations are more than often VERY unclear. Matches the overall writing of things like flavour text and monologues from the few NPCs you interact with.

Overall a huge mess of development choices despite how long it took to make the full release.
