genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
[h3] 7 Days to Die: A Veteran's Disappointment [/h3]

	I've sunk over a thousand hours into 7 Days to Die over the years, a testament to how fantastic this game [b] used to be. [/b] The core concept of a voxel-based zombie survival crafting game is brilliant, and for a long time, it delivered some truly memorable experiences. The issue is that the game I fell in love with is not the game it is today, and the developers ("The Fun Pimps") seem intent on a cycle of endless, often regressive, change rather than refinement.

	My lack of recommendation comes down to one core problem: the developers constantly redesign fundamental systems from the ground up with almost every major update. Instead of building on existing mechanics, they scrap them entirely, forcing veteran players to re-learn a "new" game every single time. This isn't early access refinement; it's a lack of vision.

    â€¢ [b] Scrapped Mechanics: [/b] We've seen multiple iterations of progression systems, from the "learn by doing" model to the current perk and magazine-based system. Each change feels like a sideways step, often removing depth and features that the community enjoyed (like empty jars or specific meat types) for no apparent reason other than change for change's sake.

    â€¢ [b] Forced Playstyles: [/b] Recent updates have introduced systems like biome progression tied to loot stages, which can feel linear and removes the open-world freedom that was a hallmark of earlier alphas. Base designs and creative building approaches that players developed over time are often patched out, forcing specific, developer-approved play styles.

    â€¢ [b] An "Eternal Early Access": [/b] After more than a decade in Early Access, the game still feels unpolished in many areas, while basic, long-promised features like bandits or robust NPC systems remain missing (though competently implemented by the modding community). The recent 1.0/2.0 updates have only amplified these frustrations, adding poorly implemented features like the annoying storm system that just waste time.
	
     I got my money's worth, absolutely. But I cannot recommend 7 Days to Die in its current state, nor can I endorse the development philosophy. If you are looking for a stable, long-term survival experience that consistently builds on its foundations, this isn't it. The game is a revolving door of concepts, and you never know when the mechanics you enjoy will be completely removed in the next patch. The modding community truly keeps this game alive; without them, it would have died a long time ago.

RHETORIC â€“ Psst, hey, you!

YOU â€“ Who -- me?

RHETORIC â€“ Yes, you. Word on the street is you're ready to talk about what *ZA/UM* did again!

YOU â€“ 'Again'?

RHETORIC â€“ Yes -- you're ready to dig into ZA/UM drama *again*. You've talked about it before, *they've* talked about it before. Hasn't really worked out yet, but neither have all those *spiritual successors* -- should we just stop making them, too?

YOU â€“ Can't argue with that.

RHETORIC â€“ So, what about all that bitterness you've been carrying? Word on the street is you've woken up from a thousand years of slumber, ready to speak of the studio's controversy louder than ever attempted before. Is that true?

YOU â€“ How come there's *word on the street*?

RHETORIC â€“ You keep saying things like *down with the ZERO PARADES*, *eat the board of directors*, *sodomize the ip-owners*, *impale all people who have more than 25% of the shares*, *literally teabag all corpo clowns regardless of their involvement in pushing out the visionaries* -- that kind of stuff.

The reason for this seems to be some kind of moral system whereby if you moral drops to zero it's as good as dying, only you can heal health and avoid fights, but you cannot avoid skill checks, unless you just want to remain in your hotel room and go nowhere and do nothing.

Like I say, perhaps I'm playing it wrong cos lots of other people give this good ratings and it did somewhat make me laugh a couple of times, but when I'm forced to sit in a chair so uncomfortable a single skill check failure looses me the game, but I cannot progress without having the conversation... As a avid TCG player who has been heavily invested in the game since 2005, I have to say this is nearly unplayable.

While naturally it shares every issue with normal gameplay of the real card game, it also goes much deeper then that. First point: The gatcha system (while theres certainly FAR worse ones out there) is terrible. Grinding gems takes forever and once you've cleared solo mode, say goodbye to ever getting anything new ever again, because the game will VERY slowly drip feed you a paultry sum of gems IF YOU WIN a ranked match and thats about it (GOOD LUCK winning without a tier 0 deck)

Second point: Cheaters. The game is FULL of them. Everything you can imagine. FTK bots, AFK bots, players who can see your hand at all times, people who manipulate the cards drawn on both sides, deck stacking, its awful and nearly unplayable.

Third point: The TERRIBLE and WILDLY inconsistent banlist. So...you're telling me that the current tier 0 (which has been tier 0 for nearly 3 months now) doesn't have a single card even so much as semi-limited, but secret village, card of demise, POT OF PROSPERITY are banned? Maxx C is at 2. Pot of duality is at 1. What.

Fourth point: It is VERY begginer hostile. The game just expects you to casually pay over 100 REAL LIFE dollars to MAYBE get a CHANCE at getting specific cards that are essential and you litterally CAN NOT win even in rookie without. 

Fifth point: Bugs. And lots of them. I get this is the most complex card game of all time so naturally, when in digital form, its not gurenteed to work properly every time, but this is absolutely ridiculous. Were getting nonsense like a card that does NOT have to be face-up to resolve somehow fizzeling after being MST'd, cards whos activation requirement is something like "Target 1 card you control" and somehow not being allowed to activate it despite the fact there is NOTHING preventing targeting anywhere, special summoning from the grave with necrovalley on the field, ect ect. FIX YOUR GAME KONAMI

sixth point: The horrible meta: I get this is an issue in the TCG and OCG as well, but due to the wonky and weird banlist, i think its at its worst here. You better REALLY enjoy seeing the same 3 decks, because once you get past bronze its ALLLLL youre ever going to see for the rest of your life.

Seventh point: While this is not 100% proven yet, there is evidence to suggest the game is bias for asian players. Letting asian players start every duel with 3 different handtraps plus 2 different 1 card starters every single game whilst giving the english players 3 same named HOPT cards and 2 extenders that can't play through 3 hand traps. Or for the first time in 20 duels you open maxx c but AWWW DIDNT MATTER because the asian player opened ash, 2 starters, and extender, TTT, and maxx c themselves. It happens SO often and is almost always exlusively from asian players, that I am convinced the game plays favorites.

eighth point: The community is ULTRA toxic. No one is helpful, everyone is hostile, and everyone thinks theyre king of games while everyone else is worthless peasents. Any time you complain about ANYTHING its always "skill issue" (despite 50% of the game being luck) No, its not "skill issue" that konami themselves wanted the opponent to win and gave them 4 hand traps and a starter whilst not giving me and handtraps or breakers, thats RNG, not skill.


Overall, I simply can NOT recommend this horrible game to anyone who values their life or sanity. If you enjoy being screwed over by RNG while everyone who you simply ask for help or tips from mock you, go ahead, but no thanks. Im good.

From the start of the game to the credit roll, Nier is a pleasant and melancholic game that pours a lot of attention into its side quests to paint a picture of life in a dying world.  It's a game as much about loving the NPCs struggling day after day as it is about its character-driven main story.

However, you may be aware that Nier is a game with multiple endings.  Rather than a choice of parallel endings that you see in many RPGs, this game follows from Drakengard and VNs in having sequential endings that build upon each other.  Or at least, they try to.

The positive part of my review ends at the credit roll for Ending A.  (Or a little afterâ€”the backstory you get for KainÃ© just after is also easily worthwhile.)  To reach the other endings, you have to repeat sections of the game again and again and again.  The actual new content is minimalâ€”just a few extra cutscenes stretched thin across old bones.  What new content there is is rarely interesting, instead repeating or expanding emotional points that were already present in the original playthrough and could've been included the first time around.  The personality flaws of the main cast go unexplored, and the extra characterisation for your enemies changes the story from a tragedy into a tone-deaf farce.  Meanwhile, what emotional impact the story originally had is scrubbed off as you sit through the same scenes again and again, waiting for it to be over.

It should also be noted that combat itself is very shallow, and really doesn't stand up to replay.  By my final run of the ending boss gauntlet, I had figured out several points [i]during combat[/i] where I was free to scroll on my phone while button mashing or evading one-handed, barely glancing at the game screen.

There is at least some actual novel material when you get to the final ending, and it's quite sweet... but it's only enough to remind you that the first half of the game was actually good, and not enough to justify the crime against art that is the second half of the game.

Do not get this game if you are expecting Nier Automata. I love Nier Automata but this is not it. Do not get this game at all actually, it just did NOT age well at all; lacking all QoL and extremely annoying "puzzles" that are just absolute bs and huge time wastes. Go watch the story on YT.

This game to me is one that deserves a mixed rating. While I liked the game and had fun playing it, there were plenty of times  when it felt more of a slog to get through. The world is semi open-world that is both good and bad. Constant Saving felt like a must

Starting off, making my characters was fun, there were a good amount of classes to choose from. Playing around with some starting skill options, personal customization was ok nothing too crazy for the Two Player Characters you create as my heroes.
A few voices to choose from, personalities etc. Not everything in the game is voiced, most MC dialogue gets voiced with their little side quips, side characters here and there, most dialogue will be read. A few companions to choose from, I choose two and rocked with them, since I believe if you swap them in later their level's won't match yours, needs more testing?

Combat was fun and not fun, while it worked and gave me chances to be creative with combining the environment, items I have, spells and such to fight, it meant the enemy could do the same. With the world being open-ish often I'd find myself in fights I wasn't going to win, the battles can drag on since the AI sometime is fast, othertimes It's like Internet Explorer making a turn. Getting wiped just to fight the same long tedious fight drags on, trying multiple strats just to get perma stunned by 5+ enemies. The wide variety of spells and weapon types means you have to adjust based on the enemy, with some damage types healing them, (my best weapons healed the final boss, that was fun).

Locales/Vibes- locations looked great, it felt like an adventure, from simple beaches (how original lol) to ancient caves and tombs to spirit realms & even to the ends of time. In the same vein some locations were terrible, like the Luculla Sandstorm,  nothing was fun about making a conga line with my party to pull the enemy, spending 20 minutes to beat a enemy then running away to escape combat and teleport away just to rinse and repeat. 
There are traps and secrets hidden in the world, things like hidden grave to lava traps.

Puzzles, some felt fun and rewarding, while the majority were just annoying and killed the pace and fun of the game, You'll need to be used to separating your party and multi-tasking with them, along with reading everything ever. Or needing very "specific" weights needed on weight plates. Many of them feel like they're trying to be overly clever and are doing too much imo. 

This is the kind of game where you need to interact and talk with everyone and everything, which takes forever. Even then you'll still miss things and interactions. If only I realized my choices in events that gave my character points in their personality things like "vindictive, pragmatic, romantic" etc actually affected my character stats and potential dialogue options that could lock you out of things. Along with knowing what items can actually be dragged onto others to work.

To me, this game would make one do new runs over and over to fix their mistakes if they get softlocked. So yeah you could respec everything except personality points from dialog and benefits/detriments, but what if you lose your skills? So what if i can buy them again or craft them again except the skills for my Knight and ranger? Ones that can't be gotten again? I committed to my build and mistake and suffered for it. Some skills felt useless and were a waste of precious talent points. My rogue had near max stealth skill, and I was still getting discovered, so I just used his "Make Invisible" skill which actually worked and was 1000x better.

Quick Side note, Don't sell Tenebrium items to merchants, I then had to deal with dying merchants for the rest of the game, I kept alive with my mage spamming Rejuvenates.

An annoyance to me was near the end game, I couldn't progress past a door needing me to have Blood stone/Star Stones, story/lore items that also double as "full party heals" basically omega tier heals. It said I didn't have enough but I already went everywhere I could ingame. So there I was backtracking the whole game searching high and low for these supposed stones. I found one, the only last one, but he still wouldn't open. How was I supposed to know I needed to use my rare healing stones? Then after that go to my homebase to talk to some merchants for the door to then open saying I was then worthy.

While I did enjoy my time with this game, those moments were here and there bogged down by slow moments, overtuned encounters, overly annoying puzzles, slow combat and general shenanigans one would expect from this style of game. Again I say to better enjoy the game, it'd take multiple runs/attempts. It'd be more fun for me now that I know how it plays out and how to spec better. I'd recommend it to people who like this type of game and difficulty, however to the casual RPG gamer who just wants to have easy fun without thinking, no stress kind of thing, this isn't for you.

I didnt really like it, it seems like step down from BG2, the story didnt intriguing and feel more exposition dumping. Didnt like how the quest dialoque is written, feel like the character say a lot but end up say nothing. didnt like the fact this is linear game but masked like open world, the enemies not respawning so you just following straight line, meaning have to planning before-hand, putting wrong skillpoint will doomed your whole playthrough, so combat is your only playstyle, cant go rogue cant do rp, because end boss always hard. with a game that farming is not possible due to enemies not respawning, then doing RP is pointless, why even put trait/karma system in linear game? Its blurry the focus of the game. Planning to finish this and play EE next, heard both of them have different quest and spell, but idk if i can even finish this one. The world is in verge of war but somehow the game painted it so bright and dandy, not clicked on me.

interesting rpg but i prefer divinity original sin 2. original sin is a very fleshed out and self contained story, but I didn't feel like that story ever did enough to capture or hold my interest to finish it. the combat is pretty weak and if you look around at all, you will quickly stumble on an encounter that is impossible at your current level. it feels less like "dont go there" and more like "dont go anywhere," and you wont. I thought i never made it far enough to pass the starter town, but it turns out, thats the only town. everything is greatly improved in the sequel, which makes this entry obsolete for me and i have very little love for it. its not horrible, its just not as open as its disparate systems have the potential for.

So get this, its a roleplaying game that gives you the choice between being good or bad with lockpicking skills, smokescreens, a sneaking and stealing system, but if you decide to roleplay an evil and resourceful character, then you may use your shovel on the first "suspicious mound" you come across. Youre even encouraged by some intriguing descriptions of soiling a fresh grave and a +heartless indicator over your heads. When suddenly BOOM PARTY WIPE NO YOU DONT GET TO ROLEPLAY IN THIS ROLEPLAY GAME, gravedigging big bad crime and lovely developers are going to add the option to what, make you deal with their shitty autosave as punishment? Oh, which in case you didnt know, the autosave doesnt activate after extensive menu juggling so if you just explored half a city, completed a quest, and spent an HOUR JUST FIDDLING WITH THE CRAFTING SYSTEM, congrats, THAT HOUR WAS WASTED because you couldnt remember which FUNCTION BUTTON the quicksave was bound to and figured the game wouldnt have a nonfunctional autosave system in place- WRONG AGAIN FUCKO. Feels like playing dnd with a dm that will happily wipe the whole party because he doesnt like that the characters did an "evil" action or refreshes the browser so the combat data is lost because you landed a crit on his cool new bad guy or spent too long minmaxxing HIS OWN GAME. IM GOING TO FINISH THIS GAME AS EVIL AS POSSIBLE NOW OUT OF SPITE. You wanted to show me an experience but what you did was took my money and spat in my mouth and instead of thanking you IM GOING TO GO FUCKING FERAL. ALSO IM REBINDING AUTOSAVE TO MIDDLE MOUSE BUTTON

Great game ruined by the ending.  Came back to this after never having completed it before.  Recurring theme with Larian games is amazing story and mechanics, but absolutely awful initiation in fights.  You either need to always sweat position for them or you have an unavoidable rigged fight.  Ending sequence involves a multistage fight where not once, but twice you are forced to have your characters amassed like idiots close together.  Can't really pregame potions with the no pause setup, summons despawn before  battle.  Stacking initiative is kind of pointless as it forces a start rotation.  This isn't highest difficulty, this is forced nonsense that removes all strategy.  All of your characters are force pulled in so that you can't hedge against the eventual fight.  The two different sides of enemies ignore each other to attack me exclusively.  I have absolutely no idea what the developers were expecting you to do here other than play one exact specific way cheesing certain stats, which is extremely boring.  Feel like I wasted my time on this playthrough, unless I use cheats to just skip to the story conclusion.

the game loading time is pathetic, it freezes and doesnt advance half the time, and its not my pc's fault because i can play way more demanding game like baldur's gate easily with no problem

i really want to love this but i just cant, the world and characters are very interesting and cool but combat system with basically 3 hp types is very annoying to play around with even with all the build flexibility in the world that this game provides

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of those games that remind you why you fell in love with RPGs in the first place.
The humor? Chef's kiss.
The characters? Absolute chaos goblins with personality.
The graphics? Weirdly gorgeous for a game thatâ€™s not exactly new anymore. Honestly, half the time I forgot this thing came out years ago, because everything looks like it has been polished by a team of very dedicated fantasy elves.

And the classes? Amazing. You can basically create anything from a teleporting rogue assassin who politely stabs people in the faceâ€¦ to a necromantic violinist who heals by bleeding on things. Truly art.

But thenâ€¦ Source Points happen.

Ah, yes. Source Points. The magical energy that fuels your strongest abilities, your coolest spells, is needed to acomplish dungeons/quests, andâ€”apparentlyâ€”your greatest frustration in life.

Itâ€™s not that the game limits you on them. That would actually be interesting, right? Making tough choices, thinking strategically, feeling the weight of your decisions?

Nope.
Divinity says: â€œYou can refill them endlessly, dear player!â€
And then quietly adds:
â€œâ€¦Just run back and forth like a lost chicken to do it.â€

Why?
Why give me infinite refillsâ€¦ but only if I prove my dedication by jogging across Rivellon like Iâ€™m training for a marathon?
Why ruin the pacing of such a brilliant game with a mechanic that feels like an unpaid internship?

Instead of epic adventure, I get Source Point Fetch Quest Simulator 2017.

And thatâ€™s when my enthusiasm died a dramatic, theatrical death. Not by combat. Not by a boss. But by pure, uncut inconvenience. Itâ€™s like the game whispered:
"You like fun? Too bad. Go touch another puddle of ghost juice, peasant."

So, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is still an incredible game with unforgettable humor, beautiful visuals, and rich gameplay.
But Source Points?
Yeah, no. Hard pass. When a mechanic makes me feel like Iâ€™m clocking in for my shift, I put down the controller and walk away.

Final Verdict:
A masterpiece held hostage by a mechanic that thinks I have the free time of a bored god. If Larian ever patches Source Points into something less annoying, Iâ€™m back in. Until thenâ€¦ Rivellon, itâ€™s not you. Itâ€™s your weird energy system.
Not even MMO.
Game's balancing and systems are still as unfun as I remember. Also there's an annoying launcher now? Had to look up how to bypass that asap. Just play BG3, it's just better.

This is a good game. An amazing even. Perhaps one of the best RPGs that exist. I see all the effort and how genuinely worked-through the game is. I'm sure it was a lot of work and effort, gameplay-wise, voice acting -wise, and in many other ways.

I just genuinely didn't enjoy playing it. Not because it's bad, but because (as it turned out) it's not in my taste. I should have probably catch it and not play BG3 (which I disliked too). After an hour in this game I feel exhausted and get a headache (it's not even due to the strategic difficulty: I enjoy stellaris for example or actual D&D).

I originally played this on the PS4 and decided to get it on steam so I could make sure that I'd have it forever, but I just cannot get past the "tinny" audio issues during dialogue. The 6 hours of playtime is not of me playing the game, but is rather 4 hours of play and 2 of on-again off-again trying to troubleshoot the terrible audio. I'm playing on Windows 10 with a Sony 2.1 Soundbar. Sounds AMAZING for other games like Helldivers 2 or Split/Second. But for Horizon I just can't cope with the awful compression when people talk. I have tried several tutorials and am too fed up to keep trying.

I know I could play with headphones, but that just isn't the experience I am looking for.

Other issues include awkward body animations, cutscene/rendering glitches, and terrible facial speaking animations. This game looks and sounds like a port. And after years of being out and these issues still being present, it just isn't a pleasant experience. Sorry.

A lot of praise has been given to this game yet it really does not deserve any of it.  First of all shooting at metal monsters with a bow makes no sense.  Bows are not meant to be used on steel since arrows will simply bounce off. Probably the most mid game I've ever played. I'm enjoying it, because I don't really have anything else I want to play right now, but I'm not really _enjoying_ it if you know what I mean. It hits the right buttons to keep you playing, but never does anything to make you feel anything more than "yeah I'm playing this game. it's fun. it's ok". Thinking about it, it's actually quite impressive in its average-ness tbh. 

Graphics are great, even 8 years on from the release, combat is fun, writing is awful, acting is pretty average. There's the guy from The Wire, so there's that. I wish there was a "meh" button for my review, but given that there's not, I'll not recommend it. You'll probably low-level enjoy it if you download it and don't have anything better to do though.

if you don't have much experience with great games, its going to be a great game. However if you've played games where you feel like you're really interacting with the world, games which immerse you instantly into their world building and characters you'll always have a feeling in the back of your head: "Damn this is kinda boring?".

That feeling never left. I really tried for 15 hours to enjoy this, I couldn't. The world is beautiful but soulless, there are a lot of characters but none of them really interesting. The gameplay is interesting, but only for the first few hours and gets pretty finicky. The story starts out interesting but is really, really shallow and predictable.

As far as movement unlocks go, there are a few great ones in there, but most are just basic stuff like double jump or dash, or even horrendously reused ones, like triple jump, dashing underwater or dashing in the sand.

All in all I'd give it a mixed review. The story is cute, but not deep enough to carry the game.

Why am I here? 

Devs...when *I* play a game and spend hours unlocking abilities. I want to use those abilities. Seems pretty straight forward?
 
To those who may not know, in the game are "spirit trials". These are races through areas of the game, and each zone seems to have one, more or less. I thought it best to wait until the end of the game, when I had the movement skills before I'd attempt anything with racing. Come to find out quite a few of your abilities are deactivated during these races because....reasons. "It's because the races would be trivial! unfair! You should have done them as they came up!" I can hear people saying. But I didn't do that? I waited because I wanted the be able to freely move in the game. You know, the movement abilities I spent time to obtain in the first place. 

I wanted to potentially 100% the game, but this Dev choice was just so short sighted, I could NOT be arsed to care about the completion, even though I adore the world that was created. What a fumble....and because the game is too old now to address this...that's it.

Devs...I beg...STOP DOING THIS KINDA SHIT. Just stop....stop. Or, come up with some kind of explanation as to why it's needed, and I mean NEEDED to somehow enrich the game. If it's really not, don't do it.

This sequel is just a stright up downgrade in so many things. Im so sad that in just two hours it made not want to play it anymore. First Ori game was peak... So many questionable design decisions and changes for the worst on this one... Disappointing...

Not to talk about the unnecesary change of gameplay feel in comparison with the first game. Here it just feels like enemies are carefully placed to interrupt you movement flow.

And the annoying meaningless side quests...

Such a downgrade.

In the year 202X, it is absolutely unacceptable to release a game where you cannot rebind the controller. That is a cardinal sin in gaming. The default controls in this game suck. Why are jump and attack both thumb buttons while the left bumper is barely used? Makes no sense. And before anyone says you can rebind with Steam, the prompts on screen show up wrong when you do that. I hate playing "Guess the button" every time an on screen prompt appears.

And it keeps asking me to sign into Xbox LIVE. I am already signed into Xbox LIVE.

Art is beautiful, but boss battles are poorly designed where the game seems to intend for you to just take hits, checkpoints are annoyingly far away at times, and there are too many speedrunning segments where if you fail you have to start over from the beginning of the sequence. Platforming hooks are often unresponsive which makes the speedrunning feel even worse. A rather frustrating experience overall.

Somehow I ended up with the burrow and water dash abilities, but neither of them worked. I was pressing the buttons to use both abilities but nothing happened. I thought this might have been a bug or something so I looked it up. Turns out, they both require the regular dash ability to work. Nowhere in the game or ability descriptions does it say this. A simple "requires dash" in the tooltip would have sufficed. I've probably beaten a dozen metroidvanias now, and have never been able to normally get to an ability that required an earlier, missable ability for it to work. It happened twice in this game. That's just poor game design, and instantly made me lose all desire to keep playing. Why even make those areas accessible in the first place? So I could waste more time backtracking to them later on? So the game wouldn't feel as short as the first Ori? GTFOH

Just to maybe have enough health to fight the constant barrage of enemies with legendary actions. I recommend playing divinity original sin 2 or Baulders Gate 3.

I have been video gaming 45 years!  I will purchase EVERYTHING to do with this game except the soundtrack, and supporter bundle. The DEMO lagged on my MEDIUM END machine yet looked AMAZING.  So I MAY need a GPU upgrade :)

What really does it for me in this title are the SETTINGS in addition to the MASSIVE CONTENT!  Like my first play-through of the stock/vanilla campaign is set to IRON-MAN & STORY-MODE, and we will go from there, pure gamer DELIGHT!

Gorgeous musics and pixel art visuals, responsive controls, ok, but the 3 big components of the gameplay (combat, exploration, platform) all feel frustrating (...although there's much worse, at least this game is not too difficult).

Here's the most frustrating characteristic of each point:
- platform usually requires high precision, i.e. if you don't jump exactly at the border of a platform, you won't grab it but instead will fall through it;
- exploration doesn't give you clues about where to go next so, every time you beat a boss and complete an area, you either look on the Internet or have to go forth and back in every single part of the map, until you find a new area you can access (and, of course, being a souls-like, this not only takes time but it's also annoying because enemies keep re-spawning);
- all enemies deal damage just by contact, and with punishihng hit-boxes (like, being close to a still enemy is equivalent to getting smashed by a hammer).
  This is not only another source of frustration both while doing platform and exploration/navigation, but also results in added frustration while fighting, in having to calculate not to end up too close to an enemy after an attack, and sometimes in not having a single safe point in the screen, when it's full of enemies.

The concept: it feels captivating, but then dialogues feel boring and pointless, I didn't catch the story, and I wouldn't dare reading the descriptions of all the collectibles.

This game is really annoying to play. Idk what word describes it but its so "animation-heavy". There's nothing innovative, all of the lore writing in place of "what the item actually does" is annoying. It's not challenging if it's just not fun to control/play.

Tries to capture what makes dark souls titles so great but fails to understand why. This feels like paying a groundhogs day version of that gameplay loop, instead of one where you adapt to new methods of approach and combat.

So far I love absolutely everything about the game... except the controls and platforming mechanics.
I hate those. They simply do not work properly.

I've played some horrible platforming sections in games prior, but this takes the cake, no the whole bakery.
Trying to grab unto ladders is 50/50 and trying to sword climb/hang is about 25/75.
It's just inconsistent and results in your death every time, which would be fine if it wasn't caused by poor mechanics.

I've played less than an hour and have already died to this about 20 times and not a single time to enemies

Can somebody give me a reason not to refund this game? Because if this is the experience with what I assume to be the easiest platforming in the game, I dread what would be coming down the line.

Overheard during development: "You know what gamers like, don't you?" "Yeah, Ladders!" "Gamers love to have their movement restricted and slowed down." "Let's make them really slow to go down and hard to grip on to, you need to be precisely on them and point the controller you also use to move with exactly up." "Cool, and have players jump from ladder to ladder. Players love difficult stuff!" "Let's also make the ladders move!" "Great idea, are there anything that instantly kills players in this game?" "Only spikes." "Nice, put tons of spikes then underneath the ladders, what else?" "Shoot fireballs at the player to push them off?" "And have it at the end of a timed parkour track to have players redo the whole thing if they fail, and make the beginning really boring" "Perfect! (...) I wonder why Hollow Knight doesn't have any ladder-mechanics?"

Seriously though, game is ok. Great graphics. Though to get used to. Frustrating at times. I enjoyed exploration and did not use any guides until right at the end. The highlight of the game was a certain singing boss, but there were almost no other highlights like it, and the rest of the game felt bland. The biggest disappointment was that in the end game, there were almost no additional bosses or challenges to reward going for the better ending. It was just a grind with a lot of backtracking and the same final boss.

There are simply lots of better options out there.

The only thing more vague than the story is the gameplay and movement.

Does your slide have i-frames? Yes and no.
You can slide through contact damage but not attacks or projectiles.

Does the enemy have contact damage to begin with?
You won't know until you actively attempt to walk into them.

Where does the player's hurt box and collision box start and end?
This is particularly bad with the jumping animation where he raises his legs making him appear like the protagonist is jumping higher than they actually are. Combine that with similar shenanigans for enemies and it's a guessing game for where you will take damage.

Platforming feels awful combined in tandem with harsh punishment for failing it. The only saving grace is that their timed platforming challenge courses don't result in real deaths. . ., but that doesn't stop them from feeling bad and clunky. Half of my deaths on these trials are caused by not grabbing a ladder that I thought I would have grabbed from visually appearing close enough.

The enjoyable experience the narrative can provide is overshadowed by the core handling the game provides as a metroidvania. I would not recommend the game.

Okay well, if you are going into this game new (impossible) don't. You have missed the hype and most likely have already seen all of the spoilers. Either way, this game is better to watch anyway since the devs haven't updated the game since 2023 and that update was for the addition of MacOS players being able to play the game. I have a small feeling that the devs have abandoned this game which is sad since there are certain achievements that are now impossible to get due to certain areas having bugs where you simply either get soft-locked trying to enter them or can't enter them without somehow debugging if that is even possible (I'll get into those bugs later in this review). 

My personal opinion of this game is that it is amazing, it still seems to have an active community, it is cute as all hell and even funny at some parts, and the puzzles and story and interactions with the individual robots is just awesome. I love cats too :3

Anyway now, about the bugs: There is this weird bug in the game that affects three achievements. Those achievements being (from what I believe): Territory, Badges, and I Remember. The bug is where you just get stuck on certain parts of big pipes that you either walk on or through. I've had it to where it completely traps the character you play as forcing me to reload my save and I've had it to where it just blocks the character you play from progressing entirely.

In the end, do NOT get this game now. If they update it and the bug fixes, I'll update this review (hopefully). But with the current state of this game and how long it has been since it was released, do NOT waste your time or money on it.

I would probably still recommend this game, but there's one really annoying flaw that I experienced while playing it that I can't forgive. The issue is simple yet big enough to have a negative impact on gameplay for multiple sections of the game - THIS GAME IS LITERALLY SO DANG DARK. I encountered a section where you're alone in a dark house, and I almost thought my system was frozen because I could barely see anything. This resulted in me fumbling around in the dark and extending that section of the game by like another half hour longer than it was supposed to take because I just couldn't see where to go. I tried everything I could think of involving messing with brightness, contrast, gamma, docking it to my TV, etc. It seems this is not an issue unique to me, because I found a couple of forums concerning the issue and none of their propsosed solutions worked. I guess this was the case for a couple of other people on the forums because they quit the game too since there are multiple dark sections of the game they didn't want to deal with lol. I just don't see how the devs haven't fixed something so glaringly obvious and annoying after all this time that the game has been released. [i] Italian text [/i]

At first I recommended it. Now I don't. Gameplay-wise, there exists both the dream world and the real world. That's not what the game actually calls them, but it's what I'll call them. Each world has "sequences" to them. You cannot explore the entirety of the dream world before the real world, and vice versa. The first sequence of the dream world seemed decently engaging enough, where the rules that the game establishes for itself not being set in stone, and each interaction and fight feeling new and fresh. This maintains itself in the first sequence in the real world, where I was able to explore it and find all the connections between it and the dream world. And then after that...the rules have already been established, and the game doesn't particularly deviate from it, if at all. And those interesting parallels aren't really drawn anymore. So it's just a long, repetitive...well, I wouldn't say slog. But it isn't particularly enjoyable.
 Story wise...there is a twist that completely sours the story. A part of me doesn't want to reveal the twist, but then again, if you don't want to play a game again simply because you know the twist to it, what's the point of the game, really? In short, I can't sympathize with manslaughter. You, the character, have committed a criminal act. If not involuntary manslaughter, then staging it to look like a suicide certain doesn't help things, either. And THEN the main character and the character who helped you stage the body feel bad about it? They feel bad about losing a friend? Would it have killed them to, I don't know, call for help? Instead of staging it to look like a suicide? That's what a friend would do! Get their friend help! Now, I haven't actually reached the end. I've just seen enough spoilers through the community of this game to have found that out. And that twist just completely breaks my suspension of disbelief. Getting so attached to some characters in a movie, show, or video game just for it to not resolve in a fulfilling way...you know, closure...that's one of the greatest sins a piece of media can commit. I think that part is what's most egregious about this game.

Pros:
-good music
-good art
-great story
-charming dialogue, clearly the game has love put into it...

Cons:
-RPG game (Side quests are tedious, battle system is tedious... but this is just a personal opinion)
-90% sure the creator OMOCAT is a pedo.... Review would have been positive but I don't want to support them so here we are. (Don't take this as s serious allegation, instead research the MULTIPLE dramas surrounding the creator yourself...)
-This may fall under me disliking RPGs, but I really wish there was no/a higher limit on the number of saves you can have at once.
-Interacting with stuff is weird. Sometimes you need to press and hold, and sometimes it wont let you close out after a single tap. I would look at the bathroom mirror for 0.1 second (because you need to press and hold) and then be forced to look at that one photo in the bookshelf (not exactly a fan of that or that one unskippable boss's design btw [boohoo], but this last bit is an opinion also)

Overall, good game, would recommend, but maybe hesitate before supporting the creator

Decided to go cyberpsycho and add a new forceful user agreement where you can't play their game without agreeing to allow a spyware program to run in the background while you play, so you can't mod your game or do anything to alter the game in any way (It's a single player game who cares)

Cyberpunk 2077 is fine, I think. Probably one of the most 6/10 games I have ever played. It has a lot of side content, and there is definitely fun to be had, but it is more so in the Fallout 3 way of making your own fun. The cyberware feels half-baked, the perk system still feels like a first draft, melee feels basically unusable at higher difficulties, the writing is either pretty decent or just abysmal, a lot of the quest design is pretty boring and underdeveloped, the main quest ends right as it seems like it is about to get really interesting, and the city itself feels flat. It's got a lot of pretty buildings to look up at, but there is basically no meaningful verticality that the game plays with. At full price, I can not in good faith recommend the game. 

Phantom Liberty is a little better, I would probably rank it independently at around a 7/10 or maybe an 8/10, but that is mainly just because the writing and quest design is better and a lot tighter than the main game. The fundamental gameplay just does not feel good. Still pretty buggy, still a pretty bad "roleplaying game", and still a very superficial exploration of the themes of cyberpunk.

Before you read this review - if you're considering buying this game because you're looking for a good "choices matter" game with incredible time travel mechanics and attention to detail, and you haven't played Steins;Gate, definitely buy Steins;Gate instead, no questions asked. If you've already played Steins;Gate and you are looking for something that has some of the same types of themes, I guess this game kind of does... But be prepared to lower your expectations. A lot.

This game had a lot of potential and I was pretty intrigued after playing through the first episode... But then once I started playing the DLC episodes I realised pretty quickly that even though it constantly tells you "your choices will influence the past, present, and future, choose wisely", none of your choices actually have any real impact on the story. Whenever you encounter a choice that seems like it should have a significant impact, you can pretty much bet that whatever character is affected by the choice has already completed their role in the story by that point and won't really be mentioned much for the rest of the story (regardless of which option you picked).

One thing I did like about the game is the rewind mechanic. It is implemented really well, and there are quite a few good puzzles that make use of it. Unfortunately, this leads me into my next complaint, which is the abundance of bugs in the game that range from slightly inconvenient to pretty infuriating.

One of the most annoying bugs in this game is that the camera constantly locks up. I think it has something to do with "examining" something and then immediately trying to move the camera after closing the examine screen. It will lock your camera in a specific direction and make it impossible to look around for a while, and then after you walk around for long enough the camera will eventually fix itself (usually). And then there are a couple of sections where you can get locked in the rewind screen without any way of escape and you have to restart the section and go through everything again. Also something is glitched with the textures, it seems like the characters sometimes have multiple layers and one of the layers sometimes halfway glitches and they get super pale or something. Fortunately that one is pretty easy to ignore because the graphics are already bad enough that you don't really notice. Not that bad graphics really detracts from the overall experience, which is obviously a lot more narrative-driven than something that's meant to blow you away with visual fidelity.

Then there's the plot. The time travel stuff is pretty interesting and there are some genuinely clever ethical dilemmas that arise from it, but the setting really wasn't for me. Most of the characters are annoying (which makes sense I guess because they're all teenagers at a private school) and there's a lot of swearing for no good reason. And the main conflict is just weird, and doesn't seem realistic at all. Also, I grew up in Oregon and THERE AREN'T ANY FIREFLIES. I guess that's a nitpick, but that immediately broke what little immersion there was for me, lol

Anyway, I wouldn't recommend paying $20 for the DLC even if you played the first episode and enjoyed it. Your money is much better spent on something like Steins;Gate.

Dragon Age Inquisition really shows how an entire franchise can go to utter waste.

Despite how good Dragon Age Origins was, no amount of nice lore and storyline helps me tolerate the obsessive amount of grinding in this game that does not know if it wants to provide a good single-player experience or to be an MMORPG with offline servers.

Dragon Age Inquisition is the product of a new design philosophy that spits on the memory of Dragon Age Origins by diverting the player from its previous narrative-driven and consequence-driven logic to an open-world design with vestigial elements from a logic of microtransactions in pay to win games.

Of course there are no microtransactions in Dragon Age Origins, but we all know that blocking quests behind real wait times (like in the war room) are only used by game developers to force players into paying to unlock these sections of the game faster. By blocking quests merely for the sake of it under hours or days, the developers brought a vestige from the microtransaction systems of P2W games, and this is not the only instance where Dragon Age Inquisition is more akin to an MMORPG than to a good single-player RPG.

But what is so wrong with this new design philosophy that Bioware has adapted? That it breaks the narrative of what Dragon Age is.
Dragon Age Inquisition is the story of a person who seems to have been touched by divine power, surviving an explosion with a mark that provides the key to bring the world back into order from beaches that allow demons to cross from the fade to Thedas. It is the story of a person who becomes the public face of an organization tasked with saving the world. It is a story of urgency, the breaches won't wait for the main character to have a field trip before they come to save the world.

Yet, the game design gets everything wrong:
1. Despite the narrative emphasis that Dragon Age has always exhibited, every actual plot moment seems to be blocked by hours of constant grinding and filler material.
2. Every combat has lost all its meaning and it's now nothing but filler. Every enemy is an HP piÃ±ata ready to waste your time even in the easiest difficulties. And not even in the sense of being difficult, just in the sense of being unnecessarily long.
3. The open-world zones destroy all sense of urgency and of pacing, letting the player roam to the most irrelevant places.
4. Most of the side quests are filler content that lack any connection to the player's status as the Herald of Andraste or even any relevance to their mission. Yeah, you can make people be more favorable to the Inquisition by helping them do menial things, but that is not the job for the person who is in charge of closing the breaches. The open-world design forces the player character into an errand-runner, but they are not an errand-runner. They are the Herald of Andraste!

Thus, all these are symptoms of a game design philosophy that does not suit the narrative of a Herald touched by almost divine power. The open world logic forces a dissonance where, despite the urgency of the situation and the role the main character plays in the great scheme of things, the player is invited to waste its time doing everything but the engaging with the main plot. Its vast open-world zones interrupts the pacing and drama, its excessive amount of filler combat distracts from the actual point of the story and its new system of side quests excessively reliant on letters (instead of actual interesting interactions with real people) does not add to the real plot. We've gone from a story-driven game to an open world with the vestiges of microtransaction logic bringing about a degree of dissonance that just destroys the entire experience. Going to a new place like Val Royeaux does not feel anymore like advancing the plot, but like just opening a new can of worms with more irrelevant chores to complete. This game may be great for grinders and completionists, but it does not feel at all like a continuation of Dragon Age Origins.

Some people think Veil Guard was the end of the Dragon Age franchise, but it was already dying in Dragon Age 2, and its body had just decomposed by the time this game was released. Veil Guard was just BioWare spitting on the rotten meat.

Everything still seems lifeless and fake. They could have really improved it and added new content. Nowadays a few improved textures and shaders are enough. 

Playing it again just made me take the rose-tinted shades off... no multiplayer? That is criminal! I used to really enjoy that back in the day and was actually one of the reasons I bought it again. Another thing I notice is that playing renegade is a bit hit and miss, your character seems to have been designed to be paragon. Would be better if they actually improved the game instead of just giving the artwork a new lick of paint. At least you can mod it to add a little bit more life into it. 

Ultimately if you love the single player experience or haven't played it yet, it might be worth the cost to get all 3 games in one package but I was expecting a lot more.

I'm still at the first one, but this one is so overwhelmingly NOT even passable in any regard other than story, setting and production values, which are OK (but certainly nothing more, with some really aggravating and facepalming moments), there's just no way the rest of the trilogy can save the package. An abundance of idiotic one-hit-kill mechanics coupled with limitations to saving that lead to having to do boring shit over and over again (a couple of the fights are really unreasonable to boot), the lack of any (!) character development, the worst/most uninteresting loot/equipment system I've ever seen (and with the spectre weapons you can get before the halfway point being the best in the game, all further weapon looting is pointless â€“ and so are the millions of accumulating credits you can't spend on anything because there is nothing worth buying! this isn't even amateur level game design, it's retard level!), boring-as-fuck levelling which is completely unbalanced as well, psionic abilities all seem to do the same thing (namely, hindering your opponent for a few seconds â€“ I can't tell a difference between them at all!), the abominable balance of main and side quests (speedrunners must love this though...), unskippable cutscenes, many, many bugs... and, most direly, the total and utter failure in the RPG aspect as you cannot choose even your own words (!), much less anything else between generally good and vaguely evil... and it's beyond reason itself, as predecessor Knights of the Old Republic was infinitely better in each and every single regard, and DA:O which came afterwards in almost all regards!

EDIT: Game 2. Oh boy! There is more character development in the first 30 min than in game 1, but the actual gameplay is so much worse I simply cannot believe it! Only 4 to 6 things to level instead of some 15 (!), you can't specialise in weapons, the actual shooting feels way worse, the first (!) group battle is already next to unwinnable (and I did beat game 1 on hardest difficulty...), health refills are gone apparently (or I cannot find them) and to top things off, I cannot figure out how to fucking map the quickslots (which I never used in the first game, as I was able to map the weapons to keys, WHICH SHOULD ALSO BE THE CASE HERE!). Fucking shit, the sniper scope doesn't even line up with your line of sight, LOLOOLOL.

I cannot believe how hard they fucked up the gameplay compared to the already not very good first game! No inventory at all, four or five skills to level, no specialisation in weapons, still no feedback whatsoever â€“ you are literally not told whether you hit an enemy or not, and what hits you in turn (even though the latter isn't as important as you can't protect yourself against different kinds of damage, OBVIOUSLY)! No way to boost your abilities in something like the insane garage fight (complete with the biggest video game sin that exists, infinitely respawning enemies â€“ and that's against very limited ammo!!! Hell, after this shit I'll never complain about a game having infinite ammo again!), hell, the fuckers even took out health potions altogether!!! There's apparently quickslots but no apparent way to map them, so I have to change my weapon FROM THE FUCKING MENU EVERY SINGLE TIME!!! Oh and making the sprint key not only the same as Use but also Cover in this one means I will never buy another game from this developer again.

I regret spending 4,79 on this fucking shit of a game, I really do. They did not test this game before releasing it, and they did not test the re-release either... what kind of people would do that... only the worst scum imaginable. Humanity doesn't DESERVE to be saved!

[h3]A Walking Simulator Disguised as Horror and Puzzles[/h3]

After pushing through several hours, Iâ€™ve had enough. SOMA pretends to be this deep, atmospheric horror masterpiece, but in reality, itâ€™s a painfully slow walking simulator with frustrating underwater segments. Iâ€™ve played my fair share of complex, puzzle-heavy survival horror games, and this one isnâ€™t challenging, itâ€™s just poorly executed and painfully repetitive gameplay.

The first hour hooked me with its atmosphere and story potential, but once youâ€™re thrown underwater, the experience falls apart. Low visibility, sluggish movement, and maze-like areas where you wander aimlessly for hours with no sense of direction; not fun, not scary, just exhausting.

Itâ€™s a shame, because thereâ€™s clearly a good story buried somewhere under all this frustration. But good narrative design doesnâ€™t excuse bad gameplay. Iâ€™ve played walking sims before, this one just happens to be the most boring one pretending to be more than it is.

If you value your time, skip this one.
a lot of running around in the dark.

This game will not launch for me and I have tried everything the devs left as a "support guide" for when this happens but nothing works. Very disappointed since I really wanted to get my hands on this game.

Linear, short, and a frustratingly simplistic story (at least with the themes they are trying to explore) that relies too much on the stupidity of the main character to carry itself to the finish line. Obnoxious use of filters, boring stealth sections, and a story twist that is obvious once you complete the prologue. It doesn't help the sense of tension is non-existent and any form of horror is too smeared in post-processing effects to be frightening. Even on a deep discount, it is hard to recommend this one.

What does it mean to be human?

That's the question the game poses. A journey on philosophical existentialism, if you will. If you've never entertained this topic, it's not implausible the game may have a deep impact on you. For me, however, it didn't hit the mark, not even close. I tried to like it; forcing myself to continue; hoping at some point it would start to click. Sadly, it only got worse.

Story is essential for me, gameplay is secondary, always. And a game like this is *entirely* story driven; there's no gameplay here other than walking and interacting with the environment via terminals, pushing buttons, opening doors, etc. I should be right in my element yet I found myself bored to tears. I believe with just a few gameplay mechanics, like an inventory, some resource management, semi-engaging puzzles and a combat system, the game would actually be enjoyable. But, as it stands, I just can't finish it. I've given up not long after reaching Theta.

This is one of those games where the first 20 hours or so are very addicting as you learn to swim in an ocean of content and struggle with balancing your economy with logistics and raids; but once you understand how to swim in the ocean, the mechanics all feel really flat and repetitive. Apparently it is a successor to Banished, I never played/heard of that, so to me this game feels very much like Anno.

The good things about this game: the learning curve is rewarding and I think I restarted my game like 15 times before settling on the playthrough where most of my gametime comes in. I think the learning curve for me was easier than it would be for most as I spent lots of hours in Anno and other logistics based building games as well, so for me it was just learning how this game goes about it, but for others this might be a steeper learning curve.

Visually it looks really good on my machine (others state they had performance issues) and seeing the seasons change and snow collect on the ground then melt is a nice touch. Watching the world change form as you build and plan roads is also fun. Mapping your town out and placing your individual buildings to maximize benefits and resources is always a fun little puzzle to solve; the game also makes it very easy to move things around when you realize you may have placed something incorrectly, so design mistakes are not punishing.

My gripe is the flawed logistics systems: most of the storage units don't have dedicated workers to them, and the long distance logistics solution (wagons) don't seem to supply every storage facility. The problem with this is upgrading your residential buildings require that they have a variety of goods, but the citizens/workers are simply too stupid to fill the markets/storage units with the same varieties; rather they stock them with the closest buildings that make those products. This seems like a problem that can be solved 10 different ways easily, and for the life of me I can't get all the storage units/markets to carry everything I'm producing.

The combat in this game is also a chore. The first few times you encounter a raid, it will really set you back as having armed units costs money, and this game honestly provides almost no early game economy other than simply being lucky and finding ruins with gold. The AI in this game is also very sub par; RTS games of the early 90s had much more engaging and intelligent enemy behaviors than this game does. The combat was what I was looking forward to the most in this game as it is presented as a real threat, but I found selecting all my units and telling them to attack units one at a time always had me winning in an open field despite the enemy outnumbering me sometimes like 6:1. It's also just raiders, there aren't any diplomatic options with other nations or castles that you can war with, so the combat feels like something slapped together really quickly.

As many have already stated, the tech tree feels fun at first, but later it feels like a gate more than a boost as all the buildings you need are locked behind technology and if you don't upgrade the right way, technology can be EXTREMELY slow to gain; I had to once wait like 5 in game years for one tech point because I needed a building that was locked behind a technology I didn't research yet and couldn't find a tech point any other way.

Overall the presentation and mechanics had me very captivated and impressed the first 25 hours or so, and then I realized I had mastered them all; at this point I was just playing the game to grow, not for a challenge or purpose, and I didn't find the aesthetics or freedom to build captivating enough to play without some goal to work towards.

I have played this game for many months, and really enjoyed it until the final release. I tend to play middle of the road with any game, medium difficulty, medium risk, medium time commitment. The decision to place a Raider Camp near a brand new village is just frustrating and makes no sense to me. Previously, the periodic raids added just the right amount of challenge and focus on villager safety. Now, I that safety is an overriding concern from the beginning and I feel like I cannot make any headway. I am taking a break from this game, and will see what other village builders my scratch this particular itch. Too bad, because I was having such a good time.

It's a solid game for 20 hours, the first run is fun, and then by the end I just had a moment of ".. that's it?". Starting a next run you're gonna be doing the same limited set of actions you can do to build your city. I have exhausted all variation quite shortly. I feel claustrophobic and lonely, it feels like im playing an empty husk of a world. Let me explain several independent thoughts I have which I'm conflicted about. These are only a few examples to explain a small portion of my feels.

Several mechanics and rules just live in the wild online as myths and mysticisms: what for, and how to use the wagon shop for example. Of course that's not the only one, as there are several other ones that are just not declared by the game so you kinda have to guess and hope it works like you want. Reading reddit comments and forum posts of other people's thoughts on what they believe the mechanic works like. There are several annoyances in the game that keep piling up at the back of your mind as you build your city and you get to know the systems of the game. Some examples:

The upgrade and proximity system encourages you to just cramp things together and make grids. It often comes down to "do you want a pretty town, or do you want to survive?"
We want a pretty town of course, thats the game's appeal. But in the back of your mind this annoyance is always going to be there.

It's great that you can set a max limit for resources, so that villagers can quit that job and enter an other one. But this isn't true for all jobs: farmers, healers, soldiers are assigned to their duties and are still busy standing in their job title. There is no downside to unassigning them while they are not useful. You can also just let them be, which is what I do: but it's still going to be an annoyance in the back of your mind.

The reason for my dislike isn't concretely these 2-3 examples. It's the overall feel, for which I have provided these examples. This feel, while the game is in early access is fine, but not as a full release at full price: Which is how I encountered this game the first time. I gave it enough playtime for me to doubt myself, because I did have doubts, maybe I just didn't understand the vision or the game. But I couldn't prove my feel for the game wrong even after playing it diligently.

Iâ€™ve been waiting for this game to leave Early Access, but honestly, it feels like it needed at least another year before being considered finished. My biggest issue is how painfully slow and inefficient the citizens are. Iâ€™m in year 9, and itâ€™s still unbearable.

Watching them work is like watching paint dry. Progress crawls because the NPCs are so inefficient. During winter, everyone just stays inside doing nothing, so I end up staring at my monitor waiting for villagers to actually start the tasks Iâ€™ve queued. I didnâ€™t buy a game to sit and wait for hours while nothing gets done.

Right now, the gameplay feels like 70% waiting and watching, and only 30% actually playing.

If I could leave a neutral rating, I would. But as it stands, I canâ€™t recommend this game to anyone. The citizens need major improvements to their productivity. Iâ€™m aware of the time-acceleration toggle, but this is about efficiencyâ€”not speed. For example: does it really take eight people six in-game hours to chop down a single tree?

The gameplay itself is based around a simple four lane trading card game that gets a little thin after a while. Aside from a few mechanics it's pretty straightforward. They seem really proud of this gameplay because you are playing it constantly.

There are puzzles but they range from so easy I don't know why this should be a bar to progress to wow I actually had to look around for the solution to this one.

So, the tutorial takes about 3 hours.  All of the screenshots are from the tutorial.  Once you beat it, it forces you to play an *ENTIRELY* different game that *REALLY* sucks.  I mean it's really awful.  Graphics are total garbage, gameplay is awful, etc.  AND you can't play the FUN game without unlocking a hidden feature.

To play the fun game shown in screenshots after beating the game, go to start menu, hold shift, press K M.  This unlocks "Kaycee's mod", which SHOULD NOT be hidden.

Edit: After playing Kaycee's mod for about a dozen runs, and repeatedly coming across impossible to win fights, where the enemy lays 3 creatures first turn, then 3 more turn two, with no way of fixing broken  (impossible to win) fights, I'm changing my review to negative.

Why negative:
Tutorial is only 3 hours long, but it's a blast.  So there's that.  The problem is that's not enough to justify the price tag, even on sale.  There's no way to play "non-tutorial" mode on a reasonable difficulty.  I don't even mind losing to "hard" fights that "IF" I had the right cards/items I could win.  It's the "Utterly impossible no matter what cards/items" fights that are a turn off.
After the tutorial is an *entirely* different game with the worst 2D graphics I've ever seen.  It's *NOT* the same game.  It's a total bait and switch.  And Kaycee's mod doesn't make up for the ultra short "fun" part.

Slay the Spire has a lot of good things going for it but just a few key aspects that really turn me off to it. I understand that as a rouge like game there is a certain randomness to the cards you get. And I really enjoy rougelike putting hundreds of hours into the Binding of Isaac and nearly 100% the game. But I feel the randomness is a detriment, some card combos create incredible gameplay loops with a good deck build, and as someone who plays many deck builders enjoy, I really feel this game would fit better as a build a deck and play through. More so if you had different starting decks that fit certain playstyles of the character and then went to deck building. I really cuts my motivation when I get a really solid playstyle that I really like but will never get to experience again. I think because of the card and turn based system it feels much worse than getting a bad or silly build in other realtime rougelike games.
An additional gripe I have which could be a skill issue, that this game really feels like you have to replay the game to complete it, in Issac when you start the game you don't just beat the whole game but there are small victories at first and it rewards skillful play, with slay the spire I feel like I just need to throw a run in order to somewhat progress enough to get to a further tier of the game. It does not feel rewarding to always lose a run eventually in my opinion. Or at least in a core gameplay where other games have a survive as long as you can with a reward for beating your PB it just isnt rewarding here.

This game is glorified gambling. It's not fun, just addictive. 

Game devs these days get away with just making a small pile of assets and then feeding them through RNG to sprinkle in probability based dopamine hits while otherwise just punishing you for playing their game. 

It's lazy and uncreative, no real adventure, no narrative, no discovery or mystery to be unveiled. Just a slot machine with a few extra mechanics and no real payout. 

If you're looking for an unrewarding yet engaging addiction that will eat your time endlessly then be my guest. 

It's a new trend I'm noticing among indie devs to just feed a small variety of assets into an RNG and call it a game. 
Hades, Enter the Gungeon, Tiny Rogues, Slay the Spire, Baltoro, etc. 

They're just time traps. Stay away or be time farmed.
This game is not random.

This game is simultaneously too rng heavy and too one-note to be any sort of fun. Each of the 4 characters really only has 1 viable strategy; Ironclad is good at building strength, Silent is good at building poison, Defect channels orbs of which only Lightning and Dark are worth a shit, and Watcher attacks with Wrath and ends the turn in Calm. Succeeding in building into those strategies is completely reliant on your card rng- both in the sense that you obtain the cards you need, but also that you manage to draw them in battle. Failure usually means dying at the 2nd boss, or worse, at the 3rd boss after you've wasted nearly an hour of your life for nothing. This card rng could be slightly mitigated if the game had a card pack system like Balatro. Cards are already split into 3 categories: Attack, Power, and Skill; if instead of 3 random card options whenever you finish a battle you were given the option to choose a pack containing 3 cards of the aforementioned category, playing the game would feel a lot less like pounding your head against a wall.

This game is fine. Balatro does it better. The turn-based aspect is what I sought, something chill, and I'm fine with that. The other game design seems to just clutter what could be a smoother rogue like, however. The shop for instance, sacrifices ease of use just to conform to some narrative. It's fine. A lot of people like this game, and I wish Steam had a more nuanced rating system, but it doesn't so this is what I chose. It's fine.

TLDR - Game is good only with mods.
