If i buddy wasnÂ´t watching to make fun of the design i would not have finished it. 19 hours with doing all sidequests blind.

After finishing the game i think i can safely say that i would not recommend buying this game at full price. The game itself was fun however there were a few things about it which i did not like and make the game definetily not worth the full price.

1. The game is a walk in the park... For calling itself a soulslike it is way too easy. I actually did every single boss first try except (ironically) the very first one where i died once cause i wasnt familiar with the movement of my own character. At the whole 12 hour run I only died 3 times even though im by no means a god gamer... im a soulslike fan so i actually enjoy getting my ass spanked by a hard game which this game sadly could not deliver the slightest.

2. The maps all look similar especially the first 3-4 big regions so it is too monotonous for my taste. Got a bit better to the end of the game but the start was too equal looking.

3. Mob recycling is crazy in this game... Holy shit there are actually only like 5 types of enemie which get recycled throughout the whole game by getting a different weapon or element but basically still being the same enemy.

4. As mentioned earlyier its too pricey for what it brings to the table. I would say a fair price would be 20â‚¬ but would strongly advise against buying it for everything above that price.

So much for my review, i still had fun playing it though even if not as much as i did in other soulslike.

I'd have given this game more of a fair shake if it had not locked me into toggle for run/walk/dash. It also deserves a negative review purely on the basis of labeling the button to save game settings as "save and quit". I spent a lot of frustrating time looking for a way to adjust the controls without saving and quitting before I realized that "save and quit" was some imbecile's way of saying of "save settings".

Everything else here is here to fill the page. This is a highly derivative game in a saturated class of games that I am sick to death of.

The idea is honestly fantastic. Youâ€™re in this alternate version of Paris where robot soldiers patrol the streets and the cityâ€™s in chaos. It sounds cool, right? It even looks cool at first. But it gets boring fast. I'm tired of the boring AF DS tropes/mechanica and lack of imagination in how the game works. Soulslikes need to come up with a way to feel different. This one doesn't. Not that many do. And (as usual with what seems like all soulslikes) also plays like crap on PC, and was clearly only really intended for the console audience. I have a PC interface. USE IT. I'm sick of tabbing through items and other assumptions of a controller-only setup. I'm just not interested in playing anything anymore (period) that doesn't take advantage of the fact that I have a proper set of PC input devices at my disposal.

The combat never feels quite right. Everything feels a bit floaty, like your attacks donâ€™t really connect. Enemies are mostly the same few types repeated over and over, and the boss fights just drag on forever. Thereâ€™s no real excitement to them, just a lot of health bars and awkward timing.

Exploring the city is kind of boring too. The areas look nice but they all blur together. It feels like youâ€™re being guided through narrow paths pretending to be open streets. You keep looping back on yourself for no good reason, and the rewards for exploring arenâ€™t worth it anyway. The world just feels empty. Pretty, but dead.

Performance isnâ€™t great either. The game stutters sometimes even on a good PC, and the animations are stiff. The story wants to be deep and meaningful but itâ€™s so flat that it never lands. Everyone talks like theyâ€™re reading lines off a script, and I stopped caring about the plot halfway through.

Itâ€™s a shame because there are moments that almost work. The designs of the machines and costumes are amazing, and the first time you see the city on fire is genuinely striking. But that makes it worse in a way, because you can see what the game could have been.

In the end, Steelrising feels like a beautiful idea that never made it out of the prototype stage. Itâ€™s not awful, but itâ€™s not fun either. It just kind of clanks along until you give up.

Steelrising is a [i] fine [/i] game. Like some weapons feel super jank, others feel alright. But after 5 hours, I just feel nothing. I've been running through levels that can't help but feel like one giant hall after another, even though it's all themed after the devastated streets of old Paris. I've been through like 3 or 4 levels and I can already feel the enemy reuse. I think my last straw was how the possibilities for sequence breaks are held back both unintentionally from your weak jump and intentionally from invisible walls when you can clearly get over a wall. I just can't bring myself to play more.

Steelrising sounds like such a great idea on paper. Imagine an alternate history version of the French Revolution where King Louis XVI actually manages to defeat the revolutionaires with an army of clockwork automatons. Even better, you yourself are a former dancer-automaton named Aegis, tasked by Queen Marie Antoinette to find your maker, EugÃ¨ne de Vucanson, and eventually fight your way through Paris to stop the King himself.

Itâ€™s an amazing premise, and having visited Paris a number of times I was excited to see how developers Spiders would bring this alternative history version to life. Unfortunately, a great concept cannot make up for unimaginative and repetitive level design, poorly-implemented combat, terrible optimisation, and a level of jank that is difficult to put up with.

Letâ€™s start with the good stuff. You do get to see a handful of the capitalâ€™s iconic locations, including Versailles, Notre Dame, La Louvre, Les Tuileries and, of course, The Bastille, even if once you actually get inside you discover they all share a very similar set of assets. I enjoyed the different historically-inspired clothing here as well, and those that enjoy a bit of fashion souls can find plenty of tricorne hats and frilly shirts to suit their fancy. There are only seven main bosses in the game, but they are all fairly different, with interesting move-sets that need to be learnt to beat them. Finally, the map to travel around Paris is a nice touch too, rendered as a piece of old parchment.

Unfortunately, thatâ€™s more or less where the good stuff ends. I disliked Aegisâ€™s move animation immensely. Sheâ€™s either walking far too slow, or running far too fast in a disjointed, weird-looking sprint. Jumping is finicky and imprecise, only slightly alleviated by some extra traversal moves you get later into the game. Combat is strangely unresponsive : I often got the impression my character would dodge a second or so after I pressed the button, and the hit-boxes are very strange, with both my weapon and the enemies passing through me without either of us getting hit. 

My weapon of choice, the trust halberd, has an almost laughable range, and you can thrust at enemies that are three or four meters away, with Aegis seemingly getting rubber-banded to their location. In another instance, I stun-locked a miniboss with a series of heavy attacked which meant he never touched me at all. 

There are your traditional soulslike stats and weapon upgrades, though nothing particularly innovative apart from an overheat system that never really bothered me. What did bother me was the succession of drab, uninspired Parisian streets that made up most of the game, occasionally replaced by repetitive gardens and hedge mazes, all with the same gates, benches, and statues. This isnâ€™t helped by the fact that a lot of the game inexplicably takes place at night. Itâ€™s such a shame because Paris itself is a wonderful place, and with a larger budget or a bit more imagination we could have had some vibrant, colourful locales similar to what the team developing Enotria The Last Song managed to pull off.

The story is intriguing enough, but gets a bit lost in its own convoluted lore, and despite including real historical figures like Robespierre, Necker, and Lafayette, is dolled out mostly during scenes where three of four NPC monologue at you until you are eventually sent off to complete another quest.

Lastly, I will touch briefly on the many bugs I encountered, three years after release, including several hard crashes, textures not loading in properly, or, perhaps the most annoying, a loss of focus after using a â€œvestalâ€ bonfire which meant everything suddenly looked way too blurry. 

I was really disappointed with Steelrising, as its concept was so promising and other games such as Lies of P have shown how fun it can be to take cultural elements from our own history and change them in new and exciting ways. Unfortunately, Spiders failed to do this one justice.

Alright, look here. Look, listen. This game is both good and bad. You can't expect a masterpiece or even a very memorable experience, but it is a fun experience. If that's enough for you, then get this game. I played this game almost every day with my brother back in 2020-2023 on the PS5. I have over 600 hours on this game over there. I bought Fallout First all those years, though one of those was because I forgot to cancel the auto-renewal. Still, I enjoyed playing this game and completing the battle pass every season. There's plenty of content in this game now after all the updates to keep you engaged for as long as I was.

Here's probably something more important for most people: why I stopped playing Fallout 76 for a while. I believe the only reason I was able to play this game every day without getting tired was because of Fallout First. Like Elder Scrolls Online, the subscription gives you an unlimited stash amount that is required for long term enjoyment. Even though I didn't craft so many things to the point I needed all that space, it just cuts out a significant amount of frustration. There's already too much micromanagement and menuing in this game that I hate. Adding more by requiring me to stop playing and drop all my junk items and ammo so I can sprint again is astronomically stupid. I already spent more on this game than any other game I've ever played by paying for Fallout First for 3 years. That's $300 + $40 (PC version a few weeks after launch) + $10 (Xbox version a year after launch) = $350. I never buy microtransactions or subscriptions for any games. I play 100s of hours of Call of Duty and progress the battle pass, all without paying a dime. I can ignore $50 skins and $20 battle passes that only give emblems and calling cards with a couple double XP tokens mixed in. I don't excuse any of that nonsense, but I can enjoy the game with it. This game is an exception for me, and all the money I've paid isn't enough for them (the developers / publishers). I truly can't enjoy this game without Fallout First. I love scavenging and collecting things in the open world. Dropping them all the time makes it feel like a waste, and there's not enough storage space for non payers. The more I talk about the game's bad business practices, the less I want to recommend it, so I'll stop here. Just know that I could go on. I could go on and on and on...

This game is pretty great and should be an easy recommendation to anyone who just wants to play something with their brain off while they watch a video or chat with their friends. It provides a casual experience where there's always something to do, but you can stop whenever you want. The biggest flaw that completely drives me away is that the game doesn't want me to play unless I'm always paying. Other games provide a playable experience for the base price of purchasing the game, but not this one. If you're anything like me, you'll have a hard time recommending this game without a massive caveat. Honestly, the only thing that got me into this game as much as I was was playing with my brother. I enjoyed so many experiences I had with this game in all the years it's been out, but I can't get that anymore without continuously paying. I'll pop back into this game occasionally to try new content, but it never holds me for long. It's just sad that it has to be this way. This game is capable of standing alongside the other live service juggernauts but holds itself back needlessly. 

I'm only writing this review because of the Steam Awards, but it really let me reflect on the kind of game this is. I have so much more I could say, I mean I probably have close to 1000 hours of playtime across Steam, PS5, and Xbox. I just don't think anyone will read this on a 7 year old game with over 40,000 reviews. I guess if what I said is interesting enough to others, I'll come back and write more, but I've already spent enough time writing what I have. I hope anyone reading this understands where I'm coming from with this review. I doubt I'll be changing anything in the games industry with this, but I just wanted to say what's on my mind. Games can be better. So much love, care, and passion is poured into these 100 million dollar projects that it's such a shame to take all that away for a quick extra buck. But I know nobody does anything for free, and money has to be made at some point. The truly talented people are able to place that barrier in appropriate spots. If I could take this game offline and play with mods, I would easily add 100s of more hours. As it is now, though, as it was designed... I'm just sad.

[h1][b]Neither here nor there:[/b] Golden Light[/h1]

While working through my games backlog, I like to pace myself by playing one fairly "normal" game and following that up with something weird as hell. [b]Golden Light[/b] falls firmly in the latter category; however, what started as a very intriguing premise would turn out to be a bit of a disappointment.

In Golden Light, our unnamed protagonist descends into the depths of the Gut searching for She, his lost lady love. Here, the Gut serves as both the environment and the antagonist, becoming angrier and more hostile the more enemies you kill. And if you find it all too much to bear, you can always appease it by hurting yourself or making offeringsâ€¦

From what I saw, the story in Golden Light closely follows the Silent Hill "formula" (or at least, what's been accepted as the Silent Hill Formula over the years): our protagonist is lost and trapped in a purgatory-like place, searching for a loved one. This fairly well-worn base is then topped with a generous smattering of meat and weirdness (with a sprinkle of Cronenberg and Lynch), giving Golden Light a unique and genuinely unsettling vibe.

Look, I'ma be real - I'm not a huge fan of games whose idea of horror is enemies barrelling down towards me, screaming bloody murder. And since this is basically Golden Light's main shtick, I think you'll understand why I dropped it so quickly.

If you're OK with constant, annoying jump scares, I think there's actually something to Golden Light. The meat aesthetic alone is unique enough to merit at least giving it a try, and for all I know, the story might go deeper than the surface-level stuff I saw would suggest.

I love experiencing indie games I do not know anything about like this one. The first few minutes was interesting to say the least, but I also found it "funny" and intrigued to continue. However, first floor completely threw me off the game, it was too much, and I also at some point got stuck inside a meat blob, which is not a fun experience. When closing the game, it refused to actually close, not even present in task manager, so had to do a reboot, which I have never experienced before. I think the developers are on track to creating something good and interesting, but this is not it.

Maybe I just didn't get it, but the gameplay systems seem archaic and obtuse. From my understanding all you do is crawl around and pick up random things? What am I doing? Why am I doing it? Unanswered questions that would be intriguing if the gameplay loop was entertaining. Unfortunately I don't want to crawl around and die to random monsters that I have no idea the mechanics of.

More than anything I just found the game frustrating. The hub world is oversized and confusing to navigate which you have to do most of the time you die in order to get back to the level you failed, the controls are clunky, RNG can screw you over with the procedural level generation, and at times enemies imitating objects will be basically impossible to see due to the low graphical fidelity including at times, enemies imitating pages which are supposed to be given away by being blank, but if they're in the wrong place/orientation they'll be completely black like they're unlit making it impossible to tell. 

There are cool mechanics here and the game has a very distinct style, but I just couldn't enjoy it. It's not that I don't enjoy a challenge, I enjoy hard games actually. Celeste, Darkest Dungeon, Hollow Knight, Dark Souls, you name it. This game was just frustrating.
It was free and I want my money back
Even if I got the game for free, I feel like I got robbed.

While I thought Golden Light was a first-person shooter, it's more apt to describe it as a first-person tactical espionage survival roguelite. Moment to moment gameplay here is mostly scouring the floor you're in, looking for keys which will give you access to the next floor, while avoiding traps and enemies (and combat), and collecting resources that can all be used in multiple ways. Got a consumable? You can either eat it or throw it at enemies to trigger status effects. Got a new weapon? You can either use it (with very poor control and damage in general), throw it (for status effects) or eat it (?) as well. Managing these resources while deciding when to engage in combat is the core to the game, and it took me almost four hours to really understand it, since it's a very obtuse game (and unashamedly so).

So, if you want a run and gun game, this is not it. This is a much more cerebral and cautious kind of game. Buyer beware.

Outside of the 'dungeon floors' you have a hub world that is as weird as the levels, and even after beating the game I'm still confused as to how to navigate it. There's certainly a proper way, an optimal path, but I have absolutely no idea what it is.

Now, I didn't love the gameplay, and hence is why I wouldn't recommend the game. But one thing that it gets absolutely right are the vibes. Visual design, sound design, enemies, environments, loading screens and transitions, everything is super well alligned to the vibe the game wants to convey, and there's something really satisfying to see gel together. Unfortunately I couldn't get over the gameplay jank so it's still a no-go for me, but if you know exactly what you're getting into this could be your game.

[h1]3/10[/h1] I don't know what this game is. I love games with unique or esoteric visuals. Games like Cruelty Squad and Brazilian Drug Dealer 3 have strange visuals and blast your eardrums with ungodly sounds, but they do so with purpose and an artistic vision which fits the world they've established. This game just seems random for the sake of it. It's obtuse in all the wrong ways. Maybe I'll return to it when I'm high on ketamine, but I don't understand the purpose, the story, the game-play, or if there's fun to be had. All I experienced was confusion, digust, and deep concern for myself and the fact that I own this "game".

I love the visuals for this game, it's actually so cool to look at and I can't say I've seen another game quite like this one. I love the gritty / pixelly look to it so much actually.

Other than that though, I wasn't really a fan of this game. I found myself enjoying. The prop aspect was alright but overall I kinda just felt bored walking through the levels and eating the random items while collecting keys.

I'll likely watch a video on the game as the lore does seem interesting, but gameplay wise it was not for me.

i am gate keeping

Seeing how this is: 
- the 2nd highest selling PS4 game of all time: 
  -- especially how late during the console's life-cycle it was released
- Spider-Man 2 is the highest selling PS5 game of all time
I thought I would have nothing to lose getting it. I bought it via a CD key and took the risk; which excludes it from Steam's refund policy. 

But this goes to show, that, both mass critic and user reviews, cannot be relied upon as it is mostly generated hype and cult followings, favouring style over substance.

This game unfortunately falls into the generic Ubisoft sandbox. The map is huge, but there is little ways to interact with the world. The people walking around are nothing but cardboard NPCs, and the buildings are just blocks for you to swing off. There are no interiors and few unique charms that make exploring the city worth while. A denser, more alive open world with more content would have done this world favours.

The physics and controls are pretty tight. Spiderman has a varied move-set and the combat is somewhat similar to Batman Arkham series, where you have to perform timed dodges, deal with enemies wielding melee or ranged weapons, shields etc which means you have to spin a different combo to deal with them and not mash the same buttons. That part works, what doesn't is the overall game-loop. 

- the graphics are not that great, older titles like MGS Phantom Pain look far more stunning
- there is no day and night cycle or changes to weather - they do change based on story script only, so if you are just exploring, the world feels static, not dynamic.
- the side-quests are just generic activities:
  -- wave fights: (personally I think this is one of the lowest forms of gameplay, to program it you just need a simple loop of enemy respawns and triggered conditions). The particular waves in this game get very tiresome, it isn't a matter of skill, but endurance.
-- crimes: a bit better than endless waves, short and sweet, but nothing special. Vehicle chases means swinging after a vehicle, then pressing some Quick Time Events to watch a few animations.
  -- collectibles: backpacks, pidgeons etc. simply means gathering them. There isn't a skill based challenge or a gadget themed puzzle requiring you to get them. Reaching the pointer on the map and grabbing them is enough
  -- Ubisoft towers (really dated legacy mechanic most people are tired off, interact with a tower, reveal portion of the map)
  -- photographs landmarks (there are a few unique buildings, you just pull out the camera and snap a photo)
- full of mundane progression minigames - if anyone remembers Bioshock's Pipe-Dream hacking minigame, well this is back, but in the form of electric circuits. I never liked minigames, I just want to play the game, but when you have to repeat the same minigame over and over it gets stale and repetitive very quickly. In contrast to Arkham, those games require you use your gadgets to interact with your environment, where as here you find detached minigames that don't at all link to Spiderman or any of his tools. 
  -- Luckily, accessibility options do allow you to skip them entirely, which I did gladly.
- Skill trees: in the 2010s era every exclusive sandbox had to have the 3 skill trees: tap A to do this faster; take less damage;  something affects 1 more enemy etc. - quantitative checkbox updates rather than quality updates that affect how you interact with the world.
- enemy AI is not dynamic and reactive like in Arkham, they won't start destroying perch points once they see you them. They will behave in the same manner throughout
- The MJ and Miles sections are scripted, linear stealth sections. You cannot change how its done or pick your own route, you go from point to point as you're told and cannot deviate from this line.
- I don't know why so many devs obsessed with cinema do this, but if you want to explain a narrative, just add a cutscene. Instead you will be stopped with many sections that require forced walking, you walk around a room, and press the action button to interact with an object, the character speaks some monologue about what you saw, then you have to repeat this several times until you have interacted with enough objects/the correct object. Again, I just want to play the real game, save these interaction sequences for cutscenes, don't force me to hold "up" for 5 minutes pressing "Y" to move the game forward.

The pluses are:
+ lots of different suits, gadgets and suit mods to modify your play style
+ controls and physics feel tight
+ web slinging feels tight and controlled
+ map is large
+ lots of Marvel characters make an appearance

Overall I really find it hard to understand how this outsold, especially so much later in the console's lifecycle, much more dynamic and innovative titles like Red Dead Redemption 2, Witcher 3 and MGS Phantom Pain. The game mostly borrows all of its mechanics from other titles, but doesn't contribute anything innovative of its own.

My recommendation is to buy this from Steam directly, that way if you don't like it and played under 2 hours, you can refund it - this will give you ample time to test it, as what you see in those 2 hours is what you will get throughout. Or try to see if you can play a demo version. 

If you find yourself that you are not tired of generic open world games like Assassin's Creed and many other Ubisoft titles, then you can probably sink into this. But if you strive for quality and innovation, try the demo before buying (or buy directly from Steam, and request a refund in under 2 hours). To me a lot of this is very last gen, if it came out in 2012 it would have been top tier, but even Arkham City outclasses this game and has a more unique variety of activities in its sandbox, despite having a much smaller world. And that being said, I also think that most Ubisoft sandboxes are actually a lot more fun than this game, even AC Odyssey whose map is far too large and has literal fetch quests offers more thrills.

Most polished game I've ever played. Traversal feels amazing, both mechanically and visually. Manhattan looks absolutely stunning. The combat is enjoyable too. 

Story is like typical Marvel hero fantasy with bad guys vs good hero, no morally gray complex decisions. Sometimes I didn't like that story progress is linear and the MJ parts are unskippable. The puzzles were boring, maybe bc of my CS background.

But the best thing this game accomplishes is truly making you feel like Spider-Man. And sadly, that just doesnâ€™t do much for me. Itâ€™s an awesome game, just not for people who find Spider-Man kind of meh.

I forced myself to finish this game for the money I spent. Simply put it, this is a boring game. Boring combat, mediocre story, repetitive contents and dumb puzzles were really a snooze-fest. The only highlight in this game which I think is thoughts-provoking or really shows the mindset of spider man was his choice between May's life and the public's life. Everything others are simply a drag.

The game is pretty repetitive, also a carbon copy of batman arkhman games. In the first two hours only difference from arkhman games is webs.

Swinging across the city is also clunky with spidey sometimes not moving how you would like him to move.

The constant changing of pace between the spiderman and peter parker are too fast and constant even in the first 2 hours and take away from the fun.
i should be able to run this game, I guess i need a steam deck instead

review_text:
I have played this game for some time, even from the early days, so there is my review. 

The graphics made a big step up. There are moments when I leave the mouse and I enjoy the atmosphere of the game.  

Also, the skill tree has been changed many times, so I can tell that it is more or less better, even though there are some improvements possible. 

New zombies are cool, and also.. they are more intelligent.. :D My previous tactics from early days are not so effective now. But I like that is a little bit more of a challenge. There are things like the water system, which could be richer and more realistic like before, but never mind. 

If you like building bases, exploring? Try it. These are reasons I am playing this game till this day, and yeah, the waves are so much fun too. :) And with friends you will have even more fun and hours played, trust me. :D

review_text:
Oddly super clunky combat despite it being the entire point. Zombies'll sometimes attack random bits of buildings while having clear paths to you. Hitboxes are jank as hell and you'll be hit from much further than you'd think of a melee range. 

Menus are designed weirdly, making them difficult to navigate. Descriptions of various things don't match the logic of the game, including controls explained in the tutorial. Stat numbers and denotations are more than often VERY unclear. Matches the overall writing of things like flavour text and monologues from the few NPCs you interact with.

Overall a huge mess of development choices despite how long it took to make the full release.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
[h3] 7 Days to Die: A Veteran's Disappointment [/h3]

	I've sunk over a thousand hours into 7 Days to Die over the years, a testament to how fantastic this game [b] used to be. [/b] The core concept of a voxel-based zombie survival crafting game is brilliant, and for a long time, it delivered some truly memorable experiences. The issue is that the game I fell in love with is not the game it is today, and the developers ("The Fun Pimps") seem intent on a cycle of endless, often regressive, change rather than refinement.

	My lack of recommendation comes down to one core problem: the developers constantly redesign fundamental systems from the ground up with almost every major update. Instead of building on existing mechanics, they scrap them entirely, forcing veteran players to re-learn a "new" game every single time. This isn't early access refinement; it's a lack of vision.

    â€¢ [b] Scrapped Mechanics: [/b] We've seen multiple iterations of progression systems, from the "learn by doing" model to the current perk and magazine-based system. Each change feels like a sideways step, often removing depth and features that the community enjoyed (like empty jars or specific meat types) for no apparent reason other than change for change's sake.

    â€¢ [b] Forced Playstyles: [/b] Recent updates have introduced systems like biome progression tied to loot stages, which can feel linear and removes the open-world freedom that was a hallmark of earlier alphas. Base designs and creative building approaches that players developed over time are often patched out, forcing specific, developer-approved play styles.

    â€¢ [b] An "Eternal Early Access": [/b] After more than a decade in Early Access, the game still feels unpolished in many areas, while basic, long-promised features like bandits or robust NPC systems remain missing (though competently implemented by the modding community). The recent 1.0/2.0 updates have only amplified these frustrations, adding poorly implemented features like the annoying storm system that just waste time.
	
     I got my money's worth, absolutely. But I cannot recommend 7 Days to Die in its current state, nor can I endorse the development philosophy. If you are looking for a stable, long-term survival experience that consistently builds on its foundations, this isn't it. The game is a revolving door of concepts, and you never know when the mechanics you enjoy will be completely removed in the next patch. The modding community truly keeps this game alive; without them, it would have died a long time ago.

Destiny 2 is like that Ex you keep going back to because the sex is good, but once the serotonin crash hits, you realize it wasnâ€™t worth getting the clap and a sore ass from being pegged in the middle of the night. Then the cycle repeats when she shows off her flashy new $100 dress every year.

However, this is still THE BEST GAME EVER!!! I even lost my house and job playing this game, because to me itâ€™s worth more than my college education. I used to grind for hours on end with nothing but an extension cord and my modded Chromebook. Right now, Iâ€™m even considering renewing my DLC subscription (3,642 hrs on Xbox) & (10,000 hrs on PC).

This game has ruined my life, and I couldnâ€™t be happier about it.
I'll never get these hours back unfortunately

Despite what people say, this game is amazing. I would say that this game is a shining example of what a next generation game should be, even if it is now... years old. This game has set a standard for gaming that not very many can come close to competing with. Anyway if you like sci-fi and first person, and don't mind paying for expensive add-ons, you will be addicted.

Destiny 2 has a variety of issues with its monetization, new player experience, and (as of this review) a bit of an identity crisis having to do with how it wants to present its new seasonal content. But the gunplay, abilities, and general world of Destiny is unmatched. As someone with thousands of hours on this game prior to playing it on PC, this game is incredible, but the developers have a habit of dropping the bag. If you can bear with the rough patches, you'll be rewarded with such a unique gameplay experience in an incredible world. If you've got the time, give it a whirl! But no one could fault you for passing on the experience, given its past issues.

It was great while it lasted- but if you're a new player: this game is a shadow of its former self. What used to be the highlight of my day turned into over bloated, poorly optimized, festering money pit. I don't regret my time: the Final Shape was a great way to end my career as a guardian. But after an embarrassing amount of hours and money- its just not worth it anymore. 

One of my favorite parts looking back would prob- ERROR CODE: WEASEL. VISIT help.bungie.net

This game straight up suffers from repetition. Most activities recycle the same encounters, which makes the experience feel routine instead of exciting. Thereâ€™s also no commitment to story as new expansions retire earlier missions and locations, which makes the world constantly feel like youâ€™ve missed out on something. 

Powerful gear either takes too long to earn or is always locked behind strict weekly limits that designed to slow progression. When you do earn these unlocks, balance changes make certain weapons or subclasses feel weaker just after you have invested time to master them.

The live service nature of Destiny 2 brings additional criticism. Communication from the developers is not always clear or timely. Delays, seasonal story pacing, and technical issues during major updates strain la playerâ€™s patience. The cost of expansions, seasons, cosmetic items, and additional features becomes overwhelming when combined.

I donâ€™t recommend this game unless youâ€™re into slop treadmills.
I miss how this game used to be, it was so much fun now its just horrid. It sucks but its just how the cookie crumbles.

The new player experience is the worst I've ever seen. I've tried to play this game at least 2 different times. I always tend to give up and get bored around the 4 hour mark of the tutorial missions. When you compare the tutorial mission a guardian rises from Destiny 1 and Destiny 2 there really is a night and day difference. One cutscene dumping a decade of Destiny lore in a minute is not really the play in terms of good story telling. It's unfortunately out of necessity since they "vaulted"/deleted half of the story rather than having the story unfold as the player experiences it.

Additionally the vaulting of content is the dumbest thing ever. It's 2025 and they haven't figured out how to add content without needing to subtract content. Meanwhile look at other free to play games like Warframe which continue to improve on the new player experience and add new content while keeping old content completely 100% playable. Every change is either an addition or something that genuinely was better for the game.

Destiny 1 was the better game and it's a shame we never got a PC port. Destiny 2 needs to improve the new player experience and return the vaulted content. If it did that it would be a genuinely good game. The gameplay is solid and the story has a lot of potential, but until those things are fixed this is not a good game and it is not worth giving this company your money or your time. I hope Bungie gets their act together but I'm not gonna hold my breath for that.
played since Fall 2014, Yuppies ruin entertainment, Star Wars cringe reddit :(
Bungie please give all the money I spent/spend on this game to the art team. They are the only reason I open this game every week.

After the sunsetting, Destiny went downhill. Most of us stuck around to see the end of the saga. With ups and downs, when they launched The Final Shape, we tought they would come back and be what the players wanted. We were very wrong.

Destiny used to be a unique game. "Planets" to visit, amazing campaign, well written villains and characters in general. With some teaks here and there, some QoL changes (like Lfg, loadouts and subclasses 3.0), legendary campaign for the old ones (Red War, CoO, Wm and Forsaken) and also, some changes of bosses mechanics would make Destiny a desirable game to play. Now it's just menus and cards (Portal), content we paid for is gone for good, new locations are not that interesting and not worth visiting. When Destiny was "not so good", even Mercury were packed with players. 

Now i feel that i don't even need locations to go and that's one of the reasons that made me quit Destiny. You could just chill in IO, Titan, Mercury or Mars. You could chase the meta or just play the game the way you want. We had fun, now Bungie is a generic company.

I felt robbed when they sunsetted the content we paid for but i stuck cuz the narrative was good and we still had some uniqueness to the game. Now we don't.

Maybe i will come back one day and edit this, saying that they gave us back what we paid for, but i highly doubt and that just makes me sad, because i really miss the "Journey" that Destiny used to be (yeah, the feeling of the game and the best music they made)

If somehow they come back with what we deserve, i will be the first to be around. Until then, i will just reminisce on the good times i had and how used to be fun to just be playing Destiny outside the menus.
In the game's current state (before Renegades), I cannot recommend it. Too much of a grind, and many activities have been rendered worthless to play.

This game was magnificent once, you know. Bungie should have walked away in 2020, while people were still applauding. But they insisted on milking it dry for profits and Pete Parsons very basic taste in classic cars.
I discovered Destiny in those years when Borderlands 2 had grown stale as yesterday's bread. And one boring day in school,  before me opened a pure greatness of game universe, that is a cathedral of a game design. A space western without tacky laser cowboys. Futuristic industrial design â€“ sublime, functional, memorable â€“ fused with magic that felt real and harked back to magic lore and mythology of our real world.
The first cracks on facade and mold in the basement appeared in Season 8. Patchnotes. "Shake up the meta," they proclaimed, as if a hurricane in a china shop constitutes strategy. Massive damage nerfs to weapons and unique traits of armor.
Sunsetting... that was the moment when the roof caved in and walls began to bulge. They took our weapons â€“ not just items, you see, but time made tangible. Hours of our lives, god rolls we treasured like family heirlooms... all discarded with a corporate smile about "player experience."
And then â€“ slow rot. Content became faceless. Witch Queen briefly lit the old light in the windows, Final Shape reminded us what this building could have been... but the foundation was eaten through. No weapon felt meaningful. No activity â€“ irreplaceable. Class building? A lick of a fresh paint on a bumpy hardwood floor and a new layer of a plaster on a bulged walls, that was carried out for too long, and amounted in too little result.
In 2018-2020 they gave us a cathedral. Magnificent. Singular. Then they buried that potential under layers of corporate incompetence and the paranoid fear of giving players too much.
Thank you for the memories, Bungie. Shame I am witness to decay of one of your greatest creations.

review_text:
I have thousands of hours in this game and like many before me, and many after me, you come to realize that the Dark Patterns being used in this game is the driving force that causes many people to log into this game. The other content is intentionally made painfully difficult to get involved with, and all events are set up to ensure that you never get close to end game content. This is to make you spend money in game, allowing the dark patterns to take hold of you. If you are unsure of what dark patterns are, you can refer to Chris Wilson recent video. He was a CEO of path of exile that is opening the gaming communities eye to the tactics being employed by these predatory companies. 

This is no on AGS specifically, as the core component of the design if by smilegate, I could not recommend this game, and actively encourage people not to play. Maybe one day, in the future, enough people will quit to make this game a good game to play, as the raid conent is peak. Unfortunately.. so is the their free to play structure, and not in a good way.

game's story is good, combat and raids are amazing(which is why i played for as long as i did) but new player onboarding experience is non existent. you either need to have friends already playing the game at the high item levels or grind infinite(playing multiple rosters from multiple steam accounts and funneling resources to your main roster and bussing) or pay up infinite. if you don't have or can't do any of those 3 don't even bother installing if you're looking forward to the end game content, its legit unplayable.

you can squeze out couple hundred hours from the main story quests and solo raids though if you're just curious about the story and the gameplay. if you also snipe one of the new character express events you might even be able to do a raid or two but if you're looking for a forever game as many mmo players do, look elsewhere

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
Enjoyable, but even your enjoyment has a daily cap.

The game is also full of quest bloat, which quickly becomes very tedious. The game would improve drastically if it wasn't full to the brim with "I need you to deliver a pointless message to the person I'm standing right next to" tasks.

The biggest grind of all is the walled content. The game lacks so many fundamentals that make an MMO great, such as sub-stat grinding and general farming. We all play them for the grind, the grind is a necessary characteristic of an MMO, but everything from farming to raiding is limited to a laughable daily/weekly limit which can only be alleviated by climbing over the paywall in one form or another. Even the bare basics, such as mining, logging, fishing, etc. is placed behind a cap... in an MMO. That's like playing Among Us, and the game says "I'm sorry, you've completed too many tasks. Head to the store if you wish to continue." There is no grind, only hinderance.

I'll continue to play for as much as I can tolerate it, as playing in a group has taken a fair chunk of the stale away, but this game has some heavy lifting to do before I'd consider giving it a thumbs up.

I don't know where these positive reviews are coming from, must be people that completely ignore the games performance and are only factoring gameplay mechanics, lore, and world-building.. all of which are incredible. This WOULD be the greatest turn-based rpg I have EVER played.

WOULD. The truth though, is that this game stutters so badly and so frequently it is practically unplayable in Acts 2 and 3. Your game is going to be a little bit choppy in Act 1, worse in populated areas; you'll forgive it, because you're enjoying the story and game so much. Then Act 2 will come, and it will get worse. Cutscenes are now a choppy mess, character dialogue is constantly glitching out, so you're constantly pulled out of immersion. But you're invested at this point, so you sludge through the glitchiness to Act 3.

Then when your refund-window is LONG expired, and you're coming out of Act 2 finally on your way to Baldurs gate, and the truly performance-intensive areas are finally here... oh boy, it is bad. Non-stop stuttering, there is not one spoken word that isn't choppy, and the game truly becomes unplayable. I cannot believe a GOTY game performs like this. 

I WANT to finish it, I WANT to recommend it- but I can't. It's straight up broken, and the devs aren't doing anything.

It's(probably) not a bad game, but it has a number of problems(which will probably never be addressed)

The perforance is.. sad, the game struggles even on an RTX 3060 around medium settings at 1080p.

The file size is so overly bloated, it's rediclous.

Sometimes the world will take forever to properly load in(as in you can sometimes walk right out of the game world, or into an otherwise unnavagatable spot(like inside a boulder)).

Has terrible camera controls for vertical spaces.

Almost all the team mates are entirely unlikeable(I realise this is probably just a me thing).

Compared to other D&D games the character building is, just sad, it's been gutted so badly.

Level cap of 12, tells me it's unfinished.

A lot of spells and abilities even in those 12 levels worth are just missing.

One adult scene in particular(that you do have to go well out of your way for, and get plenty of warning, along with multiple chances to back out) isn't even legal in the US(thankfully I don't live there, but still worth mentioning)

Has a good number of missable quests,(as an example:  oh, you needed a rest, well too bad, this quest in a zone you haven't even gotten to yet failed, the child is dead, with nothing you can do about it other then start the whole game over) 

Mod implimentation is... bad... they should have just done the normal thing instead of, well, what they went with, Nexus may not be the most friendly of places, but it works properly far more often.

As I started with, it's probably not a bad game, but it's not a worthy sequal to Baulder's Gate II, the shift to turn based was a great idea, but the rest of it feels half baked in comparison.  I may get around to actually playing through what they bothered to make here someday, but for now, the file space is more valuable elsewhere used for programs that run at a decent rate.  Wish I could review it positively, but after playing Neverwinter Nights, along with the first two Baulder's Gate games, this just doesn't stand up, it actually fails quite spectacularly, obviously spent far too much of the budget on making it pretty, rather then making a good game.

Okay well, if you are going into this game new (impossible) don't. You have missed the hype and most likely have already seen all of the spoilers. Either way, this game is better to watch anyway since the devs haven't updated the game since 2023 and that update was for the addition of MacOS players being able to play the game. I have a small feeling that the devs have abandoned this game which is sad since there are certain achievements that are now impossible to get due to certain areas having bugs where you simply either get soft-locked trying to enter them or can't enter them without somehow debugging if that is even possible (I'll get into those bugs later in this review). 

My personal opinion of this game is that it is amazing, it still seems to have an active community, it is cute as all hell and even funny at some parts, and the puzzles and story and interactions with the individual robots is just awesome. I love cats too :3

Anyway now, about the bugs: There is this weird bug in the game that affects three achievements. Those achievements being (from what I believe): Territory, Badges, and I Remember. The bug is where you just get stuck on certain parts of big pipes that you either walk on or through. I've had it to where it completely traps the character you play as forcing me to reload my save and I've had it to where it just blocks the character you play from progressing entirely.

In the end, do NOT get this game now. If they update it and the bug fixes, I'll update this review (hopefully). But with the current state of this game and how long it has been since it was released, do NOT waste your time or money on it.

This either was planned to have a sequel or the story is just very anticlimactic.

If we knew if it will 100% have a sequel then I could maybe recommend this, but without that I feel like it was just wasted 4.5 hours and money, that could've spent on anything else rather.

Let's preface this simply by saying, I enjoyed my first 50 hours with this game. Interesting character dynamics, fun varied combat, challenging but satisfying combat, all around I enjoyed nearly all of that 50 hours; But you wanna know why I have an extra 30 hours? 

Achievement hunting, specifically ONE Achievement. Now, I'll be the bigger man and won't spoil what it was, but I'll explain a bit about this game's rouge-like element. Each of the games zones are made out of rooms. Combat, challenges, survive etc. There's a particular type of room called Encounter Rooms. They often give great benefits. Issue is, they're also bloody rare. You can go 10-20 runs without seeing one. To get 3 achievements, you need to find each of the 3 zones encounter rooms and that's not all. Some of these achievements can only be done AFTER finishing the prior one so if you low-ball cant get a certain encounter in a previous zone, you're SOOL for a while. 

Worse part is, you can customize the difficulty of your runs, you can make Zagreus stronger or weaker as you see fit, but all that pales to the sheer fact you cant control Encounter Rooms. It's literal RNG baked into the game. So you really can't cheese this outside letting the mobs kill you after wasting 15 minutes into a run.

Overall, Great game but the encounter rooms made it overstay its welcome. Won't immediately try out Hades 2 now its fully released But I hope they did fix this of all things.

Man, people love this game. And I feel like an idiot posting a negative review, but I just can't get into it.

I am a HUGE fan of Transistor, but I just could not get this game to be fun for me. I found the rogue-like mechanics to be just a little too punishing, the RNG a little too random, progression just a little too difficult, and I never really found something that made it "click" for me. I'm not normally a twitchy-platformer type gamer, so I had hesitations going in, but I made it through Basition and SO many people love this game and Transistor was SO good I decided to give it a try.

It turned out my instincts were right. If you're not into twitchy rouge-like games that - while "fair" - are still punishingly hard, you probably won't like this one, either.

If you DON'T like roguelikes, you will likely enjoy it (based on other reviews).
If you have experience in roguelikes, you will probably NOT enjoy it. Don't buy it just because of the hype (it's a mystery).

Hades really puts the LITE in roguelite.

The art is great. It's the best part for me.

The story is... I don't know, I didn't finish it. Lore is given in tiny bits of dialogue after each run. While it's nice to have a lot of voiced lines, it's just too much filler. From what I've seen, there's not much intrigue either.

Gameplay gets boring after several hours. There are fixed room layouts with the same enemies, very little gameplay variation. The most you can do is try different builds, but they all function mostly the same (basic button mashing).
After completing one almost-full run, I just couldn't force myself to do it again. And from what I've heard, you have to do 10+ complete runs just to get the full story.

P.S. Rant:
Honestly, I'm sick of everyone talking about roguelikes. It's my favourite game genre and Hades is kinda giving it a bad name.
"If you don't like it, it's because roguelikes aren't for you." "It's grindy, but roguelikes are supposed to be grindy."
No, guys, roguelikes (or lites) are NOT SUPPOSED to be grindy or boring! That's the whole point of being replayable! I have hundreds of hours in other roguelikes, but Hades isn't it.

So it's a good game. Probably. 
The artstyle is great. Definitely.
I heard that it is a roguelike even for people who hate roguelikes. And that was a lie.
I don't like boss runbacks, ok? This is like one huge 45 min runback. 

I could list everything I don't like about this game. But it would be just a list of roguelite tropes. 
But every time you unlock one line of dialogue or something like that.

So it is a good roguelite for people who like roguelites.

I went blind coming back from other Supergiant Games and this one took me by surprise.

It is a roguelite, so by nature it is grindy. Although in theory you can beat it at the first try, most players will play dozens of runs before beating the final boss and they will repeat even more for true endings, and unlockables.

However, Hades differences between runs feel  fairly minor. Updates are boring,  most of them are small improvements in health or damage,  poison vs critical damage, etc. Enemies feel to have too much life and need  plenty of button mashing. And unlock new things takes too many runs.

If you do not mind repetition and grind, this might be for your. Otherwise avoid.

As someone who adored this game and played the shit out of it on both console and PC from pre launch to survivors of the void, I cannot in any ways recommend you purchase it as the IP itself now belongs to some of the most scummy corporations in gaming, and that was clearly illustrated in how they destroyed the far more stable PC version of the game, and superimposed their buggy, FPS locked console port retroactively onto it.

But! you may be thinking, didn't they patch it? Surely it's all fixed now right, why the hate?

To which I direct you to take-two's EULA for not just this game, but everything they have a hand in. Even in absentia of the horrific anti-consumer practices that gearbox themselves are guilty of going back as far as them embezzling funding from SEGA to use on their own projects, if you look at the EULA that Take-Two is now making mandatory on virtually all of their games you will find that they have declared for themselves the rights to access and collect the following information:

-Your name
-Your Email
-Your phone number
-Your photo
-Your mailing address/zip code
-payment or purchase info
-age
-gender
-password
-platform ID
-Software products played
-Survey data
-geolocation
-and the systems or platforms you play their product on/through.

Furthermore, they also "share" (read:sell), your information with the following:

-Vendors that perform services and support for them
-Take-Two group members
-Advertisers and third party advertising partners
-Other third parties

I realize that I'm going to most assuredly get flamed for daring to mention these things, likely by a bunch of addict lobotomites who are perfectly willing to sell their privacy, and any dignity or self-respect under the auspices that no one will actually come to collect on them personally, but as someone who purchased this game and played it for ages long before the IP was unceremoniously sold off and gutted by a company I despise due to their long history of abusing their customers, I cannot overstate how much I despise this entire series of events.

And yes, the truth is we're all trapped in this awful market environment, run roughshod over by corporate interests and information brokering thieves, but to have it so blatantly done to a game I loved, and considered one of the best in the genre? To see it literally become unplayable in a proper state for a year before they actually fixed things, and have everything unique and fun about it be dragged out and abused for all it's worth by unscrupulous corporate asshairs who couldn't give a shit less about something that was until that point, crowd funded and beloved by its community? It's like purchasing a car and then a decade later the company changes hands and they break into your house and reengineer every part of your vehicle to function worse so they can sell you back the parts they just stole from you. We aren't renters, we are owners of these things, at least we damn well should be for the amount of money we pay for these products. Enough is enough.

I cannot, and will not support this, and I say if you have any respect for yourself or what this game was before they infested it, cut them off. Let something new take its place someday, and God willing let that indie dev not decide to sell out their baby to the devil.

Dead Cells â€” Fast-Paced Roguelike Action at Its Finest

Dead Cells is a masterclass in tight, fluid combat and procedural design. From the very first run, the game hooks you with its fast-paced movement, responsive controls, and endless surprises around every corner. Every level feels alive, challenging, and meticulously crafted, keeping you on your toes while rewarding skill and experimentation.

Combat is both satisfying and strategic. Whether youâ€™re slashing with swords, raining arrows from a distance, or experimenting with magical abilities, every encounter demands quick thinking and adaptability. The variety of weapons, abilities, and power-ups ensures no two runs feel the same, making every death feel like a learning experience rather than a setback.

The procedural levels are beautifully designed, blending consistency with unpredictability. Youâ€™ll explore sprawling castles, perilous biomes, and hidden areas, all teeming with enemies, secrets, and loot. Each run is a fresh challenge, keeping the game endlessly replayable.

Progression is rewarding and fair. Unlocking new weapons, mutations, and abilities encourages experimentation and creates a sense of growth across multiple runs. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenge and satisfaction, making every victory feel earned.

Visually, Dead Cells is stunning. Pixel art meets fluid animation in a style thatâ€™s both retro and modern. Coupled with an energetic soundtrack, the gameâ€™s atmosphere feels tense, vibrant, and utterly alive.

Final Verdict:
Dead Cells is a thrilling roguelike that combines fluid combat, clever design, and endless replayability. Challenging, rewarding, and endlessly fun, itâ€™s a must-play for anyone who loves action-packed platformers and roguelikes.

â€œFast, fluid, and endlessly rewarding â€” Dead Cells proves that roguelikes can be both challenging and exhilarating.â€

Overall Rating: â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­ 10/10

The most overrated roguelite of all time and it's not even close. I'm not sure what it is, I don't understand why, but I feel like this game gets tons of praise that I just don't get. I won't deny visually the game is definitely pretty to look at, but it doesn't really stand out much to me. Not much in this game stands out to me. Tons of cosmetics, tons of weapons, tons of utilities, tons of unlocks, tons of additional things you can get too like bombs or traps; it almost feels, dare I say, bloated. To me personally. But I wonder, why do I love having a ton of unlocks in games like Tboi or Ror2, but with this game I don't care for some reason? I think there may just be something in the core of this game that I don't like.

Some things I just straight up don't like: Level progression. This game's progression across levels feels so, so painfully muddled, and nonlinear. This could be something that very well might be fixed after playing the game for long enough, but dude, it's been 29, almost 30 hours of playtime as of right now. Why do I still not understand how I'm getting to like 70% of the levels I'm in. You start at level 1, then there's the two different level 2's, and then around each of those there's like 5 more levels that, I'm gonna be real, I can't even tell if they're actual main levels or just alternate areas. What the fuck is happening. I've probably been to like 10 different areas in the game so far. If you put a million dollars on the line, and put me in 7 of those areas and asked me "Where are you in the game right now?", I still could not give you a straight answer. It's just very needlessly over complicated.

I never cared too much for the combat either. I try to block enemies, but parry timing doesn't feel right that often. This could very well be a me thing but combat just feels very clunky, ESPECIALLY in the later levels when there's more enemies that have more complex and unpredictable attacks that are additionally sometimes stacked on top of each other. It's not the type of thing where enemies take turns either, shit will just attack you and that makes parrying so much harder. On top of this at the end of each level you have one mutation to pick, from a list of like 50+. It's just numbers. It's just a bunch of numbers, more damage when you do this, blocking does this, this ranged stuff is a little better, nothing stands out. It just all feels so lame and not unique or impactful enough at all. That's how a lot of stuff in this game feels for me, just a lot of Quantity > Quality, honestly.

If it sounds like I'm hating just to hate, I definitely get that don't get me wrong, but believe me, I'm not. I am STILL, from time and time again, coming back to this game and playing it for a bit, just to see if something sticks. As of right now though nothing has really grabbed my attention too much from this game. Nothing specific from it has made me truly yearn to come back to it, like a really cool weapon or gimmick or something. I'm just trying to find SOMETHING here, okay? I'm really trying, I promise. I see this game get a lot of positive reception, I want to understand it. This game's probably a better metroidvania than a roguelite honestly, and if that's your jam then that's awesome, dude. I may just not be that big of a fan of metroidvanias. As a big roguelite guy I wouldn't personally recommend it but that's just from my own personal taste.

Game is fun but small bugs and glitches ruin it.  

 - Ledge grabbing is hit or miss, creating annoying scenarios where you need to time movements or you will either repeatedly grab an ledge or keep missing

  

 - Drop down through floors needs changed to different buttons as the keys to drop (hold down + jump button) don't work well, together.  I will hold down and try to drop through the floor but instead I jump.  I try again and jump.  It takes a second to recognize the input but in a game where a split second can decide if you live or die should not rely on whether the game can read the input fast enough.  Not too mention levels with spikes just above your head and the game doesn't read you're holding down will make you jump into spikes.

- if too many enemy's are being hit by your attacks, a few may be ignored and freely attack you

- Weapon drop RNG needs refreshed as I'm getting drops for weapons I never use or don't work for upcoming levels.  Some effects rely on the environment but when only one level meets that criteria for the weapon, there's no point in using it.  Some are too slow to use and will never get any use.  Shields are completely useless and should be removed from the game.

Game wasnÂ´t catching me.
Maybe a bit overhyped. 
_________________

Main issue: 
even with lot of stuff to unlock the runs donÂ´t feel like you are making progress at all or you make a real impact. 

You have like 3 classes which make different items /skills better - but there is less difference.
I mean cÂ´mon, who cares if your turret shoots flames, canonballs or arrows. 
Same to e.g. swords, daggers - they just have like 3 attack patterns while hitting the smash button. 
You can hook, you can kick - thatÂ´s almost the highlights here. 

DonÂ´t get me wrong: You CAN parry with a shield. There is variety (ice bow, explosions,...). But you carry (mostly) 2 weapons, 2 skills. And you will exchange them, due to "level" of items. Use & exchange w/ new one.
IÂ´d have liked a "upgrade your character" thing, to really create a lasting build. 

You have 3 "passive options" to choose per run. To really make a difference this restriction is pain. 
Compare binding of isaac - you got tons of passive items, which also stack. Not here.
So donÂ´t expect really awesome combos...

Bosses will get repetitive. Yes they get stronger and have different move sets while you make progress - they still feel the same. 
Maybe this is also because of the plain story... There is also no real benefit they provide for the run while defeating them. 

There is lot to like: in my case especially the art style, humor and references to other games.
But I was expecting something different.

I loved the previous Metro games and played both almost endlessly, but I don't think I can recommend this game for the people that really enjoyed the other games. I LOVE the story and atmosphere of this game, and the visuals and crafting mechanics are a good addition but holy crap can this be a slog when it comes to getting all the moral points if you want to be a "good" person at the end of each level, or if you like exploring everything in general. Don't get me wrong I enjoy exploring and the combat is also very fun, but running around a map maybe TEN TIMES the size of the biggest level in Last Light while having the stamina of a newborn baby gets very annoying very quickly. Sure you get a car sometimes but having to get in and out of the car after the 50th time when scavenging or exploring gets super annoying, even though its only a few seconds of an animation. If I was able to run for way longer without running out of stamina every 10 seconds or if I overall moved a bit faster I feel like it would fix this issue, but as of now I'm really not enjoying the exploration like I did in the previous titles.

I like this game (I've beaten it on xbox as well) but there are some technical issues and hard crashes. Bugs that have existed since the game came out but have been ignored. Obviously it can be frustrating and seriously hinder the experience. Besides that though, there is a lot to like. Decent characters, decent story, better gameplay than previous titles, naturally. Easily the worst thing about all metro games is its "choice" system that is extremely vague and not thought out at all. It is extremely brain dead "morality" and there is no gameplay or characters moments that explain this BEFORE things that affect the outcome of a level happen. It's extremely frustrating and there is only a quick save option so you have to figure it out before your save is overridden if you want to go back. There is just some many annoying things about this game that really shouldn't be happening this late in the "game" for Metro. Biggest issue with the story is Artyom still not talking in game and it's just silly, he really needed to find his voice in this title because it seriously hinders the story. I really want to like this game more- this game should have been a minimum of an 8/10. With all its issues however I can only say its a 6/10- damn shame. Only buy on sale.

Lethal Company â€” Corporate Horror Meets Co-Op Chaos

Lethal Company throws players into a darkly comedic sci-fi world where you and your crew of unfortunate contractors are sent to abandoned industrial moons to salvage scrap for a ruthless megacorporation. What starts as a simple job quickly spirals into a tense, unpredictable experience as every mission risks becoming your last.

The game shines in its cooperative gameplay and emergent chaos. Working together to explore derelict facilities, avoid traps, and carry loot back to the ship creates constant tensionâ€”especially when creatures begin stalking the halls. Communication, quick thinking, and teamwork determine whether you escape alive or become yet another â€œunfortunate lossâ€ on the company ledger.

The progression loop is simple but addictive. Collect scrap, sell it, buy better gear, and take on more dangerous environments. Each moon offers unique layouts, hazards, and threats, making every run feel fresh. The randomness of enemy encounters and environmental quirks adds to the thrill and unpredictability.

Atmosphere is one of the gameâ€™s biggest strengths. The dim lighting, eerie soundscapes, and unsettling creature designs create an environment thatâ€™s equal parts scary and hilariousâ€”especially when panic sets in and everything falls apart. The blend of horror and humor gives the game a unique charm that keeps players coming back.

Final Verdict:
Lethal Company delivers a perfect mix of tension, teamwork, and unpredictable fun. Whether you're playing seriously or embracing the chaos, itâ€™s an endlessly entertaining co-op experience filled with memorable moments and dark humor.

â€œTerrifying, chaotic, and ridiculously funâ€”clock in, survive, and hope the Company approves.â€

As a massive fan of the original game, I do not like the sequel. It feels like less of a co-op game and more of a "everyone split up and do their own thing" kind of game because the game is designed in ways that punish you for wanting to stay together with your teammates so it just feels heavily discouraged. Enemy spawns struggle to split between 4 players in different parts of the map so it results in the hardest difficulty feeling hilariously easy at times when one or more people barely get any spawns and just freely do objectives, but if you stay together you all get all the enemies spawns pretty much all the time which just ends up wasting so much time.

Helldivers 1 was built, designed, and balanced a lot around co-op centric things, your team had far more reason to have different roles and loadouts instead of making a strong versatile build that can do everything independently, team reload mechanic was a much stronger and encouraged mechanic, and the team was not allowed to be separated.

A lot of strategems and weapons also just feel worse than the HD1 counterparts in terms of damage, ammo economy, and general effectiveness. The standard Breaker shotgun and the Kinetic Shield are some of the worst offenders to me.

HD2 also lacks some crucial teamwork focused strategems that people like me desperately want back, such as the Rep-80 heal beam gun, or the Angel Guard dog medical backpack. The stim pistol was not a fun addition to the game as trying to hit people with that is insufferable, I don't care if people say it's skill issue, it is not fun, and not like it's very effective anyway cause players tend to die faster than it can heal anyway.

Player survivability in HD2 also just does not feel as fair or as fun as HD1 too. The incap system was completely removed so you just outright die (Gives another less incentive to use SMG's compared to HD1, hell you can't even carry artillery shells with one hand and shoot a one handed weapon at the same time anymore either), and weak enemies can even kill you in just a mere few hits sometimes. The games survivability relying so much on stims is not particularly a design choice I like either. I wish they kept the incap system and players being a bit tankier, and you had very very slow health regen instead if you arn't taking damage. (Stims should of been something in the grenade slot instead to replace grenades in my opinion.)

I don't like how armor went from a cosmetic only thing in HD1 so you could wear what you want and select the perk you wanted separately, to now armor passives have to be handcuffed to armors that I don't want to wear while the ones I want to wear have awful passives or ones I really don't want to use cause it won't complement my build. Which is rather annoying.

Performance and game stability is also not particularly great either. This game used to run well on my system early on but after a bunch of updates it feels like it really struggles to be stable, I know they started trying to address this though it's still not anywhere near how well the game used to run yet. (I acknowledge more major engine tech stuff may take time, but felt I'd mention this.)

I donno, maybe it's a hot take, but I do not like this game because it took away the biggest thing I praised the original for and that's feeling like a true co-op designed experience first and foremost, where lone wolf gameplay was actively discouraged. I don't like some of the other design decisions/changes too. I'd only recommend this game if you are okay with it being nothing like the original game, the game itself isn't terrible, but as an original fan it feels too alienating for me, like it was catoring to a completely different audience for the sake of being mainstream. 

There's a lot more I'm probably forgetting off the top of my head right now, so I'll end it with this. TLDR: I wish this game just tried to be more like HD1 in almost all aspects but with the third person perspective change and with more content/features, not drastically change or redesign things that worked just fine before.

I enjoyed the idea of a game where all players are working together instead of against one another, where all efforts are for the whole team rather than yourself. Playing with my friends was a blast as we tried many different combinations and weapons to tackle bugs, bots, and otherwise. While the game was fun in the beginning, the game now feels like a slog or chore. The personal secondary objectives to get medals used to be "Use X gun for Y kills" or "Use an airstrike or sentry gun for Y kills." Now it's always "Collect samples" or "Evac 3 times from a faction-specific map." The major orders follow suit with them just being "Hold planet Z because why not?"

The samples I've collected have been in my inventory for over a year now; having upgraded my personal ship to the maximum, I don't think there will be any personal ship upgrades in the future or at all. 

The enemies are slanted towards the bugs last time I played, with them having numerous updates/upgrades from invisibility to flying acid dragons and fog-spewing chargers, while the bots do have different types of the flamethrower variety. It would be pretty cool if they had ships dispersing fog or invisible patrols or had fighting styles like the Illuminate.

The game is fun if you have a dedicated group of friends, but the way it is now, I don't see the point in playing it if every update is just a new coat of paint on the same thing.

I personally love helldivers 2, however i cannot at this time recommend anyone on steam buy this game because of what ive heard about fried cpu and motherboards. idk if theyre trying to fix this or not but for the meantime i have uninstalled because i cant even load in without the game crashing, freezing, or stuttering. i really hope the devs can fix these issues in the near future because this game is truly one of a kind.

I come to believe that this game is coded by AI. There is no reason that after having a long stable engine in the past, adding armors, guns, enemies and expanding on existing mechanics should be causing this game to blue screen my computer REGULARLY. It is impossible on on all levels to play this game longer than an hour before it will crash, and when it crashes, it will bluescreen my PC.

I 100% believe the devs have begun to us AI for their coding as the memory leaks and CPU usage have gotten so out of hand for what the game is.

Do not recommend until they create a functioning game that does actively cause harm to my hardware.
Games went too far from what it originally was supposed to be, and it runs like ass.

After yet another paywall blocking 3 stratagems and a weapon I've had enough, ever since they got away with locking key features behind a battlepass they've just been putting more and more behind that wall. "Oh you can just grind supercredits and unlock them for free" bro you get anywhere between 0 and 30 super creds per mission you do solely to farm them. That's at MINIMUM 34 missions per BP where you do nothing but farm supercreds. 

Ignoring any random lucky 100 drops (which might happen rarely) and assuming you get the full drop of 30 every single run doing a trivial mission of speedrunning by quitting the mission once you get what you need which takes about 6 minutes. It's going to take you 204 minutes to get a BP "for free". Mind you that this isn't playing the game, it's dropping in, searching the map, leaving. no samples, no exp, no requisition. 

You tell me if this is how a PAID game should monetize gameplay as well as cosmetics. Just because they pushed back against big bad sony so a psn isn't required doesn't mean they should get away with this kind of invasive monetisation.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
After a decade, this game still fails to really be the social game hub that it promises.
The scope of the game has stretched it so thin, and despite some amazing work from the art team, including the sweet OST by Donglekumquat, it wastes so much of its effort on creating games that are destined to go unplayed, or forever be half-baked.

For a social game, Tower Unite is really bad at incentivising being social, and that is no more apparent than in the highly popular casino, where about half the lobby will be pressing their space bar for hours on end at the slots, while the adjacent poker hall, a game perfect for social interactions with strangers, sits empty. The Arcade is full of minigames, yet only a handful of the 20+ are even multiplayer, and the ones that really payout are once again just mindnumbingly pressing the space bar for hours on end. 
The game's poor balancing of rewards can encourage players to be antisocial.

Tower Unite is capable of putting out genuinely great games, I would still hold its Minigolf as one of the best out there, and you can easily lose yourself in its condo system for hours with how much possibility it has, but so much of its development has gone towards things that are pointless, games that are buggy, unbalanced, or simply lack the demand. 

A social game doesn't demand a weak quake imitator requiring years of development when most of its other features are still incomplete. 
Something as simple as checkers can bring strangers to socialise, and Tower Unite really needed more things like that, simple ways for strangers to be brought together, and I think in its tunnel vision to check off Kickstarter promises they forgot that that was the most important part of the game's concept.
