My reviews for: 
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/47810?snr=1_5_9__402]Dragon Age Origins (DA1)[/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1238040?snr=1_5_9__402]Dragon Age 2 (DA2)[/url]

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The game world can be quite spectacular to behold. Inquisition takes the foundation of DA1 and DA2 and expands it immensely. The locations you visit are varied, from ancient Elven forests to sandy deserts to stormy coasts, the locations are different enough to where the biomes donâ€™t get repetitive and even have some throwbacks to DA1. Furthermore, the exploration and interaction are good. Each area has tons of collectables and lore entries that teach the player about the area and where it fits into the history of Thedas. 
Perhaps the big negative thing to point out here is quantity over quality. I would have preferred if there were actually [i]less[/i] zones with a greater emphasis on each zone being deeper and more meaningfully designed. Because while they are beautiful to behold and can be fun to explore, fatigue is very real and remembering the nuances of each area can be more difficult than it should be. 

The narrative is okay. Itâ€™s a typical â€œBig bad trying to destroy the worldâ€ type thing, but I think the setting and characters elevate the narrative to greater heights. 
As for the DLCs, Jaws of Hakkon is forgettable, The Decent is better, and Trespasser is probably the best bit of story content in the game, shame the best parts only last ~20 minutes. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The mechanics are decent, but I feel that largely it is a step back in depth from DA1 and more inline with the gradual streamlining of DA2. The prior games had a unique take on Dungeons & Dragons, while DA:I feels much more shallow. Itâ€™s kind of like going from something like Final Fantasy X to FF XV - yes, it's prettier and faster and cooler, but the RPG mechanics suffer. Gone are any sort of stat-based conversation options, the character progression is simplified, and even abilities can feel very boring and shallow. The game does open up a bit when you unlock your classes' specialization, as some of those kits are fun and work very well with the base classes, but I still canâ€™t help but feel an overall theme of having less RPG mechanics in an RPG game, which is a big negative for me. 
New to DA entirely (I think) is the crafting. This can help to customize your character's gear, especially if you donâ€™t know where the best drops are or if you are simply unlucky. 

The difficulty is generally fairly easy, especially as you level up and unlock better gear and more talents. I played on Normal, and it was a tad difficult in the beginning, but by the time I unlocked my Knight Enchanter specialization after about ~12 hours, I was blowing things up.
One thing I did enjoy is the addition of â€œTrialsâ€ which are optional difficulty increases. You can choose to add elective difficulty increases for some small increased awards like additional loot. Things like having enemies level with you (which is how it naturally was in DA1/DA2) or even an option to turn bears into mini-boss gods. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The graphics are very PS4-era, and while they do age pretty well for a ~11 year old game, certain things like animations can be very stiff and reflections on metal surfaces appear just awful. Still, I think this is a great looking game for its age. 
Probably the worst area graphically is the menu UI. It definitely feels like the focus is on the console versions because the UI is just awful to use with a mouse and keyboard. You have to constantly do things like move your mouse off and then back onto an item to get the tooltip to display. 

On the technical side, the game is not good. I experienced multiple crash to desktops and many bugs when my game simply wouldnâ€™t load, and I had to alt+F4 to the last save. Even aside from technical issues, I ran into gameplay bugs where my characters would stop using abilities, or I couldnâ€™t pick up items on the ground. I had to reload often to fix them. I even ran into bugs where essential characters seemed to have fallen through the ground and was missing all their dialog, essentially ruining the quest.  
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio â€“ [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
I found the audio to be good. The music is largely forgettable, but there were a few iconic songs that are great. 
Voice acting is top-notch and awesome. 
I did encounter many cases where the audio simply stopped working. From combat to dialog, no sound. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) â€“ [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
I think there is some decent replay value here - you can choose male or female, different races, different classes, and different romances as well as a few quests that have some slightly different outcomes. The game is pretty linear, but the choices can definitely warrant multiple runs. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
Dragon Age Inquisition (DAI) is the THIRD game in the Dragon Age series. I highly recommend you go and play the first and second, as they have aged fairly well and are great experiences. Now that youâ€™re here and thinking of diving into DAI what can you expect and how does it compare to DA1/DA2? 

DA1 has a very dark setting full of intrigue. Itâ€™s full of solid RPG gameplay that is parallel to Dungeons & Dragons. DAI does not largely have that. DA2 seemed like a step-down from many of the things that made DA1 so great, but itâ€™s still a good RPG. I feel like DAI is on par with DA2 in that it's decent, but streamlined so much that player choice suffers. 

What DAI offers is a massive open world within the Dragon Age universe, like youâ€™ve never seen it before. I want to make it clear that massive does not mean good. DAI has a clear problem of quantity over quality. You can easily burn dozens of hours doing fetch quests and other random pointless crap that serves no narrative purpose other than to increase your â€œPointsâ€ that you can then spend on unlocking more zones to do more pointless things that give more pointsâ€¦DAI is a nice 40-hour RPG adventure wrapped up in an 80-hour game. 

Itâ€™s not all bad, though. I would say the best part is the story. That 40 hour story is pretty good for about 20 of those hours. Especially the DLC, Trespasser. If Mass Effectâ€™s sendoff was anything to go by, BioWare is very good at doing epilogues for their games and where it ends immediately makes you want more. Also, I have to do a shoutout to the great characters. Itâ€™s a pretty great cast of characters with their own personalities. Sera is my elfy wife. 

Overall, yes, I would recommend DAI. I think it's an okay game. Fans of DA1 and DA2 probably shouldnâ€™t miss it. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? (Price) [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]Yes[/h1]
$40 is steep for an 11 year old game. $10 sale price though is very good for the amount of content you get, and if you can get it for the historical low of $4, VERY worth.

[h1]A vast, beautiful RPG with rewarding progression and deep lore, though overwhelming for newcomers.[/h1]
[i](This review contains no story spoilers btw!!)[/i]

[b]-Overview-[/b]
Developed by BioWare, Dragon Age: Inquisition is a massive fantasy RPG that blends real-time combat with tactical strategy. Players take command of the Inquisition, leading a diverse group of companions to restore order to a fractured world. With hundreds of quests, beautiful environments, and meaningful choices, it delivers an epic adventure, but it is also heavily built on the foundations of the previous two Dragon Age games, and newcomers may feel theyâ€™ve missed major pieces of context.

[b]-Story & Characters-[/b]
[i]A strong, engaging story, best experienced after playing the first two games.[/i]
 Inquisitionâ€™s narrative is well-crafted, emotionally resonant, and packed with political drama, divine conflict, and moral decisions. However, the game relies heavily on world events, character arcs, and choices established in Dragon Age: Origins and Dragon Age II. Returning characters make cameos, past decisions impact present events, and major story threads continue directly from earlier titles.

For players who havenâ€™t experienced the prior games, much of this depth risks feeling distant or incomplete. The Dragon Keep system, which lets you import or manually reconstruct past choices, helps fill the gaps mechanically,  but not emotionally. Reading about choices you never made or characters you never met is a poor substitute for having lived those stories yourself. This is one of the few RPGs where your personal history with the series genuinely matters, and missing that history can lessen the impact of major scenes.

As a first-time Dragon Age player, itâ€™s easy to feel like youâ€™re walking into the third act of a trilogy without having seen the first two. The story is still very good, but youâ€™ll constantly sense that youâ€™ve missed meaningful context, relationships, and payoffs. If anything: I wish someone had told me to play the first two games first. I would have enjoyed this story far more if Iâ€™d brought my own choices and experiences into it instead of relying on presets.

Companions are well-written and offer solid banter and personal quests. Their level of involvement is similar to Fallout 4: theyâ€™re memorable and distinct, but their presence has less influence on the core story than companions in Mass Effect or Dragon Age: Veilguard.

[b]-Gameplay-[/b]
[i]A complex combat system that becomes satisfying once mastered.[/i]
 Combat can be overwhelming early on, especially for players new to managing AI tactics and switching between party members. Over time, though, it becomes one of the gameâ€™s strengths. The mix of real-time action and tactical pausing allows for careful planning or fast-paced brawling, depending on your build. However, people who arenâ€™t new to this type of combat system will find themselves bored with the lack of builds you can make with your character. Still, I found it to be quite enjoyable, regardless.

Character progression is exceptionally well-paced: you begin fragile and unsure, but grow steadily stronger through skill trees, specialization classes, and improved gear. You cannot brute-force enemies above your level, they will flatten you, but the game fairly challenges you within your tier.

Exploration is vast, and each region feels alive with wildlife, secrets, side quests, and collectibles. The sheer amount of optional content is impressive, though some zones can feel bloated with minor objectives.

[b]-World Design & Visuals-[/b]
[i]One of the most visually striking RPGs of its era.[/i]
 The landscapes are vibrant, diverse, and grounded in strong artistic direction. From snowy fortresses to lush jungles and windswept deserts, each region is detailed and atmospheric. The world feels alive and lived-in, and the lighting and environment design remain a standout even today.

[b]-Music & Sound-[/b]
[i]A solid soundtrack that shines in key moments.[/i]
 While the score is not consistently memorable on its own, it elevates major scenes beautifully. Music swells during emotional peaks and blends seamlessly into exploration. Voice acting is strong across the board.

[b]-Length & Value-[/b]
[i]A colossal RPG with well over 90 hours of content.[/i]
 Even a focused run takes dozens of hours, and completionists can expect significantly more,  especially with story DLC. At its frequent sale price, itâ€™s excellent value. However, this isnâ€™t necessarily a good thing, as by the end of the game, you start to get bored exploring all these different zones and doing all these different fetch quests, and at some point, you just wish for the game to end.

[b]-Replayability-[/b]
[i]Worth replaying only if you want to see major branching outcomes.[/i]
 The game offers multiple endings and many impactful choices, but each playthrough is a major time investment. Most players will likely complete it once and revisit it after a long break.

[b]-Summary-[/b]
Dragon Age: Inquisition is a richly developed RPG with excellent world-building, strong narrative arcs, and satisfying character progression. Its size can be overwhelming, but its story and environments are worth the time, provided you play the first two Dragon Age games first.

For newcomers, the Dragon Keep system cannot replicate the emotional weight of decisions you never made or relationships you never formed. The game is filled with callbacks, cameos, and payoffs designed for long-time fans, and much of that will be lost without experiencing the earlier titles.

[b]Highly recommended, especially after completing Dragon Age: Origins and Dragon Age II, which will greatly enhance the story and make Inquisition feel like the true saga finale it was designed to be. 9/10 game, not surprised itâ€™s won game of the year before.[/b]

Dragon Age Inquisition really shows how an entire franchise can go to utter waste.

Despite how good Dragon Age Origins was, no amount of nice lore and storyline helps me tolerate the obsessive amount of grinding in this game that does not know if it wants to provide a good single-player experience or to be an MMORPG with offline servers.

Dragon Age Inquisition is the product of a new design philosophy that spits on the memory of Dragon Age Origins by diverting the player from its previous narrative-driven and consequence-driven logic to an open-world design with vestigial elements from a logic of microtransactions in pay to win games.

Of course there are no microtransactions in Dragon Age Origins, but we all know that blocking quests behind real wait times (like in the war room) are only used by game developers to force players into paying to unlock these sections of the game faster. By blocking quests merely for the sake of it under hours or days, the developers brought a vestige from the microtransaction systems of P2W games, and this is not the only instance where Dragon Age Inquisition is more akin to an MMORPG than to a good single-player RPG.

But what is so wrong with this new design philosophy that Bioware has adapted? That it breaks the narrative of what Dragon Age is.
Dragon Age Inquisition is the story of a person who seems to have been touched by divine power, surviving an explosion with a mark that provides the key to bring the world back into order from beaches that allow demons to cross from the fade to Thedas. It is the story of a person who becomes the public face of an organization tasked with saving the world. It is a story of urgency, the breaches won't wait for the main character to have a field trip before they come to save the world.

Yet, the game design gets everything wrong:
1. Despite the narrative emphasis that Dragon Age has always exhibited, every actual plot moment seems to be blocked by hours of constant grinding and filler material.
2. Every combat has lost all its meaning and it's now nothing but filler. Every enemy is an HP piÃ±ata ready to waste your time even in the easiest difficulties. And not even in the sense of being difficult, just in the sense of being unnecessarily long.
3. The open-world zones destroy all sense of urgency and of pacing, letting the player roam to the most irrelevant places.
4. Most of the side quests are filler content that lack any connection to the player's status as the Herald of Andraste or even any relevance to their mission. Yeah, you can make people be more favorable to the Inquisition by helping them do menial things, but that is not the job for the person who is in charge of closing the breaches. The open-world design forces the player character into an errand-runner, but they are not an errand-runner. They are the Herald of Andraste!

Thus, all these are symptoms of a game design philosophy that does not suit the narrative of a Herald touched by almost divine power. The open world logic forces a dissonance where, despite the urgency of the situation and the role the main character plays in the great scheme of things, the player is invited to waste its time doing everything but the engaging with the main plot. Its vast open-world zones interrupts the pacing and drama, its excessive amount of filler combat distracts from the actual point of the story and its new system of side quests excessively reliant on letters (instead of actual interesting interactions with real people) does not add to the real plot. We've gone from a story-driven game to an open world with the vestiges of microtransaction logic bringing about a degree of dissonance that just destroys the entire experience. Going to a new place like Val Royeaux does not feel anymore like advancing the plot, but like just opening a new can of worms with more irrelevant chores to complete. This game may be great for grinders and completionists, but it does not feel at all like a continuation of Dragon Age Origins.

Some people think Veil Guard was the end of the Dragon Age franchise, but it was already dying in Dragon Age 2, and its body had just decomposed by the time this game was released. Veil Guard was just BioWare spitting on the rotten meat.

To make matters worse, the vast majority of the dialogue is unskippable, none of the characters are likable, all just victims of the racist and religious evil doers with their own uninteresting stories of how they're also victims. This results in being forced to sit through literally hours of boring dialogue from people you just do not care about in the slightest. Tragedy after tragedy, makes for poor story telling, overbearing political messaging makes for a trash game. 

After finishing the game, I now understand why Big Joe was so intent on telling everyone to just STFU.
I really wanted to like this game, but it felt like a lot of build up to nothing. Very disappointing.

Genuinely some of the worst writing I've ever seen. Not just in video games, but all forms of media, and I've played the Kingdom Hearts series. The absolute lack of any critical thinking skills from our cast is appalling. Nothing Sean does or says makes any sense whatsoever. Daniel's development was horrid too; you can try to teach him to be responsible with his abilities and he just refuses to listen. What's the point of character interaction when it has 0 weight? Honestly don't even buy this game on sale, it's not even worth it.

The story is meh and the choices donâ€™t feel like they matter.

In the meantime I played Life is Strange : Double Exposure and finished it in almost one go.

I'm gonna be honest, I've put this review off for quite some time but I feel like it's now or never because I want to put this game behind me and never engage with it again.

Just like with the other titles in the Life is Strange series, I bought this game on release. I've played it on both PlayStation and PC as well as watched content creators, YouTubers, streamers and friends play through the game. I'm sure I've squeezed every bit of content I can out of this game and explored most if not all options. My tldr; it's the worst thing that's happened to the Life is Strange franchise.

To those that know me, it's no secret that I genuinely despise this game. I hate the fact that they took such a beautiful story concept that was Life is Strange (2015) and decided to turn it into a political issue and add forced religion as the cherry on top. 

Don't get me wrong, I think these are very important issues that definitely needs to be addressed, I just hate that they used Life is Strange as the platform to do it. 

Going into this game completely blind, besides seeing teasers and trailers and what the developers had shown us online previously to playing it, I was genuinely interested. I thought it was going to be an emotional journey with intriguing characters to meet along the way just like previous games but was quickly severely disappointed. 

I think my absolute biggest grudge with this game has to be Daniel. I'm not joking when I say I would put him among some of the worst, most annoying characters I have ever seen in any video game. Worse than Ashley Graham - Resident Evil 4 (2005). Worse than Navi - Legend of Zelda. Worse than Paimon - Genshin Impact. 

Not even one hour into the game and I already wanted to leave this runt in the middle of the forest to starve by himself. The dialogue, his actions, his thinking-it was all like nails on chalkboard and I couldn't stand him. The constant lying, betrayal towards his own brother, the god complex he portrayed because of his powers and his need to put others down made me have to unwillingly battle through any content throughout this game that had Daniel involved.

"But he is a child, they make stupid decisions!" I hear-yet whenever we see other children throughout the franchise they're not HALF as ignorant or dumb as Daniel is. 

"He lost his father, he is dealing with trauma!" Loss is a massive part of this franchise and it doesn't justify ANY of his poor thinking or unjustified actions throughout the game.

I've seen the praise that brothers Diaz get from others that love this game and I'm happy they have characters they're so fond of, I've accepted the fact that I don't like Daniel and I never will.

The other characters you meet along the way are "okay"? I guess.. Some of them stick out more than others and you have short moments where you get to explore them more and learn more about their story and their life and it's honestly the part of this game that I enjoyed the most. Sitting by a campfire together, drinking beer and sharing stories of past trauma or exciting events was moments where I felt the most engaged with this game. I think it's this games strongest asset but also where they missed a core opportunity for great writing. There are moments where you meet characters who are intriguing and who have genuine care for you and your brother and who offer well needed help in time of need. Only for the game to throw these characters away never to be seen again. Shout-out Brody. You won't be forgotten.

My second grudge with this game was the ENTIRE CHAPTER focused on a religious cult. 

It's like they asked each other in the office previous to making this game and brainstorming how they could make Daniel even MORE unbearable. By slapping a religious sticker on his forehead and FORCING the played to interact with it. The entire chapter as a whole felt like a chore, your saving grace is meeting your long lost mother Karen (Voiced by the amazing Jolene Andersen, aka. Ada Wong - Resident Evil) and trying to patch up their broken relationship. Yet nothing felt more justified than setting the cult's home ablaze and leaving this horrendous chapter to burn to ash (literally).

So was there any parts to the game that I actually enjoyed? Yes. Of course there was. I give credit where credit is due. Being on the run and seeking help from long lost family or strangers gave a feeling of unease and caution but also a sense of warmth and trust at the same time. Bonding with the introduced characters was great, along with music that's iconic for Life is Strange games, though I felt a slight step down from previous titles, still great tunes to get lost in.

Something I will give this game praise for is it felt like they finally landed that sweet spot where puzzles felt natural. Something I gave previous titles some bad score for because of it's misuse of puzzles, I was glad to see LiS 2 finally managed to get it right. 

In conclusion I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone unless they are looking to complete every title in the series, I feel like this game can easily be avoided or watched online. I wouldn't suggest someone to buy this game even on sale, though definitely pick it up for free or play it if it was gifted to you. I'm sure there are many others who will love this game and give it praise that it's known for.

Minor bugs were present though nothing near other titles. I was happy to see that.

All in all it's another addition to the LiS franchise and another episodic, decision based story game to get lost in for anyone looking for games matching this criteria.

Don't buy this.  Its been changed.  Its been EA-afied.  I only bought it now because I stole all three games back in the day and I was able to purchase all of them now for only $5.

Was hyped to replay it- it happened to be on sale. Played it and was just kind of bored, not enough new stuff. It's one thing to improve the graphics but the design of the hubs is just flat and dull. Everything still seems lifeless and fake. They could have really improved it and added new content. Nowadays a few improved textures and shaders are enough. 

Playing it again just made me take the rose-tinted shades off... no multiplayer? That is criminal! I used to really enjoy that back in the day and was actually one of the reasons I bought it again. Another thing I notice is that playing renegade is a bit hit and miss, your character seems to have been designed to be paragon. Would be better if they actually improved the game instead of just giving the artwork a new lick of paint. At least you can mod it to add a little bit more life into it. 

Ultimately if you love the single player experience or haven't played it yet, it might be worth the cost to get all 3 games in one package but I was expecting a lot more.

I'm still at the first one, but this one is so overwhelmingly NOT even passable in any regard other than story, setting and production values, which are OK (but certainly nothing more, with some really aggravating and facepalming moments), there's just no way the rest of the trilogy can save the package. An abundance of idiotic one-hit-kill mechanics coupled with limitations to saving that lead to having to do boring shit over and over again (a couple of the fights are really unreasonable to boot), the lack of any (!) character development, the worst/most uninteresting loot/equipment system I've ever seen (and with the spectre weapons you can get before the halfway point being the best in the game, all further weapon looting is pointless â€“ and so are the millions of accumulating credits you can't spend on anything because there is nothing worth buying! this isn't even amateur level game design, it's retard level!), boring-as-fuck levelling which is completely unbalanced as well, psionic abilities all seem to do the same thing (namely, hindering your opponent for a few seconds â€“ I can't tell a difference between them at all!), the abominable balance of main and side quests (speedrunners must love this though...), unskippable cutscenes, many, many bugs... and, most direly, the total and utter failure in the RPG aspect as you cannot choose even your own words (!), much less anything else between generally good and vaguely evil... and it's beyond reason itself, as predecessor Knights of the Old Republic was infinitely better in each and every single regard, and DA:O which came afterwards in almost all regards!

EDIT: Game 2. Oh boy! There is more character development in the first 30 min than in game 1, but the actual gameplay is so much worse I simply cannot believe it! Only 4 to 6 things to level instead of some 15 (!), you can't specialise in weapons, the actual shooting feels way worse, the first (!) group battle is already next to unwinnable (and I did beat game 1 on hardest difficulty...), health refills are gone apparently (or I cannot find them) and to top things off, I cannot figure out how to fucking map the quickslots (which I never used in the first game, as I was able to map the weapons to keys, WHICH SHOULD ALSO BE THE CASE HERE!). Fucking shit, the sniper scope doesn't even line up with your line of sight, LOLOOLOL.

I cannot believe how hard they fucked up the gameplay compared to the already not very good first game! No inventory at all, four or five skills to level, no specialisation in weapons, still no feedback whatsoever â€“ you are literally not told whether you hit an enemy or not, and what hits you in turn (even though the latter isn't as important as you can't protect yourself against different kinds of damage, OBVIOUSLY)! No way to boost your abilities in something like the insane garage fight (complete with the biggest video game sin that exists, infinitely respawning enemies â€“ and that's against very limited ammo!!! Hell, after this shit I'll never complain about a game having infinite ammo again!), hell, the fuckers even took out health potions altogether!!! There's apparently quickslots but no apparent way to map them, so I have to change my weapon FROM THE FUCKING MENU EVERY SINGLE TIME!!! Oh and making the sprint key not only the same as Use but also Cover in this one means I will never buy another game from this developer again.

I regret spending 4,79 on this fucking shit of a game, I really do. They did not test this game before releasing it, and they did not test the re-release either... what kind of people would do that... only the worst scum imaginable. Humanity doesn't DESERVE to be saved!

EA app makes this literally unplayable. Beat ME1. Was going to play 2 today, and now the EA app just won't launch the game citing cloud storage being over 1gb, which the save games aren't over 1gb, and they are all saved on my pc anyway, literally hot dumpster fire garbage EA not just letting the game run through steam, but through their awful app

EA Launcher is Cringe.

With that out of the way, honestly to me the Trilogy's narrative doesn't hold up at all. 

The first game is great and establishes the world and a solid vibe game. The only complaint I have is that the companions are a bit vapid, but the game still rocks. 

The second game sidelines the entire first game and elements established within. The first game established the Trilogy's main antagonist, how much of a threat they're going to be, and how the galaxy needs to start preparing now. What's the second game about? Oh human colonies are going missing and a human terrorist organization is using Shepard to investigate them. At least that would be the plot if the main meat of the game wasn't spent on making sure your companions' family troubles aren't resolved. The focus on the small bunch of characters takes away from the greater universe and the impending doom that will need to be resolved in the third game. 

Imma be honest, I've played Mass Effect 3 before and trying to play it after 1 and 2 is a huge tone shift that makes the game feel like it's not a Mass Effect game. Unfortunately 2 set up 3 in a bad spot and it shows from the start. "Oh no, the doomsday threat we were warned about in the first game is here! You know, that giant ship that basically required a whole fleet to take one down is now here in mass! What will we do?!" Then Liara shows up with the blue prints for the Deus Ex Machina device and a point system that will determine if Shepards lives or dies in the either the Mountain Dew ending, the Mountain Dew Code Red ending, or in the Mountain Dew Voltage ending. But along the way, you get to rush by and resolve everyone else's problems because they wouldn't let you do so in the 2nd game due to babysitting duty. 

Overall, the launcher is cringe, the first game is good, the second one is fun but derailing, and the third is just a different game trying to fix everything.

TL;DR buy it on sale for $5

ME1 - Fun third person RPG Shooter with depth for the story and gameplay Completed on Insanity nearly 100%.

ME2 - Awkward arcade hide and peek shooter that continues the story from ME1. It is a significant downgrade gameplay wise. Working on first play through on Insanity, but it simply is a worse game than ME1.

Long story less long:

ME 1: This is one of the best shooter RPG games I have ever played. Even though the graphics may be dated, the story is worth playing with good gameplay to back it up. The attention to detail in the world interactions rivals and beats games released in 2025. 

From social interactions that have implications later in the story, to physical interactions with the world, ME1 feels like a full game worth playing.

I would recommend giving it a try if this is on your backlog.

ME2: It is alright - very similar to ME1, but there are differences. The gameplay is such a let down after ME1, it feels like some exec who didn't even play the first game made some changes on how the fundamentals work by stripping a lot of the core gameplay from the game:

1.  There is no inventory system & you cannot swap weapons/armor during a mission.
2. They managed to make the maps & navigation worse and less useful in ME2. Can't even access the ground map during a mission. ME1 you could access it and place a custom marker at any time.
3. Weapon selection is limited and upgrading weapons is completely different.
4. They took the ability to crouch out of the game. This SIGNIFICANTLY limits how you can play the game compared to ME1.

 In order to crouch, you have to be directly in front of cover and it is not a true crouch, more of a duck and cover.  

Example why this is bad: I am standing, but the wall in front of me across some cross fire, could protect me if I could just MANUALLY CROUCH to hide from the enemy. In order to crouch, I have to go through cross fire that is currently blocked by a wall that will not provide protection if I crouch against it...but it is protecting me against the crossfire.

UnFun fact: You cannot crouch against every wall, anyways.

5. Sprint, Take Cover, Action/use are all mapped to same button.
6. You auto heal outside of combat, you do not use medi-packs to heal anymore.
7. They changed how weapons work in the universe, slightly. No longer do you have enough energy to run your weapon over the time the story takes place, but you now have depletable ammo. Ammo replaces the cooldown mechanic. 

This puts organics another step back from [spoiler]the Reapers[/spoiler] technology wise.

It was fun sneaking around in ME1, slowly moving around corners and peeking for shots. I hope manual crouch is brought back in future games...

I can see why people do not like Mass Effect 2. It is a stripped down version of ME1, with better graphics. The "it does not feel like as much of an RPG as ME1" comments are warranted. It doesn't.

7. Also, they made bypassing circuitry just... a hidden puzzle matching game...

All in all, my only motivation for 2 is to finish the story, but I think I will just uninstall and read the lore online.

ME1 is playable and the only issue I have with it is inventory management
ME2 and ME3 are dogshit bad console ports where your biggest enemies are atrocious cover mechanics, invisible walls and claustrophobic railrodaed environments that do not allow for any kind of creativity.
Play the game in other ways the EA Launcher is a pain in the butt to run.

Never played the ME games before, seemed worth a try though. It's hard to really comment on them as a whole though because maybe this is just a bad port or something. But it's very janky.

You need to download EA's app to play the game at all, and if you don't make an account and log in then it will pop up every time you boot your PC up pestering you about it (even when you haven't loaded up Steam yet, never mind tried to play the game). There's no workaround for this, far as I can tell... and I did look.

I've only touched ME1 and I've had problems with the game progression. There's barely any tutorial, I keep having to look up how to do basic things like holster weapons and heal. Load times are meh, graphics are worse than I expected for a modern remaster, but that's fine, I can forgive that.

But the BUGS. My god. I was prompted to write this review by the fact that I just barely got past the "prologue" section of the game and immediately hit a game-breaking bug (cannot access the galaxy map, and therefore can't... do much of anything, I'm stuck on the Citadel).

I'll try reloading an old save and give those cutscenes another run-through, but this really doesn't bode well for the game overall. And I'm not eager for the experience of playing a game constantly worried that I'll be softlocked behind some random bug which makes my save unplayable.

The game itself, in terms of story and gameplay and so on, seems like something I could've been very into if I'd played when I was 14 but I can't say it feels especially engaging to me now. Still, I would've stuck with it if the game would actually work. Not sure if I will now. I'm not sure it's worth the effort. Shrugs.

I don't know why we thought it was good. There is barely any game here; short navigational sections invite you to walk to your next objective, which is usually dialogue or a cutscene that precipitates a choice. The theme of the choice is usually "who lives and who dies" and considering how the game needs to tie up neatly into a nice knot, the choices are largely inconsequential.

It's hard to call this an adventure game, and 13 years on I'm a little impressed at how this title managed to win over even die hard adventure game fans. Mix 'n' Mojo forums was positively ablaze over it. But on reflection, I don't really get it.

We would later discover that this game was also the death knell for Telltale. Its industry veterans were thrown into the licensed IP meat grinder and churned out, over the next handful of years, riffs on the same formula: walk, dialogue, cutscene, 'choice'.

Adventure games have never been more accessible. ScummVM now features drag and drop support for even the weird Disney-era LucasArts ports here on Steam. If you'd somehow missed out on THIS title - continue to do so. Move on.

I canâ€™t avoid the fact I fundamentally donâ€™t enjoy zombie settings. I thought Telltaleâ€™s Walking Dead would be the game to finally turn me around - after all, itâ€™s rated so highly that it seemed superficial to me to write it off so easily. I love the episodic narrative-based format, and I especially love a tear-jerker. See my adoration of Life is Strange.

My problem with zombies is the fact theyâ€™re [b] such a boring [/b]enemy. By their very nature, they have near zero intellectual power, making them the most mentally unchallenging enemy to fight. The best villains build tension by outwitting the main character. But Zombies are entirely predictable. They have no personality or character traits, they canâ€™t give any dialogue or communicate in interesting ways. Theyâ€™re just spammed ad infinitum and thrown at survivors.

But zombies arenâ€™t considered the real enemy of the zombie genre. Instead, itâ€™s peopleâ€™s inability to work together which ultimately leads to their deaths. But this means pedantic infighting, petty drama and miscommunication take centre stage, which is incredibly frustrating to endure. Itâ€™s like when you watch a horror film where each character leads themselves to their deaths due to their inability to communicate. 

The Walking Dead is centred around both of these cliches, and while I wonâ€™t argue it introduces a few other ideas too, it ultimately revolves around petty arguments between the majority of the characters. I know thereâ€™s some fondness for the art style too, but characterâ€™s faces are so comically exaggerated that it feels like a kidâ€™s cartoon at times. The cell-shading doesnâ€™t feel like a choice motivated by a strong artistic identity, but rather a practicality of a low budget. The gameâ€™s story themes are dark, dreary and depressing, so this Borderlands-esque look works at odds to this.

The puzzles feel less about figuring out the problem, but instead talking to characters and engaging with items in a prescribed order for it to eventually trigger your character carrying out the solution. I do appreciate some of the decision-making, and I genuinely like Lee and Clementine, itâ€™s bogged down by the petty and childish supporting cast. Also, the gameâ€™s climax is ruined the moment you open the game because of the Steam community integration. This means under the â€œPlay gameâ€ button you see scores of memes and artwork relating to the gameâ€™s final moments, ruining the emotional impact completely.

I wonâ€™t argue this review is unfair, since I donâ€™t enjoy the fundamentals of the zombie genre, but I did think The Walking Dead might be so good as to make me overlook this. Sadly, this wasnâ€™t the case.

Can you be you without a body ('soma' in Greek)? Does our self need a biological form? How much can you alter it while still preserve its humanity? What if consciousness could be scanned and digitized to run on a computer?

[i]SOMA[/i] is a first person horror game with clever philosophical depth and profoundness. This is achieved with a few trivial yet somehow awfully meaningful choices along a gripping journey through a bleak underwater research facility. Splendidly voice-acted protagonist Simon ([b]Jared Zeus[/b]) and his acquaintance Catherine ([b]Nell Mooney[/b]) provide their own opinions but leave room for the player to think.

SOMA's weakness is the lack of gameplay mechanics: it is a walking simulator with slight puzzle and stealth elements. Replayability is almost nonexistent due to that. But for one playthrough, the game does provide an immensely immersive 10-hour experience. The physical interactivity of objects -- pushing and pulling doors, grabbing and throwing stuff -- makes the game world feel tangible.

Certain sections with a monster can become frustrating if you get stuck on repeating them. Fortunately, in a post-release update, [b]Frictional Games[/b] added a Safe Mode option that stops the monsters from hindering your progress. The mode does reduce tension considerably -- since no actual threats -- but doesn't affect the overall gloomy atmosphere that much.

Incredible game and story. Leaves you thinking about the implications of all the decisions well after it is over and the outcome. So much to unpack. Easily a game I could see myself wanting to forget to replay all over again.

Some parts of the stealth were frustrating, but I might just be bad. I would also love an option to have changed to pacifist difficulty during the playthrough, but so glad I powered through and finished the game.
This shit made me cry

Soma makes great use of the first person horror medium to provoke ethical and other philosophical questions in the player. There's enough quiet time to ponder these themes in between the monster encounters, most of which I found genuinely scary. The challenge of the game is basically to keep your nerve and figure out the monster's behaviour - short puzzles under emotional pressure. I think you'll be missing out if you use safe mode. 

There are also several more relaxed puzzles without any monster stalking you, which I found interesting and well-judged in terms of difficulty. I felt like I really could be the protagonist, trying this and that until something works. I also really appreciated that the game felt like a real environment, with lots of spaces and objects that aren't relevant to the player. I find this adds a lot to immersion. Furthermore, there are no stupid easter eggs or steam achievements for exploring every inch of the map. You can actually behave like you would if you were really in this world, instead of running around like a maniac looking for dopamine.
 
The story is excellent and very original. Not only that, I'd call it anti-formulaic.
[spoiler]Terry Akers isn't some final "big bad" boss, and the last human alive isn't Catherine Chun, instead it's an ordinary woman who's a stranger to the player and to the protagonist[/spoiler]. The major decisions in the game are also left as instrinsically rewarding - they are for asking yourself what you'd do in an extreme situation. Not for thinking how you can get some achievement or alternate ending. 
The creators clearly thought a lot about what a game could, and should be. Strongly recommended to anyone into sci-fi, horror or philosophy.
BEST HORROR SCI-FI!!! Loved every second of it, the story of this game is way better than many movies with the same vibes.

[h3]A Walking Simulator Disguised as Horror and Puzzles[/h3]

After pushing through several hours, Iâ€™ve had enough. SOMA pretends to be this deep, atmospheric horror masterpiece, but in reality, itâ€™s a painfully slow walking simulator with frustrating underwater segments. Iâ€™ve played my fair share of complex, puzzle-heavy survival horror games, and this one isnâ€™t challenging, itâ€™s just poorly executed and painfully repetitive gameplay.

The first hour hooked me with its atmosphere and story potential, but once youâ€™re thrown underwater, the experience falls apart. Low visibility, sluggish movement, and maze-like areas where you wander aimlessly for hours with no sense of direction; not fun, not scary, just exhausting.

Itâ€™s a shame, because thereâ€™s clearly a good story buried somewhere under all this frustration. But good narrative design doesnâ€™t excuse bad gameplay. Iâ€™ve played walking sims before, this one just happens to be the most boring one pretending to be more than it is.

If you value your time, skip this one.
a lot of running around in the dark.

This game will not launch for me and I have tried everything the devs left as a "support guide" for when this happens but nothing works. Very disappointed since I really wanted to get my hands on this game.

Linear, short, and a frustratingly simplistic story (at least with the themes they are trying to explore) that relies too much on the stupidity of the main character to carry itself to the finish line. Obnoxious use of filters, boring stealth sections, and a story twist that is obvious once you complete the prologue. It doesn't help the sense of tension is non-existent and any form of horror is too smeared in post-processing effects to be frightening. Even on a deep discount, it is hard to recommend this one.

What does it mean to be human?

That's the question the game poses. A journey on philosophical existentialism, if you will. If you've never entertained this topic, it's not implausible the game may have a deep impact on you. For me, however, it didn't hit the mark, not even close. I tried to like it; forcing myself to continue; hoping at some point it would start to click. Sadly, it only got worse.

Story is essential for me, gameplay is secondary, always. And a game like this is *entirely* story driven; there's no gameplay here other than walking and interacting with the environment via terminals, pushing buttons, opening doors, etc. I should be right in my element yet I found myself bored to tears. I believe with just a few gameplay mechanics, like an inventory, some resource management, semi-engaging puzzles and a combat system, the game would actually be enjoyable. But, as it stands, I just can't finish it. I've given up not long after reaching Theta.

Tough one to review. I saw the twist miles away, and think the topic explored in this game has been done too many times. The gameplay is boring. I mostly just wanted to get through the annoying stealth sections. I didn't find the game scary, which I think is what broke the gameplay loop.

Good story, but 80% of the gameplay is sitting there waiting for something to happen. Waiting for an elevator to go down, waiting for a vehicle to reach the destination, waiting for the game to load, wait for the audio log you triggered to finish because the game doesn't let you walk around while listening to them like every other game did since system shock 1 in 1994, waiting for a globule of doom to decide to finally hobble away, waiting for your character to crawl along an endless passage, wait for the character to incredibly slowly climb up a ladder (game fails the ladder rule), waiting for the endless expanse of ocean to finally lead to the next story module. The game should be like 4 hours but it's 10.

A horror game shouldn't have me intentionally running at 200mph towards the enemies you are supposed to avoid because i am tired of spending 30 minutes creeping around to avoid them when i can simply be punched in the face by them and get knocked out at which they automatically leave to a different part of the map.

There are sections of the game where the game tells you to do something but that something gets you killed anyway "follow the lights" if you follow the lights the monsters still kill you anyway and you have no way of hiding from them properly in that section so you just repeatedly get attacked anyway, so pointless.

Also, the concept of not being able to fight an enemy is unrealistic. A human can stab literally anything with an improvised spear and with enough conviction they will kill it. Welcome to being human we've been doing this since we lived in caves. (Yeah I don't care if the MC is technically only partially human in this game you know what I mean)

In short this is a walking simulator with like 5 puzzles in 10 hours. The story is good but the game is not. Also, the ending of the story sort of lives and dies on the idea of a programmer not understanding cut vs copy which I think would be the simplest of concepts for someone designing robots that contain human consciousness to understand. So I can't really take it seriously. The world itself in the story is cool though.

As a game I wouldn't recommend it because it's not all that fun to play. It's probably more fun to watch a quick playthrough on youtube.

I liked the overall concept of the game and the twist.  
There were a couple jump scares that I highly enjoyed.
I liked the length of the game (I completed it in under 12 hours).

But these things didn't tip the scale for me to recommend this game.

I thought the philosophical aspects could have been implemented better.  
The story started to feel stagnant due to only getting info from computer logs, talking with another AI (Catherine), and "tapping into the past."  The story and lore didn't make me feel the need to seek out additional lore/story and what I came across organically felt good enough.

Once I understood this, I feel like I was just on autopilot getting to the next objective.

DEVOUR â€” Chaotic Co-Op Horror With Heart-Pounding Tension

DEVOUR plunges players into a frantic co-op horror experience where teamwork, panic, and quick thinking are the only things standing between your group and a terrifying cult entity. Each map feels like a self-contained nightmare, requiring coordination and courage as the tension escalates with every ritual item you collect.

The game shines in its simple yet effective co-op design. Working together to find items, manage resources, and dodge the ever-growing aggression of the possessed leader turns every match into a chaotic thrill ride. Communication is keyâ€”splitting up can mean faster progress, but also guarantees hilariously horrifying moments as someone gets dragged into the dark.

Atmosphere and pacing are major strengths. Each locationâ€”from haunted farmhouses to burning asylumsâ€”offers distinct threats, secrets, and environmental storytelling. The sound design ramps up fear at all the right moments, building suspense as the demonâ€™s behavior evolves and the stakes rise.

Progression and replayability keep players coming back. Difficulty settings, unlockable cosmetics, and new maps with unique mechanics ensure that each run stays fresh. The unpredictability of enemy behavior and the frantic scramble near the end of each round make DEVOUR consistently exciting with friends.

Final Verdict:
DEVOUR is a fast, frightening, and wildly entertaining co-op horror experience. Its escalating tension, distinct maps, and teamwork-focused gameplay make it a must-play for fans of multiplayer scares and chaos-filled sessions with friends.

â€œTerrifying, frantic, and endlessly funâ€”horror co-op at its most chaotic.â€

Multiple ways of playing and customising your game so that each play you can do something different so there is a lot of longevity within the game. I look forward to seeing what more they bring from this, ideally adding more enemies, ways of trade or potential diplomacy as some times it just becomes a resource management game while you wait for a trader or random raid to attack you.

Over all I enjoy sinking many hours into this game and I highly recommend it.

Actions and the rate you advance feel a tiny bit slower than some other city builder games, but I prefer that as it makes me plan more rather than instantly place things or send settlers somewhere. It's fun and I'd genuinely recommend it.

This is one of those games where the first 20 hours or so are very addicting as you learn to swim in an ocean of content and struggle with balancing your economy with logistics and raids; but once you understand how to swim in the ocean, the mechanics all feel really flat and repetitive. Apparently it is a successor to Banished, I never played/heard of that, so to me this game feels very much like Anno.

The good things about this game: the learning curve is rewarding and I think I restarted my game like 15 times before settling on the playthrough where most of my gametime comes in. I think the learning curve for me was easier than it would be for most as I spent lots of hours in Anno and other logistics based building games as well, so for me it was just learning how this game goes about it, but for others this might be a steeper learning curve.

Visually it looks really good on my machine (others state they had performance issues) and seeing the seasons change and snow collect on the ground then melt is a nice touch. Watching the world change form as you build and plan roads is also fun. Mapping your town out and placing your individual buildings to maximize benefits and resources is always a fun little puzzle to solve; the game also makes it very easy to move things around when you realize you may have placed something incorrectly, so design mistakes are not punishing.

My gripe is the flawed logistics systems: most of the storage units don't have dedicated workers to them, and the long distance logistics solution (wagons) don't seem to supply every storage facility. The problem with this is upgrading your residential buildings require that they have a variety of goods, but the citizens/workers are simply too stupid to fill the markets/storage units with the same varieties; rather they stock them with the closest buildings that make those products. This seems like a problem that can be solved 10 different ways easily, and for the life of me I can't get all the storage units/markets to carry everything I'm producing.

The combat in this game is also a chore. The first few times you encounter a raid, it will really set you back as having armed units costs money, and this game honestly provides almost no early game economy other than simply being lucky and finding ruins with gold. The AI in this game is also very sub par; RTS games of the early 90s had much more engaging and intelligent enemy behaviors than this game does. The combat was what I was looking forward to the most in this game as it is presented as a real threat, but I found selecting all my units and telling them to attack units one at a time always had me winning in an open field despite the enemy outnumbering me sometimes like 6:1. It's also just raiders, there aren't any diplomatic options with other nations or castles that you can war with, so the combat feels like something slapped together really quickly.

As many have already stated, the tech tree feels fun at first, but later it feels like a gate more than a boost as all the buildings you need are locked behind technology and if you don't upgrade the right way, technology can be EXTREMELY slow to gain; I had to once wait like 5 in game years for one tech point because I needed a building that was locked behind a technology I didn't research yet and couldn't find a tech point any other way.

Overall the presentation and mechanics had me very captivated and impressed the first 25 hours or so, and then I realized I had mastered them all; at this point I was just playing the game to grow, not for a challenge or purpose, and I didn't find the aesthetics or freedom to build captivating enough to play without some goal to work towards.

I have played this game for many months, and really enjoyed it until the final release. I tend to play middle of the road with any game, medium difficulty, medium risk, medium time commitment. The decision to place a Raider Camp near a brand new village is just frustrating and makes no sense to me. Previously, the periodic raids added just the right amount of challenge and focus on villager safety. Now, I that safety is an overriding concern from the beginning and I feel like I cannot make any headway. I am taking a break from this game, and will see what other village builders my scratch this particular itch. Too bad, because I was having such a good time.

It's a solid game for 20 hours, the first run is fun, and then by the end I just had a moment of ".. that's it?". Starting a next run you're gonna be doing the same limited set of actions you can do to build your city. I have exhausted all variation quite shortly. I feel claustrophobic and lonely, it feels like im playing an empty husk of a world. Let me explain several independent thoughts I have which I'm conflicted about. These are only a few examples to explain a small portion of my feels.

Several mechanics and rules just live in the wild online as myths and mysticisms: what for, and how to use the wagon shop for example. Of course that's not the only one, as there are several other ones that are just not declared by the game so you kinda have to guess and hope it works like you want. Reading reddit comments and forum posts of other people's thoughts on what they believe the mechanic works like. There are several annoyances in the game that keep piling up at the back of your mind as you build your city and you get to know the systems of the game. Some examples:

The upgrade and proximity system encourages you to just cramp things together and make grids. It often comes down to "do you want a pretty town, or do you want to survive?"
We want a pretty town of course, thats the game's appeal. But in the back of your mind this annoyance is always going to be there.

It's great that you can set a max limit for resources, so that villagers can quit that job and enter an other one. But this isn't true for all jobs: farmers, healers, soldiers are assigned to their duties and are still busy standing in their job title. There is no downside to unassigning them while they are not useful. You can also just let them be, which is what I do: but it's still going to be an annoyance in the back of your mind.

The reason for my dislike isn't concretely these 2-3 examples. It's the overall feel, for which I have provided these examples. This feel, while the game is in early access is fine, but not as a full release at full price: Which is how I encountered this game the first time. I gave it enough playtime for me to doubt myself, because I did have doubts, maybe I just didn't understand the vision or the game. But I couldn't prove my feel for the game wrong even after playing it diligently.
The game is not what is described on steam. very low graphics, not an actual sim building game. Everything is basic

Iâ€™ve been waiting for this game to leave Early Access, but honestly, it feels like it needed at least another year before being considered finished. My biggest issue is how painfully slow and inefficient the citizens are. Iâ€™m in year 9, and itâ€™s still unbearable.

Watching them work is like watching paint dry. Progress crawls because the NPCs are so inefficient. During winter, everyone just stays inside doing nothing, so I end up staring at my monitor waiting for villagers to actually start the tasks Iâ€™ve queued. I didnâ€™t buy a game to sit and wait for hours while nothing gets done.

Right now, the gameplay feels like 70% waiting and watching, and only 30% actually playing.

If I could leave a neutral rating, I would. But as it stands, I canâ€™t recommend this game to anyone. The citizens need major improvements to their productivity. Iâ€™m aware of the time-acceleration toggle, but this is about efficiencyâ€”not speed. For example: does it really take eight people six in-game hours to chop down a single tree?

I say this as someone who plays on vanquisher.

The game is fundamentally flawed on what makes a city builder engaging for those looking for difficulty/challenge 


Logistically this game is extremely lacking in complexity, even though on the surface it may not appear so.  Villagers are completely incapable of handling distances, despite the existence of wagons.  

There is no simple button of "only allowed wagons to transport" a resource.  Villagers will walk half way across the map to a node, to grab 2 ore, instead of waiting for a wagon to deliver.

You can get gamey with it to try and force it, but to me a city builder has failed on a basic level when you are unable to set such simple limits.

Second, the tech tree suffers from the same problem.  It may appear to offer depth complexity, but that is far from the truth.  Technology mostly exists to speed bump your city and its expansion by locking previous buildings behind tech.

There are glimmers of interesting ideas in the tree, active policies that trade benefirs for penalties; but they are mostly ineffectual or extremely strong to the point where the downside might as well not exist.

I could say more, especially the shallow nature of the military, but overall this game leaves me disappointed.

Cyberpunk 2077 is fine, I think. Probably one of the most 6/10 games I have ever played. It has a lot of side content, and there is definitely fun to be had, but it is more so in the Fallout 3 way of making your own fun. The cyberware feels half-baked, the perk system still feels like a first draft, melee feels basically unusable at higher difficulties, the writing is either pretty decent or just abysmal, a lot of the quest design is pretty boring and underdeveloped, the main quest ends right as it seems like it is about to get really interesting, and the city itself feels flat. It's got a lot of pretty buildings to look up at, but there is basically no meaningful verticality that the game plays with. At full price, I can not in good faith recommend the game. 

Phantom Liberty is a little better, I would probably rank it independently at around a 7/10 or maybe an 8/10, but that is mainly just because the writing and quest design is better and a lot tighter than the main game. The fundamental gameplay just does not feel good. Still pretty buggy, still a pretty bad "roleplaying game", and still a very superficial exploration of the themes of cyberpunk.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
There are definitely mechanics you can enjoy, but personally they missed the mark.

Movement is a little too floaty, feeling similar to ARK.
The skill tree feels like it should be split up so basic survival skills (e.g mining/chop speed) are not taking away from the more fun skills.
At least early on, the game does not feel great in terms of scaling to a larger group. We tried with 6 people  and there is a constant blast of information as people unlock things or talk to NPCs, and it feels silly just whacking every enemy in a 6v1 fight.
And the biggest problem was performance stability, for most of our group even with low settings FPS would regularly dip below 30.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The start felt too much like Fortnite the survival game, in the worst way...I wanted to enjoy this game but I feel like there is not enough there to grab you at the start and I didn't want to keep the game to find out if it would grow on me so i refunded it.
I also feel like this game suffers a lot if you try and play it with too many players, I felt overwhelmed with pop-ups and didn't really know if I should be focusing on questing, exploring or survival.
Also my friends were struggling with performance a lot even after trying to make the game look like a fogged up mirror, so that is something to consider if you don't have a high end PC.

This game might become great when you progress but it's an expensive game to keep with hopes of enjoying it later.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: too early, no novelty, wish I could get a refund

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Not worth it in it's current state. I know it's Early Access, but holy moly is this ever rough around the edges. A lot of basic tutorials that you'd expect to get are simply not there, and the AI is pretty much "run in straight line and attack, repeat" for every enemy- which can still be difficult because enemies are often just spammed at you from spawners you can barely see and any attacks from behind count as backstab, even for enemies. So an enemy you didn't even know had spawned behind you can one shot you.

Which brings me to my next major gripe:  Darksouls style artificial difficulty.  Some traps and even simply existing in some areas will INSTANTLY KILL YOU. With no warning or indication whatsoever. The worst being the Shroud itself. The game doesn't tell you there are multiple "levels" of shroud, which to the player just looks like fog. There is no distinction between levels apparently. So you can be walking through shroud and be fine, then simply touch a higher level shroud and just instantly die. Insult to injury is that the game flashes a message on your screen warning you that you're IN a harder shroud area. *After* you are dead.

Being a caster is kind of a joke, as staffs require mana AND ammo, which is a huge pain in the ass to get mats for early on. Then there's the game's automatic target locking. You can't freely aim, you are stuck locking onto enemies and it can seriously screw you over if you're trying to shoot a barrel next to an enemy because. While I only found out later you can hold T and it will cancel target lock but only while holding T. There's permanent toggle.

The game has promise, but in it's current state, it is more frustrating than fun to play. Way too many annoying "choices" that bring the game down.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The performance optimization is still painfully garbage almost a year after I bought the game. I keep dropping it and telling myself "they'll probably fix it in a couple months", but at this point I don't know if that's ever going to happen. There's no reason this game should be running at sub 60FPS using medium to medium-high settings (With DLSS on performance), on a device with a core ultra 9, RTX 4080, and 32GB RAM. 

If these issues ever do get addressed, I can easily see myself putting in over a hundred hours in this game, but at it's present state, it just gives me a headache.

I'd say hold off on buying until the game is finished.

I actually loved this game. It's not as Dark Soul's like as I initial had thought, but that's not a bad thing in this case. Any Elden Ring/Dark Souls players will have an easy time with this game. I beat the last 4 bosses without a single death and that made me feel just as powerful as you should in a game where you're essentially the perfect automaton fighting a mass produced army.

Also I'd like to say that the story is A-Tier for me, the world is unique being in France during the reign of King Louie XVI and Marie Antoinette, and the addition clock work robots as the main character and enemies made this a unique experience. But as I said the story was pretty fun, no crazy plot twists or crazy revelations but just straightforward plot development which is not always in action heavy games.

This game is tagged as souls-like, but if it is, then it' a very generous souls-like. Can you imagine souls-like with infinite stamina (if built right) and infinite usages per item(as many as you can buy/collect))?
Overall, recommended if in discount, since it was released a while ago, no point of buying it full-price unless it's masterpiece, which this one is not.

Pretty good game overall, I'd recommend if you are looking for a soulslike that is short, has a fun story, and decent combat. 
I will say, the story is by far the strongest part of this game. I also really like that the devs tried a new spin on the genre, by adding interesting movement abilities. However, the levels were a bit too simple to really let these shine (even when backtracking, these abilities were used in pretty simplistic ways). 
The combat was okay, there were only a couple of weapon types (though they came with different special attacks, they were largely the same). The enemy variety was good considering the short runtime. 
The combat overall was really easy even w/o the assist mode. The bosses were a letdown - they were incredibly easy, and didn't really have any moves or combos to worry about. Also, their attack hitboxes were *really* bad - a lot of them you could just hug and they'd not be able to hit you with most of their attacks.
As a complete package, this is a fun game for the ~15hr runtime (not incl DLC). However, get it on sale, it is far too expensive at full price for what you get. But at ~$10, this game is a pretty fun time.
good game. 7/10, french revoltion but with soul eating robots.

Very interesting story, beautiful graphics and generally good gameplay and battles. This idea of automatons being the real enemies in the french revolution is an interesting view.

It is typical of a dark souls type of game with steep learning curve and monsters that respawn after each death or interaction with saving point.

In other games, where monsters do not respawn after each death and saving point, I usually play on adventure mode, like the step above story mode, but never hard core mode. I get tired of the unending grinding of games like this, where your progress don't mean shit if you havent reached a saving point. Killing 50 monsters just to die to the boss, and then having to kill them all again, is not my idea of fun.

Big plus that they have added "assist" mode so you can play more as in a story mode or similar to enjoy the game more, avoiding the unending grinding and actually be able to finish the game, even as an average player.

King Louise did nothing wrong! Get on sale.

Fun game. 

This would make for a great intro to Soulslikes for anyone hesitant or afraid of them.  This  has a great mode where you can essentially play it as easy as you want (take zero damage, even!) And while that is tempting, I'd encourage newbies to maybe just play the tutorial that way to get the hang of the mechanics and then go back and start a new game on the default difficulty. The tutorial/first level of this is by far the most difficult part and if you can get by that on default difficulty, then you can beat the game easily.  (even on default difficulty, there are items that can just trivialize bosses.) 

In addition, this game has a pause button so it is better than all the FromSoft games combined.

If Elden Ring had gone robotic/sci-fi versus fantasy, this is the game. I don't mean that in a good way. It's like they took Elden Ring's price-point and made worse gaming mechanics, while making it impossible to feel like you're gaining ground in the story line without dying and losing any power-up progress you've finally felt like you've gotten under your belt. The main-character to weakest-enemy power balance doesn't help in making you feel like your making story progression. I tried really hard to like this game, but they really need to either include more Vestule's so you don't have to go through the same 20-minute fighting sequence multiple times (either this or running past every minor robot to reach "boss-bots") or give you the opportunity to save game progress without the vestule's.

Could have been pretty decent but it had one major flaw. There is no substance.

Souls-Like games really arent just combat, thats just ARPG stuff... There is a lot that goes into the genre and world building, lore and most.importently NPCs are really vital for an impactful experience.

If you took the NPCs and or the way theyre set up out of the souls series or elden ring, they would feel exactly how this feels. Empty, lifeless, forgettable.

The way the game handles character interactions is the reason people are saying that they dont feel connected to it.

Take this advice, learn from it and apply it.

Also, please consider short cuts that actually make sense.

Overall id give it a 6.5/10 what it has is pretty good, but what it doesnt have hurts it.

Enemies are Tanky, even the small fry, which in itself doesn't need to be a problem but I found it made me get bored of the combat really quick. 

Maybe it gets better later on but I dont want to play this type of game for 10 Hours until it gets good.

If i buddy wasnÂ´t watching to make fun of the design i would not have finished it. 19 hours with doing all sidequests blind.

After finishing the game i think i can safely say that i would not recommend buying this game at full price. The game itself was fun however there were a few things about it which i did not like and make the game definetily not worth the full price.

1. The game is a walk in the park... For calling itself a soulslike it is way too easy. I actually did every single boss first try except (ironically) the very first one where i died once cause i wasnt familiar with the movement of my own character. At the whole 12 hour run I only died 3 times even though im by no means a god gamer... im a soulslike fan so i actually enjoy getting my ass spanked by a hard game which this game sadly could not deliver the slightest.

2. The maps all look similar especially the first 3-4 big regions so it is too monotonous for my taste. Got a bit better to the end of the game but the start was too equal looking.

3. Mob recycling is crazy in this game... Holy shit there are actually only like 5 types of enemie which get recycled throughout the whole game by getting a different weapon or element but basically still being the same enemy.

4. As mentioned earlyier its too pricey for what it brings to the table. I would say a fair price would be 20â‚¬ but would strongly advise against buying it for everything above that price.

So much for my review, i still had fun playing it though even if not as much as i did in other soulslike.
