I really would love to like this game. It has engaging combat, a great multiplayer and interactivity that I have not seen before.
The start at Fort Joy is amazing to play. It's the best balanced and the most well-rounded. I always knew where to go, always found new things to explore and I never felt lost story wise.

All of this starts to turn around in the following acts and I feel like it gets worse or at least more glaring the further you progress. 
These glaring issues for me are:

[b] "Open World" [/b]
On Fort Joy the open world felt rewarding. The battles were challenging but beatable. So, I was delighted to see what may come after Fort Joy.

What I ended up finding were "natural" level barriers that forced my friend and I to follow a linear route to so that we could beat the battles (note that we played on normal).
Finding this linear route after the game told us to pick and choose where we wish to go next just felt confusing. In total it took us a month to progress (we played once every week). We desperately staked out which area might be appropriate for our level 12 characters. I still remember each area of the second act and which level is associated with. 
Perhaps we where unfortunate to not have chosen this path. Mayhaps, we simply overread an important dialog pointing us towards the right direction.
The only thing I know for sure is that the only for us beatable area was [spoiler]in the top left corner[/spoiler] of the map.

You have to pass multiple other areas with higher levels to get there.
Nevertheless, this area was still a mighty struggle. We fought with everything we had. We strategized about each battle. After every loss we took notes, regrouped and attacked again. Every potential "exploit" we could see, we utilized.

This level of tenacity does not feel appropriate for a normal difficulty playthrough at least not for me.

[u]Recommendation[/u]
The pre-set levels with the exponential leveling system to not work together with the "open world" aspect of the game.
I'll get more in-depth with the leveling in the next part, but giving the player the directive to "reign freely" while setting fixed levels to the enemies does not add up. 
Adjusting the enemies to the level the player is feels way more appropriate. Maybe, sprinkle in some fixed levels as a boss to really stop the player if the story demands it, but putting this everywhere is just misguided. 

Especially since it let to us loosing track of the story completely. We started each quests, but we could never finish them due to the battles. So after a week or two we came back to the quest without having a clue of what was going on. (The in-game journal is quite lack luster on this regard)

[b]Levelling[/b]
In total you can get up to level [spoiler]21[/spoiler], which feels a little low looking at other RPGs. The issue I have with this is that you are at level [spoiler]12 when leaving Fort Joy[/spoiler]. This leads to the weird situation that levels are exponentially more important the closer you get to the max level.

At first you may be able to win a battle against a two levels higher foe, but towards the end if you are not on the same level as your enemy, you get demolished.
We literally couldn't defeat the final boss since we were one level below it. Coincidentally, we also were at a point were we felt like we completed every quest available to us. After trying for another fruitless three weeks, we loaded a previous save and tried to squeeze out another level so we have even an inkling of a chance.

As a [u]recommendation[/u] I can just offer a proper re-balancing of the later areas and a plead for general level cap increase. In the last stages of the game seeing the next level XP requirement to be in the millions is disheartening.

[b]Quest Management[/b]
A more minute point but it feels like the bad cherry on top of the issue cake. 
The in-game journal feels in-adequate to help the player remember story points and even gist's of quests. The best you can hope for is a red marker on your map, and a small to-do entry. The point of the quest, the afflicted affiliations and the severity are often not included. 

Especially after our 3-week excursion through level barrier hell, we essentially reached a point of mindless "red flag grinding". I at least felt like a zombie trying to stave my XP-hunger by any means possible. So, every found quest was like a 3-star prepared meal and I devoured it as far as I could, but the chef seemed to hate me and always put glass shards in the food so that I had to come back to it later after my gums were accustomed to the "difficulty" (Essentially I needed to level to beat a foe)

Everything combined together let to me loosing completely any inkling of the story.

A small anecdote concerning story. My friend and I felt like we managed to skip great chunks of it unwillingly. One example for this is the story around Gareth.

For me it felt as follows: [spoiler]The great leader Gareth managed to escape the prison island Fort Joy with the help of his divine acquaintances (us). Together they set sail to Reaper's Coast where Gareth's parents resided. He immediately went to his parents but Magisters seemed to have been a step ahead of him. The battle did not take long, but neither did the triumph. Beneath rubble lay two corpses ... his parents. Silently he buried them. A deep anger begins taking hold of Gareth. Before he could do anything reckless his two divine acquaintances appear. He told them what happened. The trio stood there silently. Until one divine spoke up: "It is what it is, bro".

These words quiet the anger immediately and Gareth went back to the ship never do to anything of note again.
[/spoiler] 

I do not know how one should experience his tale but this is beyond ridiculous.

This was roughly the experience I had with almost all of the story points which is why during the end credits I felt like I was being introduced to new characters since I could not for the life of me remember who any of the characters even where.

My [u]recommendation[/u] for this one would be to add more information to the journal, and to add a glossary to keep track of the different parties, their goals and what the situation currently is. The chapters setup did not help at all. It rather added to the confusion because some quests where chapter-overlapping, so they never disappeared.

[b]Gear[/b]
I had a very unique problem with gear throughout the whole game. Namely, I was often stuck with too low leveled gear because of set combos. These set combos gave me unique traits which I liked, but I could never transition smoothly to a new set due to bonuses of the set combo.

So my solution would be to upgrade my gear, but there is no way to level up gear. There is a DLC-esque bundle modifications containing the gear sisters. Which adds four sister merchants in the game which sell you (limited) quantities of gear upgrade ingredients. Even if you managed to pay their insanely steep prices (easily 10k per PIECE). Their limited quantity would not even allow you to upgrade a full set of unique gear ONCE.

I re-iterate my final gear that was a 5 piece armor set, was physically not possible to be upgraded fully ONCE even if I collected ALL the armor upgrade ingredients.

[u]Recommendation[/u]: Please let me upgrade my gear, I'm begging you.

[b]Overall[/b], I think the game has a fantastic premise, but these points just gave me such frustration while playing that I simply felt saddened by the thought of what could be. If I'm just unlucky with how my playthrough went please tell me what I could have done. I'd really love to find my appreciation again for this game.

Crashes frequently. Different places, different times, whether playing a few minutes or for longer periods of time. Crashes in Fort Joy walking into arena. Crashes in Reaper's Coast. Game simply exits. No error message, warning, or indication about to exit. Just back to desktop.

Windows recommended compatibility settings for Windows 8. Larian support page recommended running game directly without Steam. Still crashes on windows 10. Played fine for a while. Then doesn't play fine. 

Camera is visually disorienting when edge panning due to elevation changes (trees, cliffs, anything similar). Camera jumps high, jumps low. When scrolling around to see where to go, find a chest, road, or something, this is just plain awful.

Find a place you want to go on the big map? No way to click a point and instruct party to go there. Exit map and walk there bit by bit or scroll the area (with that disorienting up / down camera going across terrain), find your spot, click and hope your party doesn't stop for ground obstructions or obstacles.

Mario 64 has better camera free look than Divinity OS 1 or 2.  That's on Nintendo 64! 
I don't know how beta testers didn't get headaches from this camera in Divinity 2.

General rule of thumb appears to be destroy opponents before they get turns. Enemy turns take a long time. Sometimes, game decides to think about what to do (I guess?) so a minute or so later, finally completes that opponent's turn. Now do it again for the other 5+ in the fight. No way to skip this waiting.

Battles are so monotonous on enemy turns, I do something in another monitor. Maybe that's why I get crashes ... trying to play windowed. I don't know. Battles are time consuming and boring. Wait, wait, and wait some more. Oh, you're incapacitated? No turn for you. Now wait again. Oh, look, still incapacitated. Just reload game, try to knock them into incapacitated statuses first. Or just explore elsewhere, come back with another level or two, and wonder why they were difficult at all.

Some waypoints should be closer, especially when a story quest sends you somewhere repeatedly. 

The quest log ... is unusable the more quests appear on the list. No search option. So you play along, get a message such and such quest updated, go to look. Spend 20 minute reading them line by line looking for this quest that IS NOT THERE!! Where is it? I don't know. I saw the message, I know the name. I can google it. I cannot find it in the log. The log is USELESS clutter. The internet is easier if you're looking for a particular quest, details, story, or what to do. The built in quest log in this game is unusable as it enlarges with various quest tidbits. A search feature would help immensely here. Same for inventory for finding something. Some prankster designed a chest that you must be in precisely the right camera position to actually reach. Thankfully, there's a skill to just put stuff like that into your inventory without that level of work. After 5 minutes of trying to copy from a youtube video, I gave up and used the spell. That's just bad design.

Game's a time suck. Get used to it eventually. Pace of combat is slow. You can click faster than the game is ready, ending up walking somewhere instead of actually using a skill from your hotbar. Camera is horrible for elevation up / downs. Other games have similar jerkiness in their camera movements as well. This game, you have to look around and that's difficult to have occur so much, even just rotating around to see the terrain for a battle.

Oh, and my favorite is staring at the game waiting for combat to advance only to see the message: Not your character's turn. Have to go click on your portrait to do your turn. The game didn't put it there automatically. Seems random when it occurs.

 I must've put in 30+ hours without a crash. Then, one day, crash after crash. Install new software? No. Change drivers? No. Skip playing a week or so, then put in a long time - all the way to Arx with maybe two crashes. Fire up next day, try a new game for kicks to experiment, four crashes before even escape Fort Joy. That's not fun.

Divinity OS 2 has easier inventory management (still a pain with a lot of stuff) and equipping gear, spells, etc. than Divinity 1. Game 1 is more stable on my windows 10. Game 2 crashes - a lot. That's what sucks the fun right out of number 2.

Also, divinity 2 has less of all that creepy blood emphasis of game 1.
It just crashes repeatedly :(
So no, I wouldn't spend a dime on it in this state. But I already have it, so I'm stuck with it.

I found this game to be a real slog to be honest. While I would like to give it the thumbs up due to the overall quality of the game, I found the multitudinuous quests cumbersome and uninteresting (much like all the NPCs), which required endless backtracking and busywork that felt more like a chore than entertainment. This immediately became one of my favorite games! 
Looking forward to playing Forbidden West on my Steam Deck too.. hopefully, it gets optimized and verified :D

played this game 3 times during lockdown. Had to get it for my pc. one of the best Sony games made
I found the combat system in this game to be a lot of fun and really enjoyed the world building around the story. No regrets about getting this game and completing every single quest.

Horizon Zero Dawn blends story-telling and exploration well. The main and side quests bring Aloy to a variety of locations that showcase different environmental details. From chilling mountain tops to arid deserts, there is plenty to see in the vast open-world.

However, the grinding needed to unlock crafting options takes the fun away from exploration. The amount of animal hunting required to carry more weapons and ammunitions is tedious and repetitive. Patience is needed to complete the necessary upgrades before the game starts to be fun, especially when playing in the harder difficulty levels.
Looking forward to a 2nd one, Really great game. Love it

The combat feels great, and fighting robot dinosaurs does more than justify the price.

The graphics are pretty good for everything other than the people, and if that's a sticking point for you then I would still recommend going with the remaster either via upgrade or buying it outright.
There is a good range on difficulty from Very Easy, to Ultra Hard. I personally found it to be best on Hard/Very Hard as it makes you use more of your tools, but I also find the jump from Very Hard to Ultra Hard to be a bit much compared to the others.

The writing is... mediocre. Many points are rehashed several times on several different occasions and the dialogue swings wildly between stock NPC templates and amusing if not interesting characters, most of which I find to be located in the DLC. To its credit the few times the game gives you a choice in how to respond it feels like the choice is actually different from the others, but they do all lead to the same point in the end.

The combat has unique systems, and a good number of monsters to fight, even with a fifth of them being some flavor of "large cat with a gun strapped to it back". There probably could have been a bit more variety in monster types, but the ones that do exist each have their own strengths and weakness to exploit, so combat feels more engaging than just "hit the thing till it dies". 

Overall a great game, and if your looking for multiplayer Guerrilla has just announced an MMO in the same world so keep an eye out for that.

I am..... okay with this game?

I don't like it, and I don't hate it. it's just kind of. There. I feel like this game is massively overhyped and then when I got around to playing it, it took me a good few attempts to actually get into the game. The story is mediocre and I had already guessed most of the major plot points from act one alone since it is really unsubtle. and every thing good about the gameplay is just done better in Monster Hunter, in which Melee combat is also viable in that game as well, I don't understand why this game got so much hype around it and why Sony decided to throw Aloy's face everywhere and into every collaboration possible.

So I mean, I can't NOT recommend it, but I also can't recommend it. If someone was to already own this game though and bring it up in conversation, I'd say 'Yeah, I remember that game, it was aight' but if someone earnestly came out and mentioned that they might buy it, I'd tell them not to bother and just go get Monster Hunter instead.

This game leaves me feeling very critically confused. it's slightly above average, and the machine designs are cool for the most part, but there isn't anything interesting here.

It tastes of the colour beige.

Late to the party on this game but I found it to be an overall good experience but not as exceptional as many reviewer did.  Lots of content in the game with some pretty cool quest lines.  

The weak parts of the game for me is that the weapons for most of the game are all kinda the same.  there isn't really much good loot in the game other than modifications and crafting supplies which makes exploration not as rewarding as I would have liked.  The skill trees are basic and the sense of progression in the game feels stagnant.  Despite these things I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

I originally played this on the PS4 and decided to get it on steam so I could make sure that I'd have it forever, but I just cannot get past the "tinny" audio issues during dialogue. The 6 hours of playtime is not of me playing the game, but is rather 4 hours of play and 2 of on-again off-again trying to troubleshoot the terrible audio. I'm playing on Windows 10 with a Sony 2.1 Soundbar. Sounds AMAZING for other games like Helldivers 2 or Split/Second. But for Horizon I just can't cope with the awful compression when people talk. I have tried several tutorials and am too fed up to keep trying.

I know I could play with headphones, but that just isn't the experience I am looking for.

Other issues include awkward body animations, cutscene/rendering glitches, and terrible facial speaking animations. This game looks and sounds like a port. And after years of being out and these issues still being present, it just isn't a pleasant experience. Sorry.
The humans feel more robotic than the mecha-dinosaurs...
I'll change my review when I get access to japanese voices.

A lot of praise has been given to this game yet it really does not deserve any of it.  First of all shooting at metal monsters with a bow makes no sense.  Bows are not meant to be used on steel since arrows will simply bounce off.      I found the controls to be awkward with Aloy bouncing all over the screen according to its camera allignment/movement.   The game is severely unbalanced as MC's weapons just do not measure to the games level of difficulty.   To me this game just felt frustrating and nonsensical.

Probably the most mid game I've ever played. I'm enjoying it, because I don't really have anything else I want to play right now, but I'm not really _enjoying_ it if you know what I mean. It hits the right buttons to keep you playing, but never does anything to make you feel anything more than "yeah I'm playing this game. it's fun. it's ok". Thinking about it, it's actually quite impressive in its average-ness tbh. 

Graphics are great, even 8 years on from the release, combat is fun, writing is awful, acting is pretty average. There's the guy from The Wire, so there's that. I wish there was a "meh" button for my review, but given that there's not, I'll not recommend it. You'll probably low-level enjoy it if you download it and don't have anything better to do though.

if you don't have much experience with great games, its going to be a great game. However if you've played games where you feel like you're really interacting with the world, games which immerse you instantly into their world building and characters you'll always have a feeling in the back of your head: "Damn this is kinda boring?".

That feeling never left. I really tried for 15 hours to enjoy this, I couldn't. The world is beautiful but soulless, there are a lot of characters but none of them really interesting. The gameplay is interesting, but only for the first few hours and gets pretty finicky. The story starts out interesting but is really, really shallow and predictable. 

I really tried to enjoy it, really tried to get immersed but the game just wasn't capable of it.
was a great game on playststion , on pc it is terribly unstable and crashes more frequently that a junkie in detox

Gameplay is good but the characters and story is down right terrible. Gender roles are reversed and all woman complain which I guess is accurate. Wish there was more males instead of the 3 which they are either bullies or the villian. Game is sexist and plays every movie and game cliche.

-combat is a mixed bag I think, I can see some people enjoying it but there's just something missing, even TLOU has, it just doesn't feel that satisfying to shoot the bow, and use the other gadgets at your disposal imo. at the same time, it can be quite strategic with how you can set up a fight and approach an enemy. then again, it's just not for me.

The game looks great and seems fun, but I can't play for more than a few minutes at a time before it crashes.  Originally, turning frame gen off made the game playable, pointing to a GPU/driver issue, but unfortunately, I can't recommend purchasing this with a 9070XT installed, though it worked fine with my 6700XT.  Something happens and the game crashes within 5 minutes every single time the game is loaded.  Perhaps with older hardware or an NVIDIA card it may be better.  Perhaps the remastered version works better with modern hardware.

I remember liking this game the year it came out, and yeah it has good points, but the underlying structure of the game is >AWFUL< even by the year standards.

Numerous glitches, numerous flaws in pathing, numerous flaws in graphics... it's a fight just to play the game. At a certain point the devs just got extra lazy and decided that if they didn't have time to make it actually fun, they'd just throw alot of different machines at you and say "good luck".

I had a level 15 quest in game that took me past rockbreakers that are recommended at level 24+, two of them. the level 24+ quest had me arena fight one. I would say this is one for the darksouls crowd, but it would also make them mad because you can just die or fail because the game says so.

The writing reads like a 14 year old fanfic, the combat is only fun after you get god-armor, and the hunter trials are broken.

I love this game, I really do, but this version of the PC port is hopelessly broken on modern versions of Windows.

tl;dr - this game, as far as I can tell, no longer works on Win11, at least 24H2. Constant sound drop-outs and crashes during gameplay, and the the game hard freezes when you try to exit. Best part, it won't release focus on the window, so I can't even kill the process in task manager.  Every time I've played, I've had to force restart my PC. 

Guess the only good thing is the upgrade to the remaster is only $10.00...
Game sucks.

took me a while to realize what was going on but the movement and target tracking just blows.  the dodge is so inconsistent and if you dodge at the wrong time they will track you.  arrows clip through people.  the mounts are atrocious to maneuver jumping on them sucks and sometimes the mount will just stop.  then theres a weird eye twitch with every character.  like theres a fly in front of them and they cant help but follow it with their eyes.  idk im trying to like it cause everything else is great but im having a hard time enjoying the combat.  maybe it gets better as you level? but i dont see how a mechanical flaw would get better later on.

I will never recommend a game with this kind of dodging.  it's just a super unfun mechanic.

Did not care much for the game. 
World and combat was very engaging, the scenery in some places is stunning, there's enough enemy and weapon variety to keep combat interesting with freedom to create your own unique play style.
The Main story not so much, on the surface it has a very interesting direction but didnt seem to fully "hook" me, I guess it just felt disappointing, it had a great concept but didnt take it anywhere exciting or new for me and Side quests range from boring/goofy/repetitive. 
Aloy feels a bit off in the sense that she comes off as having no personality, stuff just seems to happen around her and she's just reacting, like having no agency of her own, There wasnt really any character I was able to connect to on any level (Tonight's the night). I also felt the voice acting was mostly terrible with the notable exception for Lance Reddick. Rip
Ultra Hard Difficulty wasn't too hard either but hey that's okay, not looking for Souls game here.

Review: 5.5/10, buy it on sale or dont, Its your money...

My feelings on the game are a bit mixed. Generally speaking it's a good game. It's enjoyable for the most part. HOWEVER

First and foremost, there are a lot of things that were improved on:
- more and varying enemies
- improved area details
- more content
- improved graphics
- incredibly beautiful music
- world feels much more alive 

HOWEVER, here are my nitpicks:
- WAY too many abilities (my controller buddies will understand that one)
- parasitic game design with the abilities 
- puzzles are less creative than from the predecessor
- story is alright, however it feels like a downgrade from the story of the predecessor and doesn't make a whole lot of sense at certain points

At times it feels like the game is an Ori game in name alone. I REALLY liked the first game for what it made different from most games. I don't really understand why Ori needed weapons in this game? Especially since they feel a bit off for a character like Ori. 
Sure, Sein existed in the predecessor. Which you could technically count as a weapon. And certainly the first game had a lot of different ways to engage with enemies (stomp, throwing them into thorns, throwing glowing balls at them, throwing their own projectiles back, etc.). Perhaps I'm just thrown off that Ori was given swords, a giant frying pan, bows, spears, etc. in this game. Might just be me tho.
The sheer amount of different trees that can be found throughout the game make the trees much less special to find over time.
I remember playing blind forest for the first time and getting very excited for every tree I found. In "Will of the Wisps" finding trees does get tiring after a while due to the sheer oversaturation of them (not to mention all the other stuff you can find, like shards). 

I kind of wish that Ku would've played a bigger role/would've been playable for longer. 

At times it feels like the devs tried making a different game, but had to use the Ori IP for it (That's just my tinfoil hat theory tho, lmao)

If you expect puzzles like in "blind forest", this is not really the game for you. Stick with the first game.
This game focusses much more on combat and for that it's well done. The bosses are challenging and enjoyable (My favorite is Mora). Less abilities or a different way to implement them all would've been preferred from my point of view.
If you want a lot of bosses, play the Hollow Knight series instead.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps â€” A Breathtaking Journey of Light and Emotion

Ori and the Will of the Wisps invites players into a beautifully crafted world filled with wonder, danger, and heartfelt storytelling. From the very first moments, the game showcases a vibrant, hand-painted art style and emotional depth that elevate its platforming adventure into something truly unforgettable.

The game excels in its fluid movement and refined gameplay. Oriâ€™s expanded abilities make traversal smooth, responsive, and deeply satisfying. Whether youâ€™re dashing through forests, gliding across windswept plains, or navigating intricate platforming challenges, every moment feels buttery smooth and expertly designed.

Combat has been significantly enhanced. A new suite of weapons and abilities adds depth and strategy, making encounters dynamic and rewarding. From fast-paced battles to clever ability combinations, the system offers a welcome layer of complexity without overwhelming players.

Exploration and progression are deeply rewarding. The interconnected world encourages curiosity, offering hidden secrets, side quests, and upgrades that enrich the journey. Each new area feels distinct, beautifully animated, and filled with environmental storytelling that draws you deeper into the worldâ€™s lore.

Visually and musically, the game is a masterpiece. The stunning art direction, expressive animations, and emotional soundtrack by Gareth Coker create an atmosphere that is both magical and affecting. Every momentâ€”peaceful or intenseâ€”is elevated by the gameâ€™s impeccable presentation.

Final Verdict:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a breathtaking and emotionally resonant masterpiece. With its polished gameplay, gorgeous visuals, and powerful storytelling, it stands among the best platformers ever made. A must-play for fans of world-class 2D adventure.

â€œA stunning blend of beauty, emotion, and masterful designâ€”an unforgettable experience from start to finish.â€

First playthrough review time.

This game continues the style of the first one, with smooth platforming and a clear layout. The level design, graphics and gameplay are nice, and each area has different hazards to watch out for. I played both games with a keyboard and mouse, and the controls work well enough for the movements the game asks for.

The early parts are simple, mainly teaching basic actions. As the game goes on, the paths get more complex and the obstacles become trickier. Some sections rely on quick input, while others need steady timing to avoid mistakes. The difficulty rises at a steady pace, so the progress through the areas stays manageable.

Overall, the game is focused on movement, timing, and careful navigation. The game demands timing and focus in every sections.
A masterpiece, very fluid movements, graphics looks absolutely amazing. One of the best Metroidvania imo.
Masterpiece

This game is nothing short of AMAZING! The game play is great, the graphics are stunning, the colors are beautiful and the storyline is touching. I wish this game would get more recognition because it is a phenomenal game. I was a little skeptical at first because I the trailers don't show much fighting, mostly just platforming but there is a ton of fighting and, of course, also platforming. Enemies are tough and challenging. The levels are very well made with secret areas that are rewarding to find. This is a 10/10 for me.

A rock-solid followup. The devs really nailed the visual polishâ€”every scene element has smooth, detailed animations that make the world feel lively, and the extra layering gives the whole game a stronger sense of depth. There are also a lot of smart quality-of-life touches that other Metroidvania-style games should definitely learn from: the death penalty isnâ€™t excessive, thereâ€™s no pointless grind or â€œtrash timeâ€ and the speedrun challenges are super efficient to retry. Mess up? Boomâ€”instant restart. And when you finish a run, it sends u right back to the starting point eliminating unnecessary waiting or backtracking. Plus, all hidden items can be collected before finishing the game, so you never get permanently locked out just becuz the story moved forward.
[b]Downsides:[/b] Map opens with an awkward lag and doesnâ€™t remember ur zoom level. The pacing falls off right before the endâ€”thereâ€™s one brutally hard area that completely breaks the flow. New soundtrack doesnâ€™t have any standout tracks, mainstory is pretty forgettable, and the guidance toward new areas is really unclear.

Good game, but it has a very low amount of enemy variety. About halfway through you will have seen every enemy the game throws at you. Bosses are few and far between with most being just mechanically boring chase sequences.

The graphics are pretty, but often hard to read, especially if there are a lot of neon colours on the screen. 

As far as movement unlocks go, there are a few great ones in there, but most are just basic stuff like double jump or dash, or even horrendously reused ones, like triple jump, dashing underwater or dashing in the sand.

All in all I'd give it a mixed review. The story is cute, but not deep enough to carry the game.

Why am I here? 

Devs...when *I* play a game and spend hours unlocking abilities. I want to use those abilities. Seems pretty straight forward?
 
To those who may not know, in the game are "spirit trials". These are races through areas of the game, and each zone seems to have one, more or less. I thought it best to wait until the end of the game, when I had the movement skills before I'd attempt anything with racing. Come to find out quite a few of your abilities are deactivated during these races because....reasons. "It's because the races would be trivial! unfair! You should have done them as they came up!" I can hear people saying. But I didn't do that? I waited because I wanted the be able to freely move in the game. You know, the movement abilities I spent time to obtain in the first place. 

I wanted to potentially 100% the game, but this Dev choice was just so short sighted, I could NOT be arsed to care about the completion, even though I adore the world that was created. What a fumble....and because the game is too old now to address this...that's it.

Devs...I beg...STOP DOING THIS KINDA SHIT. Just stop....stop. Or, come up with some kind of explanation as to why it's needed, and I mean NEEDED to somehow enrich the game. If it's really not, don't do it.

This sequel is just a stright up downgrade in so many things. Im so sad that in just two hours it made not want to play it anymore. First Ori game was peak... So many questionable design decisions and changes for the worst on this one... Disappointing...

Who asked for less focus on the character. The camera zoomed out, combined with the insane visual clutter, is visually unappealing. There's an annoying excess of glowing and glooming and blooming that gets annoying really quick. 

Not to talk about the unnecesary change of gameplay feel in comparison with the first game. Here it just feels like enemies are carefully placed to interrupt you movement flow.

And the annoying meaningless side quests...

Such a downgrade.

In the year 202X, it is absolutely unacceptable to release a game where you cannot rebind the controller. That is a cardinal sin in gaming. The default controls in this game suck. Why are jump and attack both thumb buttons while the left bumper is barely used? Makes no sense. And before anyone says you can rebind with Steam, the prompts on screen show up wrong when you do that. I hate playing "Guess the button" every time an on screen prompt appears.

And it keeps asking me to sign into Xbox LIVE. I am already signed into Xbox LIVE.

Art is beautiful, but boss battles are poorly designed where the game seems to intend for you to just take hits, checkpoints are annoyingly far away at times, and there are too many speedrunning segments where if you fail you have to start over from the beginning of the sequence. Platforming hooks are often unresponsive which makes the speedrunning feel even worse. A rather frustrating experience overall.

Somehow I ended up with the burrow and water dash abilities, but neither of them worked. I was pressing the buttons to use both abilities but nothing happened. I thought this might have been a bug or something so I looked it up. Turns out, they both require the regular dash ability to work. Nowhere in the game or ability descriptions does it say this. A simple "requires dash" in the tooltip would have sufficed. I've probably beaten a dozen metroidvanias now, and have never been able to normally get to an ability that required an earlier, missable ability for it to work. It happened twice in this game. That's just poor game design, and instantly made me lose all desire to keep playing. Why even make those areas accessible in the first place? So I could waste more time backtracking to them later on? So the game wouldn't feel as short as the first Ori? GTFOH
Love the game, but the fact that you STILL can't change controller keybindings is mind blowing. Who even dashes with bumper buttons?!
Seeing this fuck ass ghost going flawlessly through all the races and having to pan over the entire race arena after every reset  is making me fucking off myself.
How can they not figure out how to offer a bordered fullscreen. Nothing else matters when you cant figure out the basics.

Performance issues have improved over its predecessor, however, refer to my review of that one for this one. These games aren't for me, man. Frustrating af out the gate. Beautiful visually with prologues that capture you but all that is undone by frustrating mechanics, frustrating direction & frustrating design.

Mild spoilers ahead regarding gameplay, nothing about the story though.

I really enjoyed this game but there were a few pain points which makes me hesitate to recommend it to my friends. The over-arching theme of my issues with the game can be summarized with 'I don't know what to do / where to go' - I should note I went into the game completely blind having only played ori 1 so I had no pre-info about the game.

1: some mechanical kbm skill is required to play(/enjoy?) the game, but people who have the needed kbm skills will probably figure out pretty early on that some melee attacks can give you some extra air time, allowing you to bypass obstacles and reach areas you shouldn't reach. I thought I was being clever by juggling my way up ridges and plateaus or by being able to get the relatively expensive triple jump as soon as I saw the merchant, but in reality I was progressing more than I actually should have been leading me to get stuck multiple times and sometimes even having to use back-up saves.


2: fake solutions (things that seem plausible but are not the solution). Example: I used the bash ability to juggle an enemy along in mouldwood depths (they provide light) to reach a location which I thought held a secret, but it was actually part of the natural progression of the game I had to go to later. It wasn't always clear to me what was a secret and what was natural progression of the game where I really shouldn't have had access to, and boy did this happen often.
One more example would be the soup kettle in the glades, I had not been introduced to the mechanic of fanning (with the feather, like bellows) the fire of the cooking pot to get it to erupt something and I think I didn't even have the flap ability at this point in the game, as I reached this area through 'clever use of game mechanics'. So here I am spending 15 minutes seeing whether the monster has to use his axe on the floor to break the ice (plausible solution), or whether maybe I had to buy the blaze ability to melt stuff (plausible solution) and so forth. When I finally did get the instruction of having to use the fanning to get it to erupt I thought I had to redirect the fireball to the ice via bashing to break it (plausible solution) and was very disappointed when it didn't.

The most egregious one was in the ice zone and I actually had to google how to pass this, but it's where a wall of ice is blocking the final door keystone and there's a kettle nearby. Above you is a monster that erupts when you get close and shoots a projectile at you, from what I could tell these monsters are used almost exclusively to provide you with a projectile to bash off of. Now right in front of the kettle is a wooden plank on which you can stand, but projectiles pass through, and this is demonstrated very clearly with the aforementioned monster. When you drop down into it the only point of interest is a shrine that needs to be lit up, so every fiber of my intuitive-game-logic is telling me that I need to fan the pot and redirect the fireball into this area, but it just isn't working and I can't figure it out. Turns out there's a shrine much further down which had to be hit by the projectile.

3: minimap. I am naturally a bit 'lost' when it comes to navigating, both in real life and in videogames, so this isn't really a stab at the world being hard to navigate but rather about how cumbersome it is to keep having to load up the map (which takes a while btw!) to check where exactly I am and have to go. I would much rather have a sort of 'overlay' map option that I can toggle freely without it having to load.
Perhaps some sort of arrow indicator would be nice too, to remind me where I'm going (before anyone says this breaks immersion: loading up the minimap every 10 seconds also breaks immersion). I'm thinking similar to what BioShock would use.

Finally, the minimap could highlight some things better, like points of interest. In Kwolok's cave (or whatever it was called) there's a door that's unlocked by pulling a lever after redirecting a bolt to destroy a purple wall, and for whatever reason I had done all of this except pull the lever and I couldn't figure out how to open the door, I had done pretty much everything else there was to do at this point in the game regarding the main storyline and was stuck. I had to google it (which made me go 'duh, how did I miss that'), it would be nice if it would just indicate on the minimap that there was a lever there. At the end of the game when you're killing creeper hearts it shows where the teleportation funnels lead to with dotted lines, can't we have something similar for levers and things? I'm just a bit of an idiot, I need the extra guidance (although I did immediately realize what the bell music puzzle was and how to solve it, but that's probably because I played the Abe's Odyssey and Abe's Exodus games a million times).

4. speedruns are annoying to watch
Too much menu'ing, interestingly something that plagued the first game as well and it's even worse here. I enjoy looking at different types of speedruns after I've completed the game but the menu'ing is just so annoying, even in categories which restrict menu'ing. I would have hoped that the devs (who I KNOW some of to be speedrun enthusiasts) would have added a 'speedrun' mode of the game which unlocks after having finished the game, that automatically skips things like cutscenes and prevents saving/loading (aside from autosaves like when you die in game), perhaps even has an in-built tracker (which the normal game already kind of has).

Overall this was an enjoyable game that I do not regret buying but I did find myself more frustrated than I would ideally like to have been and also far more than I have been in other types of games, and unfortunately this frustration was not a good type of frustration. I didn't feel like I overcame a challenge when I got frustrated, but rather 'I wish this was made more obvious to me' or 'oh God do I really have to backtrack that much? there's no spirit well to warp to?'

FWIW: It took me just under 15 hrs to finish the game on a blind normal playthrough at around 65% completion if the in-game time is to be believed.

EDIT: one more thing I forgot, the limited (3) ability options at the same point in time. I knew from the moment I saw the wheel of abilities with the potential spots available that at some point in time I was going to have overlap between abilities (as in, for example: I always have a certain ability on X and swap it out for another ability when needed, but now there's an area where I need both of these abilities, which means I want to press X for both of them due to muscle memory). Did we really need to limit this to 3 slots? I don't particularly care about having to swap out abilities (like swapping to regenerate to heal and then re-swapping to a damaging ability for example), but I do have a problem with the overlap as mentioned above.

This game commits a cardinal sin that immediately ruins the experience for me. It's a Metroidvania, so the map opens up as the player explores and unlocks new abilities. The problem is that, unlike Symphony of the Night or other classic titles in the genre, Ori and the Will of the Wisps lets you go incredibly far in the wrong direction before you discover you can't progress because you're missing a key ability. A better game would lock its paths behind the abilities you need for completing them. In other words, if you need the bash ability to reach the end of a hallway, a well-designed game would require you to use bash to even [i] access [/i] that hallway in the first place. It would not waste your time, allowing you to wander down the impassable hallway for several minutes, before discovering at the end of it all that you don't actually have the ability to proceed. At the very least, a better game would branch that hallway into other areas you [i] can [/i] access so you're not stuck backtracking for hours on end.

This isn't a tiny gripe. It's a key problem with the way the game progresses. Map design is absolutely crucial to a Metroidvania, and Ori has a poorly designed map. A good Metroidvania gently nudges the player in the right direction. If you discover you can't reach the path to the next boss, there's likely a route somewhere nearby that will unlock a crucial ability for defeating that boss. Since Ori never locks any of its routes, getting lost means getting [i] really [/i] lost. You start to wonder if you're going the wrong way or if you're just missing something hiding in plain sight.

A perfect example: I couldn't access an area of the game called the Wellspring. It turns out, I needed to use an ability to redirect enemy projectiles to open a door. The game never explained that I [i] could [/i] redirect enemy projectiles. It simply told me to use the redirection ability for movement, and that's all it required me to do with it for a very long time. So I was stuck for over an hour trying to get the enemy to shoot the door itself, trying to unlock a new path, and trying to find a new ability I [i] thought [/i] I was missing, all because the game failed to demonstrate the projectile-redirecting ability before it was crucial for progression. A good game teaches the player how to use a new ability in a low-stakes situation before progressing to a high-stakes oneâ€”essentially taking the training wheels off. A bad game expects the player to know the mechanics automatically, even when they aren't intuitive.

Ori just doesn't understand how game "psychology" works. A lot of negative reviews say the game is too hard. I disagree with that. The game is just badly designed, so it makes itself harder than it needs to be. Are you jumping incorrectly, or are you missing a power-up? Is the door ahead of you locked, or is there some secondary use for an ability you already have? Those are questions that lead to frustration. A Metroidvania should feel rewarding to play. It should be addictive to unlock new areas and create a stronger character. It should not grind to a halt every thirty seconds and leave you wondering if you're missing something.

Aside from that, while the graphics are beautiful, the main character is small, and the camera is pulled too far back. It's easy to lose sight of Ori on screen, especially when there's a light shining in the background behind him. The environments are lush to the point of sacrificing visual clarity. It's sometimes hard to tell what's an overhang and what's dangling moss, what's a thorny vine and what's set dressing. The music is fine. It's nothing special, but it fits the mood of the game and provides calming ambiance. The characters aren't the next Mario or Sonic, but they're designed reasonably well. Ori looks appropriately quick and nimble. The world looks like an illustration in a storybook, which matches the childlike nature of the plot. There are good production values here, but they're in service of an inherently flawed experience.

I knew, just by looking at it, that Ori and the Will of the Wisps would be the type of game players lose their minds over. It's pretty. It copies Hollow Knight. It tugs on the heartstrings in a Disney kind of way. But I think players are focusing on the flashy trimmings and ignoring the core game play. That core is rotten. There's too much wasted time, too many frustrating questions, and too many shortcuts taken by the developers who should have been crafting a thought-out, interconnected map. They prioritized the wrong elements and made something that is more "vibes" than substance.

5/10. Mediocrity disguised as something original. Copies Hollow Knight. Fails at map design.

Man, I wish I would have listened to the reviews. It's been a awhile since I've played such a buggy, clunky mess. To even attempt to compare this disaster to other CRPGs is ridiculous. I mean where do I start?! The bugged quests ( Looking at you Library Orb ) The aggravating map navigation, terrible crafting, the PS2 graphics, the VOICE ACTING (WTF?) The wonky camera, the lackluster "treasure"......I could go on and on but I want to get back to an actual good game.  No need to wish list Solasta 2 after slogging through 7 hours of this trash. Oh well, at least I got it on sale.

Play the 50 hrs. Get to see all the mechanics by hr 20 and have all your gear by 25 and you can only have 3 cool pieces at a time, but have 10 slots. Get railroaded at the end to a terribly fast paced ending that doesn't fit the rules or mindsets of characters just 10hr prior. Spend the last 2 hr with no long rest and no spells/smite/items by the ACTUAL final fight. Win that by the skin of your teeth. 2 team members incapacitated. And get ANOTHER ACTUAL FINAL FIGHT. All downed teammates still down and die to the immediate aoe coming your way. I refuse to replay ALL that. Just to maybe have enough health to fight the constant barrage of enemies with legendary actions. I recommend playing divinity original sin 2 or Baulders Gate 3.

I can't understand how anyone could ever rate this anything other than what I have.

This is truly the best strategy game I have ever purchased!

I have been video gaming 45 years!  I will purchase EVERYTHING to do with this game except the soundtrack, and supporter bundle.  I had zero idea how much Joy this game would be when I first booted it up.  I have tried the DEMO to Solasta 2, this will most likely ALSO be an instant buy as soon as it goes on sale after release!  The DEMO lagged on my MEDIUM END machine yet looked AMAZING.  So I MAY need a GPU upgrade :)

What really does it for me in this title are the SETTINGS in addition to the MASSIVE CONTENT!  Like my first play-through of the stock/vanilla campaign is set to IRON-MAN & STORY-MODE, and we will go from there, pure gamer DELIGHT!

i can't tell if i hate this because i was forced to buy it from a "friend" who promised it was amazing, or because this is like playing DnD 5e if your DM was a 12 year old with every syndrome possible. co op randomly disconnects causing hours of play lost, the story is the blandest "high fantasy" you can imagine, and i had so many moments where i would pick a dialogue option and go "my character would not fucking say that" in my head.

but, i am not my character. by virtue of this being a videogame and not an actual TTRPG scenario, i cannot pick any option in this game that would actually suit how anybody in my party would react to the situations presented in this game. nobody acts like sentient beings who have the possibility of having any internality. in fact, the game has so many "quirky" dialogue options that it just seems like all of the party actually hate each other and none of them want to be doing what they're doing, but the plot demands it, so they must.

the only thing i enjoyed in this mess of a game was the combat. but it is quite literally bog standard 5e combat, so it's very hard to truly fuck up. 

oh yeah, and having to pay for the DLC to get access to basic things such as the barbarian, druid, bard, warlock and *monk* classes across multiple $10 DLC packs is unforgivable. the greed is genuinely sickening.

TL;DR , play any baldur's gate (or other DnD module turned into a game, like icewind dale!) if you truly want a single player TTRPG experience. if you already have and want something new, make friends or join a table and play actual DnD.
The bootleg version of BG3. If I could go back in time and not get this game, I would. The way the characters look was enough for me to uninstall and hide it from my library.

I got Solasta because someone said itâ€™s like Baldurâ€™s Gate 3 but more D&D 5e. That sounded cool. Turns out, itâ€™s like Baldurâ€™s Gate 3 if everyone in it had the personality of a wooden spoon.

The characters look rough. They look like they were created by someone who only had access to five polygons and a hangover. Every time I made a new one, I thought, â€œI donâ€™t think I should be seeing that many cheek angles.â€

Early on, you fight a lot of Sarkas. Or Sorkas. I donâ€™t know, man. Theyâ€™re like discount doppelgangers that look like Koopa Troopas who lost their health insurance. They fly around, stay outta range, and make me wish Iâ€™d rolled a character who specialized in doing something fun.

You only get three male voices to choose from. I had four dudes in my party, so I had to reuse one. Now I got two guys who sound like twins who donâ€™t get along.

The gameâ€™s got crafting. And guess what: the best gear comes from crafting. I hate that. Thatâ€™s like finding out the best food at a restaurant is the ketchup packets.

The early areas are a lot of walking, not much fighting. I didnâ€™t sign up to be a pedestrian, man. The most fun I had was fighting a random necromancer and his skeleton crew. That felt classic. Everything else felt like waiting in line for that fight to happen again.

Anyway, I donâ€™t recommend it. Unless you like ugly characters, boring enemies, and crafting systems that make exploration feel pointless. I wonâ€™t be buying the sequel unless it comes with a charisma potion for the entire dev team.

Now my absolute biggest gripe with this game in the DLC purchases needed to get in IMO content that should have been included. I'm completely fine with the DLC being exclusive to different stories/ areas/ etc but freaking locking away normal 5e PHB races and classes it absurd and greedy. I'm not even talking about making an aarakocra or alchemist I'm talking about I had to buy DLC to get a half orc race or barbarian class. That is so greedy and ridiculous I hope the next game they include all the base 5e core classes and races.

Overall â€“ Blasphemous is a haunting blend of tough combat, stunning pixel art, and deeply atmospheric world-building. Playing as the Penitent One, you explore the bleak land of Cvstodia, an environment overflowing with twisted religious imagery and beautifully crafted, unsettling detail. The gameplay leans into deliberate, Souls-like combat. Every swing feels weighty, every enemy demands attention, and bosses are memorable, punishing, and incredibly satisfying to overcome. Youâ€™ll die often, but each attempt teaches you something, making progress feel genuinely earned. The story is delivered through cryptic dialogue and environmental clues rather than straightforward exposition, giving the game a mysterious, poetic tone. Itâ€™s the kind of world that invites you to piece it together rather than giving you answers outright. If you enjoy challenging Metroidvanias with rich atmosphere and art that sticks with you, Blasphemous is absolutely worth playing. Highly Recommended.

Gorgeous musics and pixel art visuals, responsive controls, ok, but the 3 big components of the gameplay (combat, exploration, platform) all feel frustrating (...although there's much worse, at least this game is not too difficult).

Here's the most frustrating characteristic of each point:
- platform usually requires high precision, i.e. if you don't jump exactly at the border of a platform, you won't grab it but instead will fall through it;
- exploration doesn't give you clues about where to go next so, every time you beat a boss and complete an area, you either look on the Internet or have to go forth and back in every single part of the map, until you find a new area you can access (and, of course, being a souls-like, this not only takes time but it's also annoying because enemies keep re-spawning);
- all enemies deal damage just by contact, and with punishihng hit-boxes (like, being close to a still enemy is equivalent to getting smashed by a hammer).
  This is not only another source of frustration both while doing platform and exploration/navigation, but also results in added frustration while fighting, in having to calculate not to end up too close to an enemy after an attack, and sometimes in not having a single safe point in the screen, when it's full of enemies.

The concept: it feels captivating, but then dialogues feel boring and pointless, I didn't catch the story, and I wouldn't dare reading the descriptions of all the collectibles.

This game is really annoying to play. Idk what word describes it but its so "animation-heavy". There's nothing innovative, all of the lore writing in place of "what the item actually does" is annoying. It's not challenging if it's just not fun to control/play.

Tries to capture what makes dark souls titles so great but fails to understand why. This feels like paying a groundhogs day version of that gameplay loop, instead of one where you adapt to new methods of approach and combat.

So far I love absolutely everything about the game... except the controls and platforming mechanics.
I hate those. They simply do not work properly.

I've played some horrible platforming sections in games prior, but this takes the cake, no the whole bakery.
Trying to grab unto ladders is 50/50 and trying to sword climb/hang is about 25/75.
It's just inconsistent and results in your death every time, which would be fine if it wasn't caused by poor mechanics.

I've played less than an hour and have already died to this about 20 times and not a single time to enemies

Can somebody give me a reason not to refund this game? Because if this is the experience with what I assume to be the easiest platforming in the game, I dread what would be coming down the line.

Overheard during development: "You know what gamers like, don't you?" "Yeah, Ladders!" "Gamers love to have their movement restricted and slowed down." "Let's make them really slow to go down and hard to grip on to, you need to be precisely on them and point the controller you also use to move with exactly up." "Cool, and have players jump from ladder to ladder. Players love difficult stuff!" "Let's also make the ladders move!" "Great idea, are there anything that instantly kills players in this game?" "Only spikes." "Nice, put tons of spikes then underneath the ladders, what else?" "Shoot fireballs at the player to push them off?" "And have it at the end of a timed parkour track to have players redo the whole thing if they fail, and make the beginning really boring" "Perfect! (...) I wonder why Hollow Knight doesn't have any ladder-mechanics?"

Seriously though, game is ok. Great graphics. Though to get used to. Frustrating at times. I enjoyed exploration and did not use any guides until right at the end. The highlight of the game was a certain singing boss, but there were almost no other highlights like it, and the rest of the game felt bland. The biggest disappointment was that in the end game, there were almost no additional bosses or challenges to reward going for the better ending. It was just a grind with a lot of backtracking and the same final boss.

There are simply lots of better options out there.

Great game if you're a 14 year old who watches beheadings in your free time and thinks the catholic church is the reason we aren't a type 2 civilisation yet. Would rather read all the Genealogies in the Bible than play through this sorry excuse for a platformer ever again. It insists upon itself

The only thing more vague than the story is the gameplay and movement.

Does your slide have i-frames? Yes and no.
You can slide through contact damage but not attacks or projectiles.

Does the enemy have contact damage to begin with?
You won't know until you actively attempt to walk into them.

Where does the player's hurt box and collision box start and end?
This is particularly bad with the jumping animation where he raises his legs making him appear like the protagonist is jumping higher than they actually are. Combine that with similar shenanigans for enemies and it's a guessing game for where you will take damage.

Platforming feels awful combined in tandem with harsh punishment for failing it. The only saving grace is that their timed platforming challenge courses don't result in real deaths. . ., but that doesn't stop them from feeling bad and clunky. Half of my deaths on these trials are caused by not grabbing a ladder that I thought I would have grabbed from visually appearing close enough.

The enjoyable experience the narrative can provide is overshadowed by the core handling the game provides as a metroidvania. I would not recommend the game.

5,5/10

As someone who beat the 5th pantheon in Hollow Knight the boss fights were easy, mostly cool, but the biggest enemy was the stiff movement.
Game finished in less than 11 hours at 78%

Also, I don't like the style of the narration of the story like in Souls games so I simply skipped all the dialogues and I judged the game only by its gameplay.

Easily one of the clunkiest experiences I've had with a game in this style. The controls and the level design are just bad, I don't really know what else to say. It's a shame, because the art design and the lore seem genuinely interesting. The arbitrary difficulty of this game just makes it plain not enjoyable. Most of the time it feels like you're dying because of the game design and the controls, rather than your own mistakes. 

I've also had a myriad of issues relating to controls with both controller and keyboard/mouse. Sometimes when you die playing with a controller, the game stops recognizing any buttons during the death screen, so you have to press a key on the keyboard and then all your inputs go back to KB/M. Even if you continue playing like that, since the game still recognizes the controller, it turns out the Dodge button doesn't work, which leads to yet another stupid death. You then decide to play with KB/M (spending some time in the control settings to remap things) and then think that you're good to go and enjoy the game when you pick up an item and realize you can't scroll the text in the item description, but you can with a controller. 

I'm surprised that there are still issues like this in the game given that it first released 6 years ago and it even got a sequel. Really messy and clunky, but it at least looks and sounds beautiful, which is unfortunately not enough to make me power through this. Unfortunate.

This game is all form and no substance. It has a cool style and lore but that doesn't mean anything without good game play to back it up. It is stuck between a metroidvania and souls-like game but fails miserably at being either one. Really boring. Do not recommend.

This is a *real*, officially licensed, completely free dating sim where your main objective is to:

* Attend culinary school
* Make life-changing choices
* And romantically pursue a bishonen anime version of Colonel Sanders, who has more abs than menu items.

Not a parody *of* KFC.
A parody dating sim **by** KFC.

---

### Pros

* 100% free, which is good, because youâ€™ll need that money for actual chicken afterward.
* Genuinely gorgeous anime art. Everyone looks like they escaped from Ouran Host Club and fell into a deep fryer.
* Youâ€™re a culinary student at the â€œUniversity of Cooking School: Academy for Learning,â€ which is the most legally safe fake school name ever written.
* Cast includes:

  * Hot Sanders
  * Your supportive bestie
  * Evil rivals Aeshleigh & Van Van the Man Man (yes thatâ€™s his name)
  * Professor Dog, who is an actual dog in a little chefâ€™s hat
* Thereâ€™s a secret ending, â€œsecret recipes,â€ and dramatic â€œcooking battlesâ€ that feel like Iron Chef on a marketing budget.

---

### Cons

* Steam tags say things like â€œSouls-like,â€ â€œFPS,â€ and â€œWorld War Iâ€ because the community is unhinged. Please ignore them.
* Choices â€œhave consequences,â€ but most of the time the real consequence is Colonel Sanders being slightly disappointed in you, which honestly hurts more than a game over.
* Actual dating content is pretty tame; itâ€™s less â€œthirst simâ€ and more â€œbranding exercise with sparkles.â€ Critics wereâ€¦ not impressed. Players, on the other hand, are just vibing.
* You *will* finish it and realize you just emotionally invested in a man whose primary character trait is â€œ11 herbs and spices.â€

---

### Peak Colonel Experience

* Trying to give a sincere answer in class and being out-performed by a literal cooking robot named Clank.
* Getting genuinely nervous about impressing Sanders with your mashed potatoes.
* Replaying scenes to optimize dialogue like: â€œIf I pick the wrong line, will he *not* franchise with me?â€
* Credits roll and you close the gameâ€¦ then immediately google if anyone has actually cosplayed this version of Sanders. (They have. Of course they have.)

---

9/10
Itâ€™s dumb, itâ€™s pretty, itâ€™s a walking ad, and it knows *exactly* what it is.
Came for the meme, stayed for the anime colonel calling my mashed potatoes â€œexquisite.â€

All Style, No Substance â€” A Gimmick That Wears Thin Fast

When I first booted up I Love You, Colonel Sanders!, I expected something campy, absurd, maybe even weirdly charming. A branded dating sim starring a hot anime version of the KFC mascot? Itâ€™s a wild concept â€” and in theory, a great setup for a parody or tongue-in-cheek experience. Unfortunately, once the initial novelty wore off, I found myself stuck in a painfully shallow game that feels more like an extended advertisement than anything resembling meaningful entertainment.

Visually, the game does a decent job. The character art is polished, and the overall aesthetic embraces the overly dramatic tone of anime dating sims with enthusiasm. But once you get past the surface, thereâ€™s not much there. The writing leans heavily into absurdity, but rarely in a way that feels smart or subversive. Most of the jokes fall flat, relying on randomness or self-awareness without actually saying anything clever. Itâ€™s quirky for the sake of being quirky â€” and after ten minutes, the charm runs out.

Worse, the â€œdating simâ€ mechanics are practically nonexistent. Thereâ€™s barely any player agency or branching narrative to speak of. Choices feel inconsequential, and the story rails you through a linear path with little room for exploration or interaction. Youâ€™re not really playing a game â€” youâ€™re reading through a branded fever dream with a couple of flavorless choices tossed in to justify the format.

And letâ€™s talk about tone. For a game so fixated on parody, itâ€™s weirdly toothless. It doesnâ€™t parody dating sims so much as copy their structure and coat it in fast-food references. There's no critique, no clever twist â€” just KFC product placement wrapped in anime tropes. The whole thing feels safe, corporate-approved, and strangely hollow, like someone tried to be ironic without really understanding the genre theyâ€™re riffing on.

I donâ€™t mind games being silly or promotional, but they still need to respect the playerâ€™s time. I Love You, Colonel Sanders! is all concept and no follow-through. Once you get the joke â€” â€œHaha, itâ€™s Colonel Sanders but hot!â€ â€” thereâ€™s nothing else to latch onto. No gameplay depth, no meaningful story, no emotional engagement. Just a long commercial disguised as a game.

Cute, Tim Burtonesque morbid survival game with all manner of customisable elements like spawn rates for all enemies as well as resources and many more. Play on your own terms. This and Oxygen Not Included are absolute gems whether you like hardcore survival or easy, mind-relaxing sandbox games <3

Easy to get started for non-gamers.  Entertaining. Though I've only played 8 hours on steam I have played a lot on my nintendo switch and love that it remains challenging even hours and hours in.  The fact that you need to start overif you lose keeps you on your toes!

It's creepy, chaotic, and WAY more addictive than I expected.

Donâ€™t Starve surprised me with how well it blends whimsical art with grounded survival mechanics. The atmosphere is incredible, the survival loop is addictive, and the game still holds up after all these years. Combat is the weakest part, but everything else pulled me in. For the price, itâ€™s absolutely worth it.

The Good:
â€¢ Amazing Tim Burton-style art and quirky tone
â€¢ Strong survival loop with great early-game pacing
â€¢ Realistic mechanics that actually matter (fire spreading, sanity, sleep)
â€¢ Weather, darkness, and nightfall create genuine tension
â€¢ Lots to discover and experiment with
â€¢ Time flies, easy to get absorbed

The Not-So-Good:
â€¢ Combat feels basic and predictable
â€¢ Early sanity confusion until you understand the system
â€¢ Building in a 2.5D space can feel a little awkward
â€¢ Requires trial-and-error before things start to really click

Final Verdict: 7.5/10

One of the better survival games out there if you like creepy whimsy and grounded mechanics. Combat needs work, but the atmosphere and loop are excellent.

My Recommendation:
At full price ($11.49 CAD), itâ€™s easily worth it.
On sale? Even better.
If you like crafting survival games with a creepy twist, you should try it.
It's a great game I recommend it for players who like adventure and fast and also slow gameplay. It was 100% worth the money

I would probably still recommend this game, but there's one really annoying flaw that I experienced while playing it that I can't forgive. The issue is simple yet big enough to have a negative impact on gameplay for multiple sections of the game - THIS GAME IS LITERALLY SO DANG DARK. I encountered a section where you're alone in a dark house, and I almost thought my system was frozen because I could barely see anything. This resulted in me fumbling around in the dark and extending that section of the game by like another half hour longer than it was supposed to take because I just couldn't see where to go. I tried everything I could think of involving messing with brightness, contrast, gamma, docking it to my TV, etc. It seems this is not an issue unique to me, because I found a couple of forums concerning the issue and none of their propsosed solutions worked. I guess this was the case for a couple of other people on the forums because they quit the game too since there are multiple dark sections of the game they didn't want to deal with lol. I just don't see how the devs haven't fixed something so glaringly obvious and annoying after all this time that the game has been released. I would've considered returning this and purchasing it on the Nintendo Switch but I already went over the 2 hour play time and couldn't return it so I didn't want to waste my money again ğŸ™ƒ

[i] Italian text [/i]

At first I recommended it. Now I don't. Gameplay-wise, there exists both the dream world and the real world. That's not what the game actually calls them, but it's what I'll call them. Each world has "sequences" to them. You cannot explore the entirety of the dream world before the real world, and vice versa. The first sequence of the dream world seemed decently engaging enough, where the rules that the game establishes for itself not being set in stone, and each interaction and fight feeling new and fresh. This maintains itself in the first sequence in the real world, where I was able to explore it and find all the connections between it and the dream world. And then after that...the rules have already been established, and the game doesn't particularly deviate from it, if at all. And those interesting parallels aren't really drawn anymore. So it's just a long, repetitive...well, I wouldn't say slog. But it isn't particularly enjoyable.
 Story wise...there is a twist that completely sours the story. A part of me doesn't want to reveal the twist, but then again, if you don't want to play a game again simply because you know the twist to it, what's the point of the game, really? In short, I can't sympathize with manslaughter. You, the character, have committed a criminal act. If not involuntary manslaughter, then staging it to look like a suicide certain doesn't help things, either. And THEN the main character and the character who helped you stage the body feel bad about it? They feel bad about losing a friend? Would it have killed them to, I don't know, call for help? Instead of staging it to look like a suicide? That's what a friend would do! Get their friend help! Now, I haven't actually reached the end. I've just seen enough spoilers through the community of this game to have found that out. And that twist just completely breaks my suspension of disbelief. Getting so attached to some characters in a movie, show, or video game just for it to not resolve in a fulfilling way...you know, closure...that's one of the greatest sins a piece of media can commit. I think that part is what's most egregious about this game.

Pros:
-good music
-good art
-great story
-charming dialogue, clearly the game has love put into it...

Cons:
-RPG game (Side quests are tedious, battle system is tedious... but this is just a personal opinion)
-90% sure the creator OMOCAT is a pedo.... Review would have been positive but I don't want to support them so here we are. (Don't take this as s serious allegation, instead research the MULTIPLE dramas surrounding the creator yourself...)
-This may fall under me disliking RPGs, but I really wish there was no/a higher limit on the number of saves you can have at once.
-Interacting with stuff is weird. Sometimes you need to press and hold, and sometimes it wont let you close out after a single tap. I would look at the bathroom mirror for 0.1 second (because you need to press and hold) and then be forced to look at that one photo in the bookshelf (not exactly a fan of that or that one unskippable boss's design btw [boohoo], but this last bit is an opinion also)

Overall, good game, would recommend, but maybe hesitate before supporting the creator

Before you read this review - if you're considering buying this game because you're looking for a good "choices matter" game with incredible time travel mechanics and attention to detail, and you haven't played Steins;Gate, definitely buy Steins;Gate instead, no questions asked. If you've already played Steins;Gate and you are looking for something that has some of the same types of themes, I guess this game kind of does... But be prepared to lower your expectations. A lot.

This game had a lot of potential and I was pretty intrigued after playing through the first episode... But then once I started playing the DLC episodes I realised pretty quickly that even though it constantly tells you "your choices will influence the past, present, and future, choose wisely", none of your choices actually have any real impact on the story. Whenever you encounter a choice that seems like it should have a significant impact, you can pretty much bet that whatever character is affected by the choice has already completed their role in the story by that point and won't really be mentioned much for the rest of the story (regardless of which option you picked).

One thing I did like about the game is the rewind mechanic. It is implemented really well, and there are quite a few good puzzles that make use of it. Unfortunately, this leads me into my next complaint, which is the abundance of bugs in the game that range from slightly inconvenient to pretty infuriating.

One of the most annoying bugs in this game is that the camera constantly locks up. I think it has something to do with "examining" something and then immediately trying to move the camera after closing the examine screen. It will lock your camera in a specific direction and make it impossible to look around for a while, and then after you walk around for long enough the camera will eventually fix itself (usually). And then there are a couple of sections where you can get locked in the rewind screen without any way of escape and you have to restart the section and go through everything again. Also something is glitched with the textures, it seems like the characters sometimes have multiple layers and one of the layers sometimes halfway glitches and they get super pale or something. Fortunately that one is pretty easy to ignore because the graphics are already bad enough that you don't really notice. Not that bad graphics really detracts from the overall experience, which is obviously a lot more narrative-driven than something that's meant to blow you away with visual fidelity.

Then there's the plot. The time travel stuff is pretty interesting and there are some genuinely clever ethical dilemmas that arise from it, but the setting really wasn't for me. Most of the characters are annoying (which makes sense I guess because they're all teenagers at a private school) and there's a lot of swearing for no good reason. And the main conflict is just weird, and doesn't seem realistic at all. Also, I grew up in Oregon and THERE AREN'T ANY FIREFLIES. I guess that's a nitpick, but that immediately broke what little immersion there was for me, lol

Anyway, I wouldn't recommend paying $20 for the DLC even if you played the first episode and enjoyed it. Your money is much better spent on something like Steins;Gate.
