Tedious game with a beautiful make-up. Donâ€™t Starve is one of the more popular indie games of the recent years for reasons I simply do not understand. It does look charming indeed. In fact, it has beautiful Tim Burtonesque style graphics and the game easily grabs the attention of anyone who takes a look at the screenshots. You start as a character whose only goal is to survive as long as possible. Similar to other survival games, you farm, craft, build to stay alive. The first problem with Donâ€™t Starve is that the grinding part is simply boring. Often, it feels like a flash game with a fairly bad user interface where you click, click, click with your left mouse button without having any kind of fun. If you are curious about how grinding can be fun, please check Terraria out.

Second major problem with Donâ€™t Starve is the permadeath. I am not suggesting that permadeath is bad per se, it can be quite enjoyable when it is done right. In Donâ€™t Starve, however, it turns the tedious game design into something unbearable. You may find yourself grinding for hours, just to die by a random encounter (and it wonâ€™t be your fault). Oh yeah, some might suggest â€œthatâ€™s what the game is aboutâ€ or â€œyou will learn from your deathâ€. Just give me a breakâ€¦ By now you should have played plenty of difficult video games to differentiate good game design from bad ones. Just look at the Souls series. When you die, you know you made a mistake. Maybe you made your move too early. Maybe you did not block the attack when you were supposed to. And if you die, you may lose your â€œsoulsâ€ and thereby some of your progress, but not the entire game. In Donâ€™t Starve, unless you are playing with a second monitor with wiki open, there is no way of knowing what will kill you. The only way to learn about what kills you is to be killed by it. And then you will start over, go through the tedious grind for hours and die again for another reason you could simply not prevent. In Donâ€™t Starve, you are Sisyphusâ€¦

Last but not the least, the combat is atrocious. Combat in Donâ€™t Starve is literally the same combat in any of the other thousands of flash games. If you have a good armor, left click the enemy until it dies. Or alternatively, make the enemy chase you and do your attacks while you are on the run.

If dull, repetitive games with poorly executed game mechanics are for you, play Donâ€™t Starve. If you have a friend who happens to have the same tastes as you do, play Donâ€™t Starve Together. But if it is the art style that pulls you in, your valuable time would be much better spent rewatching The Nightmare Before Christmas.

3.5/10

Hollow Knight isn't just a game: it's an emotional experience disguised as entomological torture. It makes you suffer, frustrates you, humiliates you... and yet, when it's over, all you can say is, "Should I start another playthrough?" That is its power: converting pain into art.Everything in Hallownest (its silence, its difficulty, its withered beauty) is designed to make you feel something real. Every fall teaches, every victory thrills, and every note reminds you why this Metroidvania remains the gold standard of the genre. So yes: thank you, Team Cherry, for ruining my nerves... but also for healing my soul.

Hollow Knight was my first metroidvania, and I absolutely loved it. The animations are incredibly smooth, and the art style is beautiful and iconic. At first it might look like a cozy little game, but you quickly realize itâ€™s notâ€”itâ€™s challenging, but never unfair. The more you play, the more satisfying it becomes, especially during the amazing boss fights. Beating them feels great every time. My favorite boss fight was the Mantis Lords one, which almost feels like a rhythm game because of how perfectly timed everything is. The developers created a deep and fascinating lore, full of mysteries waiting to be uncovered, even though the narrative itself can be a bit unclear at timesâ€”itâ€™s not always easy to fully understand what happened in Hallownest. The map is huge and packed with secrets, and every single area is memorable. After spending several hours in the game, you start to know your way around instinctively. All the characters are wonderfully designed, each one iconic in their own way. Hollow Knight is a masterpiece of atmosphere, challenge, and explorationâ€”an unforgettable experience.

This game changed everything.
Hollow Knight was a random exploding success, a genre definer, something every subsequent metroidvania is held up to and compared with. The gameplay loop is sleek and sharp, the map and currency systems solid, the charm builds customisable. Exploration is rewarded and there is no right way to play. The sense of wonder and dread as we explore the buried kingdom, the challenge of the bosses and the platforming, the utterly stunning world and character design, and Christopher Larkin's generational soundtrack, all come together into what I dare call the prime metroidvania. This game has held strong, the lore and horrifically tragic story keeping audiences engaged for more than half a decade, and is a prime example of how love for the craft always beats the love of cash. Gaming changed with Hollow Knight. It wasn't obvious at first, but the release of Silksong makes it all the more clear.

Omori, for a RPG made by a small dev team and being OMOCATS first game. Is probably one of the greatest if not the greatest of all time in the RPG aspect. Now the reason? The story, Besides the random negative reviews that sound like they were asleep while playing the game And writing the reviews. The games gameplay is fine, not anything groundbreaking but it is enjoyable. But the story, music and art (in cutscenes) is immaculate. It is the most deep game I have ever played, and I am confident that I will never forget this story, now I won't spoil anything because this is a game genuinely needed to be played blind. But if my word doesn't mean anything, you can search up OMORI on YouTube and you can see so many different YouTubers, big and small praising the game in thumbnails and stuff. It makes sense too.

The game has around 20 hours of gameplay and six years of real life development to flesh out everything from the story to the music and hand drawn and pixel art.

Now I get it, OMORI isn't for everyone, the game is rated M for a reason and it is not because of swearing, sex or violence (No Humphrey doesn't count), it genuinely gets that deep. And in MY summary? If you like RPG games OR like games or media with a good story, OMORI will GENUINELY be the closest you get to a MUST-PLAY (also it's worth the 20 dollars btw, crazy how pokemon legends ZA is 70 yet absolute dog **** compared to OMORI OR literally ANY other indie game.)

And key note, Omori in all is a serious game, so if you can't take it seriously, then you most likely won't enjoy it to the degree that everyone else playing the game did. Omori at its core is a STORY game. So I don't actually advise playing it if you don't like a good story, but if you do it's a near must play.

Letâ€™s cut through the pastel-colored fog: Omori is a confused, clunky mess that tries to be everything and ends up being nothing. Itâ€™s a Frankensteinâ€™s monster of mismatched genresâ€”psychological horror, quirky comedy, slice-of-life dramaâ€”all stitched together with the subtlety of a Tumblr meme dump. The tonal whiplash is real: one moment you're navigating trauma, the next you're watching a talking toaster crack jokes. Itâ€™s not cleverâ€”itâ€™s **** controls are stiff and outdated, a relic of RPG Makerâ€™s limitations. Movement feels sluggish, menus are unintuitive, and the interface design is more aesthetic than functional. Itâ€™s like the developers prioritized mood boards over playability.Combat? A snoozefest. The emotion system is a neat idea on paper, but in practice itâ€™s shallow and repetitive. Battles drag on with little strategic depth, and the pacing is glacial. Youâ€™ll spend more time mashing attack than actually thinking. Compared to other indie RPGs with tactical nuance, Omori feels like a **** characters are painfully flat. Sunny, Basil, Aubreyâ€”none of them evolve meaningfully beyond their archetypes. They exist to serve the plotâ€™s emotional beats, not to feel like real people. Dialogue is often stilted, and the attempts at humor land with the grace of a brick. Itâ€™s the kind of writing that might resonate with someone deep in a Tumblr echo chamber, but outside of that bubble, itâ€™s hard to take **** letâ€™s talk about the reviews. The praise surrounding Omori is almost cult-like, centered almost exclusively on its â€œsad story.â€ But thatâ€™s the bait. The game leans heavily on trauma and tragedy to mask its mechanical shortcomings. Itâ€™s emotional manipulation dressed up as profundity. Critics and fans alike seem so enamored with the endingâ€™s gut punch that they ignore the slog it takes to get there.

Played a bunch more games over the past week or so, so imma write a bit about themPlayed â€œbefore your eyesâ€ at toms cus he has vr n whatnotAll I had going into this is the selling point of the blink mechanic and the fact it might make me cry, so I didnâ€™t really know what to ****â€™s hard to describe anything about the game without spoiling it so Iâ€™ll say this; the way the mechanic of blinking pushing forward time is really innovative and clever, works amazingly in VR. Itâ€™s about the POV / life **** who grows older and you see his life unfold. The start of the game youâ€™re greeted with a ferryman who wants to hear about your life and then itâ€™s shown blah blah, thereâ€™s some twists and turns at some point in the game yaddaâ€¦ basically the way the story is executed and reveals is so clever and I think the medium of vr with this blink mechanic drives the emotion home because, with blinking enabled, you forcefully donâ€™t want to miss anything important, you wana not accidentally blink and miss out on a chunk of the story. I think playing the game with it enabled works well (I was advised to turn the mechanic off but I think it worked better having that experience). Metaphorically the â€œblink and youâ€™ll miss itâ€ idea is neat, for a story driven game you donâ€™t wana miss out on a chunk of the personâ€™s life or story and you donâ€™t know whatâ€™ll happen next in their life. Itâ€™s an interesting and very emotional game, from the segments with the ferryman to the sound design, writing and voice acting itâ€™s all ace and very emotional not only at the end, but just throughout as it throws around many heartbreaking moments so well, the littlest things are so sad to hear.Great short game and I get the hype for it. Only issue I had wasnâ€™t the game itself but just the vr being uncomfortable on my head after a while-9/10

review_text: What a surprise this game has been for me. This is the first speedrunning game I've ever played, and it was a great experience. I enjoy fast-paced FPS games like Doom, and now I can say I enjoy games like Neon White, even though it's not a **** is a puzzle gameâ€”a puzzle game with story and shooting elements injectedâ€”and it works like a charm. I typically don't like the Japanese aesthetic in games, but this one didn't bother me in that sense. The characters, though, are simply put: "lame." They have weird reactions, and their personalities are too simple. The story is also super **** could have been better if they had included more boss fights. But this is definitely worth trying because, from the start, you'll know that you are playing something original.

There's a lot style over substance here, which I could let slide if the substance was noteworthy, but unfortunately it's nauseating.

Life is Strange: True Colors reclaims the franchiseâ€™s strength, but its weaknesses, too.

First off, I need to declare my bias: I regard the original Life is Strange as one of the best, most memorable gaming experiences in my life. I liked the prequel â€œBefore the Stormâ€ well enough, mostly because it gave me more of one of my favorite characters. Life is Strange 2, however, left me cold.

So when I say that True Colors felt like a return to form for me, that is high praise. This slice of life story around another teen with with supernatural abilities (supernatural empathy instead of time manipulation) making their home in a small community inhabited by quirky, well realized character (Colorado mining town instead of Oregon coastal village) is just as engrossing, charming and gripping as the tale of Chloe and Max was.

Alex Chen, an orphan grown up in the system and our protagonist, has had a hard life, but things are looking up for her. Upon invitation by her estranged but loving brother, she moves to the small mining town of Haven Springs, and right then and there the game won me over: This very first scene is incredibly bucolic, full of life, color and golden sunlight. You can practically smell the fresh mountain air. That was the first hook that got me.

The second hit home only minutes after, when I witnessed the awkward reunion between Alex and her brother. Both of them didnâ€™t quite know how to deal with each other and the situation, and I could read every conflicting emotion, not only in the excellent voice performances, but in their expressions and body language, too, and it all felt so true, so emotionally resonant that I couldnâ€™t help falling in love with these two lovable, damaged humans trying clumsily to connect to each other, the captured facial animations were that good. 

These two things, colorful, joyful art direction and charming, emotionally resonant characters are the great strengths of this game, and they made playing through it a joy. Together, they convincingly create the idyllic atmosphere of a tight-knit community living in the ideal small town. Or would, if the actual plot didnâ€™t complicate things. There is actually quite a bit of socio-political commentary to be found, if youâ€™re open for that kind of thing.

The plot itself meanders a bit at times, but still creates room for a few incredibly moving scenes, the odd successful twist and ultimately a finale that for all its understated subtlety packs an incredible punch. Unfortunately there are a few mediocre valleys between these peaks of engagement, and a lot of them have to do with the implementation of Alexâ€™s superpower. While the idea of Super Empathy is fascinating and is used very well during the high points of the narrative, Deck Nine struggled to create meaningful everyday applications of it. But they couldnâ€™t let it lie either, thus Alex has to empath her way through way too many two sentence dialog sequences with no import and no emotional resonance.

As a controller-based adventure game, there are few gameplay systems to be had, and the riddles here barely deserve the name. There are precious few things to be discovered away from the beaten path. Innovation is scarce, after youâ€™re over the incredibly improved character animations. If you are not here for the characters, the vibes and the story, you might not have a good time.

But if you are, if you want to see Alex through her journey, smile with her, commiserate with her tears, you will find it incredibly easy to fall in love with her, and with Haven Springs. 

TLDR: True Colors is a return to form for the Life is Strange franchise. While it might be just one step above a walking simulator, this game will nevertheless charm you with its characters and atmosphere.

Me encantÃ³ la historia principal, el poder ver las emociones de las personas es increÃ­ble pero ciertas escenas y/o finales no cumplen por completo mis expectativas, pudo haber sido mÃ¡s detallado. Algunos personajes no captaban mi atenciÃ³n pero la ciudad, los minijuegos, el arte del juego en general y entre otras cosas lo hace destacable. Recomiendo darle una oportunidad.

The game was generally fine, with the first four chapters playing well. Unfortunately, the fifth chapter showed surprising laziness from the developers. Overall, though, it was an enjoyable experience.

Life is Strange: True Colors, a game I've been eagerly anticipating, truly lived up to my expectations. As a long-time fan of LiS, I was curious to see how Deck Nine would handle this installment, given their previous work on Before the Storm, which, while decent, was just a prequel with an existing storyline. However, True Colors presented a completely original tale from start to finish, and boy, did they deliver excellently.

The gameplay remains familiar, but with intriguing new features and gameplay elements tied to the protagonist's unique power, adding a fresh twist. The choices I made felt relevant, and I relished the various options I had throughout the game. The graphics are generally fantastic, but there was one gripe that broke my immersion - witnessing sudden changes in texture quality when new objects or scenes appeared. Additionally, there were occasional instances of unexpected FPS drops that lingered for entire scenes, albeit these were rare occurrences, happening maybe three or four times in the entire game. Despite these minor issues, I must commend the breathtaking scenery and the phenomenal OST. The soundtrack, in particular, was truly outstanding, capturing that classic LiS essence. The visuals might not reach the level of DontNod's previous works, but they were still stunning, and the facial animations were incredibly impressive, surpassing my expectations even after seeing them in the trailers. Can you believe it's still LiS?

Now, onto the heart of it - this game screams Life is Strange through and through. It radiates more LiS vibes than LiS 2 ever did, and Alex, the main character, is simply the cutest, most lovable character the series has seen so far. The supporting cast is equally well-crafted and captivating. While it may not have outdone the brilliance of the first LiS, I found myself emotionally invested in Alex's story right from the first chapter (now chapters instead of episodes). Her heartrending backstory evokes empathy early on, which is a definite plus. I did sense that Life is Strange and LiS 2 were more expansive in some ways - not just gameplay or story-wise, but in terms of the world they built. True Colors felt somewhat smaller in comparison, though I still adored the story and its universe and couldn't help but make some comparisons throughout my playthrough. There were moments where I felt the final episode could have been handled better, though it wasn't bad by any means; it just had room for improvement in certain aspects, in my opinion.

In conclusion, I absolutely loved Life is Strange: True Colors. It successfully encompassed everything that makes LiS special - it was great, melancholic, intense, and captivating all at once. It captured those emotional highs and lows I've come to associate with the series, leaving me thoroughly engrossed in the story. While I personally enjoyed it more than LiS 2, it still couldn't dethrone the original LiS from its throne (no comparison with BtS or Captain, as that wouldn't be fair). More LiS games, please! I can't get enough of this world, and I eagerly await any new installments that may come our way.

A step up in quality in most aspects - except for where it really matters. It looks a lot more polished, but the tame story and Alex's "power" really doesn't make for a immersive experience. The story is very weak and short compared to the first game. I tried really hard to give this game a chance, but ultimatelyâ€”it did not deliver.

This game failed to deliver similar LIS game experience previous games did bring me. The story looks rushed, some places I even think it was deliberately rushed. In the other LIS games you usually are given with options and choices that will affect your future, or the world around. Even though there are choices to make in this game, they don't seem too different one from another. It's like picking between two apples - one is green and the other is red: at the end of the day, it's still an apple you choose. So when you've finished the game and you're looking at the charts of other players' decisions you kinda think to yourself: so that is all there was? I almost never felt it for the characters, even during their hardest times. I suppose I didn't have enough time and opportunity to get to know them better. Then, when playing particular parts of the game, it suddenly feels like the character is a naive 12 y.o. girl. But seriously, when making some decision, Alex is being way too naive and for some reason over-simplifies some important events and decisions. The superpower itself is very interesting and is worth exploring, but we don't particularly see any development on this throughout the whole game.

This game isn't a sequel to Life is Strange 1. It's a perfectly told new story. Those who aren't open to that will struggle. If you're open to it, the story is emotional, heartbreaking, and captivating. A very successful second part.

Oh boy I never thought I would actually be unable to push myself to play this game. It was an absolute hellish mental torture. Daniel is just one hell of piece of **** brat childish and insufferable character. It's actually insane how insufferable he is. The relationship between Sean and Daniel is more unrealistic then having super powers, like who tf even have such patience would have to be a saint and a parent of this lil **** to actually treat him as good as Sean. Like holy mother of god couldn't they just have give us the option to abandon him and end the game early. In short, Daniel just spends the entirety of LIS2 **** up Sean's life in every way imaginable, and we're supposed to be cool with it and love him anyway, because blah blah he's just a kid. Sean's a kid too, and he sure as hell doesn't deserve all this. Anyway, I **** on this game enough, I stopped playing around midway in EP3 and the good things about this game are its amazing soundtrack and how good the art style looks. That's pretty much the only good things about it. Everything else is either average or below average like the super power of moving **** around is just inferior to what we had in LiS 1 and LiS True Colors and the story is just straight up dumb, Sean's decision is dumb and makes absolutely no sense story-wise and it's basically what the whole game revolves around. Oh and literally every single important decision is not up to you, Sean will just agree to all of Daniel's braindead moronic ideas that will keep getting you in all sorts of stupid troubles just so they can keep the story going.

TL;DR If you can't stand the most annoying 10 yo in video games history don't play this game because even if you can stand him in EP1 he keeps constantly getting worse no matter what choices you've made.

I thoroughly enjoyed the game... and VERY RARELY does a single player game grab my attention. I have played through The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct about 5 times now in attempts to save all the necessary survivors. EVERY time I have played through the game.. I have experienced different content (locations) I was not exposed to before...

I felt the AI was aptly responsive and worked very well. This is not the Left 4 Dead series... getting hit means soemthing... Stealth is somewhat required.

Sure, there could be more graphics tweaks, or coop, or pvp... but the game was just released... who knows what they may have in store later. Until then I found the game stimulating and entertaining all around. I also experienced no glitches or bugs.

At the end of the day.. this game was created for hardcore Walking Dead fans... which I am  and I love the game.

The game could be salvaged from a "marketing" standpoint quickly by releasing more meaty content for the game.. and not charging the players for it.

The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct is an enjoyable game that combines the claustrofobic feeling of being chased by walkers and the need to scavenge in a good way, but the graphics are very dated and some issues keep the experience from its prime.

For a 2013 game, the graphics and gameplay are very dated. Only Telltale has been able to make a good series of games related to the Walking Dead brand. Although years have passed, we still haven't seen a big budget AAA game from this brand. They ruined the game side like the TV series. If the owners of the Walking Dead brand didn't only care about making more and more money without spending money, a game close to Days Gone could have come by now. But after this hour, there's no point anymore. There are too many zombie games on the market.  They couldn't use it when they had the opportunity.

The Wolf Among Us really pulled me in from the start. I loved the gritty atmosphere and the way it mixed fairy tale characters with a dark, detective story. Playing as Bigby Wolf felt intenseâ€”every choice I made actually mattered and had real consequences. The art style was amazing, and the voice acting brought everything to life. Honestly, itâ€™s one of those games that stays with you. If you like strong stories, you should definitely try it.

While closer to a TV show or similar experience than an actual "video game," The Wolf Among Us has a rich and enthralling story with fantastic characters throughout. Enjoyable throughout its entire runtime, and leaves the player always wanting to find out more. Can't wait for the sequel.

Best telltale games after twdg. What a masterpiece and can't wait for the sequel. Bigby is such an amazing character and his development is good and can be great if they do it right in the sequel. The plot twists in this game are so great and unexpected too

God, I love this game. As tired as the concept may be for some, the idea of taking fairytale/fantasy characters and putting them into modern cities and realistic situations has always been something I dug, and it was done wonderfully here. The setting is vivid and easy to immerse yourself in, the characters are varied, likeable, and charming, the mystery is suspenseful and gripping, the choices and consequences are satisfying, and the soundtrack is brilliant. The ending has one of the cliffhangers that have haunted me most through my time in gaming, and I am both excited for and terrified of the sequel. Hopefully it lives up to the first game's quality and ties up the loose ends it needs to. (Sidenote I include with all Telltale reviews: Telltale's games often get a bad rap for having your choices not influence the story, but to me this misses the point of what they do. Variant endings are a nice bonus in games, and I enjoy them when they do pop up in Telltale's stories, but for the most part your choices aren't here to change where you go. They're there to change how you get there, who you are when you get there, and often who you get there with. They influence and change your relationships with the characters around you. The joy of replaying these games is to experience the different dialogue, the different reactions to you, the different routes you can take on the way, the different bonds you can evolve with people - not to have a wildly different ending. I think this aspect is overhated and sadly misunderstood by a lot of players, so if huge, game-changing differences are what you're looking for, I'd temper your expectations.)

Beautifully Written, Beautifully Presented. And for telltale the most Dynamic in experience, and if anything its not about branching paths with these games its about how you yourself engage with everything that will depend on what you get. and for me, the inability to not change some things is actually in the games favor, Because I would much rather have crucial points, and a focus be uncompromising. the Empathetic thoughtful and even emotion and intense writing have kept this game as the only rival to the walking dead. I just oddly wish the aggroget was higher then 80 but equally as so I see it as just, well its a perception on what is actually important in a game. For the type of game this is, its about the experience of seeing the world, seeing the position of Bigby and what happens to him, some things that you believe is more important, which again will not change everything but more or less, will change how you view everything in each subsequent play through. Your aggression and your softness, your approach to each character, it often change me, and made me feel a roller coaster depending on what I said, when I didn't keep track of what I said and whether or not this guy was gonna say the same thing anyways, I was feel the very grounded, tight and honestly intricate story that pulls no punches and containing bold plot twists. Immersive, and emotional to its absolute core, I just wish It was longer. not so short, only going 10 hours but It has no filler, just opting for you as a player to just feel everything and take your time, and feel the vibe. Brilliant game. Side by side for the Walking Dead honestly.

I gave this game an 8, but that's an advance. I really liked the game for its atmosphere, music, and of course the story itself. Lovecraft would have definitely liked this game: a short story about otherworldly horror. Maybe cosmic, maybe afterlife. Just the way he liked it. But for me personally, this game was on the verge of a 7 because walking around this island was very tiring, and because the dialogues required you to react quickly. I hate timed quests, timed traps, and timed dialogues, so for me it spoiled the feeling of the game a little. And the tedious walking could have been easily fixed with at least small fast-travel, like 4 benches in different corners of the island. And that's it. Because of this, I didn't really like running and looking for red frequencies first, and then running around the island again looking for these damn notes... and also hunting for different endings. Overall, it's an 8, but on a very-very fine line with a 7.
An excellent little game with a very interesting story. Definitely would recommend.

Storytelling is so good and it's actually like "Inception" It blows your mind and while playing the game you don't have to do so many things just look at the map and listen radio while walking. Besides our story(because I don't want to give whoever reads(btw I am glad you're reading this) any clue about the story) game has a good radio mechanic which is our literally only playable mechanic other than choosing our words which is at the very beginning I did not realize we can be quiet or we can choose to not talking. In the end, the game is all about the story and I literally started to play it and then finished it(yeah sometimes took a bathroom break as normal). You definitely should play it too and guys please make a good ending for us. See ya!!

I first played this game 6 years ago â€” I now reached an ending I hadn't found.
Oxenfree is a uniquely dynamic enigmatic narrative game that is as complex as the player's willingness to engage. It introduces characters begging to be understood despite their confounded pasts. The game challenges players to look beyond the surface, reminding us that all carry a history that shapes their present.
Oxenfree prompts players to reflect on the control we have over our lives. It's a journey through acceptance, illustrating that acknowledging the past allows for moving forward. I love how deeply one can dig for lore in this game, even extending to an ARG. 
Playing today, I was able to reach an ending I was satisfied with as I could find the confidence in myself to be proud of the choices I made, embracing the consequences: a reflection of my growth.

Ok so I was lucky to have been able to download the PC version of Oxenfree for free on an offer from Epic Games this year.
I finished the game in two days, and I enjoyed this a whole lot. The storyline was good and emotional. I like how they put everything in place and I honestly loved how the characters got flashbacks from happy moments in the past. The background music was good and it created the typical atmosphere which fitted in the game. I really liked the genre of the game, it was spooky but at the same time pretty emotional, and the best part was that everything was unexpected. Not once could I guess what would happen next, and that's what made this game more exciting. The characters were greatly designed as well and the graphics of the game was just amazing. Here and there there were a few glitches or the game froze, but that's usually normal.

For people who are suffering from loss like I have, I would definitely recommend this to you. It actually helps you deal with the pain.

I would rate this game 98/100. There were some things which were hard to figure out and there could've been some guides through the game to make it easier. The map could've also tracked the characters at the exact spot in the location so that you know where you are going and if you are taking the right paths. Other than that, I am satisfied with the gameplay experience! :)

I have seen a lot of people online saying how they liked Fran Bow but didnâ€™t like Little Misfortune due to the lack of puzzles. I can understand that because I have the opposite reaction for the same reasons. Fran Bow was a puzzle game that had a fantastic narrative while Little Misfortune is just a narrative game without the puzzles. I disliked the puzzles in Fran Bow so Little Misfortune was basically giving me what I enjoyed from Fran Bow and leaving out what I didnâ€™t. The art style is great and carries onto the credits which is a unique one. The voice acting is fantastic. Both Misfortune and The Voice. There are moments which are sad, funny and in between and they nail all of them. Misfortune has a interesting accent and way of speaking which is a mix of child and adult. There are a lot of points which are pretty macabre, to the point where I surprised the developers took it as far as they did  but was glad they did. The nightclub full of hamsters comes to mind. I donâ€™t think the game would have grabbed a hold of me the way it did if they had of held back. The music was also very interesting as it made me think of an Eastern European disco and a cyberpunk synth type of vibe. There isnâ€™t much in terms of â€œgame playâ€ here. Most of the game is you making choices and interacting with the environment to proceed. I donâ€™t say this as a slight against the game because the story was great. Had the story been bad then the game would have fallen apart because there was nothing else to hold it together but luckily it was good. In regards to choices when The Voice says that there are no good or bad choices, just consequences, they mean it. It made me think of the episode of The X-Files with a genie who when granting your wish would always find a way to warp what you asked for in a way you hadnâ€™t expected. For instance a person asked for a boat and got it but then realized they would have to pay docking fees, maintenance fees and taxes on the boat that they hadnâ€™t thought of and thus they couldnâ€™t even use the boat that they had asked for. There are a lot of things like that associated with the choices you make in Little Misfortune so donâ€™t try to over analyze it, the Voice will find a way to turn your choice bad regardless and I have to say that was a sadly realistic take on things from the developers. I was left with some questions such as just how Morgo was defeated; who was responsible for what happened to Misfortune; what role we the player played seeing as how the Voice talked to us as well but overall enjoyed myself. The middle part of the game had some stretches where not much happened in the story but it got past that.

I played Little Misfortune on Linux. It never crashed on me and I didnâ€™t notice any bugs. There was an option for V-Sync; PostFX and resolution. Alt-Tab didnâ€™t work. You could manually save whenever you wanted and there were 3 save slots available. You could also just use the auto save feature if you wanted. You canâ€™t pause or skip cut scenes. The game ran great with no drops in frame rate.

Game Engine: Unity
Graphics API: OpenGL
Save System: Manual and Auto
Input Used: Mouse and keyboard
Game Version Played: 1.0

Game Settings Used: V-Sync and PostFX on; 1920x1080
GPU Usage: 0-57 %
VRAM Usage: 685-1219 MB
CPU Usage: 3-8 %
RAM Usage: 2.2-2.7 GB
Frame Rate: 132-144 FPS

If you are willing to accept narrative over game play then Little Misfortune has a lot to offer. A great story; voice acting and art style. It has itâ€™s limitations and leaves some questions on the table but overall I came away impressed. It is equal parts cute; macabre; sad; and funny. There is a demo available for those who want to try it first.

Little Misfortune Ã¨ un gioco dalla trama accattivante che tratta temi importanti, ad esempio la depressione e di come questa venga affogata nel "Succo magico", si parla del padre violento della protagonista, di speranze, delusioni, insomma un arco emotivo molto ampio e ben costruito ed il tutto accompagnato da un black humor che sarebbe molto divertente se non fosse che nel gioco mancano la lingua ed il doppiaggio ITALIANO.

Little Misfortune is a walking simulator masquerading as a point and click adventure game. There are no puzzles of note here, and the game is a strictly linear path from start to finish.

I donâ€™t have anything against walking simulators, but a walking simulator lives and dies on plot and presentation. And unfortunately, Little Misfortune falls short on both.

This is a game that is deliberately ugly. The characters are all deliberately drawn to be â€œoffâ€, and everything is drawn to have a run-down and often outright creepy vibe. The main character has a veneer of innocence but obviously has had a messed up life with a messed up family, and the only really nice thing in the game â€“ â€œMr. Voiceâ€, the voice in her head â€“ is obviously evil, with the first thing he tells us being that Little Misfortune, the â€œprotagonistâ€ of the work, is going to die.

And while all of this can work if thereâ€™s a strong plot and purpose to it, honestly, this game isnâ€™t impressive at all in that department. The problem is that Little Misfortune isnâ€™t a particularly interesting character â€“ sheâ€™s a little girl from a messed up family, and she is more or less the same person at the start as she is at the end. The entire plot of the game is an excuse to take us through a series of rather morbid areas while being led on by Mr. Voice, and while the game does try to misdirect us about when and how Misfortune is going to die, thatâ€™s really the only â€œtrickâ€ it has up its sleeve. The game is very transparent about almost everything that is really going on, and the overall morbid and gross-out â€œhumorâ€ that the game leans on wears on the audience after playing for only a short while. It is just too one note, and as I never actually came to care about Little Misfortune, there was nothing to connect with here.

I canâ€™t recommend this. It is endlessly morbid, but the messed up humor of the walking simulator is basically three hours of variations on the same joke, and there is a great deal of meandering around before the work finally goes somewhere.

I would describe this as a very immersive card game that's quite different from the usual bunch. The game is divided into multiple main chunks, which are all very different from each other, I won't go into details here to not spoil anyone, but when you think you've beaten the game you just really haven't. Generally speaking, you'll get surprisingly attached to the characters and really immersed into whatever is going on. The card game itself is also good, once you beat the game you'll get access to ridiculously difficult challenges, whatever you prefer, this game really just has it all. Complaints? Not that many really, just the amount of back and forth you have to do with it, but that's not really a big issue
[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]

I'll be honest. I was very much on the fence about whether I wanted to play the full game after trying the demo but I sure am glad I did. Inscryption is more than it appears to be on the surface and did not fail to delight me all the way through.

The card game itself is fun. It is pretty much a stripped down version of Magic: The Gathering or Hearthstone, but the rogue-like campaign format suits it well as you can beef up your deck in ways that would be considered game-breaking in a traditional CCG against human players. If you ever fantasized about having OP cards in these types of games, Insrcyption can very much fulfill that fantasy. The drawback of that is that perhaps it allows a bit too much freedom; if you are at all familiar with the fundamental principles of CCGs and have some basic understanding of deck building and card value, the game will not be a challenge to you.

But I liked that. I honestly did not need the game to be challenging for it to be entertaining. I got to play it the way I wanted to play it, and that was fun for me. The difficulty curve is a bit wonky and it does somewhat lessen the impact by failing to provide a steady increase of difficulty, but this is a minor complaint on my end. The good thing is that it is highly unlikely that you will feel stuck or frustrated at this game for not being able to get through it. The focus here is on the experience rather than the challenge. Inscryption actually has a pretty elegantly integrated hand-holding system to nudge you in the right direction without being overtly obvious about it.

I have to praise the tone and atmosphere of this game. The music and sound design is perfect and the visuals set a unique, haunting tone. Even the camera movements bring about a sense of nostalgia without making the game feel clunky. There are certain parts of the game I would like to review but I am trying to keep this spoiler free, so I'll just say that it never gets boring and that there's always something new to delight your eyes and ears.

The weakest part of Inscryption is probably the "puzzles." A lot of these can be passed just by pure random guessing and maybe that was the point. If puzzles aren't your thing, you don't have to worry because they're quite frivolous.

Take your time with this game and savor it. Be creative. It's a good one.

Verdict: EXCEPTIONALLY GOOD

Interesting game. Inscryption is pretty decent, an adventure that changes gameplay and art per acts, tons of secrets, fun gameplay and a interesting lore.

Gameplay wise game is divided into 3 acts that play pretty different. They are each different in gameplay and style each with its own secrets. The first act is pretty fun, explorable, filled with secrets, great art style and a nice pacing. Second one and third one are kinda spoiler ish, but they change, the second one is more about strategy, you do your deck and also have a little adventure. The third one is similar to the first but its less luck based and more skill. The first one is by far the best, well done gameplay system and mechanics, more secrets than any other act, characters, a very interesting place you can walk on and its kind of short but it hits the sweetspot.

Art style and visuals are interesting, they are done with care and suprisingly good, the first and third act have a dark tone while the second ressembles more like a classic rpg (a lot darker). I liked most of the designs and i liked how unique it looks.

Story wise, there are 2 parts. The direct one which is easy to understand, but it is kinda generic, the first act does a good job in keeping it mysterious and interesting, while the second and third kind of abandon that or at least doesnt execute it as well as the first. You have the indirect one, told trough IRL videos and secrets hidden in the game which is pretty complicated, but can be fun.

As for other stuff, OST was decent, nothing id listen but fits the game neatly and thats more than enough. Controls and gameplay is agile for experienced players but you can play it slow until you know more the stuff.

Inscryption is more than a card game â€” itâ€™s an experience that toys with your expectations at every turn. It lures you in with accessible mechanics, then drags you through layers of unsettling, genre-defying brilliance. For fans of rogue-likes, puzzles, and games that dare to experiment, Inscryption is a must-play.  Geeksace  .  com

Act 1 :I loved the experience. Like i'm usually not into card games at all but this game's presentation and art style in general absorbed into the game almost immediately. It's dark as **** but not in a way that you couldn't see anything, you see just enough for you to put things together and try to figure out the puzzle pieces in the game. The game has this sort of gritty feel to it. I don't wanna say edgy cause it's definitely not that, but it's atmosphere is creepy and unsettling enough to make me wanna piss myself(Positive sentiment).

Act 2 :This part of the game is probably the most controversial one. It changes the presentation drastically. Even though yes the core gameplay is still the same turn based deck building card mechanics, the visuals take a huge turn here. From a heavily stylized 3D gritty horror-ish art direction, it turns itself to a pixelated 2D perspective. It was a necessary decision to build a visual direction that could explain the lore and lay out the general gameplay effectively. While i do think this visual presentation breaks the previous act's immersion and atmosphere, it was inevitable for this game to present itself in the more usual card game aethethic. BEFORE it brings you back to it's previous gritty/horror-ish atmosphere in the third act. I'm getting way ahead of myself here. But with that knowledge in mind, act 2's visual direction actually worked pretty well for a change of pace in contrast to the game's often gritty visual style.

Act 3 & overral thoughts :Absolutely my favourite part in the whole game. The visual presentation is incredibly good, the soundtrack elevates the experience, and stack it up with a genuinely well-made deck-building card game mechanics. Another thing that made this game popular is it's lore, overral story, and the Meta usage of how a video game works. They legit access some of your steam file for **** and giggles lmao i love this game. The story, the lore, and the creepy atmosphere immediately caught my attention and immersed me into the game entirely. I love it. This game is amazing. I could see myself playing this game over and over again just for the sake of it. The replayability of the title due to the rogue-lite mechanics is a huge part of my appreciations towards this game as well.
Why would anyone give this game a 10/10? This is a terrible game. All of you who would give this a perfect score are completely out of your minds. Every act is worse than the last. Avoid this game.

A fun game for the first 1/3 but then a twist COMPLETELY changes the game for this unique and interesting dark card game to something that pushes the Atari 2600 to its graphical limits

The combat system is by far the main player in this game's package. The diversity of cards, the amount of abilities you could stack up, this game's mechanics has so much depth (i don't think i've seen everything the game offers). Very easy 10/10 for me, absolutely flawless experience. I'd definitely blow multiple hours into this game in the future!

Un vicio infernal, llevo casi 100 horas y no me canso. Siempre estoy echÃ¡ndole partidas. Siempre aprendes algo nuevo, todas las partidas son diferentes en cuanto a estrategias y combos con las cartas. Estoy deseando ver que son capaces de hacer con The Slay Spire 2.

A Near-Perfect Blend of Strategy and Replayability. Slay the Spire is one of those rare games that hooks you in with a simple concept and keeps you coming back with endless depth. The mix of deck-building, roguelike progression, and turn-based combat is executed with near-flawless precision. Every run feels different, and the synergy between cards, relics, and enemies keeps strategy at the heart of every decision.
What really sets it apart is how well-balanced and rewarding the gameplay loop is. Whether youâ€™re a newcomer experimenting with basic card combos or a seasoned player chasing Ascension levels, there's always something new to discover. The four unique characters add even more variety, each offering radically different playstyles that keep the game **** art style is charming and distinct, and while the visuals may not blow you away, they suit the game perfectly. The soundtrack quietly enhances the atmosphere without ever getting in the **** you love strategic thinking, risk-reward decisions, and games that respect your intelligence and time, All in all, Slay the Spire is an absolute must-play. Itâ€™s one of the most satisfying and replayable indie titles of the last decade.

Roguelikes are, in some ways, comparable to shuffling a deck of cards: all the parts are there, they just need to be rearranged to make a random order. You would think, in this way, that a roguelite with the central gimmick of a deck of cards used for almost every action would be a match made in heaven, but Slay The Spire needed only one swing at it to prove to me that the idea should have stayed nought more than a concept for all of time. It's problem is, simply put, that it isn't an enjoyable system, and adding the two ideas together only makes for double the number of ways that you can be unfairly executed. Along with this, I just personally don't like the sense of "you will eventually just have to take damage", because it feels like if I get damaged or not is entirely out of control. Commit to dealing damage, or allow me to influence it directly. To sit in the middle just feels like poor design, and forcing that to then rely on RNG? That just makes no sense to me.

This game is as good as any Yugioh game that is focused on multiplayer can get, the gameplay is fast, precise and noob-friendly. It also has nice scenarios/missions that work as a single player experience and lore expansion that are pretty fun and add to the value of the game. The crafting system seems fair enough and its not pay to win, which is already a good thing in today's industry. It also has good graphics and an epic soundtrack that never looks or sounds dull. They also have done a lot of events to shake things up, though maybe they could have had some different modes, like a legacy one for those that are a little tired of the current meta, but that maybe is asking a little too much. But yeah, obviously a must play for those that like the franchise.

It's pretty good. The game's balancing is for sure out of whack but you'll still have fun duels. Any complaints I have would be toward Yu-Gi-Oh itself rather than Master Duel. Overall, this game is a great medium for playing Yu-Gi-Oh so I'd recommend it.

PROS

- Unlike other TCGs (Duel links etc), Master Duel is F2P. With minimal daily grind anyone can make one meta deck per month.
- Smooth Yu-Gi-Oh simulator with great visuals.
-This game managed to bring back to Yu-Gi-Oh, players that havenâ€™t touched a single card since 10-15 years ago. Also the replay feature is a great learning tool for not top tier players.

CONS

-The game feels empty. Thereâ€™s only the ranked ladder mode and the occasional event for a few days every month.
-It can be very cruel for beginners, especially those that donâ€™t even have knowledge of the TCG.

ONE LAST NOTE

This game has a different card pool (not up-to-date) and different ban list from the TCG. Many players find that a huge minus. But I feel that this is more a plus. This way there can be more diversity in the meta (for example Mathmecks) and also avoid bad metas (Tearlament tier 0 meta)

This is what brought me back into Yu-Gi-Oh!, and convinced me to but my own deck (Speedroids) in real life for the first time ever. Thinking about getting Floo for tournaments and such, and Ancient Warriors for fun.

I've been a fan of Yu-Gi-Oh for as long as I can remember. And while not perfect, Master Duel is fine. Any deck, if the player behind it is a good pilot, can climb the ranked ladder into Diamond. It also takes luck but we don't talk about that part. Just some broad points from playing the game for a year:

1.) For a game that's purely a multiplayer online battle simulator, the economy in Master Duel is above other popular online multiplayer games. 2.) Being a best of one format leads to more degenerate strategies like stun, obsessive amounts of flood gates, entries strategies dedicated to infinite negates, and ftks, that lead to some games being just plain unfun to play.

3.) The solo gates in my opinion do a fairly good job of not only teaching players all 6 of the summoning gimmicks, but also give players a insight to a number of different archetypes in solo mode so they can get an idea of what deck they would want to make in the game proper.

4.) I do wish there was more prominent modes besides ranked, the occasional festival, and maybe solo (if you squint hard enough.) Even with casual, team battles, and duel rooms, they either don't do anything to flaunt or show those modes off, or the only real enjoyment you can get is with friends.

5.) I wish there was more of an incentive to push in ranked. With the same rank up rewards you find in Bronze also being the rewards in Diamond, I feel like asides for bragging rights, Konami doesn't currently offer enough to sit down and grind on Master Duel.

Overall, like I started with earlier, this game is fine. There's things that I both like and dislike in this game. Hopefully in the future, Komoney can fix the flaws present in Master Duel to have it reach a new level of standards.

Yu-Gi-Oh in general, but especially Master Duel, are a masterclass in why the developers of games of this nature need to guard closely against power creep. The majority of duels are won before they begin based on the initial coin flip, because cards are so insanely powerful, special summoning and searching mechanics are incredibly unbiqutious and deck consistency is near perfect. Win conditions these days involve going first, and special summoning a field of heavy hitting monsters with various effects that negate anything your opponent plays. The player going second, loses before they even get to play a card.

The game makes no concessions for new players, you will be dumped in with very little explanation, no ability to pause the game, and a 300 second timer to understand what your opponent is doing, make your plays and complete your turn. It's not uncommon for your opponent to pull out a 20 card combo on turn 1 to set their field up and you'll be given zero opportunity to digest this information overload.

The game is broken, the community is toxic, there are many better alternatives out there, there's absolutely no reason to download this game.

I left this card game because of how broken it was and this application seemed like a good time to return to find that it is more broken than ever, there is not a single turn that you can summon a monster with 10001 indestructible effects and win in one departure. It's not enough to ban cards, this game needs a complete makeover.

It's a great deck builder that introduces a completely different mechanic to the traditional combat.

Diplomacy might sound like it's just combat, but with a different name, but it is not so. Combat works as you'd expect from other games in the genre. Diplomacy, however, functions fundamentally different and has potentially multiple arguments you need to deal with, while also potentially dealing with or ignoring the "side objectives". It's a refreshing mode and you often get to choose between combat or diplomacy.

This also features more choices than usual for this genre. Usually these choices end up making someone love or hate you, which can provide different benefits.

Deck Building Gem

Visual (8/10) I like general sci fy design and drawing characters, but card design a bit average, for example in battle deck you can find a lot of card with same dagger, also after upgrading cards they will have same picture and same design, so you need to double check description, for card game is a minus. Also music is average and almost don't change in different locations. Interface is very important in card games. So my first impression was - emm another one messy over headed interface, but after some games I can say that it's very helpful, you just need to get used yo it.

Gameplay (8/10) Gameplay is very addictive because you constantly upgrade your perks, cards, get new one and you can check different playstyles through one party. Great Idea to have more playable characters with different styles and story missions. On the other hand not so many perks are really unique and main strategy is pretty straightforward.

Story (7/10) Story is pretty average, but I really like characters. And the fact that to know full picture you need to play this game more than one time. I think that all sci-fi lovers can fnd some references to different universes.

So all in all, I like this game and still have it installed on my PC, so I can play it time to time. I definitely can recommend this game to everyone, neither you are big fan of card game, or just want to start your journey.

"Negotiation battled" are a neat concept, but it kinda falls flat. The main problem is that actual battles are what really matter in the end, and by negotiating you skip battles, and thus don't get to improve your battle cards. So you'll be playing a diplomatic playthrough, get into an unavoidable battle, and get curbstomped by ultra overpowered enemies with no chance to retry and lose hours of work.

It was okay. The fight system was very unique. But the enemies were way too overpowered making the game extremely unfair. The story was okay. The main plotline made sense. The rest of it did not. The graphics were okay. Overall, skip it unless you're really into the genre of visual novels and dark-souls kind of tough fights but in a different mechanic with turn-based manner.

Negotiation battles are original but donÂ´t add that much value to the overall experience and itÂ´s hard to fully understand what is going on. These just drag the gameplay.

My most played game of 2024. It's flawed, but still extremely fun. Fast paced combat, customizable skill grids, many party combinations, and tons of deck possibilities. But the best part: it actually has a campaign, which is rare for these kinds of games.

Deep, varied turn-based deckbuilding RPG with accessability options to switch off permadeath. I like the non-grim style and the perfectly polished UI works great with remote play on tablets. Story mode with 2D maps and quests is a great addition to the linear and repetitive structure of Slay the spire, which playstyle is covered with "realm mode". It's hard to put the game down.

However, the many (many!) mechanics are not perfectly balanced yet, a lot of the options thrown at you are not properly introduced and kind of overwhelming, as it is very easy to **** up your build while progressing, at least the first time you play. Has a steep difficulty curve too, the first two acts are easy-peasy but then it may start to become really difficult.

This is l the greatest platformer game I have ever played. The controls are extraordinarily tight and responsive, and the level design constantly provides interesting and fun new gameplay. The game gets a bit tricky at points, but is consistently very forgiving. The game also looks and sounds quite nice, and the story is a good edition. The platforming is based in a few simple actions, but the tech can get incredibly deep. I have played 300+ hours across multiple consoles and would gladly play 300 more. Cannot recommend this game enough to any platformer fans.

Un titolo da giocare assolutamente

A really good game. At its core it is just a platformer, but it has some really advanced and interseting mechanics, introduced gradually meanning you are never confused about it. The difficulty is just right, and there are plenty of ways to make it easier/harder. The story is really good, and the music and art are both fantastic. If you like platformers, play this game. If you have never tried a platformer, play this game. If you like good games, play this game. The only real criticism I have is that diagonal inputs are a bit finicky with a controller, which can get a bit frustrating. However it is a relativly minor issue.

For years I had been eyeing the infamous Cuphead, the notoriously difficult run-and-gun platformer that made everyone throw their hands up and say "this game is hard." I was never all that into run-and-gun games â€“ the only ones I enjoyed were I Wanna Be the Guy and Valorant (hah). Megaman wasn't really my thing and I always associated the run-and-gun genre with confusing hitboxes and awkward controls. I knew that Cuphead was visually stunning -- I could never stop looking at it â€“ but I just wasn't sure if it was fun. Still, its reputation of being a truly difficult game drew me in and I gave it a shot. And it's fun. Really fun.

I'm not good enough of a writer to give Cuphead the praise it deserves in the art and sound department. It's a masterpiece. Tasteful, clever, delightful, pristine, maybe even flawless â€“ these words come to mind when I think about what Cuphead looks and sounds like. But you knew that because you've seen the trailer and the promotional art and probably also watched some streamer or Youtuber play it. So read on to learn more about how the game actually plays.

One aspect of the game that I didn't expect to enjoy so much and also enjoy more and more as I play the game is the customizable loadout feature of the game. Being able to switch weapons, ultimate abilities, and charms seemed unnecessary at first, complicating what could have been an elegantly simple game. But I had so much fun switching out my weapons and abilities to suit my playstyle for each level that I can't imagine playing Cuphead any other way.

One of the coolest things about Cuphead is the strategic element. Make no mistake: Cuphead is first and foremost a skill-based game. You wonâ€™t be able to â€œstrategizeâ€ your way up to the Devil if you donâ€™t have some basic platforming skills, at least not on â€œregularâ€ mode. However, Iâ€™d venture to say that youâ€™d have an almost equally difficult time if you donâ€™t use your brain. I went into Cuphead expecting it to be a muscle-memory trainer in that Iâ€™d just play each level that was impossibly difficult over and over again until my fingers somehow learned how to dodge every attack and get the win. But I noticed that I could make a boss considerably easier just by studying the patterns and strategizing the most optimal moves. Where are the safest areas of the screen? When is the best time to switch weapons to maximize damage? Should I hang up in the upper portion of the screen to lob torpedoes or hang back to preserve my life? I found that I could magically make certain sequences that initially seemed impossible into cakewalks just by playing smart. And that is not a bad thing. Cuphead is not only an action-packed finger gym but also a game about experimentation and creative thinking.

Now, I'm going to start nitpicking. My main gripe about the actual gameplay of Cuphead is the frustrating RNG projectile moments. If projectile A is coming at me and I jump to evade it... and projectile B launches while I'm still in my evasion arc from projectile A and collides with me, I get frustrated. Now, you might just tell me to "get good" or whatever because there are probably Cuphead-heads out there that can 100% the game without taking a tick of damage but at my level, I have definitely felt robbed of my life just due to bad luck. Itâ€™s not a big problem, and I get why the RNG is in there but that didnâ€™t make it any less frustrating.

Another small detractor from the game was the order of difficulty. Maybe I found a style of gameplay that made certain bosses easier, but I felt that some bosses were way out of order in terms of difficulty. Not a huge gripe, but why is the Devil easier to beat than some of the earlier bosses?

All-in-all, I love Cuphead. My plan for this game was simply to beat it so I could tell people that I beat Cuphead. I didnâ€™t need all the perfect scores or anything like that, I was never one to be attracted by the idea of 100%-ing a game. I was going to beat it once, write this review, and be done with it. But Iâ€™m still playing. I canâ€™t stop. I donâ€™t know what Iâ€™ll do if I stop playing this game.

Verdict: SUPERB

The gameplay is more comparable to Sonic than Wario Land as there is a huge emphasis on speed and momentum especially if you aim to 100% which requires getting every collectable and secret in each level while keeping a combo.
Each level introduces new mechanics including transformations which are very reminiscent of Wario's transformations in Wario Land, there are also some difficult but fair bosses that are also similar to bosses in Wario Land. The art style is simple but charming and the soundtrack is extremely energetic.
The level design is perfect for speedrunning and the move set has lots of depth which made replaying levels over and over again for 100% incredibly fun.
All of this stuff may be overwhelming at first but mastering it made me feel like a speedrunner and gave me so much adrenaline, this is a game I could never get bored of.
Not sure if the best platformer I ever played but certainly the funniest. Originality is over the roof and despite being frustrating at times the fun of try again makes you keep going.

I didn't really want to play Pizza Tower at all because I thought it looked gross, but I promised my friend that I'd play it if they played Ghost Trick and here we are. The game does look gross but in like a sick nasty radical way. It is astounding how good it feels to move fast in this video game and I don't understand how Sonic couldn't do this for 25 years. Every part of Peppino's arsenal feels specifically made to make going fast feel like you just had intercourse in a sick nasty radical way. I love his dives and his different speedy punches they're really fun. I used to hate little things about Peppino's moveset like the way he dashes and the different ways that he throws enemies, but the more I play the game the more I am just infatuated with the way he does everything. It might be my favorite game to control behind Celeste it is so insanely good.

The animation is so incredibly amazing. If you hold down the taunt button Peppino just starts busting it down sexual style and that's chill. I love the little Tv in the top right that shows little buddy and how much character it gives him. I'm usually not paying attention because of how fast he is going but every so often I'll take a little peaksie up at the screen and this jokester will be making a very funny face! John Gutter is so fugly that it won't seem like it at first but every single other stage is an absolute feast to the eyes.

Speaking of the stages, it is amazing what lengths that they've gone to making every single one so unique. One stage you'll be running through the desert into a UFO and then you're going to space and then you're at the whims of Mort the Chicken from the hit game Mort the Chicken on the PS1 and then you're in Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria and then you are in war it is so fun. A big part of the stages that I love is that the devs are not afraid to make a gimmick to fit a stage and keep it in the stage. I love Mort the Chicken as much as the next guy but I don't think he would really fit any other stage in the game, and he doesn't need to.

When I first played this game it was a very low 8 out of 10, then after a bunch of time playing it was a 9 out of 10, and at the very moment everything finally clicked it became one of the easiest 10 out of 10s that I have ever experienced.
Pizza Tower is an awsome platformer evolved from the Wario Franchise. I can say its a must play, but It lacks levels and the game is a bit short.
[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]
this might be the best 2d side scroller on the market, good artstyle, peak level design , low skill bar yet high skill ceiling and genunely addicting gameplay, play it if you have not done so already
I hate jumping italians I the burning thermonuclear reaction of one hundred thousand suns

This game currently ranks #1 in Top 150 highest rated Steam games of 2023 by game reviewers. I had to see what the fuss is all about, only to find out that this is nothing more than a generic 2D platformer. The pizzas with the red lips make annoying noises. The running animations are very cringeworthy. The pizza guy always makes incredibly cringeworthy faces. To make matter worse, there is a stupid TV on the right-top corner where the pizza guy makes even cringier faces. When you pass a level, there is music that is extremely cringeworthy. It is over-exaggerated and tries too hard to be upbeat in a pathetic attempt at making players excited when they win. It didn't make me excited in the slightest. All this cringe made me grab my monitor and slam it against the floor out of frustration. There is no multiplayer, but I didn't expect one at a cheap price. Did I say cheap? The greedy developers are charging $20 for a flash game. I immediately refunded this garbage after nearly 2 hours. I don't want to torture myself any further with this garbage. Besides, there are plenty of free flash games on the internet. I don't recommend this game at all, unless you like looking at cringeworthy faces literally every second. â— P.S. I originally wrote this review back in early 2023, so that's when it ranked #1 on Steam and I had to see what all the fuss is about. All the crazy things that happened to me this summer made me realize it's best for me to just quit gaming altogether. College Football 25 would've been my last review. I have 0 faith on these lazy and greedy devs, so that was the plan. But after the deletion of this review, I'll postphone my departure. I'm not letting you toy-collecting millennials get away with controlling the narrative, and I'll let these devs know why it's a mistake to listen to you. I'll make sure they develop a highly successful $70 game (regardless if I like it) that will trigger the nerds, before I quit gaming for good. Anyways, I slammed my monitor because of this game. So it deserved this score, Metacritic. Speaking of which, I need to pick up a new TV after destroying it. When I come back, I'll continue gaming.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
A cute retro-style indie platformer, just like many other games in this genre. But oh boy does this game feel different. First, let's begin by what really matters : gameplay. This game is really fluid, with quick but still precise movement. The characters are a masterpiece of design, with their own sense of humour, quite absurd yet very effective. The time travel mechanic, with this completely different 16-bit style is a great game mechanic, that allows for exciting challenges. The Metroidvania part where the levels that you got through in a classic left-to-right 2D platformer show much more depth is a great idea, although some may find it a bit repetitive. And finally, the OST. Probably one of my favorites OST, with this 8-bit style music that where most songs ended up on my playlist. The NewGame+ mechanic also allows for some replayability if you really enjoy the game.
In conclusion, The Messenger is definitely a great game, and itreally is worth your time.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: (ReseÃ±a sacada de mi cuenta de Steam: APolChrome) The Messenger es un juegazo. Y es que cuando lo empiezas te esperas que es un plataformas mÃ¡s, que estÃ¡ entretenido, pero ya estÃ¡. CrÃ©eme que no. Por si acaso quieres jugarlo, va a contener spoilers la reseÃ±a, asÃ­ que te recomiendo no seguir leyendo o leer sabiendo las consecuencias. DespuÃ©s de esa parte plataformera, el juego se convierte en un metroidvania sobresaliente que tambiÃ©n combina de forma magistral la exploraciÃ³n y el plataformeo, haciÃ©ndolo un indie maravilloso. Voy a hablar largo y tendido, asÃ­ que poneros cÃ³modos y empezamos.Jugablemente, es una maravilla. Al principio nos presenta un plataformas de juego de los 80 que estÃ¡ bastante bien. Un diseÃ±o de niveles bastante bueno, bastantes mecÃ¡nicas que hacen a cada zona Ãºnica, unas boss-fights increÃ­bles y unos controles y mecÃ¡nicas de movimiento sobresalientes. Hasta aquÃ­, el juego estÃ¡ bastante bien, pero es que en un momento el juego pega un giro tremendo y ahora sorpresa, puedes viajar en el tiempo y tienes que recorrer todas las zonas como si de un metroidvania se tratase. Esto puede sonar a extensiÃ³n artificial. Pero es que aquÃ­ reside el nÃºcleo y mejores partes del **** exploraciÃ³n que se luce The Messenger es una barbaridad. Recorrer los mundos es una gozada (gracias a las anteriormente mencionadas mecÃ¡nicas de movimiento y controles) y realmente sientes que hay muchas cosas por hacer en zonas que son realmente pequeÃ±as. Los sellos de poder, por ejemplo, expanden la exploraciÃ³n una barbaridad y nos permiten tener retos mÃ¡s difÃ­ciles apartados de la historia principal. Pero de la mecÃ¡nica principal que quiero hablar es de los viajes en el tiempo.Estos nos permiten alternar entre los 8 y 16 bits (cosa que le da un toque cÃ³mico al juego) y asÃ­ cambiar el entorno en el que estamos. Esto al principio no se nota mucho, pero la mecÃ¡nica se desarrolla muchÃ­simo a lo largo del juego, basando muchos puzzles del entorno solo en cambiar de tiempo para poder avanzar o teniendo hasta mecÃ¡nicas Ãºnicas en una lÃ­nea que no hay en la otra. Donde mÃ¡s me han gustado las ideas a mÃ­ ha sido en el futuro. Siento que hay mÃ¡s variedad de jugabilidad, las boss-fights son sobresalientes y tiene mecÃ¡nicas Ãºnicas que lo hacen diferente.Audiovisualmente, es un 10. El juego visualmente es incrreÃ­ble, tanto en el estilo de 8 como en el de 16, ofreciendo un diseÃ±o de zonas, enemigos, personajes y de todo. Pero es que ya la banda sonora de este videojuego no tiene ningÃºn tipo de sentido. No entiendo cÃ³mo alguien puede hacer temazo tras temazo y encima dos versiones y que todas queden bien. Es una barbaridad. Encima mientras juegas, es como volver a los 80/90. IncreÃ­ble.Narrativamente, es donde me parece que mÃ¡s flojea The Messenger. No estÃ¡ mal y de hecho la trama me ha gustado bastante, pero cÃ³mo se cuenta la historia es un poco raro. SÃ­ que es verdad que los personajes estÃ¡n muy bine hechos y tiene un humor bastante bueno, pero la historia se concentra sobre todo en el final, haciÃ©ndolo un poco extraÃ±o. Aunque lo compensa tambiÃ©n con pequeÃ±as historias que estÃ¡n bien. EstÃ¡ lejos de ser malo en este apartado, pero simplemente, es donde peor estÃ¡ el **** resumen, The Messenger es una obra maestra moderna. Que no te deje engaÃ±ar ese estilo simple y de los 80 o te parezca que va a ser un juego retro, porque estÃ¡s ante una carta de amor al medio y a los juegos clÃ¡sicos, que sabe innovar en lo suyo y ofrecer un juego diferente y divertidÃ­simo que te engancharÃ¡ hasta que te lo pases. Un must-play sin ningÃºn tipo de duda

Aliado a isso temos excelentes boss fights e mobs estrategicamente posicionados para dificultar nossa aventura o suficiente. genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Pros.:
- Great characters and dialogues.
- Great idea of platformer then mutating into mild Metroidvania.
- Weapons - not many but effective.
- Mechanics mostly are intuitive.
- So many Easter Eggs about previous franchises and games (Ninja Gaiden, Battletoads at least).
- Friendly to achievement seekers.
- Special secret areas.

Cons.:
- I hated that "hit" jump. Why didn't do normal double jump? Because of that some seal areas are quite annoying.
- Phantom and Muse - I found these names quite lame for the characters. But it's personal thing.

The game is awesome. Buy and play :D

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: Fantastic 2d platformer/action game. It's not quite the level of polish and perfection that Celeste and Katana Zero are, but it's still an incredible game, with very satisfying gameplay and abilities. One thing with many lesser 2d platformers I see is that they tend to increase difficulty by added cheap tactics and unfair elements to the obstacles. I loved how Messenger was pretty straightforward, and you'd know what to expect with everything just by briefly observing it. Every success was earned, and every failure was my fault. If I knew how to clear something, and timed it correctly, I could do it every time without fail.

Literally created this account just to point out that destructoid review is absolute nonsense and is bringing down the score for no reason. Never did i read something as stupidly bias in my life before as this and almost every point is wrong. Game is not flawless but still one of the best platformers ive played in years.

It's an outstanding side-scrolling game I can't explain much more in detail about how great it is and why it is soo good, it's a fresh new take on the series that makes the game a step in the right direction for more installments.
