Good-
The core Shovel Knight gameplay has aged like fine wine; The updated look manages to maintain Shovel Knightâ€™s aesthetics without going overboard; Simple progression and story mean more time to actually play the game.

Bad-
Music can get repetitive; Randomly-generated levels mean less overall challenge.

Thoughts-
Ultimately, however, Shovel Knight Dig manages to pull off just about everything it was going for. The new roguelite gameplay loop works quite well with the protagonistâ€™s limited-but-adaptable move set, and the game does as much as it can to engender the â€œone more runâ€ mindset. It doesnâ€™t bog you down with an overly-complex story or complicated progression systems. All it really wants you to do is dig downwards, and have fun doing it.

The game's a pile of balls. Loses all the balancing from other Rogue Likes by having:

Infinitely spawning enemies.
The most sluggish combat (1:1 with OG shovel knight. But OG Shovel Knight worked with the combat).
An instakill drill which spawns when you sit in an area for a minute, meaning you can't plot your route or attack plan. 
A constant feeling that this should have been a regular platformer. 

It gets a 4 as it's music is amazing. But overall avoid it. Play Dead Cells instead if you want a decent Rogue Like.

Good-
The core Shovel Knight gameplay has aged like a fine fecal matter; The updated look manages to maintain shovel knights boring retro aesthetics while also going overboard; Simple minded progression mean big idiot like a whole lot.
Bad- Music can get repetitive, because it ****; Randomly-generated levels means the level design **** too. Thoughts- Ultimate cheeseburger, however, Shovel Knight Dig manages to pull off just about everything that's terrible with modern games, but I'm an idiot so I love it.
bad game, it's a disgrace to the original shovel knight, how they managed to destroy the core of the OG game is beyond my comprehension.

Amazing game! Everything fits together perfectly. The incredible soundtrack, the challenging gameplay, the charismatic characters, the difficulty just right. Only the story mode is a bit too short, in my opinion. Even so, I highly recommend it.

Really really great music. Great rhythm game to be honest. And it was one of those games where I listen to the music to this day. It doesn't matter if you are a beginner or a master of rhythm games. You'll love this game.

Just Shapes & Beats is amazing!
The main game alongside with its DLC Lost Chapter is outstanding.
The title of the game says whatâ€™s happening in the game - Shapes and **** how these shapes and beats are executed is magnificent.
Gameplay provides player with a huge variation of colorful and challenging level, yet thereâ€™s a casual mode, but I find original difficulty fair and giving player a satisfaction upon defeating a boss or difficult level.
Unfortunately I cannot say something like that about lore or story, the only thing I can say it **** it only serves as justification of gameplay.
Soundtrack is consists of lots of cool songs from some famous musicians such as Bossfight, Chipzel, Nitro Fun, Shirobon and **** the soundtrack is magnificent.
Also these arguments also perfectly fit DLC, but Iâ€™d like to add that Undertale Easter eggs, and even a whole level called Spider Dance is pleasing to see.
8.5/10

Ez but Good Game.
Big GG on that

I remember the first time I played this game; I completed the game in a single session (would recommend) with a friend in 2 player mode. The music is PHENOMINAL and at some points i got up and started dancing. Sometimes it can be a little slow doing the 3 level parts to unlock the next story part, but the boss fights make it all worth it. This game is a blast and I love it! It's sad that the game isn't very re-playable though as I crave more jsb. My favorite Boss fight is the pyramid as the music and visual effects are stunning! 10/10 play this game!
Sarebbe bellissimo trovare nella tracklist anche dei brani di undertale. Cmq il gioco Ã¨ quasi perfetto.
One of the most enjoyable split screen games for 4 players. Me and my friends had great time playing this.
Shapes, beats and extremely fun gameplay. (But the game is short 3.2 hours) Musics are great too.
This game has AMAZING music and really good graphics. It is simple, yet challenging, and the music and shapes/attacks are perfectly synced. A must for anyone who likes addicting music-based games.

I first heard about this game from a YouTuber I watch on his Favorite Game Animation of 2018 video. When I saw it there I found it kinda interesting, how can a 2d game with just simple shapes be considered one of the best-animated games of the year? I looked a bit more into the game and figured the concept seemed fun and it had some songs I like so I bought it to give it a try and boy was it worth it.

First off Just Shapes & Beats 100% deserved that spot on New Frame Plus's video. The animations are sublime. You'd never expect to see simple shapes convey such personality but Berzerk Studio does it so well! Everything in the entire game is just loaded with personality and creativity to the point that you can just get a feel for the dev team behind it and how much they enjoyed it themselves.

The only negative note I have on it is that my typical rule of thumb is that I get 1 hour per $1 I spend but in this game, I beat story in 4 hours. Typically this would make me more hesitant to recommend but with how beautifully crafted it is I am totally fine with letting this one issue slide. This issue could also be taken care of if the devs release a way to make custom maps, this would become one of my most played games if that was a thing.

All in all this game is wonderful and I would highly recommend it!
I like bullet hell games and rythem games. Its a pretty good game. Controls very good. It has a very simple look to it, well it is just shapes whit edm in the background so ofc its simple.

Unrailed!, tek baÅŸÄ±nÄ±za veya arkadaÅŸlarÄ±nÄ±zla oynayabileceÄŸiniz eÄŸlenceli bir tren rayÄ± dÃ¶ÅŸeme oyunu. AmacÄ±nÄ±z, treninizi mÃ¼mkÃ¼n olduÄŸunca uzaÄŸa gÃ¶tÃ¼rmek. Ä°lk oynayÄ±ÅŸlarda oldukÃ§a keyifli olsa da, 3-4 saatlik bir deneyimin ardÄ±ndan sÃ¼rekli aynÄ± ÅŸeyleri yapmak sÄ±kÄ±cÄ± hale gelebiliyor.

Fun game with fresh concept.

(Played via Remote Play)

There are many small indie games out there, many of them with exactly the same concept, idea, game mode etc. However, Unrailed! has something unique. You need to transport a train from point A to point B, while completing the tracks under its wheels. 

You need to collect stone and wood to build tracks, cool down the engine from time to time using a water bucket and keep an eye of the movement of the train at all times. The multitasking makes it fun, especially with friends, where everyone has a different task.

After each successful mission, you can buy upgrades for your train carts, making the later stages a little easier. However, in the later stages, the train will move faster and faster, giving you less time to complete the track.

When your little train crashes, it is game over. All progress, upgrades and carts are lost, and you may start over again. 

Unrailed! uses simple, "Minecraft" graphics which are fine for a simple game like this. The character models look silly and hilarious, especially when moving.

The sound effects and music are alright and just play nicely in the background.

Control wise, this game is very simple and easy to learn. 

Overall, I liked Unrailed! especially with some friends on a Saturday night. It offers some quick casual fun and with its unique concept, I would surely recommend it.

This gameis insanley fun. Even with just one other player. Even when you crash your train, it doesn't get frustrating because next time you have another tactic and will do better.

An addictive, relaxing cooperative experience that can be nerve wracking at times. Our runs always end in the most stupid situations which on paper shouldn't be that hard. Frustrating. It's hard to not blame your friends for screwing up, since everyone is kind of playing their own game. Other cooperative games are much more communicative which can be better or worse depending on your mood. Still worth the money.
Great Game, but it is very difficult and me and my friends rarely get very far.

Yet another game to add to the repertoire of co-op indie games like Overcooked. Game is straightforward, but can get hectic. Best played with a friend, and not the AI. The mistakes are what makes the game fun to play.

Alas, Unrailed does get boring after a while, as there is not much to do. It's a game about multitasking, and trying your best to do that well. The difficulty ramps up as you progress, which is the main driver for adrenaline. Overall, it's a cup-of-tea scenario which depend on what you are looking for in a co-op game.
pretty fun to play with friends, not much to do apart from the main mode, and not much single player to play, neat co-op game

As soon as I started the game with my friends, I played for 5 hours. It's a very immersive game. The price is also very cheap and there are no bugs at all. If there is one downside, it gets bored a bit easily. After 4 days of playing, I felt bored.
Best game. I like it. Best game. I like it. Best game. I like it. Best game. I like it.

One of the best game of all time. I like trains and this game. Thank you Indoor Astronaut for this
great job!!!!
Tries to force you to join a discord server. Not to mention the outrageous price.

Video izlerken, podcast dinlerken veya arkaya bir mÃ¼zik aÃ§Ä±p bir ÅŸeyler oynayayÄ±m diyorsanÄ±z tam aradÄ±ÄŸÄ±nÄ±z oyun. I'm not a massive fan of Rogue style games, but in Dead Cells, each time you die you somehow manage to unlock a small something that makes you feel like you are progressing: Maybe you reached a new level, got a new weapon, etc... that's motivating.

The graphics and animations are extremely well done, and while not an easy game it does not feel like the designers are trying to punish you.

[Final review after fully beating the base campaign | 16+ hours]

I fell in love with this game after fully beating the campaign. I've said so much regarding the game's presentation and combat mechanics. But genuinely, after beating the base campaign, i could say with confidence that this is my favourite game of all time--at least my favourite Rogue-like entry.This game is a complete, solid, and amazing package in general. Vibrant visual style, immediately memorable soundtrack, tight & satisfying combat mechanics, infinitely replayable--all are my categories for the picture-perfect Rogue-like experience.I can't promise that anyone reading this review would fall in love with the game like i did. However, i could promise that Dead Cells is an absolute must-play for any fan of the Rogue-like genre. 10/10.

The game is absolutely spectacular. The combat in the game is unmatched. It is one hundred percent not for the faint-hearted and it requires perseverance. You will die... a lot. However, you don't start completely from scratch. A problem a lot of people might have with the game is that it forces you to change your weapons. I like some weapons better than others. As I said, this game is not for the faint-hearted. But if you are faint-hearted and you already got it, here's some things to remember before you commit to hating the game:Even if you have your favourite weapon, it will slowly become less and less powerful as you go on. The further you go, the more powerful the enemies and items are, the items you have become relatively weaker. You can still find stronger versions of your items later on, don't get too **** can't choose all of the scrolls. Sure, the extra health is nice but it makes you much weaker in terms of weaponry. Are you forbidden from getting one or two from the scrolls you aren't maining? No. But just pay attention to your weapons and mutations, which class are they? Mutations and damage are affected by scrolls, not just **** you die, it's okay. The fun is not in beating the game but playing it. The story is interesting if you pay attention but it is not the best story ever written. You shouldn't be playing the game for the story, you should be playing it for the action. If you die, it's an opportunity to play again.

HECK YEAH THIS GAME IS AMAZING GO PLAY IT :D
It's really good I haven't played much but from what I've seen it's amazing :D

It is a beautifully directed game with marvelous and well animated graphics. The is simple on the surface but does get pretty deep. Its humor is great and adds value to the game. The best though is the references.

This feels a similar game to play compared to PSO or Diablo, when it comes to how you progress.
You get some pre-determined buffs after X deaths and collect cells to unlock upgrades.

What does not look the same is that the randomness aspect means you have to slog through the same dungeons looking for the way out, instead of getting to the new areas fast, as on more classic RPGs. The areas just do not change enough to be interesting.
It is the same type of upgrades scattered, same type of enemies, just spwaned differently.

There is a pretty big lean into increasing difficulty through not restoring your life, which can make this incredibly frustrating. There is not much room in the combat to feel you are getting better, it is much more related to what you pick up and what upgrades you can keep unlocking.

The massive christmas lights also don't help with enemy visibility and further deter from the combat being interesting.

Collectively, this has been the most frustrating game I've played in years. I have given this multiple tries but always put down the controller feeling like this is a waste of time and no fun is to be had here. At most, some 3h-4h of getting to know the game and the fun ends there.
While its art style and combat are decent, repetitive gameplay, punishing difficulty, and lack of story drag it down.

The game's way too hard. You're expected to die repeatedly and slowly make the newer character stronger through a process of very slow grind. That's a very artificial way of expanding the time. 

The bosses are usually way too overpowered and they attack almost continously. I used the Assist mode to change that to my liking so can't complain about the normal enemies. They were a fun breeze through.

The levels became more and more maze-like where it becomes less of a platformer and more of a search for the right path by revisiting the old areas over and over again.

Most of the weapons that you get are pretty much a repeat of what you've already seen just with slightly different levels or slightly different extra effects.

Overall it's a pathetic experience.

Very good. Please play it. Too hard. Dark souls of rougelikes (ik, overused phrase)

I can see why Hades is so popular. I just canâ€™t seem to get into the game. There is too much chaos and button mashing for my liking. It just feels to chaotic.

Hades 2 is a very disappointing for such a highly anticipated sequel. The gameplay is still solid, but it feels too much familiar. The story moves too slowly, and the new features donâ€™t really change much. Some bosses feel frustrating rather than challenging. Too bad,  the first game set the bar so high.

Hades II looks great at first glance, but once you dive in, the cracks show. The combat is messy, progression feels sluggish, and the magic of the first game just isnâ€™t there. Itâ€™s not terrible, but itâ€™s nowhere near the masterpiece its predecessor was.

I loved the first Hades, but the sequel feels like a step back. The pacing is slow, fights are unbalanced and drag on with spongey enemies, and the new characters lack the charm of the original cast. Technically itâ€™s rough too, with performance drops and clunky controls. Instead of fresh ideas, it often feels like recycled content packaged as a new game.

Got it gifted to me after watching two of my friends froth out the mouth over it and uhhhhh it's fine. Sure, the graphics are really polished and the high speed gameplay is really engaging, but the music and voice lines are legitimately so annoying to me that I've just been playing with most of the audio muted. Not to mention, some of the enemies themselves often end up turning the combat into feeling more akin to something like Contra with the infuriating amount of bullets and attacks being thrown at you. Most of the actual gameplay itself is fine, but there's definitely more I dislike than enjoy.

this game is one of the worst roguelikes in terms of gameplay. It's literally Click-Click Dash. You just click on enemies from afar, and the game takes the worst aspects of combat in isometric games - the enemies are dumb, there are a lot of them, and they're so fat that you have to click on them for about 30 seconds. The gameplay is terrible, there's no depth, and there's nowhere to explore. The build system is the same - there's no variety or depth to the build - you choose one thing and focus on that for the entire run, because if you try to focus on multiple things, you won't have enough damage. It hurts me to see that many people consider this game to be one of the best roguelikes. It's not a bad game, but it's a shame for the genre as a roguelike. It's a roguelike for those who have never played a roguelike before.

This game is one of the most original and amazing games ever created. I wish the devs would hire the guy who made the Multiverse mod and create FTL 2. Playing on the PC is slightly less fun than on the iPad as the controls are even more smooth, but there is no Multiverse on the iPad. Please make multiverse for iPad. Please make FTL 2.

Fight or flee? Should I buy this weapon or hire this crew member? Do I hit the weapon control first or the shields? Every decision is a test of my judgment, and winning isnâ€™t just about skillâ€”itâ€™s about a bit of luck too. I love that I can pause anytime and issue orders, completely removing the need for twitch reflexes.

FTL. The classic roguelike space captain sim. It's a ton of fun, with maybe a bit too much rng that means on some runs you can feel like you couldn't reallly have done anything more and lose horribly. It'a maybe a bit too punishing. Is that just me being not good though? Potentially. There may well be mods that help balance the game a bit and I would look something like that up if I was going to play it again on PC.

Still highly recommended and probably cheap as chips these days in a sale.

Very satisfying roguelike that is made so much better by it's dedicated modding community. 

Multiverse makes FTL so much deeper, complicated and customizable. On average, runs are probably easier with default options on normal mode but the game becomes more well balanced (with some rather extreme exceptions like intentionally over or underpowered cruisers). Overpowered things from base game are nerfed and useless things are made more viable.

Fun game to play in between bigger games. Can be quite addictive ('just one more run'). RNG can be brutal, but that's part of the fun. The runs don't take that long, so you can just start another. One of my palate cleansers after I finish a bigger game.

BEST. GAME. EVER. MADE.!!!!

I hope god makes a special place for the creators.

Only comparable to BG3, don't try to convince me otherwise.

Recently, I gave Deadcell another go, but unfortunately I found that the game's mechanics ran out of steam rather quickly, and that there was too much linearity in the game's progression, based on collecting cells to unlock upgraded items. This meant that I had to finish the game several times to see what would happen next, and then start again with an extra level of difficulty. After 1 or 2 days, I'd get fed up, drop the controller and never want to pick it up again to continue the adventure, and it was the same with Darkest Dungeon...

FTL is the only roguelike to have kept me going for more than 135 hours. And it's the one with the least scenery, and no carrot for upgrading your ship post-mortem. It's a game that demands insane creativity and great foresight to optimize your ship and the confrontations. All the elements that make up the game are both original and complement each other so well that it's hard to get bored even after hundreds of hours. The possible combinations and strategies are virtually unlimited, making each game unique! That's why, in my opinion, FTL is one of the best roguelikes ever released.
If you want more details, I've put together a review on youtube about this game :
[french review]
 ****/Ik2RGP_LAN

To sum up: 

 The positives
imaginative, diverse and fun combat systemthe number of possible combinations for your ship.
The uniqueness of each game, which forces you to think and find the best strategy to optimize your ship, making every run unique.
The music.

Negative points :

Frustrating RNG, especially for novices.
You have to achieve a run to unlock new ships.
The game is very difficult.

A legendary game that was so fun and entertaining, it spawned multiple sequels. The developer was so good at making it, it even spawned countless mods and fan remakes. In addition, one of the few games where DLC was released after launch, for free! This effectively added a significant amount of content to the game for nothing, and further boosted it into the popularity it once had. Easily one of the best strategy games to exist, specifically in the â€œspaceâ€ genre.

FTL is composed of wide variety of possible scenarios that are arranged randomly to create a unique run. Each play is distinct and creates a personal story of individual player's struggle. Here is just another one of them.

I started with federation cruiser. Defying odds I progressed through increasingly difficult sectors before arriving to the Nebula under the control of Slugs. There I resolved a few challenging combat scenarios, taking heavy damage because I didn't encounter any appropriate equipment and didn't really have an opportunity to upgrade weapons in earlier sectors. Luckily I found one more advanced weapon in stock, randomly found earlier. But I couldn't power it yet, needing a separate upgrade. With that in mind I pressed on. Eventually I arrived at a sector that housed a planet with several moons. The slug found on the surface quizzed me about the number of natural satellites orbiting the planet and taking advantage of my momentous distraction stole some of my missiles, drone parts, all of my exp and most of my remaining fuel. With exp gone and without a way to upgrade my system I didn't have realistic way to win future altercations but I pressed on.
I encountered a dangerous ship. I disabled shields using my remaining missiles so I could actually damage systems using my pitiful lasers. All of my shots missed and I without ammo I couldn't switch to missile weapons. I dropped the shields, disabled the weapons, ordered all of doors opened to vent the ship of oxygen and concentrated the crew in one large chamber so they would suffocate. After they slowly and (I hope) painfully died I uninstalled the damn game.

FTL is based entirely on your luck. It is a digital version of Russian roulette. Some weapons, augmentations and systems are just better than others. If you luck out and get them advancing through the game becomes trivial. If you do not it is impossible.
I understand that it is alluring to some people as they like the risk. But I would advise anybody who likes to have any actual agency to stay away from the game.

There are achievements that you can collect and unlock bonus ships. Unfortunately a standard run seems to be at least two hours long and if you die before getting an achievement you don't unlock anything. In that case each minute of your life spent playing is retroactively wasted away. There is absolutely no payoff if you lose. A standard tagline for rogue-lites is "Losing is fun". But this game simply isn't fun.

On the other hand soundtrack is awesome. I would say that if you can get it without the game it's worth buying. Just don't buy FTL and don't give it any bump in it's statistics.

(ReseÃ±a sacada de mi cuenta de Steam: APolChrome) Soy bastante principiante en esto de los rogue-lites, pero sÃ© que Enter the Gungeon es un gran referente del gÃ©nero. Y despuÃ©s de jugar durante 10 horas, entiendo por quÃ©. Enter the Gungeon es un juegazo que lleva muy bien el gÃ©nero. Ahora voy a hablar en profundidad del juego asÃ­ que, **** Enter the Gungeon, tendremos que explorar las Armazmorras, unas dungeons de toda la vida solo que tienen como temÃ¡tica (intentad adivinarlo) las armas. Se dividen en varias recÃ¡maras, y en cada una hay diferentes enemigos, tipos de sala y jefes. Jugablemente es una locura. El sistema de combate es sin duda lo mejor, teniendo en cuenta que han hecho un sistema de apuntado que funciona muy bien para ser en 2 dimensiones. Al sistema de combate se le aÃ±ade la profundidad de objetos (tanto activos como pasivos) y de diferentes armas (algunas muy graciosas por cierto) que hacen cada run realmente Ãºnica. Los enemigos y bosses de las mazmorras (aunque me quedan muchos por descubrir, sobre todo jefes) estÃ¡n bastante bien y tienen maneras muy diferentes de combatirse, por lo que acabas haciendo estrategias para cada enemigo o boss del **** diseÃ±o de mazmorras del juego me encanta. EstÃ¡n se crean procedimentalmente (o en idioma normal, aleatoriamente) haciendo todo tipo de combinaciones. La progresiÃ³n en estas tambiÃ©n se siente muy natural, teniendo muchos tipos de salas que se van desbloqueando poco a poco y haciendo que cada run pueda tener algo de importancia, desde encontrar un nuevo NPC o conseguir un nuevo objeto que no habÃ­as visto nunca. El hub principal (que se llama la Brecha) tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ bastante bien, aunque siento que es un proyecto muy a largo plazo (como todo el juego en realidad) pero que se siente muy bien al avanzar un poquito.Audiovisualmente, estÃ¡ muy bien. En el apartado grÃ¡fico, el juego tiene un estilo artÃ­stico muy bonito, que aunque sea pixel-art (algo que ya tenemos sinceramente todos muy visto) es muy bonito, con un diseÃ±o de personajes, enemigos y zonas espectacular y animaciones bastante buenas tambiÃ©n. Y la OST del juego es una pasada. La verdad que tiene temazo tras temazo y me ha sorprendido mucho en este aspecto.Como me queda mucho narrativamente que ver (aunque puedo decir que los personajes que he visto me han gustado mucho y que el humor aunque a veces sea un poco absurdo, estÃ¡ bastante bien) termino la reseÃ±a diciendo que Enter the Gungeon me gusta muchÃ­simo. Es tÃ­pico juego que es bueno tenerlo instalado siempre por si acaso no tienes nada que hacer y te apetece echar un par de runs. Si te gustan los rogue-lites, es un must-play y si no, empieza con este que te lo vas a pasar en grande

This game is very good, however, it tries very hard to be more difficult and less fun than it is, especially with the random elements.
While the enemy patterns and boss fights are pretty much skill based, your experience each run varies WIDELY based on the items you get. Some items are great, some are just fine and the vast majority are borderline useless and unfun. I cannot express enough how much more fun rainbow runs are, because you can get some cool weapons and items and just experience more of what the game has to offer you. A lot of the time in regular runs I realized I just wasn't having fun because I'd take a lot more time to clear floors and bosses because I had to use the default weapon, or some terrible item and gun and run out of ammo for it. The ammount of times I'd restart a run on floor one/two because I got 3 D-C quality weapons in a row is more than I can remember.
This is not to mention a bunch of hidden mechanics and item descriptions and synergies left intentionally vague that will just result in you opening a wiki to see what it does. We are not on the SNES days anymore where these things would have to be figured out through repeated playthroughs and discussions with other players, there is not much reason to not have these things explained in game on a menu.
I kinda wanted to give a lower score, but since I've played so much there is definitely something engaging and fun to this game. It just tries really hard to not let you experience it.

Enter the Gungeon's massive amount of unique weapons and items can create some wild combinations and interactions, but not being able to see their stats or remove some of them from your item pool can force you to use a lot of weapons that you hate.
Great game in general but the difficulty ruins everything. I played this game for a couple of weeks and couldn't even get past the first boss. **** game

although the game has a really neat animation, good controls that can be used to with, and great graphics..

this game just doesn't really hit my favor, because of how slow it is just trying to get through everything, and it's deeply repetitive with rooms just being the same with different characters trying to shoot bullets at you as the player, nothing is ever fast in the game.

While i don't think I'm madly in love with this game, i do like it quite a lot. The presentation is good despite not being too interesting. The soundtrack is charming i guess, but none of them are anything to write home about.This game's strongest quirk is the mechanics. It's basically a 2D platformer game with metroidvania and rogue-like sauces. Also, in the start of each run, the game gives you an option to pick between 3 characters. These characters have their own class, abilities and quirks. Guess what? You don't control what you get. You only get to choose between whatever options you're presented ****'s not like Dead Cells where you could buy and sell weapons when given the option. It's not like Hades 1 & 2 where you get to put together your own build, combining weapons, boons, and other abilities and you stick with them for the rest of the game. In Rogue Legacy 2, your choices are basically locked in whatever the game's RNG is feeling like. This game does have permanent progression in the forms of upgrading your characters' health, armours, unlocking new characters etc. But the very core of the game's mechanics is still randomly generated. You're not fully in control of your runs.This game is heavily reliant on RNG, which in itself isn't a bad thing. However, it does kinda ruin my lust to 'master' the game's mechanics. Simply because I'm not in control of everything available. Rogue Legacy 2's premise is very arcade-like. Which makes the game perfect for pick-up-and-play whenever you want. Rogue Legacy 2 is a good experience still, and i won't deny that. It's just a very different type of Rogue-like compared to what I'm used to. Of course, that doesn't make this game bad or anything. It's more of an arcade 2D Platformer with Metroidvania and Rogue-like aspects. 8/10
These games always make me feel like the progression slows too much in the mid game

Unfortunately, too much of everything does not automatically make a better game. Some character classes are practically useless or extremely week compared to others. 

In later NG+ playthroughs, the grinding aspects gets annoying. In addition, many enemies have similar moves to those in the regular game, except that you sometimes die after just 2 hits, depending on the character class and trait. 

Less would sometimes have been more here.

I played the first one and loved it and beat it. Iâ€™m hesitant for any sequel anymore as Ive been disappointed alot but this was a pretty good one and for once Iâ€™m happy with it. Everything is even better than it was before and the artwork and classes got even better. I love it.

Rogue Legacy 2 starts off very badly. The game is obviously quite hard, but some mechanics, like collision damage and directional damage, can throw you off from the game. But something keeps reeling you back in: the levelling system. You can level a character to Narnia and turn them into an unstoppable beast, but to get to that level you'll need to grind a lot of money, The boss fights are well realized, and some characters are fun to play as, but most of them are embarrassingly sloppy (Mage, Ronin).
The new reference point of the genre, deep, fun mechanics, very high longevity for an indie title, a little more accessible would have made it a perfect title

Very fun game with a high skill ceiling. A ton of classes to unlock and master. Very generous game in terms of itâ€™s content. You can easily sink hundreds of hours into it if you want to see and unlock everything. Only caveat for me was it can seem pretty grindy at times. Sometimes you just have to levelup/unlock things so multiple runs are dedicated to just that. Not a problem if you have a lot of spare time, but for someone with limited free time this was undesirable.

Rogue Legacy 2 is a wonderful improvement from its predecessor. It takes all of the most necessary steps forward to making a worthwhile sequel and none of the steps back. It is a fantastic entry for fans of indie games, roguelike RPGs and Metroidvania. Whether you are a fan of the original Rogue Legacy or not, this is an easy game to recommend.

For all the improvementâ€™s cellar door has made to polish, platforming and more diverse enemiesâ€¦, the inescapable fact is that combat is still boring due to the 1 note brain-dead moronic enemies that dominate this game.
And when they add in out of balance, hard, mid-level enemies, they just spam attacks in an unfair way because thatâ€™s the â€œtensionâ€â€¦. That actually demonstrates lack of combat design more than anything else.
The fundamentals of combat are still boring. Thatâ€™s the core gameplay. That part is boring & archaic. Not much different from Ghouls n Ghosts 1000â€™s of years ago.

Still I really appreciate all the player friendly options like choosing enemy health, turning off enemy contact damage, stopping level randomisationâ€¦.

Rage inducing grindfest. Terrible game design with many areas where you cannot avoid damage. I don't understand why you would make a game just to cause rage. This is Flappy Bird the rogue version. The devs are a joke for making the same game twice.

The nicest thing I can say about Rogue Legacy 2 is that it really makes me appreciate every other roguelike on the market. This game doesn't have any microtransactions, but it feels as soulless and unrewarding as a game built on microtransactions.

A few things ruined this game's loop:
1. You can't touch enemy. It has huge dmg.
2. Most your class attack range or angle is pathetic, while enemies can easily attack outside the screen. Huge dmg too.
3. **** the trap, no, **** the traps.
4. No iframe if you dash, not even if you upgraded the dash.
5. Very little gain from grinding.
6. Latter boss, enemies giant health pool.
7. No build, resolve is the stupidest system.
8. You have armor for dmg reduction, but it is capped at 35%, so the highest defense armor set is a joke.
9. Magic is barely useful.

Reminds me of meat ball. Pretty tough platforming game. And the world is very vast. You can spend hours just navigating through the maze. Story is lackluster. The upgrades are the main selling point of this game. I loved how we can upgrade the main tower, unlock new characters, upgrade weapons etc.

What this game needs is some kind of navigation system to make our lives easier in order to know where we need to go next. Because currently navigating is a major chore on the high level map. It's an even bigger chore as you navigate between trillions of enemies clustered together in every room. Quite unsatisfying.

It's pretty sad. The first Rogue Legacy was more groundbreaking than actually FUN, but it certainly did push roguelikes forward. This sequel does so, so little to improve upon the first. It plays like DLC for the original that was cranked out in a single weekend 9 years ago.

It would take too long to outline the things that RL2 does poorly. Combat, movement, exploration, upgrades. Everything looks and feels remarkably shallow. Rogue Legacy 2 is easily the worst roguelite I've ever played; every upgrade feels like an ineffectual waste and every bit of gameplay makes a strong argument to play something.
RL2 adds a lot of complexity to the original game and exactly no fun. The original Rogue Legacy is, at this stage, kind of an old, janky game. This sequel feels even older and jankier.

I was a big fan of the first Rogue Legacy and am pretty soundly disappointed with the follow-up. The original came out almost 10 years ago and the formula has seen virtually no improvement. It's truly shocking how little the devs seemed to have learned from making the first game, and how little they gleaned from the subsequent 10 years of rogue games becoming streamlined and dominant. Playing Rogue Legacy 2 feels like playing a 10 year old game, and not in a good way.

This is a great deck builder.

The concept of combining 2 classes (or races) is always great and underused in games. It leaves so many potential combos, and surprisingly many of them work well. Each race has their unique cards and combining 2 races' cards leaves some interesting potential combos.

Runs include a card selection after every encounter, as well as 2-3 activities of choice, including various types of shops, recruiting a unit, removing cards from your deck, copying a card in your deck, relics, special events, etc.

There are also "challenges" that you can toggle on or off on some encounters to increase your reward, but also difficulty. These can be interesting because the extra rewards is not always worth it depending on the circumstances.

This feels more complex than Slay the Spire and you need to manage which units you put at the front, which units on which floor, which enemies will skip a floor, etc. This is not that similar to Slay the Spire though, as you don't directly control a hero that attacks & casts spells, you summon units & use spells from the "outside". It's more about managing the battle, the 3 floors of your train and the health of your Pyre.

Monster Train es un juego bastante entretenido, a medio camino entre roguelike deckbuilder y autobattler. La idea es que vamos por el mapa escogiendo rutas aleatorias y formando el mazo, mÃ¡s o menos lo esperado. Pero las batallas se luchan jugando cartas en los distintos pisos del tres y luego dejando que las criaturas invocadas luchen automÃ¡ticamente segÃºn sus posiciones. Los enemigos intentan matarnos y sobrevivir hasta llegar a la parte alta del tren, nosotros intentamos evitarlo y matar al boss. Hay cinco mazos de juego en el juego bÃ¡sico y lo cierto es que son muy distintos entre sÃ­, dando pie a jugabilidades muy diferentes y estrategias muy originales con algunos de ellos; y, como se pueden combinar siempre en parejas, da para interesantes combos. Los enemigos y bosses quizÃ¡s no son tan variados como podrÃ­an haber sido, pero cumplen bien su labor. QuizÃ¡s lo que mÃ¡s me falla es la falta de una historia que anime a seguir jugando, ya que no hay historia como tal.

GrÃ¡ficamente el juego no es ningÃºn portento, especialmente en las animaciones que son bastante flojas, pero cumple con una estÃ©tica llamativa y colorida. La mÃºsica tambiÃ©n cumple, sin grandes aspavientos, lo mismo que los efectos sonoros. Y, al menos en mi tiempo jugÃ¡ndolo, no me he encontrado ningÃºn bug.

Por todo ello, es sin duda un juego recomendable. No serÃ¡ rompedor ni le cambiarÃ¡ la vida a nadie, pero si que os mantendrÃ¡ entretenidos un buen puÃ±ado de horas. Un 7.

If Youre a card games fan like me You cant go wrong with monster train. It offers tons of options, probably most complex deck builder created to this date. Definitely recommended, hundreds of hours of great gameplay. One of the best along with Slay the Spire and Castle of Morihisa.

There is no other game I've ever been able to put over 2k hours into and still find it fun and engaging.  It's so much better balanced than other card roguelites, I was a huge Sts fan (over 1k hours) but this just blows sts out of the water IMO.  True, technically it's easier, but for 99% of us that doesn't matter.  I still can't win every game of MT, and only a select few players in the world can.  And I like that - unlike StS where the best players can only hope to achieve around a 50% winrate, it shows that MT relies far less on RNG and allows proper tactics to usually overcome even the worst RNG that can occur in the game.
If you eat deckbuilders for breakfast, this game might not be the challenge you are looking for.

The negative reviewer doesn't know what he's talking about, imo. I have so much time in Slay the Spire (A20 on all characters) but this game is much better to me! It is not quite as difficult, but assuming you are trying for Divinity wins on Cov25, it has plenty to offer in that regard. Besides, top players frequently achieve a low win rate on StS A20 Heart runs (sometimes 25% win rate, and that is the best players in the world). To me, that is not just difficult, but in many ways impossible. In Monster Train,a run is almost always winnable - if you play perfectly. And to me, that's much better, as if I lose it was my fault! Long story short, it's plenty hard and well worth your time, just go straight for Covenant wins to start unlocking the highest difficulty where (imo) the game truly shines.

Monster train is a turn based card strategy where you fight your opponent inside the train, protecting the Spyre. It's very much like Slay the Spire with extra layers to the combat system. It's also less RNG as you know where you're heading to.

Each run starts by selecting one of two (three in total) superpower options for the champion and an artifact of our choice. There is also a temple (from DLC) which allows us to gain artifacts and various rare upgrades for an additional difficulty.

Our goal is to get through 9 rings of frozen hell in a monster train; that is 8 battles if we get to the final boss.

Each combat starts off with deploying your champion unit against waves of enemies. Most of the time, the enemy boss will be flying between the floors deploying some distractions and joining the forces at the last wave into the combat phase or simply spawn last. Until that time you're supposed to fill up all floors with units and buffs to survive.

The boss destroys the floor once it clears it from our units and it means we have less space to put units and less turns to beat the level. If the spyre falls, it's game over. Luckily, spyre still shoots back so it can serve as a 4th floor well if you've got dazed cards and increase its strength. We can also upgrade our Spyre with additional damage, armor, health and apply dazed to enemies entering it.

The cards have various effects and can be upgraded, having 2 upgrade slots by default. The best part is 5x duplicating double, triple or even quadruple upgraded cards but having so many upgrades on one unit is uncommon. Each unit takes up space in the floor so when they're full we can use magic on top of it, and it's wise not to have too many units without enough buffs because they will be easily wiped out in the late game so there should be a nice balance.

Another great feature is the alliance. We get to receive cards from two races depending on which railroad we choose or when we receive after battle rewards. We can make useful synergies, but sometimes allied cards just do not fit with our main one and only take up valuable space in our deck, but we can still get rid of them.

Between battles, there are events like merchants for units, spells and artifacts, special caverns, duplicate hellvents, remove vortexes and health wells. We can even gain an extra gold. And the best part is, we can preview our run from start to finish, however we do not know the outcome of special events. So it is always wise to first take gold, buy upgrades, visit cavern, and then take artifacts, duplicate and regain health.

Apart from those, we will be able to upgrade our champion 2 more times, once in mid and once in late game. We can have as many different artifacts as we get. They make the run easier in a way.

Early game offers 5+1 champions, starting at level 1. We can also play Daily Challenges which are always Covenant 1. That is where the PvP element comes in. We can create our own runs and share them with friends. Our rankings are saved after we finish the run. We can also play simultaneously with other players at the same time, being only time limited.

In mid game, we unlock the second champions and higher covenant ranks, probably reaching covenant 10 and getting used to all of the races in the game and learning some useful strategies. Now it is about making the perfect decks with a bit of luck from rewards.

We will understand the whole concept of the game once we reach Covenant 20. Upon reaching 25, we gain even more difficult challenges that are usually available to mix up in custom games. The game is significantly more challenging than Covenant 1 and we can even easily lose the first battle with all challenges accepted.

The game has a very high skill ceiling and me as an occasional card player, now only became an addict thanks to this game. I usually gain half or third of the best players ranked in the daily and custom challenges.

There are 5 races + 1 in the Last Divinity DLC;
Hellhorned - high damage multi strikers, rage and armor gainers focused on melee combat.
Awoken - high health gainers, multi strikers and sweepers with abilities to draw more cards.
Stygian Guard - incanters, frostbiters and spell users, low melee damage and starting HPs.
Umbra - unit eaters, lifestealers, damage shield gainers, a lot of small units, late high stats.
Melting Remnant - stealthers focused on resurrecting units and slow stat and gold gainers.
Wurmkin - eggs and worms, echo infusers, focused on making the floors magically strong.

Every run is unique, we can replay the same alliances and get different starting decks and meet different bosses.

There are 3 major bosses and 12 minor bosses; they are accompanied by many heavy and support units. There is also a bonus level with 1 more boss but I only got there once.

Coming from Slay the Spire, I was really feeling like a similar game and I quite found it with Monster train. Nice concept, nice monsters, and a good replay value with the different races.
I was just slighlty disapointed by the very low number of bosses that makes every run feel the same and some races like Umbra that are nice to play but a bit of a one trick pony.

this game is worse than Slay the spire in everyway possible

In short its bad, its not fun

I give it a 9 but part of me wants to give it a 0 because this game is like METH IT IS SO ADDICTIVE AND MAKES MY BRAIN CRAZY it is literal dopamine fed directly to your brain. Vampire Survivors â€“ Review SummaryVampire Survivors is an addictive and deceptively simple roguelike shoot-â€™em-up where your character auto-attacks through endless waves of monsters, collecting upgrades, evolving weapons, and trying to survive for as long as possibleâ€”usually up to 30 minutes per stage before the inevitable arrival of a death-dealing Reaper. With minimalistic controls but deep progression systems, itâ€™s easy to pick up and hard to put down.Developed by Luca â€œponcleâ€ Galante, this indie gem began as a small solo project in 2021 and exploded into popularity thanks to its affordable price, nostalgic Castlevania-inspired art, and wildly satisfying gameplay loop. What starts off slow quickly turns into chaotic bullet-heaven mayhem, with the screen packed with colorful enemies, projectiles, and loot. Despite its visual simplicity, itâ€™s mechanically rich, offering endless combinations of characters, weapons, power-ups, and unlockable **** game constantly rewards experimentation and persistence. Each run earns gold that you can use to unlock permanent upgrades, characters, and relics, and players are encouraged to explore different builds and gameplay modifiers. Its DLCs (both paid and free) continue to expand the content with new stages, characters, weapons, and crossover content from franchises like Castlevania, Among Us, Contra, and SaGa.Content-wise, the game now includes local co-op, mobile cross-platform versions (with ads), and ports on nearly every major platformâ€”including Tesla carsâ€”and even has a live-action film adaptation in the works.With nearly 53 hours of playtime, one player likened the experience to a serotonin bomb, comparing it to the addictive mind-control game from Star Trek. Itâ€™s thrilling, hypnotic, and overwhelming in the best wayâ€”though not for the photosensitive.Final Verdict: An exceptional indie time-sink bursting with charm, challenge, and replayability. Highly recommended.Score: 9.5/10

This game is incredibly addictive, simple yet absolutely genius. I play Brotato everywhere â€” itâ€™s my favorite 2D game of all time. I really appreciate the addition of the co-op feature and all the new content.
Easily a 10/10 â€” a brilliant tactical masterpiece!

brotato is a really good game its combat mechanics are really good its got good progression in terms of difficulty its character selection means that it never becomes dull plus its one of the most cheapest games you will ever buy plus its dlc is really good too
rating 10/10

I tried brotato in an extremely perfect time where I was exhausted  by hard games and desire a short fabulous game that feels challenging but not frustrating. It did the job well, the game don't provide you tedious instructions but it doesn't overwhelm you with a bunch of new things. In conclusion,  It is good, cheap and worth a try.

really fun game,I like the variate of weapons and characters to choose from, and I love how challenging this game is, even without seeming it,I'm on danger 2 rn, I'm not very good at it yet, but this game is so simple, yet they did it so good even tho it is,Icant name a problem rn, but I dont think this game is a 10.

Pretty fun addicting rougelike, but the game is so simple that there isn't any real variety to everything, as even with the likely hundreds of options, they are in reality very similar. Like for weapons the only real variation is melee and ranged. There are tons of its own categories within those that give different set bonuses for using that class of weapon, and different weapons with some different abilities within those, but they all feel the same when you play. The game is very very very addicting, but fun wise it is pretty much the same from the get go with little actual variety.

This game is really great. It is quite simple, as you are just left in a rectangle map with survival as your only goal, but man does this simple concept allow for a fun, smooth gameplay. The weapons synergise very well with the different characters, and have their own feeling. Some characters may be too easy to beat the game with, whereas some characters really are a hard mode, but I'd say you can still enjoy the game with any character, as long as you find the appropriate build.
Another thing this game does very well is shopping. Unlike some similar games, items in Brotato feel impactful and a single item can save your run, get your character to another level, or, at the complete opposite, completely ruin it. Definitely recommand this game.
Dude this game is really good, it's like Vampire Survivors, there are different classes, they have their own starting weapons, so it's a fun game

i feel like the trailers dont do this game justice. ive had the game in my library for a while but only recently started playing it but i see the draw to it now. If you like metrovania rogue lites or something similar in that regard you'll like this one for sure. Easy to understand stat modifiers, plenty of characters to unlock and play with. enough weapon variety to change play style. good progression system

Back in 'nam I was warring in guns a go go and I was going through hell but I  thought to myself at least I'm not in London.This game was a severe PTSD trigger for me due to all the realism but it is very 'MERICAN so 10/10 I tell you hwhat. GOD BLESS AMERICA!

Balance is absolutely non-existent, which renders Brotato insanely difficult and unfun at higher levels. Plenty of characters but that just makes the game feel wide as an ocean and as deep as a puddle. Fine to mess around with for a couple hours but not even worth the five bucks they're asking for it.
Bland enemies and bland gameplay. The weapons and item combinations don't synergize well at all. It's so repetitive. This is the worst vampire-survivor-like game I've played.

Nice art style and music, but gets incredibly frustrating at higher difficulties due to the luck necessary to win. Maybe fun if you play it casually, but if you find fun in mastering the mechanics, just about every other game in the genre does it better.
So much fun yet so much pain in a single game can only be worthy of a 10 out of 10
[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]
[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]

Noita is an impressively deep game with lots of replayability. Although the quality of a run heavily depends on RNG, it doesn't detract much from the enjoyment of the game itself, as even dying is fun.
[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]
This game has made me realise two things. One, the more people ask for realism in games, the more we get things like this. Two, I need to stop accidentally falling into lava.

*sigh* 
108 hours in, yet I'm still an absolute noob.
Why am I still doing it over and over
*sigh*

I got mixed feelings about this game. you dont get anything handed to you. Every runs start you from the start. There is no meta progression at all. Even insanely lucky runs with op items and perks can fail in seconds. The game is the first game I'm close to saying that its too hard. It took me about 15hr for my first win, so hang in there. Im satisfied with my win but I wont be going for another because its just too much rng.
Very good game. I enjoyed playing this game a lot. I strongly recommend this.

The inclusion of physics in every dot is a kind of madness.
The replayability and the ease of death may not match the game in some aspects, but I can definitely recommend this roguelite action game as a fun game!

I recommend you to be very careful, as the difficulty level is quite high!

Such a unique game. At it's most basic level, it is a side scrolling rogue-like/lite action game where you try to get better wands and spells and make it to the bottom and "win", all the while featuring a very cool set of physical, chemical, and sometimes bizarre interactions from their cool custom game engine. Only after you have "won" might you start seeing that you've only touched the surface and start to see how far down the rabbit hole goes. Just a heads up, if you're an unlucky lad like myself (or even if you are lucky), this game can be punishingly brutal at times.

Overrated. As a pixel fan who owns almost every type of game I can say Noita has some of the best physics which most pixel games don't have. I think most gamers are just caught up in the environment but not so much the gameplay. Its like a RNG, hide and seek simulator. You dungeon crawl very carefully on a handful of dungeons and RNG some wands and spells along the way. You have to take it super slow so you don't RNG yourself to death. What good is having those physics if you cant go crazy battling monsters and creating havoc on the world around you. Just wasn't my style of gameplay and felt more inhibiting then fun.
Meh story, weak animations, it's just whatever. Wouldn't recommend in all honesty. But that's just me and i like quality.
This game didn't really keep my interest. Feels way overrated than it should be.
Hard pass from me, how does it have so high user score? Makes no sense.............
I tried it because i was extremely bored and i will be completely honest, i made better video games with game-make program in 2007.

Noita exists not to be played, but to be watched in trailer form. It may be thin and repetitive game with shockingly little polish and hundreds of examples of needless, fun-stopping complexity, but it does have some nice trailers. Loads of fun until you try to play it.

Terrible game. First, it crashes constantly. Second, the dev doesn't respond to attempts to contact. Third, the game just kills you with RNG. Fourth, recent changes make the game even more random for no reason.

1 star instead of 0 because it looks nice.

Like the first game its an absolute banger. Especially during the main story the quality and content density is insane. beat the main story in about 20 hr and I was engaged for another 20 hrs in the endgame. If you are so inclined you can continue with insane "challenge" runs. But this is where i stop. 10/10 voice acting and art btw.

The amount of variations and the continuity in dialogues, character progress and quests are absurd (there're problems during ea and 1.0, but after the newest patch I really have nothing to complain). During my 100+ hrs gameplay I only have a few vague dejavu about those characters' comments.
Combats are also refined: non-repetitive elements are natural and immersive, repetitive ones are also posh enough to make me want to repeat. It can give you everything in between broken cakewalks and tough stressful wars at your will and things are almost always playful with either strong builds or wacky funny builds.

TrÃ¨s bon jeu le meilleur rogue like Selon moi une histoire bien Ã©crite des personnages attachants des niveaux cool et lâ€™impression mÃªme si câ€™est un rogue like de toujours vraiment avancer alors que certains ce nâ€™est pas le cas

Simply a masterpiece voice acting and the soundtracks, everything makes u wanna dig deeper into the game to discover everything, the visuals are great, u can upgrade weapons and u have plants to take care of, while every conversation in every new run not the same, so the game is not repetitive.

[SPOILER ALERT: This review contains spoilers.]
I don't like rogue like games, but i really enjoyed my time on hades 2. The universe is close from the first game but it's allways a pleasure to launch "a last run"
Hades II is a crazy fun roguelike, fighting through the underworld with cool weapons and magic! Simple.

One of the best games ever. Infinite replayability, plenty of options to customize the difficulty, great characters, voice acting, music, and I could go on - I don't think there is a single thing I disliked. Even the ending, which I learned that people have issues with, seemed perfectly appropriate given the time-related main plotline.

If you love roguelike games, you must absolutely not miss this one!

Such a breath of fresh air in a time where every game is just a mindless pew pew with guns. I find it hard to find something that I hated about this game, but if there's any con to point out, I'd say the requirement to reach the true ending really tests your patience at how many runs you need to repeat, which is why it's a 9 for me. But other than that, I love everything, the music, the graphics, the combat, the story, the dialogue, the **** the anime art is just...they knocked it out of the park.
The GIF "Same same but diffenrent, but still same" has never been more relevant than it is now.

What can I say about Hades 2? Well, not much. The only thing it really has going for it is it's combat and that's it. 

The Combat in Hades 1 however was better, well everything about Hades 1 is better than 2. The characters are boring, their designs are horrible and uninspired. 

When you think of these types of gods you think yeah they're going to look awesome! Amazing Armour and styles that fits what they're based on. But nope, bland, poorly designed and for the life of me why are they taking away from what they should look like? 

For example, you have a god in a wheelchair... I'm sorry but what? You're a god, make a new pair lol.

It got to a point where I didn't care about the story at all and just became annoying to listen to so I just tried skipping past them all just to get back to the game play but it just got too boring with everything that surrounds it.

It's just worse than the first. The boons are either nerfed or boring.
It's more bullet hell than the first one. The weapons don't do anything interesting. The enemies spawn from the first moment with armor.
It seems they got feedback alright, from the jobless squad to ensure they make this game feel like a chore. My bad for trying to have fun and not enjoying the x3 boon of weakness. WOW "30% less damage" never seen that one before. Miss me with this sh**.
The story is good, the graphics are also good but... It's a game. It should be better in gameplay. If all you wanted was to recycle the gameplay so you can tell some spinoff you could have made a visual novel.

-Quick Review-Crypt of the NecroDancer is a roguelike rhythm game, developed by Brace Yourself Games and released in 2015. Crypt of the NecroDancer combines all the elements of a 2D Top-down Roguelike with procedural generated levels, picking up different weapons gear and items to make your â€œbuildâ€, all the while digging through walls and battling monsters in an underground dungeon to the beat of the music.

-Detailed breakdown review-Story: At the start of the game, thereâ€™s a cutscene of the first playable character named â€œCadenceâ€ digging in a graveyard to uncover the truth of her long-lost treasure-hunting father. She falls underground and the NecroDancer steals her heart and forces her to move to the rhythm of the **** Cadence plays through the acts, she will unlock new characters which will have different quirks, some helpful, some not so helpful, for example one character has infinite bombs, and another character canâ€™t attack at all.

Gameplay: Movement is up, down, left, and right, some items require you to tap two directions at the same time, like down + left to drop bombs, and up + left to use an item (The Steamdeck assigns buttons rather than directional inputs. This game is great on Steam deck by the way). You attack by moving in the same direction as an enemy or attackable **** the previous mentioned movement must be done at the rhythm of the music, if you miss or skip the beat your character will NOT be injured however youâ€™ll be at a â€œdisadvantageâ€. You lose your gold multiplier, and the rest of the dungeon will move around you to the beat of the music, sometimes youâ€™ll miss a critical turn and die because the monster got an extra turn. I have used this to my advantage once or twiceâ€¦ but the game definitely rewards and incentivizes the player to move with the **** experience at the start of each zone was â€œOh noâ€¦ thereâ€™s no way Iâ€™m going to figure out how to play this gameâ€. Then after playing and dying on the same level for a bit, Iâ€™d make progress and get lucky with my weapon, armor, items, etcâ€¦ then Iâ€™d get to the next zone, and we were right back at square one â€œoh noâ€¦ this is when Iâ€™ll need to quit, itâ€™s too hardâ€. But I did slowly learn the monstersâ€™ attack patterns through lots of trial and error.

Conclusion: Crypt of the Necrodancer is a good game. Iâ€™d recommend it to people who enjoy rhythm gamesâ€¦ maybe more so than recommending it for people who like roguelikes. Certainly, it has roguelike stuff in it, but you really need to like the rhythm-based gameplay, if you donâ€™t like rhythm-based gameplay the game really wonâ€™t appeal to you in the same way. However, it does have options to make the game easier too, so it can be more accessible to **** you donâ€™t commit to getting everything, youâ€™re looking at roughly 13-15 hours playing the game as Cadence. (More or less playtime will be required depending on how naturally good you are at the game, and how lucky you get on your runs) And if youâ€™ve got the time and motivation to really learn the game youâ€™re looking at hundreds of hours of play. The game is a completionist nightmare, I wouldnâ€™t recommend doing that to yourselfâ€¦ but completionists already subject themselves to that agonyâ€¦ whatâ€™s there to lose to a little indie game, right? 

â€¦There's more to the review... If you want to know more, please check out my YouTube Video or Steam Review.

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a brilliantly unique rhythm-based roguelike that blends dungeon crawling with beat-matching mechanics. Its pulsating soundtrack, addictive gameplay loop, and quirky charm make every run a thrilling dance of strategy and reflexes. A must-play for fans of both roguelikes and rhythm games.

Crypt of the NecroDancer completely surprised me. I didnâ€™t think a rhythm-based roguelike would hook me, but the moment I started syncing my moves to the beat, I was hooked. The soundtrack is electric, the gameplay feels like a constant high-stakes dance, and every run feels fresh and intense. Itâ€™s one of those rare games where I catch myself nodding along even after Iâ€™ve closed it.

Very challening but great game. I am not that good in the game but I love it. It's mostly trial and error. If you keep playing, you will eventually get good. I don't think you need you necessarilyneed any experiance with other rythm games.

Very good game. I enjoyed playing this game a lot. I strongly recommend this.

An entertaining combination of dungeon crawler and rhythm game. Although it can be a bit difficult and confusing at the beginning, as the hours go by you start to enjoy better the different games in the game.

Crypt of the Necrodancer blends real-time and turn-based combat by making players and enemies move to the beats of its infectious music. The varying items and enemies all randomly combine into puzzles that need to be solved on the fly.

I'm not sure what people's expectations are sometimes. This game is such a unique little game that oozes style. Indy games like this need to be supported!

The soundtrack is amazing, the replay ability is enormous, the gameplay is simple but original.
it has only four levels with each character and yet it takes long time to master the movements of the enemies and the uses of the weapons.
I simply don't know why this game doesn't have more people getting into it.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play, Indie
review_text: A masterpiece, meticulously crafted with such thoughtful details that it will make you ponder religion and belief systems for hours.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play, Indie
review_text: I can't believe I was sleeping on this game, so so worth it to play. I do play on the Keyboard instead of the recommended controller, but I find it just as simple to use, honestly.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play, Indie
review_text: Love the dungeon exploration, love managing your base, love the art style, but it does get boring after a while. I find the designs of the characters and enemies in this game to be very good (especially the bishops. My god they look sick), but for all of it's charm, it does start to feel repetitive after a while, especially the base building aspect. Also, maybe it is just me, but my game kept freezing and I constantly had to reset the game. Not a deal breaker (could have just been my computer) and overall, had a lot of fun. (Also rest in peace River Boy. You will be missed.)

review_text: Uninspired and uninteresting. Painful to play in local coop as the game takes away your controls while the other player is talking to the cultists.

review_text: I got softlocked in the home stretch of the game, I had my faith just randomly drop to nothing and there was nothing I could do to stop it. I game-overed and it set me back to when it had just happened so there was nothing I could do.

TL;DR Fun deck builder with a good challenge. No bugs.

I have high hopes for the future development of this game. It combines elements of chance through Plinko with deck-building and dungeon-crawling akin to a Slay the Spire clone, which is as refreshing as it is unique. The enemies are challenging, and the unlockable levels of the Cruciball mode add further challenges after each successful run. In addition, the option to speed up the entire game is a nice touch that helps with the grind. 

Negatives are few and far-between, outside of the normal frustration of difficulty. I may argue that more goblin classes (now unlockable), relics, or more orb types could add further variety to the game, but there is absolutely plenty of variety in the current state. I highly recommend this game for fun, quick entertainment if you enjoy deck builders with a touch of mindlessness.
Entertaining for a while, good on mobile. Finding synergies in your orb is fun and the game can be quite challenging

I'm lost as to what precisely the draw of Peglin is meant to be. For a **** machine it's unsatisfying and uninteresting, for a roguelite it's repetitive and dull, and for a deck builder it's restrictive and lacks variety. At least a small amount of charm and heart shines through, but I think one run is enough to tell you if you will enjoy this game or not.
Its the best game i have played in years since dark souls 3...that says a lot about the company. all of there games are amazing. Elden ring easily 10 out of 10

The best game I've ever played. I've finished it from the beginning about 10-15 times using different methods, and I still want to play it again. It's the most expansive and magnificent game in history.

The game speaks for itself
The only bad thing I would say (if there is anything) is finding your way around is annoying without tuorials, in fact you need tutorials for most of the game.

This is the most expansive open world game I've ever played. The possibilities are truly endless. Every play through can be completely different. I couldn't imagine fromsoftware making a a better open world souls game.

An open world with various matryoshka dungeons Dark Souls-like. Yes. But that would be reductive. This game takes the open-world formula from Zelda: Breath of the Wild and adapts it to Miyazaki's vision, with incredible results. The journey will be incredible, and the desire for discovery will be great around every corner of the map. Shadow of the Erdtree DLC reinvents the level-based rules of the game, but with dedicated perks that might demoralize level-farming players, but once you get the hang of it, it works much better than the original game, forcing you to change your approach, especially with bosses.

One of the all time peak video game experiences of my 30yo life. The game play, the aesthetics, the difficulty, the cheese, the aura, the story, the atmosphere, the loot... just peak. FromSoft is just showing how it's done and they truly deserve all the acclaim, support, and financial success.
This is every videogame should strive to be. A perfect blend of player choice, story, combat and world building. A perfect game, a culmination of every masterpiece FromSoft have released before it.
It's one of those rare games where I enjoyed every second of it, whether you're new to the genre or not, this game is a masterpiece that must be played.

Imagine the open world of breath of the wild and the gameplay of dark souls. The open world and its secrets make this a really good attention grabber on top of the similar souls like difficulty.

Yes, this game is very difficult at times but once you beat a boss you were stuck on, its worth it
Absolute cinema. So many feet and so peak characters. Ranni is so bad Put a ring on it.

I don't find this game to be much fun. Mostly just tedious. I made it maybe halfway before I decided it just wasn't for me and quit. I stopped after the underground part, after beating ancient spirit I think. This was my first fromsoft game besides sekiro which is awesome. I did like the legacy dungeons. 

The open world is a time waster. You're really just going from boss to boss. The things in between are either worthless enemies or rewards which, 9 times out of 10 are also worthless. 

That'd be ok if combat was good but I find it boring, especially coming from Sekiro. Mostly stay away from the boss or dodge roll until you get an opening. Repeat until boss is dead. Vastly inferior combat system compared to sekiro. People will just say git gud but what's git gud even mean in this game. I had a lot of trouble against an optional boss, ancient hero of zamor I think, so I left and came back much later and whooped it. I hadn't gotten any better at the game. I simply had better weapons and leveled up. So it did not feel satisfying to me. That's really the whole point of these games, the satisfaction of beating a boss, but Elden Ring just feels like a chore to me.

This game got endless praise so I've watched a lot of criticism videos hoping to find I'm not crazy for not liking the game. I think it's odd that many of these videos called it a great game or even a masterpiece with flaws. That makes no sense, a masterpiece to me means as flawless as one can reasonably expect. There seems to be a culture around this game that can't accept criticism. The only thing that is a masterpiece around this game is the marketing campaign that combined with the reputation of fromsoft, created a feeling of fomo and a degree of hype that led to its massive success.

My advice: Try it for an hour on Steam. If you donâ€™t enjoy the first hour, you can get a refund (as long as youâ€™ve played less than two hours). That first hour gives a clear idea of what the entire game will be like. 
Suspiciously overrated by so-called "pros." 
I gave it 1 star because I personally disliked the game mechanics â€” not because itâ€™s buggy. Itâ€™s an easy game, but frustratingly hard to play. The gameplay is clunky and takes a long time to get used to. Thereâ€™s no story. No guidance. Itâ€™s artificially difficult due to the lack of information needed to play it properly. The difficulty is poorly balanced. The beginner tutorial is a complete joke. Combat mechanics feel outdated and poorly coded. The latency is awful and takes ages to adapt to. Iâ€™d estimate you need around 50 hours of practice just to handle the battle interface. Once you finally understand how to play and uncover the hidden mechanics, the game becomes boringly repetitive and ridiculously easy. The graphics are terribly optimized and run painfully slow even on a high-end PC. Donâ€™t buy.

I think that Elden Ring is again one of those games that got popular because of overly glazing users and critics. It drifts the furthest from the basic souls games premise out of all the souls games. It lacks those emotions and gameplay that games like Bloodborne offer you. So the only way I would recommend this to you is if you have some extra big money that you want to spend on something expensive, then buy this game, otherwise buy Bloodborne and experience some real gameplay and emotions.

most overhyped game ever nothing but a dodge roll simulator designed for kids who have infinite time

Super fun game with a very richly-developed world.  Excellent controls and mechanics.  My only real gripe is the bosses; the developers seem to have gone out of their way to make the bosses as annoying as possible.   Combine this with some cases where you have to walk a long way to get back to the boss and the game can feel like a bit of a chore at times.  I still prefer the original DS but this is an excellent sequel.

Our beloved Dark Souls is a game that has given us so many emotions. Everything in it is perfect, everything is in its place, nothing is superfluous.
just finished my third playthrough and this is one of the best games i have ever experienced in my life , easily 10/10 game and for sure it is the best out of the trilogy
Straight up amazing. wonderfully dark atmosphere and some of the best bosses of the trilogy with some exceptions of course.

me parece el juego con los mejores bosses, de todos los souls me parece el mas infravalorado, esta a la altura para ser de los mejores juegos de la historia, ademas q concluye de muy buena manera la que es una de las mejores trilogias de la historia, y si hablamos de la musica me parece tambien de lo mejor, plinplinplon, no le encuentro algo realmente malo la verdad
Llevo jugando este juego menos de una semana y ya le tengo 15 horas al juego. El juego me ha encantado, como los boses, los caminos con sus cada respectivos mountros. El juego es una locura!

Tight level design and refined combat make this a culmination of the Souls formula. Fast-paced yet deliberate, it hits a near-perfect balance of challenge and reward.

Weakest soulsborne game. It's the dodge-roll simulator boss rush personified. Dark Souls 3 lacks atmosphere, innovation, immersive level design, cohesiveness and is too fan-servicey. A lot of areas are reused assets from Bloodborne and some of the bosses are straight up bad. This game gets a good rep for its bosses but in truth there's 2 bad bosses for every good one. You can tell Miyazaki was forced to make this game due to the backlash of DS2 but he flopped pretty hard on this one.
