Look at other games just think that this game is fully finished no areas are rushed or left behind!! 

Such a unique atmosphere and music, dark Pinocchio with surprising twist, I love this game combat and verity of weapons with assembly tools to try new combos soooo many choices I canâ€™t tell you how many times while finding new weapons I keep thinking of my NG+ and now we have boss rush sooo they gave us what we want I come back to it anytime I feel like going to the hotel and putting the records and listens to their amazing tracks

If thereâ€™s even a hint of Soulslike appreciation in a player, itâ€™s hard to imagine they wouldnâ€™t fall in love with Lies of P. The bosses are fantastic: never unfair, always exciting, and the game gives countless ways to customize difficultyâ€”summons, consumables, or powerful weapon optionsâ€”so how tough it feels is truly up to the player's choices. Itâ€™s often called challenging, but with these tools, the real difficulty is self-imposed. Lies of P gave me that â€œonce-in-a-lifetimeâ€ feeling I only rarely getâ€”in many ways, it made me feel the same magic as playing Dark Souls 3 for the first time. It isnâ€™t just a clone; it has real identity, a unique story, and NPCs whose fates I genuinely cared about. The motivation to push through tough moments and the excitement of discovery are both strong, thanks to its powerful narrative. Krat, the city you explore, is incredibleâ€”dense, atmospheric, and refreshingly straightforward. Iâ€™m grateful it isnâ€™t another bloated open world; instead, it strikes a balance, offering side routes and hidden areas to explore, but with purposeful direction. Rarely these days can a game deliver a peak experience in a tight, focused package without unnecessary padding. The story, inspired by Pinocchio, is charmingly unique and walks a perfect line between mystery and emotion. Choices matter and deepen your investment in the journey. That said, the game isnâ€™t flawless. In the latter stages, enemy designs are often reused, sometimes making encounters feel repetitive or dull. It can be disappointing to see an imposing boss earlier in the journey reappear later as a regular foe. Additionally, one or two of the more gimmicky bosses didnâ€™t live up to the challenge or creativity of the rest. While narratively justified, these moments felt like missed opportunities for more engaging gameplay and broke the momentum at times. Gameplay-wise, it delivers crisp, challenging combat with phenomenal weapon variety, thanks especially to its unique blade-and-handle crafting system. Mixing and matching weapon parts kept my experience fresh, allowing for creativity and making every battle unique. For me, Lies of P is more than a gameâ€”itâ€™s an unforgettable adventure that Iâ€™m genuinely happy I experienced. Despite these minor hiccups, I can wholeheartedly recommend Lies of P, even at full price. The journey it offers is truly worth every penny.

The game is truly beautiful and stands as one of the best Souls-like experiences, very close to Bloodborne. The bosses are powerful and beautifully designed, and the world is exactly as it should be. Thereâ€™s only one real issue: the shortcut system. At first, it was well done, but later on, the placement felt completely wrong. However, this doesnâ€™t kill the fun at all, since the save points are perfectly distributed, making it not too bothersome. As for the story, it was good at first but became excellent with the addition.

Thatâ€™s why I highly recommend it!ï¸ï¸
One more thing for those who say the game is extremely difficult: itâ€™s a Souls-like, what did you expect? The game actually becomes relatively easier once you master perfect parries. Thatâ€™s why I think those who criticize it for being hard are simply not the target **** thank you ï¸

Lies of P stands out as one of the most impressive soulslikes in recent years. I'd describe it as a story-driven soulslike, thanks to its focus on narrative, the inclusion of multiple difficulty modes, and the fluidity of both gameplay and storytelling.Combat-wise, it holds its own against FromSoftware's best. The parry system, while challenging to master, offers incredibly satisfying feedback once you get the hang of it. It rewards precision and timing in a way that feels genuinely rewarding. The soundtrack deserves special praiseâ€”it's phenomenal. Every track complements the story and the atmospheric setting beautifully. That said, I would have liked to see more engaging and less linear level design. While the ambiance does a great job setting the tone, a more interconnected world could have added another layer of depth to **** area that could be improved is the pacing of difficulty. The game begins in a fairly approachable way, making it welcoming for newcomers, but later boss fightsâ€”despite their excellent designâ€”feature abrupt difficulty spikes that might feel discouraging to those new to the genre. A smoother difficulty curve would have made the experience more consistently rewarding. 8/10
One of my favorite games of the decade. Great combat, art style, level design.

Beatiful, Lore is amazing, the DLC had strong and Hard Challenges. This is a good Souls like for anyone who like the real style. HAd a good perfomance on PC. Nice Game  play weapons are good and in future will be more accessible for anyone with Difficult modifier.
Impressively executes everything it sets out to do, with refined Soulslike mechanics, strong atmosphere, and tightly designed encounters that rival its inspirations.
Great souls-like but it could be a bit harder. Very nice atmosphere, graphics and cool background story

It's a good soulslike, but it's a bit overrated. The exploration is much too linear and easy. The boss are very challenging, so this feels a bit like a boss run. It has a decent storyline, great visuals and soundtrack. And the Quality of Life features that make this game accessible (like difficulty settings) are amazing.

It has awesome combat mechanics and great level design. The bosses fell short for me, but some of them really stood out. This game was short and sweet and didnâ€™t overstay its welcome. I had a blast playing it

The game is a disgrace,stupid and frustrating. The gameplay is terrible. You're walking on a plank barely wide enough for your foot, and the slightest touch makes you fall and lose half your health or more. Make games that are actually fun, not just difficult for the sake of dragging out the time it takes to finish them. It's not our fault if you've run out of imagination and creativity and you can't make games be fun anymore. That's why we won't be buying the garbage you make and call 'games' anymore.

Devs really know how to waste your time and piss you off with these stupid bots its almost unplayable and you cant progress the game without getting rage baited and im sure not putting the game on easy mode, its like they purposely make things un enjoyable i stopped playing after the 6th chapter before i called it quits.
I hope there are fewer games in this world that increase the difficulty of games by making the protagonist suffer from polio.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: The Scorn of Dark Souls clones. It's a 7 from me but a high 7 (green rather than the default yellow colour).  The aesthetics are oppressive and beautiful. The slow methodical exploration and figuring out what to do is way more obtuse than Dark Souls but has a similar feeling of reward.  I'd argue that the mechanics are a little too obtuse and that as a result I didn't commit to any other playstyle rather than my starting one, but the sense of being lost in an aggressive dream-like world is very strong.  The combat for me was repetitive and sluggish and the bosses aren't the best I've seen.  For me the game shines in it's 3 main 'dungeons', and the genuinely scary 'run-backs' to base camp after killing the bosses.  As others have said the long animations and clunkyness are what hold it back, despite it clearly being intended to give the impression of heft - it does but at a cost.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The game is skeletal and not very fleshed out but still is fun.

Don't expect to want to play all the time but is a really good first-time playthrough and should last 6-10 hours. It is fun to revisit and is worth it if you're ok with not playing a ton.

The game is a bit of a maze if you just wander so use the visions or you might want to look up a quick playthrough.

The biomes are great and are designed so that you don't spend too much time in them so they don't get repetitive too quickly.

Everything that isn't a boss isn't as fun to fight though. Mechanics are fun but I try to avoid using the hardening ability to make it feel less choppy.

The lore is interesting but there isn't a lot to it when playing through unless you dig for it. If you want lore, playthrough, and level as Solomon.

Music is good enough and sets the tone of the game.

review_text: Desde la perspectiva de un SoulsLike, es excelente su gameplay y ambientacion, tanto como sus mecanicas originales y unicas, tambien es un juego muy versatil a la hora de tu poder cambier de estrategia para un boss o alguna zona en concreto. Pero donde pierde es en la variedad de sus Bosses y enemigos, algo aceptable teniendo en cuenta que no es un juego triple A, pero donde NO me gusto para nada y por lo cual no le doy mas punto es en su Jefe final, es realmente decepcionante.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: He jugado a juegos malos, lentos, tediosos, que no cargaban bien los personajes, con combates aburridos y sin sentido, con parrys malos o inÃºtiles, con escudos inservibles, juegos donde el prota es lento y torpe o donde hay muchÃ­simo delay en las acciones, frustrantes, donde los enemigos te ven desde muy lejos y te atacan, juegos donde los enemigos que normalmente tienen poca vida, tienen mÃ¡s que de costumbre, juegos liosos, sin historia, sin lore, incluso juegos sin sentido, pero este se lleva la palma! A parte de todo lo anterior, no he jugado un souls mÃ¡s malo en mi vida, menos mal que me saliÃ³ gratis. Parece sencillamente una demo (sin acabar) de un juego, los enemigos no cargan bien, el combate es monÃ³tono y aburrido, el parry no sirve de mucho, los objetos y cosas que salen en la pantallas de carga ni siquiera te sirven como consejo o para enterarte de algo, parece claramente que ni lo han testeado, tienes varias armas y no vas a pasar de la principal (la tengo al mÃ¡ximo y el resto todavÃ­a no puedo tenerlas ni a la mitad de nivel), las mejoras de los personajes no tienen sentido (porque no son mejoras; hay un ataque que si te conviertes en piedra en el aire haces mucho daÃ±o al caer, pero no puedes ni saltar ni caer por los sitios, Â¿para que he gastado monedas y vestigios? todavÃ­a no he podido usar el ataque) y estas mejoras no se aplican bien (por ejemplo no hay otra oportunidad al matar muchÃ­simos enemigos o no te curas al conseguir vestigios, aunque diga que aumenta la probabilidad de conseguir vestigios los enemigos no sueltan mÃ¡s, etc.), no he visto nada del trÃ¡iler en el juego, ni las velocidades de los personajes, ni las habilidades, ni nada de todo lo chulo que parece que promete y ademÃ¡s de todo esto, es injusto y muy corto. EstÃ¡ sin pulir, con controles que en mando dejan bastante que desear, controles de cÃ¡mara bastante malos, esquivas contra una pared que no sabes que estÃ¡ porque no ves a tu alrededor, hay muchos objetos que no son destruibles ni movibles y te entorpecen la batalla (como las tiendas) y muchÃ­simo delay, no tiene nada de profundidad ni en el mapa ni en la historia (no sabes porquÃ© haces nada, no tiene ningÃºn sentido ni motivaciÃ³n detrÃ¡s, Â¿salvo el mero hecho de explorar?) ni con los enemigos (ni con nada), te lo puedes pasar prÃ¡cticamente corriendo todo el rato y evitando un montÃ³n de peleas (son mejores las peleas contra boses que contra los enemigos normales, tienen mÃ¡s sentido). El tema de la familiaridad, que me parece algo innovador, queda totalmente opacado por el resto de cosas (lo pondrÃ­a como algo "bueno", pero ni si quiera). Los vestigios se quedan en cada armadura (o shell) lo que genera que cuando te cambies de una a otra para mejorarlas, te lleves una desagradable sorpresa, ademÃ¡s de obligarte a manejar una clase de personaje que igual no es tu estilo y te deja con clases/armaduras a medio mejorar. Para usar las "habilidades", necesitas determinaciÃ³n, que consigues al rellenar unas barras tipo stamina en los combates pegando enemigos.... pero si dejas de combatir y no has rellenado lo suficiente la barra, desaparece y se vacÃ­a (cosa que pasa bastante porque no quieres estar todo el rato peleando), las mejoras de las armas no puedes comprarlas, debes encontrarlas, pero tampoco sirven de mucho ya que consumen muchÃ­sima determinaciÃ³n (hasta el parry la consume, quitando un personaje, el resto casi no tienen barras de determinaciÃ³n y no es algo ampliable, encima esta es una de las cosas top que aparecen en el trÃ¡iler, pero it's a trap.) En consecuencia a todo esto, el precio base me parece una pasada y que los DLC sean de pago me parece todavÃ­a mÃ¡s basto. Hablando de esto Ãºltimo parece ser que han metido en el DLC una 5Âª clase al estilo pay to win. No sÃ© de donde habrÃ¡n sacado nada para hacer el 2, pero espero que sea mucho mejor que esto. Un juego estilo souls no es un juego frustrante, desquiciante, austero o con mecÃ¡nicas injustas o limitadas, son juegos que te ponen a prueba y con bastante dificultad pero te permiten mediante mecÃ¡nicas a tu alcance poder probar diferente modos de combate y demÃ¡s, pero este no lo hace. No sÃ© si es que las nuevas generaciones se conforman con cualquier cosa mediocre (o con cualquier plagio, ya que intenta desesperadamente parecerse a Dark Souls), pero creo que deja bastante que desear. Como culmen de todo esto, ademÃ¡s, tiene bugs... No se lo recomendarÃ­a ni a mi peor enemigo. Por sacarle algo bueno, los grÃ¡ficos no estÃ¡n mal (y eso es gracias a UE4) y las canciones del laÃºd. No pretendo que esta crÃ­tica sea un ataque al juego, es simplemente mi experiencia con el mismo y lo que me ha transmitido (decepciÃ³n). Lo probÃ© desde la beta y ahora que han pasado varios aÃ±os y lo he vuelto a probar esperando alguna mejora, me he encontrado con lo mismo que en la beta.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Theres barely anything redeemable about the game

This is one of, if not the worst, Souls like I have played in my life. This game doesnt feel like it was tested or examined by people other than the devs. Do no waste your time on it, I have died to jank more often than my own lack of skill. The enemy placement is not clever, it is annoying, Dark Souls 2 SOTFS levels of annoying. The bosses are uninspired, or worse, buggy, I have been killed MULTIPLE times by lingering hitboxes after an attack has clearly, visibly and obviously stopped. Theres is no level ups or character builds, you simply unlocks "Abilities" for your current armor that has a probability of procing.

This game is nothing like a fair Souls Like game, This game is either untested, unfinished or the developpers are incompetent

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: This game is just not good. The combat and world building and atmosphere is very lacking and subpar to other soulslike.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: ###  **Mortal Shell â€“ A Soulslike That Forgets the â€œLikeâ€ Part**I picked up *Mortal Shell* looking for that classic Soulslike experience â€” intense combat, memorable bosses, and rich, atmospheric dungeons. What I got instead was a glorified running simulator with the worst dungeon design Iâ€™ve ever seen in a video ****â€™s break it down: **Dungeon Design? More Like Labyrinthine Headache**I spent more time running around in circles than actually fighting enemies. The level layout is so confusing and poorly thought out that I constantly found myself ending up in the **same area I just came from**, only from a different angle â€” as if someone twisted a maze and forgot to label the exit. Some sections are so large and **completely empty** that I genuinely wondered if I glitched into unfinished areas. Zero enemies, zero atmosphere, just giant hallways for no reason. Whoever designed these environments seriously needs to reconsider their career.ï¸ **Combat: The Lone Shining Lightâ€¦ If You Can Reach It**Boss fights were decent, Iâ€™ll give the game that. But the journey to get to them? **An absolute joke.** Youâ€™ll have to run a **marathon-length trek** through those same confusing, enemy-scarce hallways just to get back to a boss if you die. No shortcuts, no reasonable respawn points â€” just a big ol' middle finger to your time and patience. **Item Descriptions? Nah, Figure It Out Yourself**You want to know what an item does? Too bad! *Mortal Shell* gives you **zero info** unless you use the item first â€” and once you waste it, well, that's just your loss. No forgiveness, no hints, just frustration. This isn't challenge; it's **bad design** dressed up as mystery.ğŸª– **Shells Are Coolâ€¦ Until You Try Upgrading**The Shell system â€” where you can possess different fallen warriors with their own strengths and weaknesses â€” is actually a **great idea**. It gives you flexibility and encourages experimenting with different playstyles. Unfortunately, the **skill upgrades are mostly trash**. Youâ€™ll waste precious resources unlocking garbage-tier perks that barely change anything. Whatâ€™s the point of customization if itâ€™s not worth the investment? **Final Verdict: Save Your Time, Save Your Sanity**I spent like $2 on this, and honestly, that feels like $1.50 too much. If youâ€™re craving a Soulslike, **replay Dark Souls, Bloodborne, Sekiro**, or even other indies like *Lies of P* or *Nioh*. *Mortal Shell* is **not worth your time**, no matter how cheap it is.ï¸ My Advice: **DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.**Save yourself the pain. Unless you want a walking simulator with a sprinkle of combat and a whole lot of bad design, steer clear.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: I had high hopes for this one, but unfortunately, it was completely unplayable, so I deleted it. The combat feels too clunky - so after playing DS, Bloodborne and Sekiro, it was way too frustraing. Obvicouly, my opinion is biased based on playing otger much faster paced games with smoother combat style, so if you have not played any of those titles and are going straight fromthe first genre of comsoles, you might have a better time...

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The atmosphere was definitely done correctly but my god is there a lot of jank in this game. Bosses disappearing mid fight so you have to reset. Hardening not working. Mobs not spawning in until they have already shot their arrows at you. Mobs not spawning in until you walk past the spot where they usually are and then spawning in behind you. The list goes on.

And what do Playstack do? They introduce patches that only patch out the speedrunner strats. Why?

It wouldnt be so bad if the boss fights were at least fun after the slog of going through the janky world. But no. Two of the four main bosses have about 3 moves only and the other 2 are gimmick fights.

Not worth checking out unless you are really into the souls-like genre, if even then.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
This takes every mechanic from a soulsborne, and misunderstands them completely.

Leveling: you don't. There are no stats to speak of in this regard, or rather, you start "level evened" with your enemies and it stays that way. You'd think this is a good thing, but it absolutely is not.  You have "shells" (which you have to find). It's basically a class with extra steps, and you can't develop that class outside its bounds- like giving the no-stamina tank some stamina, or the no-HP rogue some HP.  They're stuck with those stats.

You purchase sidegrades for these shells, of which only half per shell actually relate to combat in any way, and three are universal between shells. Each shell has to have their tree unlocked *individually.*  "oh that's not so bad!" wrong. There's only four. If your playstyle doesn't fall into one of these four ideas the devs had for you, you're S.O.L. It also means that if you DO find one that's your playstyle, and you unlock the stuff you want, the EXP resource of the game becomes completely obsolete besides buying consumables.  There is no fear of death besides having to go back to the starting area of that zone.

Parrying: Parrying isn't a normal thing. It's attached to an item you have to locate. This item needs to be charged in segments, by dealing damage. If you don't, it doesn't work.  If you don't fill the segment, it decays.  Half the enemies in the game ignore parrying anyway, because "they hit too hard" or -surprise- it was actually a throw attack and you were supposed to I-frame it with a dodge. This leads to healing.

Healing: Awful.  Parrying when it's charged, and consumables you have to find in the wild.  No, they are not blood vials- blood vials you have a max you can carry and they actually work. In Mortal Shell, the consumables that heal worth anything tend to remove the resource that lets you parry. Yes, you read that right.  Healing, removes your ability to both parry & by extension, heal more.  By the way, that resource is also the resource used for special moves.  So if you ever have to heal, you can't use special attacks, because those attacks cost so much of the resource, and your healing just deleted that resource.

Weapons: There's only four weapons. Three of them are big beefy two-handers your character swings like they're just waking up. The only short weapon that swings "fast" is dual-wielded, and only does full damage if both weapons in the attack animation hit. This dual attack swing has the same overall attack speed as the big two handers with none of the range.  In addition, all the weapons seem to do the same general damage besides the one small fast weapon, for the reason I just listed (everything has to hit). It's literally just choosing what you want your attack combo to look like, and maybe some consideration to range.  Now, how about upgrades?

To unlock your special move, you have to locate a unique item for that weapon and upgrade it at the workbench or anvil.  You also *cannot switch weapons* without going back to the hub, which you cannot do regularly because there *is no fast travel.* The other alternative is finding a specific item related to that weapon, which is an item you have to "use."  However, these items tend to be hidden. That's right, they made weapon switching an item usage.  By the way, that goes for shells, too.

You can't just stop and switch your class outside the hub. You have to find a *consumable* item to switch your class out in the wild (no joke, these do NOT refresh on rest).  If you want to swap out before a boss, since there's no fast travel, you have to go *all the way back to the starting hub* or burn an item.  How bout travel, then?

There's no fast travel from point to point.  There is an infinite use item to go back to the start of the zone you're in and lose your important resource, glimpses, which don't drop on death anyway.  It's literally simpler to teleport by letting enemies kill you and respawning. If you have your shell's sidegrades unlocked, which is all glimpses do, you won't even care then.

Finally, enemies.  Half the ones had throws that'll eat huge chunks of HP, can't be parried, and are long-range lunges.  Some bosses have them and they ignore parrying AND blocking.  There's an abundance of snipers that always stun when they hit you, overlooking fight zones with heavy enemies that can two shot you.  There's multiple ambushes in every zone that are completely untelegraphed, and no way to trigger them early when you DO know about them. There's no dogs, but there's worse- poisonous suicide bomber frogs.  It's actually impossible to hit them due to how the combat animations work, their size, and when they explode.  You whiff high on every attack as they approach, and angled attacks are aimed where a torso would be, but they're on the ground.  Furthermore, they're in thin tunnels, so you just have to accept getting poisoned or burn a poison immunity.

Even Salt and Sanctuary did things better.

Salt and Sanctuary is a weird experience, and it's the best I can describe it. It is all a metroadvania game should not be. It has an interesting gameplay, a bit sloppy controls, OK sound design and overall has tough as nails boss fights and a over-simplistic story. Its souls-like elements feel unfinished. All of the classes - even the Rogue - feel slow to control, this feels like a huge step-down from its competitors such as Hollow Knight. This game has too much gore, it remains a mystery as to what the developer was smoking. The game's sinister atmosphere creates unease.
My verdict is 7/10: it has good character customization and an OK gameplay.

For metroidvania fans. Pros.: story; locations, map, upgrades. Cons.: no minimap and map access; overall difficulty and forcing into grinding.

Good souls-like metroidvania side scroller. Despite being among the first in this genre, it still holds up well. The character creator looks weird and almost makes it feel light-hearted, but once in game, everything is a lot darker and looks much nicer.

RECOMENDADÃSIMO
Me he pasado 95 juegos en mi vida(sÃ­, llevo la cuenta con una lista, soy un friki),  y he jugado a muchÃ­simos mÃ¡s.
Quiero dar ese dato para demostrar que soy un gamer empedernido y darle el valor que este juego se merece al decir que lo situarÃ­a en el top 5 de los juegos que mÃ¡s he disfrutado en mi vida. Y escribo esto 6 aÃ±os despuÃ©s de haberlo jugado, (no es la calentada de segÃºn te terminas un juego, lo digo con la mente frÃ­a).
La mÃºsica de los combates contra jefes, que sigo recordando aÃºn a dÃ­a de hoy, la atmÃ³sfera oscura, un diseÃ±o artÃ­stico fabuloso, los mil escondites y secretos que hay por el mundo, los combates tan difÃ­ciles y desafiantes que tiene, las infinitas posibilidades de personalizaciÃ³n y enfoque del personaje para el combate...y pensar que esta obra maestra fue creada tan solo por 2 personas...
Lo Ãºltimo que quiero decir es que tiene una "secuela" que se llama "salt and sacrifice" y que pongo secuela entre comillas porque no sigue la trama del primero y porque es una absoluta BASURA, que no le llega ni a los pies a esta primera entrega original y no exagero al decir que lo empeora absolutamente todo. En mi vida he visto una decadencia tan bestia de una segunda parte de un juego(a la altura del bajÃ³n de Dragon Age II). Pero lo dicho, SALT AND SANCTUARY ES DIOS.

Oh well, this one was LIT! I received Salt and Sanctuary as a free epic store game at christmas, and I couldnt stop playing it during the whole holidays.

As a Dark Souls and metroidvania fan, I couldnt be more surprised, how this synergy of genre works in this game. The art style is just perfect, gameplay and combat is just as punishing as in souls games. The exploration element, skill gaining and backtracking - things that are defining metroivania works here more then well.

As for the combat itself, maybe it could be more "complex", but the difficulty is ramping up with few bosses. Overall it keeps the metroidvania's combat style and feel.

If you like metroidvanias and/or dark souls, this is a game for you as even if you will get bullied over and over, you won't be able to stop playing until you finish it.

As many other have described this is a mix of DS / Castlevania. Overall I loved it and considering the team behind this i have to give it a 10 / 10. I dont know if theres a lot of replayability because at the end of the day its pretty linear. My mage playtrhough was very fun and challenging altough the end of the game got way easier.
+ graphics, music, atmospehre, builds, mechanics / - replayability, navigation

Souls-like Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼ĞµÑ€, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»Ñƒ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞµĞ½, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğº ÑĞµÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğµ ĞºĞ°Ğº Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ°ÑĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ».
bored, no funny, not interesting and very colourless. why am i playing this game? for only boss fight or something?

S&S is pretty much advertised as '2D Dark Souls', but it falls short of it's 3D inspiration on many accounts. The graphics are mediocre mid to upper flash game tier. Forget about feeling something like immersion in this game. The general theme of the background music, if present at all, alternates between repetitive and repetitive & annoying.
Weapon and armor balance is probably S&S's weakest part. Items are tiered from 1 to 5. High tier weapons are awkwardly placed and mostly useless filler - by the time you get to craft tier 3/4 stuff you can already access tier 5, making the former pointless. Lower tier weapons are simply not worth upgrading, unlike in dark souls. Lore consists of RPG boilerplate mediocrity sprinkled with the expected DS references - same for level design. It's not bad, but nothing really stands out as innovative or memorable either.
Combat.... sigh. It quickly becomes cheap and unrewarding - there is only so much you can do in this regard in a 2D engine. Total opposite to the original. There are enemies that pounce you or have some other lockdown (in some  cases instant kill) mechanic if you get close, enemies that have long range melee which you need to evade between attacks ( rinse and repeat) and various projectile attacks. The parrying system is a bit easier than in DS. High HP pools on the mob side combined with limited HP and few opportunities to attack on your side feel like something in between an attempt between a ramped up version of Dark Souls difficulty. Bosses basically require learning of patterns as well as their faster alternates which trigger once the 50% HP mark is reached, making for very drawn out fights. If that's your thing, or if you enjoy spending hours just getting through one boss pretty much every single time, this might be the one thing that will give you some enjoyment in this game. But if you think ornstein and smough or manus type fights felt least rewarding about DS, chances are you wont enjoy the boss fights in S&S because 'fast and aggressive' is the common theme here.
Blending out the copious boss fights there's actually pretty little content in the game. Excusable because there are only two devs from what I've heard but it's another thing that makes the game feel a bit too much like something that evolved from a cheap flash game hobby project. Which makes you wonder why you had to pay to play it.

Una autÃ©ntica lÃ¡stima.

DesearÃ­a que me gustara este juego, pero no va a ser posible. Salt and Sanctuary solo se ha dedicado a matarme injustamente y a robarme mis merecidas almas; pero el mayor pecado de SaS es, sin duda, el olvidar que SaS es otro juego, no un remake de Dark Souls en 2D.

HabÃ­a jugado en el pasado un remake de DS para Spectrum, un pequeÃ±o juego hecho en coÃ±a parodiando el original. Ese remake para Spectrum, aÃºn siendo una parodia hecha por un fan, aportÃ³ elementos en su jugabilidad que no se habÃ­an visto en el DS original, no muchos, pero algo nuevo metiÃ³.

Esto no lo ha hecho SaS, se ha olvidado de su propia identidad, y se ha limitado a calcarlo todo de DS, solo dejando sin copiar los elementos imposibles en un entorno 2D. AdemÃ¡s, ha fallado al entender porquÃ© DS funciona, lo que tampoco le ayudÃ³ a copiarlo bien.

Es una autÃ©ntica lÃ¡stima, insisto, llevo siguiendo este juego durante aÃ±os y lo he jugado ahora solo para llevarme un batacazo y una decepciÃ³n, con todo lo que prometÃ­a.

Tal vez, no sÃ©, los developers ahora hagan un DLC arreglando el juego bÃ¡sico y aÃ±adiendo mÃ¡s contenido, copiando lo que ocurriÃ³ con DS 2, pero algo me dice que no va a ser asÃ­, y que este juego llamado SaS que parece un prototipo, seguirÃ¡ siendo un prototipo toda la eternidad.

Insisto, una verdadera lÃ¡stima.

Criminally under-appreciated game. OverBorder studio (which is a team of only 7 people, to the best of my knowledge) made a game who's biggest flaw was that I just wish there was more of it. It's not perfect, sure. But the music, atmosphere, and gameplay make for a truly enjoyable souls-like experience.

Towards the end, I was a little disappointed with enemy variety. I think they probably needed a couple more tough later game enemies. Additionally, I was begging for one or two more unique and challenging bosses by the end. The Odur fight at the beginning is notoriously challenging, but I absolutely LOVED it. It was incredibly satisfying to learn the timings and movements of his combos. Unfortunately, I don't think any of the following bosses are nearly as good as that first one, but they're still all pretty respectable.

TLDR, great game, wish there was a little more content.

Please do not be discouraged by the beginning of the game, as it is only difficult and looks unimpressive at the start. The storyline is also challenging initially, but later it becomes understandable with notes, videos, conversations â€“ itâ€™s well done. As a long-time fan of Spiders games (still waiting for Mars War Logs 2 and Technomancer 3!), I must add my opinion. Pros:

- Great music and atmosphere (the first time I see robots with souls). 
- Fun combat, though it gets a bit tedious after side missions with recycled locations (if you play just the main story, it remains consistently good). 
- Good graphics in most locations, mainly urban and underground; the worst is the beginning of the game and the bastille when walking by the river (but I play on low settings) â€“ the river is awful, and whatâ€™s beneath it    
- Very interesting, though serious story, definitely has potential for development (despite the robotic elements, itâ€™s emotional, and the historical thread picks up later)
- Huge selection of weapons, fewer outfits, but it's okay    Nice protagonist, relatable, has a cool voice   
- Nice storyline characters (though I discarded La Fayette)   
- Cool feature with the vestals where you buy things 
-  Also like the new options over time, such as breaking walls or the rope for climbing higher (though there could be more of this) 
-  Quite a variety of enemies, but towards the end, you know them too well and maybe four more would be needed  
-  Worth buying the Discus Chain DLC, as it can attack from a distance and interrupts many enemy attacks

Cons:  
-  Terrible optimization, on an RX6600 I have to play on nearly minimal settings, and still, the fps can drop from 80 to 30 in many places. Luckily, I like this game enough to grit my teeth; the worst are a few options including textures, which even on high can exceed 8GB VRAM usage, not to mention ultra, and they arenâ€™t even hyper beautiful; the game also takes quite a long time to load on HDD 
-   Lack of newer FSR (1.1 looks ugly and helps little) etc.  
-  Lack of patches for the game, as if the developers abandoned it  
-  A downside is part of the combat where the enemy can attack even if we attacked them; that is, our attacks do not interrupt the enemy's attack animation, though sometimes they do (probably a paralysis issue); the best is to play with the chain as you can hit from a distance, avoiding enemy attacks 
-   Poor character development; I played as a dancer, focused only on strength, health, and stamina, the rest seemed unnecessary (unfortunately)    
- The first location is a downside as it puts many people off the game and they return it, as itâ€™s not as carefully made; once you get through it, itâ€™s great  
-  Zero game balance; Iâ€™m someone who kills the monsters on hand, destroys all crates, so I collect various items and have a lot of them 

And yes. The beginning of the game is as hard as Dark Souls, but you can level up and develop your character, so you manage (I play without assists). Then the game is moderately difficult and fun. However, at the end, I play with one hand. At the end of the game, I had around level 40, weapons upgraded to level 5, over 100 healing oils, 50 grenades, lots of HP. Just any boss I encounter takes maybe 10-15 attacks, throw a few grenades at him, add a special attack, and the boss is gone. And I have so many healing tools that thereâ€™s no fear of losing life. I just play the game without major emotions, unfortunately. I play only because I like the overall setting, atmosphere, but thereâ€™s no challenge.

And I play without assists, so I donâ€™t understand people who need assists. Really only the beginning of the game is hard (indeed too hard). But then not anymore. Then you have various special attacks, the weapon has 2 attacks, you have fire, ice, and lightning attacks. Thereâ€™s really a lot of it. Therefore, the game offers many development options, equipment, various attacks, itâ€™s overwhelming at the beginning. But later, when you know how to use it, the game becomes very easy. Really very easy. With high endurance, you also easily dodge enemy attacks and donâ€™t get tired, which is obviously a plus for people who donâ€™t like Dark Souls, as there you have to be 10x more careful.

I would buy the game for up to 150 PLN if only it had good optimization, FSR/DLSS updates, and if the developers didnâ€™t abandon it.

Of course, I hope for a Steelrising 2, but seeing that the developers donâ€™t like sequels to their games, I probably wonâ€™t get my **** I also hope the game brought some financial success. Because itâ€™s really not bad. The beginning of the game is off-putting, the story is not understood, the game is difficult to master, and the first boss is also very hard, the optimization is terrible, but if these were improved, it would really be a solid 8/10.

Steelrising es un soulslike que innova muy poco (alguna de las armas son algo originales, y puedes saltar y tienes algo mÃ¡s de movilidad que en otros juegos del gÃ©nero) pero ejecuta bien lo que se propone hacer. Para mi tiene una virtud innegable en su ambientaciÃ³n, ya que la Francia revolucionaria estÃ¡ desgraciadamente muy poco explorada en juegos o pelÃ­culas y es un periodo fascinante, incluso en esta versiÃ³n fantÃ¡stica. Caminar por las calles del ParÃ­s de la Ã©poca, visitar palacios y lugares importantes como la Bastilla o Versalles, es genial. La historia en sÃ­ estÃ¡ bien pero tampoco es para tirar cohetes, pero sin duda estÃ¡ mejor contada que en cualquier Souls, cuenta con diÃ¡logos y decisiones que afectan al final de la historia, etc. Y el combate es Ã¡gil y fluido, con una personalizaciÃ³n del personaje mÃ¡s simple que en un Souls pero que funciona decentemente bien. GrÃ¡ficamente no pasarÃ¡ a la historia, especialmente algunas animaciones faciales flojean un poco, pero como ya dije la ambientaciÃ³n me fascina y estÃ¡ muy bien recreada, con lo que a nivel visual acaba resultando un juego distinto y bienvenido. QuizÃ¡s algunas zonas se hacen demasiado parecidas entre sÃ­. A nivel de sonido estÃ¡ todo lo bien que se puede esperar, tanto en efectos, como voces (me gusta que intercalen palabras en francÃ©s) como en el apartado musical. Y en cuanto a bugs, he encontrado muy pocos y todos han sido bastante irrelevantes, lo cual siempre es **** resultado es que, sin ser un juego memorable, sin duda es un buen juego en su gÃ©nero. Un 7.

Yet another Dark Souls clone - yawn! Enough already! Souls mechanics aren't that great to be copy & pasted over and over again!
There is nothing new to see here, you once again collect [insert game currency] after slaying enemies, when you die you respawn at the last [insert game save point] you rested at and have one chance to reclaim [game currency] by returning to that spot without dying again. Using [game save point] also respawns all enemies except for bosses. The game's main goal is to fight bosses and mini bosses, yada yada, nothing new here.
Steelrising drops the grimdark atmosphere in favor of an overly colorful 18th century France backdrop with robots(!). I prefer the dark fantasy which is why this one rates even lower than Thymesia for me. Graphics themselves are alright but nothing to write home about. Unfortunately the game is very poorly optimized so be prepared for a lot of stuttering - in a game that relies entirely on timing! Frame dips are frequent this is an absolute no-go. How these 10 out of 10 morons simply ignore this is beyond me.
The reason some reviewers seem to get overly excited about Steelrising's graphics probably is due to the fact that the big front runners FromSoft have delivered their games with the same outdated graphics engine from 2011 on and all other titles look next gen by comparison.
Steelrising also makes the mistake of putting a $50 price tag on this game. Sorry it's a C game lacking anyinnovation, worth $20 max! Definitely a wait for a deep deep sale and only if you are a die hard Souls fan and need to own every game in this "genre". There are much better titles (Mortal Shell, Lords of the Fallen) than this. If you want something that isn't dark fantasy (why would you?) Deck 13 has you covered with The Surge 2.
Hard pass & refund on my side. Sorry.

At its heart, Sea of Thieves revolves around the thrill of exploration and the hunt for treasure. Players set sail across a beautiful, open world filled with islands, shipwrecks, and hidden coves, all packed with treasures to be found. While on these voyages, you can encounter various threats, including rival players who may be looking to steal your loot, or AI-controlled enemies like skeleton crews that provide exciting combat **** shared-world nature of Sea of Thieves adds an unpredictable element to your journeys. You never know when you might cross paths with another crew, which can lead to tense standoffs or full-blown naval battles. The freedom to play either cooperatively or competitively keeps the gameplay dynamic, as your treasure hunts may end in epic victories or heartbreaking **** of the game's most thrilling aspects is the random encounters with legendary sea monsters. You might be peacefully sailing with a hold full of treasure when suddenly the waters turn dark, and the Kraken's tentacles emerge from the deep. Or you may hear the ominous growl of the Megalodon stalking your ship.
One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is its highly detailed and enjoyable navigation system. Steering your ship is not just a matter of pointing in the right direction and hitting â€œgo.â€ Instead, it involves a range of ship management tasks: raising and lowering sails, adjusting their angle to catch the wind, managing the anchor, and even patching up holes when your ship takes **** collaborative nature of managing a ship with a crew of friends makes this experience especially fun. Each crew member has a role, from helming the ship to navigating using the map, or managing the cannons during combat. The sense of teamwork needed to successfully sail and survive in the open world is one of the gameâ€™s most satisfying elements.While Sea of Thieves nails the navigation and exploration aspects, the combat system leaves much to be desired. Whether fighting other players or AI-controlled enemies, the melee and ranged combat can feel unsatisfying and overly simplistic. The melee combat, in particular, often devolves into repetitive and "spamy" exchanges where players simply mash attack buttons rather than using any sort of strategy or **** some players, the experience of sailing the high seas in Sea of Thieves can come with an unfortunate side effect: motion sickness. The gameâ€™s realistic ship movement, combined with the rolling waves and constant swaying, can cause dizziness or nausea for those prone to motion sickness. Spending extended periods navigating the ocean can exacerbate this, especially during storms or rough seas, when the shipâ€™s motion becomes even more pronounced.
I had fun with friends but it did get a bit boring after a while. But a fun game, would recommended.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: Rust was released to an â€œearly accessâ€ stage in late 2013, debuting to a peak of 22,000 players in the release month. As of now, Rust has peaked at approximately 260,000 concurrent players in January of 2025, more than ten times increase. Rusts growth has been continuous, due to the â€œForce Wipe,â€ a concept that on the first Thursday of every month they release a big update, wiping everyone's progress, across all servers. Rust is from the development studio, â€œFacepunch,â€ responsible for games such as â€œGarryâ€™s Mod,â€ a sandbox game where anything is possible, and â€œChippy,â€ an arcade style game based on the mechanics of â€œSpace Invaders.â€ Rust is a multiplayer survival game, comparable to the likes of â€œArk Survival Evolvedâ€ and â€œDay Z,â€ both of which are also set in post-apocalyptic warfare filled maps. These types of games are immensely popular due to their sadistic nature, taking others hard-earned resources for your own gain. Rust has been one of the most consistent games i have ever played, every single month they release a noticeable update to change the meta of the game. This keeps the gameplay fresh, this in addition to the server â€œWipesâ€ makes sure that players will be able to play for the whole month without it starting to feel old. However, this makes Rust extremely addicting, and very impactful on social life.  Rust is based on a post-apocalyptic island, leaving the island radioactive. It is rumoured that the island which all players first interact with was infested with the likes of a cold war, the island was used as a testing ground for weapons and personnel to do as they will. This left it in a state of warfare and an idea of â€œevery man for himself.â€ Rust is a difficult game to learn, and it takes a long time to learn the mechanics, let alone to gather enough knowledge to be able to take fights, at the right time, with the right weapons and with the right amount of people. In Rust you also must learn recoil patterns along with refining your aim to insure you will hit your shots, without learning you are bound to lose every fight you take. In Rust there is not a definitive end, you can always have more resources, raid more people, take more fights. That's the beauty of Rust, you can never actually â€œcompleteâ€ the game, this is what keeps players consistent through the month, chasing a never-ending goal. Since you never actually can complete Rust there is no â€œreplayâ€, however, there is a concept of server â€œWipesâ€, where there is a set schedule and on the day specified everyone's progress gets reset, just for them to go back and get it all again, showing the true nature of Rust. Rustâ€™s settings are vast and varied, however you cannot modify the game farther than they let you, since its multiplier they must discourage and punish third party programs, especially ones that aim to modify the games memory. Rust is available on Steam, PlayStation Store, and Microsoft Store on XBOX, bearing in mind Rust is not cross-platform since PC players would have an advantage. Rust usually sells for Â£34.99; this is on console stores and on steam. Rust hovers around a 40GB size, reasonable for the large amount of content. Rust pays a large amount of attention to the graphics, the greenery and the buildings all have intricate details to make them look as realistic as possible, and they do an excellent job at it, the interiors of the â€œmonumentsâ€ are all rustic, adding to the feel of a post-apocalyptic island. Rust has a variety of sound effects and music cues, the gun sounds are somewhat realistic, although not the best, the music is commissioned especially for rust and gives an aurora of creepy, scary survival. Rust changes the sounds depending on the environment a player is in, for example in a cave, sounds reverb and appear louder and somewhat inaccurate, while above ground there is a distinct sound for everything and a direction of where it came from is recognizable. This is unique and enhances the player experience, really helps in a survival game. Rust usually does not experience many bugs, every update is meticulously tested before being pushed to the main branch, additionally they have a â€œstagingâ€ branch which allows players to play updates before they are officially released, allowing for user-reported bugs to be fixed and community feedback to be taken before a new update. Rust is a multiplayer game, the game requires an online aspect to actually be enjoyable, other players are out to get your resources and you have to protect them, no matter if youâ€™re online or offline, which introduces a sense of urgency to get back to the game and play it for even longer. In conclusion, Rust is absolutely a game to try if you have not played it already, it has a certain player base who chase the adrenaline of losing and gaining resources throughout a period, making it intense and exciting. Although, I'd be careful about the addictiveness of it, it's no joke how many hours you can pour into this game without realising.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: Rust Huh, the game that made my childhood better since I was watching the continuity creators on YouTube back when Zombies were on the map. I ended up playing with a friend for about 140 hours, most of which hours were done on empty servers or done by one of my friends using our monthly subscription initiated servers. Initially, I would have several reasons not to recommend the game, mainly because one of those main reasons is the overpriced price. But instead, I won't do this, because from my point of view, for how many hours I invested in the game and how I didn't feel them passing by me, being the game at the same time and very fun, I suppose they deserved their money. Starting with the worst phases of the game, as long as you don't play on a server made by you, you can't really put your soul into what you created or built on the game. In the game there is the wipe term, which at the choice of the owner who owns the server, can be: weekly, every two weeks, or every month) After this deadline, the whole map returns to its initial form from the beginning without any progress. The houses, your items in the inventory and everything you have mined or collected will disappear and you will basically get it from the beginning every time. It sounds very bad since most players of Survival games grew up with Minecraft, The Forest or Don't Starve, where in these games your progress was saved for the entire period of ownership. But it's not really like that, this only applies to servers officially listed on the server page of the game, if you want to create a server you can keep it for life without giving it a mandatory wipe but it will be unlisted and not you can set it as public, if you want it public you will have to comply with this requirement. It sounds decent so far, but there is another part to come. For you to be able to maintain a server is not as easy as in other games and especially since the game does not maintain the server created by you. Either you use Wireless Lan Party programs to invite others if you have a map and want it to run on your computer, or you have to buy a server domain which is not at all cheap unlike what I was used to do until now. These would be some disadvantages in what prevents its purchase if necessary. (You can have a public server with "No Wipe" only if there are no servers with Survival game mode. (example: PVP)In the rest, apart from these aspects, the game is ingenious, and comes to its base with a lot of new features and monthly or bi-monthly **** updates do not in any way damage the game or its image and even revive it every time something new appears because you always have something to do in it, especially if you are just starting out with the game and especially if you have a server with Wipe. The idea is that having a server with "No Wipe" you cannot expand your creativity as you want on it, most of the time you end up making a construction with the walls upgraded to the maximum and then you think that you have nothing left to do being that everything you did you did during the construction of the house. That's why Wipe exists, to evolve each player individually and all starting from the same point at the time of the Wipe. Imagine Hungar Games with Unlimited Respwn (that is if you don't play on Hardcore Mode) and with several players all evolving differently and attacking each other to capture territories and get materials from the battle or loots found on Map. The idea is very good and I wonder how since its launch it has not received an award or a congratulation for this complex idea, the basis of which is the community that continues to create and maintain active servers even today after a long time. I haven't really seen any bugs or glitches, the game is decent on the optimization side and the difficulty of the AI â€‹â€‹in the game is to be congratulated. I recommend the game strictly if you have many friends with whom you can have a Party or Squad for Raids because otherwise it would sometimes seem boring to you and you would want to take a break with the game more and more often until you end up losing your interest completely, so that later to return to it again being a good game. On the music side, they tried to copy different ideas from other well-known Survivor games that have good music, and somehow they came out, but not how the developers expected it to come out. All in all, it's good, but it hasn't received updates with the music packet for a long time and I'd be impatient to see that. There are many things I could talk about when it comes to this game, but many of them end up having a positive impact on the game, which makes the final conclusion I recommend it with confidence, especially if you get it at a discount like - I also bought it by the way. I recommend to try for yourself to understand much more than from this review,

No matter your availability, game preference, or skill ability, there is a server for everyone and a great experience waiting in Rust.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: Rust is a compelling and intense multiplayer survival game developed by Facepunch Studios, where players must gather resources, build shelters, and engage in PvP combat to survive on a deserted island. Starting with nothing, players quickly scavenge for materials to craft tools and weapons, navigating a challenging day-night cycle and constant threats from other players. The game's building and crafting systems are deep and rewarding, allowing for the creation of complex bases and equipment. Voice chat enhances social interactions, fostering alliances and rivalries within large servers. Despite its brutal and unforgiving nature, Rust offers an enriching experience as players outlast competitors and thrive in a hostile environment, making it a must-play for fans of survival games!

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: Created by Facepunch, a group known for games such as g-mod, comes Rust. This PvP survival game pits you against both the struggles of surviving on a stranded island with no escape, but also the threat of other people and NPCs. Rust differs from other games in this genre because of its vast plethora of mechanics alongside a seemingly simple premise: survival.  Rust has a reputation for being a very challenging, unforgiving game, but I believe this simply adds to the excitement. Although it might seem that after a short while, there may be nothing new to do, but the constant fear of losing all your progress to either another player or natural causes is what makes this game stand out, as there is no safety for your hard-earned resources when offline.  This does, however, cause many players to develop severe addictions, with many members of the community gaining hour counts into the thousands.  Rust is well known for its steep learning curve, with players being judged harshly by others based on their playtime alone. The gunplay in this game also is quite difficult, making players memorize recoil patterns for many different guns, and get used to the fast time to kill. Even with the short TTK, fights involving larger groups can last hours at a time, with neither side wanting to leave the battle after putting so much time and resources in.   Many servers also introduce prizes and incentives such as bounties for the most competitive clans to compete for. This leads to the formation of very large groups, sometimes with 40+ players, working together to win money on a regular basis. The nature of the game, however, means that to keep a bounty for long enough to be cashed out, the clans have to stay active on a single server for days at a time, often leading to many sleepless nights lying in wait for an attack.  The gameplay loop can vastly vary in length with some so called â€˜wipesâ€™ lasting anywhere from a couple days to over a month. However, even though it may seem repetitive, with little variation on the gameplay, each wipe has many different encounters with new people each time, leading to an enjoyable experience for as long as you make it enjoyable.  Rust is available on both console and PC, costing upwards of Â£20, and can be played on either keyboard and mouse or most standard modern controllers. However, the advantages offered by keyboard and mouse leads to problems in the console community with external devices such as zens.  Graphics/Attention to Detail and Environmental interaction/Scenery/Art Direction and Style Rust has a reasonably minimalistic art style, but this doesnâ€™t detract from the game's positives.  The sound design for the game is both immersive and reliable, with most sounds being easily distinguished between. Rust can be very difficult to run on lower end devices, and can often crash alongside excruciating loading times, but there are very few noticeable bugs, and with the game being updated regularly none stay around for too long. One of the worst and best aspects of this game are the interactions with other players. While some can be kind or funny, most are extremely hostile, and the majority of encounters involve a stream of slurs through the microphone. For this reason, I would definitely not recommend this game to younger individuals as a lot of the language and threats used are quite nerve racking for less confident people.  Overall, the game itself has many strong features, but the community does slightly let it down at times.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: Mechanics are from 2013, few weapon classes and poor design contribute to a sadistic experience only a true psychopath could enjoy. No story or environmental design is present, the developers clearly had no plan at the beginning, playing RUST feels like a middleschooler's idea of a video game, where mechanics from various genres are cobbled together without any underlying rationale or thought. How, anyone could continue to produce such a game without any premeditation is simply stunning. If you meet somebody, and you learn they play RUST, avoid them as they are a true psychopath.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: If you're not playing this game 24/7, or you don't have a 10 man group you wont really enjoy it. The game is about, surviving. But the thing is as you born there "Naked" there will be always a person with guns, and you cant really do about it anything. Watching this game is amazing, but playing it is just bad, boring, stressful. Not worth the problem. Play Alan Wake 2, thats a horror game and worth every second of scare. It has a story, characters, a lore rich universe. And Alan Wake is just awesome.

review_text: I used to love rust, have been playing it since 2014. Now with the recoil update the main aspect of the game, the pvp, has become really, really stale. genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, Simulation, Sports, Free To Play, Early Access
review_text:
If you find some nice people and ignore the trolls trying to get a rise out of you, this social platform has some stunning worlds, and amazing people. I don't regret a single one of my, at the point of writing, around 1200 hours here.

It looks a lot worse on quest standalone, and you can't see most of the stuff people on PC can see, so if you can, play on PCVR.
Also, the devs should sometimes just listen to their community. And even on my very high-end PC, the game sometimes runs awful. But that's not too much on the devs, it's just the nature of user generated content.

Cool Overwatch clone in the Marvel universe. Generic graphics, but great regular updates. Can quickly become repetitive and there's a lack of willingness to fulfill all roles from other players.

Marvel Rivals is hands down the best live Service game Iâ€™ve played in a long time â€“ and honestly, itâ€™s my number one "on going" game! From the very first match, I was completely hooked. The mix of fast-paced action, strategic teamplay, and that unique Marvel flair is simply unbeatable.Each hero feels distinct and powerful, with their own unique playstyle. The combat system is smooth, dynamic, and super satisfying. The maps are well-designed, and the graphic design shows a real attention to detail.What really stood out to me is the cast â€“ the selection of playable Marvel characters is both diverse and perfectly executed, both visually and in terms of gameplay. Every Marvel fan will find something to love here.I could barely stop playing and Iâ€™m already excited for whatâ€™s coming next. For me, Marvel Rivals is more than just a great game â€“ itâ€™s become my personal go-to game.

This is currently one of my favorite games to play right now. The gameplay loop is engaging, the art style is incredibly stunning, and the update cycle keeps this game feeling fresh for months on end. The progression for proficiency  feels rewarding with some cool rewards. Each character felt very unique with their own set of lines for every other character and ultimate attacks that feel very distinct and fun to use. The developers are extremely committed to giving the game content at a high frequency, but without rushing the skins, updates, and more out the door unfinished. Despite all that, I cannot ignore the gaping issues within the game. The matchmaking is atrocious, some of the skins are pretty questionable, and the toxic environment can be very unwelcoming. The rank system can sometimes feel like walking through mud. If these things can be fixed, the game has potential to be one of the best multiplayer games on the market, but for now, it stand as an eight out of ten.
Absolute Gooner game, that being said i am a man so anything below a seven would be blasphemy

Never been a hero shooter kinda guy. Played maybe 20 hours of overwatch back in the day. Never been much of a marvel guy either but this game. Is actually pretty fun. I mostly main iron man or winter solider

Marvel Rivals brings beloved characters to life, perfectly aligned with what fans love from the MCU. The frenetic gameplay feels like a true evolution of what Overwatch started, now faster, flashier, and even more addictive. Waifu and husbando material? Absolutely â€” the skin designs are top-tier, and all of it comes in a free-to-play package. For anyone who enjoys multiplayer arena games, this is an easy 10. Marvel Rivals is here to stay, and with more characters, modes, and skins on the way, itâ€™s only going to get better. Massive props to NetEase.

As someone who has been disinterested in the MCU since iron man 2 and with limited interest in the hero shooter genre, the fantastic art style and solid gameplay loop in this game was able to break through all those past barriers and get me addicted. A fun shooter with a lot of visual splendor.

A simply disgusting game. Every update they mess something up, healers do more damage than DPS and heal way too much. Some DPS do a lot of damage but also heal a lot. It seems that the developers of this awful game have no idea how to make a balanced game. There are matches, and unfortunately there are many, where the opposing team simply doesn't die. Everyone heals too much and everyone does too much damage. I gave it a 0 rating only because, unfortunately, you can't give a negative number, because this game deserves a -50 rating.
whose idea was it to give AI to predetermined your loses and wins is pretty dumb, since they gave zero f****ks for matchmaking, i'll just give zero f***cks for the review

751.4 hours on this game, feels like i wasted a decade of my life into this game.Your time and money is better spent elsewhere, the community is for the lack of a better word decrepit. If you're a casual enjoyer that's fine you hop into quickplay play a couple of games but for a competitive focus game, it ****. The matchmaking, it forces you into a 50% win rate or sometimes lower it is not worth your time and effort to rank up. Honestly the game does not deserve any love as the developers only cares to manipulate every outcome of a match. Overwatch literally took them years to tear down everything they build, and rivals took them a year to tear everything they so hardly try to build.

in conclusion i would have given the game 7 out of 10 at the beginning but as time goes on I'd rather give it a 0. every rival's player who knows and plays this 80 percent of them are miserable.

Was a pretty good game, but Daredevil ruins it. Every Daredevil just uses a macro and pushes one button to instantly delete any non-tank from the game. There's no counterplay to him.

Black Panther's running around with macros as well, instantly 180Â° dashing pixel perfect through the center of an enemy, that is physically impossible for a human to pull off and should get automatically caught by the anti-cheat.

Spider-man needs a rework. No one likes playing with or against spider-man.

Jeff is the dev's favorite hero. Massive AoE healing for insane amount that also very easily deals damage to enemies at the same time for fairly high damage and can hit around walls. Has 100 ammo for some reason and reloads really fast. Is low to the ground, but has no issues aiming, unlike Rocket who's bullets will hit the floor 90% of the time. Has a tiny hitbox. Moves really fast. Has hitbox issues that have been in the game since launch that the devs for some reason refuse to fix. Always has at least 2 or 3 team-up combos.

I've provided lots of video proof of cheaters to the devs, with hard aim snap and aim lock, sometimes even doing so through walls, which is very easy to spot in a replay where you can see both team's outlines. No one on the enemy team able to see through walls or able to ping the target for the team to see, so it's insanely obvious that they are cheating, but they don't even look at the video and just claim the cheater isn't cheating. They only seem to ban those who receive X number of reports or are caught cheating on some popular streamer's channel.

Also, UE5 runs like ****.

I played for 6 hours and this is my idea. The problems of the Game:
- Low Frame Rate
- Bad Grafic 
- Chaotic Game Design
- Opponent and Ally are difficult to distinguish
- Game mode are like to Overwatch and Paladins but worse.
This game on PS4 is unplayable.
I don't know what makes these Chinese developers think it's ok to give a player 6 losses in a row with such bad matchmaking. I keep getting the worst player in the room in a row sometimes.

Worst matchmaking and balance of any competitive game to exist. Terrible Devs and awful bug issues with each update. Theres also a 2:1 imbalance of dps chars to Tanks and Healer characters causing horrible team compositions.

This game couldâ€™ve easily been one of the most fun releases of the year, but sadly it struggles in a few key areas like performance. The biggest issue, though, is the matchmaking â€” by far the worst part of the game. You often get paired with random teammates who clearly arenâ€™t interested in playing seriously, and they just end up throwing the match.
I loved it for thelongest Time, unfortunately as it is so often, Neteasy screwed the pooch as always and took all the funout of the Game once again

Devs lie about their engagement matchmaking, or EOMM, which makes the games a coin flip and either you're getting stomped or you're stomping, there are no equal matches.  When you lose, it's people on your team literally running out solo and instantly dying repeatedly, getting zero kills, standing out in the open basically throwing, while the enemy will be celestial level players getting 30 kills.
The game also has a rising cheating problem which the devs refuse to even address.  Troll players in a growing number of matches are using aim, invincibility, and other cheats, and nothing happens to them.  It's OBVIOUS.  People surviving point blank Ultimate atacks, being hit by your entire team and their health bar not moving.  People just spinning and auto locking you when they didn't even know you were there.
The devs WILL NOT actually ban anyone from the game.  You can use cheats, throw, smurf, call people whatever you want using bigoted language, all they'll do is "limit their competitive matchmaking" for a while.  They'll just log out and be back later.
All Netease cares about is using the Marvel brand to sell skins until this dies.  They put out 3 or 4 battlepasses to buy, WHILE there is still a battlepass you've already paid for.  They put NO effort into reverse the garbage "matchmaking" or stopping the cheating and smurfing making the game unplayable for anyone but trolls.
This game could be SO good, the artists do their job well, as with most games, but the people running the rest don't care about literally anything but making a quick buck off Captain America and crew.

A game that plays the gamer rather than the other way around. 0 fun in having constant win or loss streaks. 0 fun in getting into a match to stomp or get stomped. props to NetEase though, for knowing how to build a matchmaking system to get gamers addicted by letting them get high from win streaks and to always chase that feeling when going on loss streaks.

Update September 2025. Matchmaking and smurfing made me and literally all of my friends quit this game. The smurfing is absolutely out of control and the matchmaking encourages it. NetEase seriously cannot design proper matchmaking or protection against repeated smurf accounts. They must salivate at the idea of high rank players creating new accounts to steamroll low rank players, because they basically ask for people to do this. 

Update: it's still absolutely terrible. Myself and literally all of my friends who used to play this game have quit because of the abysmal, unfair, toxic matchmaking. Good riddance. NetEase, sorry I won't be spending another penny on your awful game. 

Placement matches. Is it so hard to do NetEase? Guess not because 'something something something' money?  This game is already horrendously terrible enough with matchmaking with "engagement optimized" matchmaking where it literally puts you with/against higher tier players, but the seasonal rank resets and literally non-existent quickplay matchmaking are the icing on the cake. There's a reason you don't see 'casuals' playing anymore......Matchmaking is an absolute joke, you will never ever have a fair match where you feel like you could've made a difference. It was fun in the beginning, but NetEase scared and chased off all the fun, casual players it had in the beginning. So, all that is left is a shell ****, with only the sweatiest, sweat lords you can imagine. I'd say "it's just me", but I used to play with 4-5 friends, daily, for several months. Zero, none, not a single one of those friends play this game anymore because of how toxic and un-fun it has become.

Do better NetEase.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
Where it seems most games are hardly worth the time to play Lost Ark is the exception.

The writers of lore seem to be initiates into some mysteries. Even some of the fan base, the way they seem to analyze the goings on in Arkesia and Petrania (The worlds of Lost Ark) seem to be of another class.

It is in fact similar to other games as far as the story / lore goes, but itâ€™s not just killing demons (although it has a lot of that too !). Planets and stars from our own solar system, such as Regulus are revered and worshipped, making this game more believable and in turn, immersing the player in the story and game.

From the lore, to the soundtrack to the graphics and character design this game excels.I can hardly believe i took a break for 3-4 months only to play other popular games. To get disconnected every day, multiple times a day. To experience graphics bugs and glitches, UI bugs and glitches each and every **** this only helped me to realize how poor alot of these other popular games are and how superior Lost Ark is. In fact, if i can recall, i dont think ive been disconnected once on Lost Ark and i dont think ive ever experienced any bugs or glitches

.There is alot going on in this game, the ways to improve your character and abilities can be overwhelming at times and honing can seem next to impossible, even to finish the main story. However it is worth sticking with this game.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text: Lost Ark falls short of its promise as a captivating MMORPG. Despite its visually stunning graphics, the game suffers from repetitive quests and a lackluster storyline that fails to engage players. The combat, while initially exciting, quickly becomes monotonous and lacks depth. Additionally, the game's monetization practices heavily favor pay-to-win mechanics, creating an unfair advantage for those willing to spend real money.

review_text: Be warned about this game. They will issue bans if you don't play. Many players got the game for free on steam, realized it wasn't the game for them, and quit playing. Now the developers have issued gamewide bans for inactive players, which shows up as a red mark on you steam profile. Further more, there are a number of other steam games that won't let you play if you have a ban. If you have a old steam account with thousands of hours and dollars invested, do not get this game unless you are prepared for a ban.

Dota 2 is not just a game; it's an experienceâ€”a challenging, sometimes infuriating, but ultimately rewarding journey. For those unfamiliar, Dota 2 is a highly complex multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game that demands strategy, skill, and ****â€™s be honest: Dota 2 is hard. The steep learning curve can make it feel overwhelming, especially for newcomers. The intricacies of the game mechanics, the vast pool of heroes, and the ever-changing meta can leave even seasoned players scratching their heads. It's not uncommon to feel frustrated, to the point where you might consider breaking your keyboard or mouse after a tough **** that's also what makes Dota 2 the perfect game. The intense emotions it evokesâ€”from the highs of pulling off an incredible play to the lows of a devastating defeatâ€”create memories that last a lifetime. Every game is different, every match a new story.Beyond the gameplay itself, Dota 2 has a way of bringing people together. Whether you're teaming up with old friends or meeting new ones from around the world, the bonds formed through shared victories (and defeats) are strong. Many players find themselves making lasting friendships through the **** conclusion, Dota 2 is a demanding but deeply fulfilling game. It challenges you, pushes you to your limits, but also rewards you with some of the most unforgettable gaming moments. If you're willing to invest the time and effort, you'll find that Dota 2 is not just a gameâ€”it's a community, a passion, and a source of endless joy (and maybe a bit of rage too).
